abstract: The series of heavy battles which began on Wednesday morning last, near the small stream called Kettle Run, a short distance southwest of Manassas Junction, seem to
lead_paragraph: The series of heavy battles which began on Wednesday morning last, near the small stream called Kettle Run, a short distance southwest of Manassas Junction, seem to have come to a virtual termination on Saturday evening, near the historic ground of Bull Run and Centreville. An authorized Washington telegram this morning announces that there was but little if any fighting going on yesterday. Throughout the four days from Wednesday to Saturday the fighting was continuous, hot and bloody. Beginning on the first day, with but a single division of the National army, which was the attacking party and achieved a decided success, the battle waxed in magnitude on Thursday, with dubious results, swelled into the proportions of a general engagement with fearful carnage and a successful issue on Friday, till on Saturday the reinforced rebels became the attacking party, and a "severe battle" -- how severe we as yet know not -- followed, the result of which, according to this morning's dispatches was that "the advantage, on the whole, was with the enemy, and Gen. POPE fell back to Centreville with his whole army, in good order."

abstract: EXPLOSION AND LOSS OF LIFE. Between 3 and 4 o'clock on Saturday morning, an evaporating pan in THOMAS ANDREWS  Co.'s saleratus works, corner of Morgan and Washington streets, Jersey City, exploded, killing one man and slightly injuring
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION AND LOSS OF LIFE. -- Between 3 and 4 o'clock on Saturday morning, an evaporating pan in THOMAS ANDREWS & CO.'s saleratus works, corner of Morgan and Washington streets, Jersey City, exploded, killing one man and slightly injuring two others. At the time of the explosion a man named NEAL MCELROY, the night foreman, was engaged in stirring the contents of the pan. He was blown up to the roof of the building and falling to the ground received such injuries that he expired in a few moments. An iron bar, which he was using at the time, was thrown up to the roof with great force, running very nearly through one of the rafters, where it still remains. Two other workmen were slightly scalded by the hot saleratus which was scattered in every direction. The body of MCELROY was taken to his late residence in Bay-street, where it was viewed by Coroner GAFNEY and a permit given for burial. The pan was made of boiler iron and put together in the strongest manner.

abstract: About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, two men, one named WM. MCFADEN, a butcher, residing in First-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street, and the other named MARTIN GALLAGHER, had a dispute relative to some trifling matter, which resulted in a desperate struggle between them. There seems to have been some difficulty previously existing between the men, and at the time of the altercation GALLAGHER was under the influence of liquor. While in this condition he began a quarrel with the father-in-law of MCFADEN, when the latter became exasperated and interfered. GALLAGHER still continued abusive, and MCFADEN seized an old-fashioned butcher knife, one of the long, narrow kind, and plunged it with full force into GALLAGHER's neck behind the ear, driving it up to the hilt and leaving it in the wound. He then turned and fled. GALLAGHER fell to the sidewalk, from whence he was taken up by citizens and conveyed to the New-York Hospital. It required the united strength of two men to draw the weapon from the wound. The injured man breathed his last in about two hours. He was 22 years of age. The Eighteenth Precinct Police were on the ground a few moments after the murder, and Capt. CAMERON detailed officers to pursue the assailant. Up to midnight, however, no trace of him had been found. It was one of the most brutal affairs that has for a long time occurred in the Ward.

abstract: There appears to be no probability that the enrollment will be completed so as to render a draft practicable in this State before the middle of September. If enlistments continue as brisk as they have done for the past two weeks, the quotas of New-York City and Brooklyn will, by that time, be nearly full for both calls; so that a draft, if it shall be found necessary, will be a mere nominal affair. An estimate, published in the Sunday Mercury, and purporting to be accurate, states that there have already been recruited in this City, under the last calls, 16,468 men. The quota of the City, for both calls, is 25,160, leaving only 8,700 to be raised. More than half of these will doubtless be raised within a week, for the Corcoran Brigade. In Kings County, the quota for both calls is 8,632, of which 4,000 are already recruited, leaving 4,632 yet to be raised. As to the special draft to fill up old regiments, it is said that this is only to take place in case those regiments were not filled up by volunteers under the first call for 300,000. In the Cities of New-York and Brooklyn the recruits for the old regiments have thus far been so numerous that there is little doubt they will be full before the time for a draft.

abstract: A meeting of the exempt members and friends of the Eighth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., was held yesterday at the armory, over Centre Market. The object of the meeting was to make arrangements to give
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the exempt members and friends of the Eighth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., was held yesterday at the armory, over Centre Market. The object of the meeting was to make arrangements to give the Eighth a proper reception on its return. A Committee was appointed to carry out such arrangements, but it not being definitely known when the regiment would arrive, the members adjourned to meet to-day at the armory at 4 o'clock.

abstract: Editorial says Union has not attained any great successes this year; compares situation with Crimean War; Editorial compares Union situation with Crimean War
snippet: Editorial says Union has not attained any great successes this year; compares situation with Crimean War; Editorial compares Union situation with Crimean War
lead_paragraph: John Bull professes to be very greatly amazed that we do not abandon a war which we have failed to end in a year. He thinks we ought to be satisfied, by this time, that we never can conquer the South, inasmuch as we have not done it already. There is undoubtedly a good deal that is discouraging in the experience of the past year. Our armies have not accomplished what they ought to have done, nor a tithe of what they would have done if they had been led by competent commanders. We have lost a great many men by disease, and a good many in battle; we have neglected many opportunities to cripple the enemy -- we have wasted a great deal of money -- we have made a good many mistakes, both military and political -- we have lost a great deal of time -- we have frittered away the most splendid resources ever put into the hands of a Government for war purposes -- and, on the whole, we cannot pretend that our past year's experience has been a very brilliant success. We are free to confess that it has been rather a dismal failure; and, to any community less courageous, less plucky, less fixed in its purpose and less confident in itself than our own, it would probably be very discouraging.

abstract: There appears to be no probability that the enrollment will be completed so as to render a draft practicable in this State before the middle of September. If enlistments continue as brisk as they have done for the past two weeks, the quotas of New-York City and Brooklyn will, by that time, be nearly full for both calls; so that a draft, if it shall be found necessary, will be a mere nominal affair. An estimate, published in the Sunday Mercury, and purporting to be accurate, states that there have already been recruited in this City, under the last calls, 16,468 men. The quota of the City, for both calls, is 25,160, leaving only 8,700 to be raised. More than half of these will doubtless be raised within a week, for the Corcoran Brigade. In Kings County, the quota for both calls is 8,632, of which 4,000 are already recruited, leaving 4,632 yet to be raised. As to the special draft to all up old regiments, it is said that this is only to take place in case those regiments were not filled up by volunteers under the first call for 300,000. In the Cities of New-York and Brooklyn the recruits for the old regiments have thus far been so numerous that there is little doubt they will be full before the time for a draft.

abstract: A large number of privateersmen, released from Northern prisons, have arrived in Charlson. The Mercury gives a list of their names, and dates of capture, and states that the accounts obtained from them in regard to the brutal treatment to which they have
lead_paragraph: A large number of privateersmen, released from Northern prisons, have arrived in Charlson. The Mercury gives a list of their names, and dates of capture, and states that the accounts obtained from them in regard to the brutal treatment to which they have been constantly subjected during their captivity, realize all that has ever been written of the cowardly and malignant cruelty of the Lincoln Government and its hirelings. Most of the privateersmen were tried and convicted as pirates, and, during the long and terrible term of their confinement in the close, damp, and filthy cells allotted to condemned felons, the cheerful prospect of a halter was frequently held up for their edification. The crew of the Petrel were imprisoned for six months in Moyamensing Prison, Philadelphia; five months in Fort Lafayette, and about four weeks in Fort Delaware. A considerable portion of this period was spent by these unfortunate men in double irons! Their fare was a very small piece of bread, and a still smaller piece of salt pork, twice a day, occasionally varied by a little bean soup of about the consistency of water. Nearly two-thirds of the men had scurvy and the itch.

abstract: Editorial urges immediate drafting because of Union being threatened in Virginia
snippet: Editorial urges immediate drafting because of Union being threatened in Virginia
lead_paragraph: The past week has been another "week of battles" in Virginia. Fighting -- heavy fighting -- has been going on there almost every day, and with results generally favorable to our arms. We have given from day to day, as they have reached us, somewhat imperfect accounts of the important events which have occurred -- necessarily imperfect, because in most cases written at a distance from the scenes of operations. They have been sufficient, however, to give a general idea of the great movements which have been effected, and the series of skirmishes and battles which culminated on Friday and Saturday in the great struggles, of which we give accounts elsewhere. We on Saturday morning published a dispatch from Gen. POPE to Gen. HALLECK, giving an official account of the battle of Thursday, which was ended by the darkness of night, and expressing the expectation that it would be renewed in the morning. In a dispatch dated Saturday, Gen. POPE states that a terrific battle was fought on Friday, on the old Bull Bun battle-ground, with the combined forces of the enemy, lasting with continuous fury from daylight until after dark, by which time the enemy was driven from the field, which was occupied by our forces, who were too much exhausted to push matters. Gen. POPE intended to pursue as soon as reinforced by FITZ-JOHN PORTER's corps, which was expected up during the morning. At the moment of closing his dispatch, however, word was brought to Gen. POPE that the enemy were in full retreat toward the mountains, and he made immediate preparations to pursue. Gen. POPE estimates our losses on Friday at not less than eight thousand men killed and wounded, and the losses of the rebels at fully double that number. Our captures in this battle are said to be great. Their extent will probably soon be made known. We have as yet no official reports of the operations of Saturday, but they appear to have been fully as serious as those of the day previous, and with results not quite so satisfactory. The retrograde movement of the enemy in the morning seems to have been for the purpose of meeting reinforcements, which are reported to have come up in large numbers, swelling the force to such an extent as to embolden them to make an attack in their turn --the attack on Friday being made by us. The attack was boldly met, and a severe battle ensued, the advantage of which was, on the whole, on the side of the rebels. Gen. POPE consequently fell back in food order with his whole army to Centreville, where he was reinforced by FRANKLIN's Division, and where he was also joined by SUMNER's Division during the night, and again prepared to take the offensive. Yesterday, however, according to our latest dispatches from Washington, no fighting of any consequence took place, though various rumors of a great battle were prevalent throughout the day. Washington was, of course, intensely excited, and this excitement was not allayed in any measure by the report that some rebel scouts had been seen at Langley's, in the vicinity of the Chain Bridge. This report, however, does not seem to be verified.

abstract: Amongst the passengers to-day by the California steamer is Mr. LEWIS LELAND, who for many years has been in charge of the office business of the Metropolitan Hotel. Mr. LELAND goes to open DONOHUE's new hotel -- the Occidental -- in San Francisco, which is said to be one of the finest structures of the kind in the world. That Mr. LELAND will do well in the golden land we believe -- that he deserves it, we know.

abstract: Gen. CORCORAN returned from Boston on Saturday evening, accompanied by Capts. Kirk and Clarke and Quartermaster Tully and Aldermen Farley and Dayton. He came by the New-Haven Railroad, and was greeted all alone the route by large crowds of people, who assembled at the different stations. He took lodgings at the Astor, which he will make his headquarters until he returns to the field. The recruiting for his brigade (or division) will commence in earnest, to-day, and the General well devote his whole attention to enlistments, until he goes back to the field, at the head of his command.
lead_paragraph: Gen. CORCORAN returned from Boston on Saturday evening, accompanied by Capts. Kirk and Clarke and Quartermaster Tully and Aldermen Farley and Dayton. abstract: The season at the Winter Garden has commenced auspiciously. Every evening through the  week there have been large and appreciative audiences, performances of unusual excellence, and a general air of brightness and prosperity, that seems to promise cheerful fortune in the future. The
lead_paragraph: The season at the Winter Garden has commenced auspiciously. Every evening through the week there have been large and appreciative audiences, performances of unusual excellence, and a general air of brightness and prosperity, that seems to promise cheerful fortune in the future. The changes which have been made in the decoration and lighting of the auditorium are vast improvements on the previous aspect of those important items of theatrical completeness; the regular company comprises a good deal of acknowledged talent and efficiency, and, now that Mr. HAWTHORNE is engaged in the pictorial department, more artistic scenery than has of late appeared upon the stage may be expected. The success with which the season has been inaugurated, though, belongs chiefly to Miss BATEMAN, whose unquestionable genius infuses vitality enough into plays that have lost the charm of freshness to make them still attractive. It is an achievement of no ordinary magnitude, and one that any actress may be justly proud of, to draw enthusiastic crowds for six consecutive nights to see a piece like the "Hunchback," which every play-goer has seen unnumbered times before, and usually without finding any of those qualities in it which compel especial admiration and delight. Yet Miss BATEMAN, without startling the town by any attempt at a sensational reading of her part in it, has made it a vehicle for the development of so much genuine power, pathos and well-discriminated individuality, as to render it, for the time, a more desirable dramatic study or entertainment than almost any novelty would be. Very wisely, she has had secured for her support the services of actors of established reputation, whose excellence combines with her own to produce the nearest approach to perfection which can be reasonably hoped for under what is called the "star" system. "The Hunchback" will be given again before the close of Miss BATEMAN's engagement; but tonight it gives place to "Rosa Gregorio," the drama by Mr. DEWALDEN, which was received with so much favor at the Winter Garden last Spring. Miss BATEMAN, of course, plays the heroine, and the other leading characters are in the hands of Mr. J.W. WALLACK, Jr., and Mr. EDWIN ADAMS.

abstract: -- We are sure the invitation which the Surgeon-General to-day extends to all loyal women and children, to supply lint and bandages for our wounded soldiers, will meet with a prompt response. The battles of last week have been the bloodiest of the war, and among the bloodiest on record: and more remains behind! Many, many thousands have fallen. For the dead there are immortal tears; for those who lie wounded in the hospitals there are tender offices. A million hands of loyal women and children will obey, with a sad alacrity, the call to aid in this work, by furnishing lint and bandages. In their own sphere they are thus co-workers in the good cause. It is given them to staunch the wounds of those who prefer themselves to bleed, rather than that their country should perish.
lead_paragraph: -- We are sure the invitation which the Surgeon-General to-day extends to all loyal women and children, to supply lint and bandages for our wounded soldiers, will meet with a prompt response. abstract: Every day, as well as every indication from the North, serves to impress upon us not only the importance, but the absolute necessity of a formidable forward movement of our armies, and the repossession of our lost ground, before the forces of the enemy shall be strengthened in overwhelming power by the new levies. There is no longer any room to doubt that LINCOLN will very speedily get all the troops he has called for, and to resist successfully their overrunning our country will tax the patriotism as well as the bravery and muscle of our people. The South should -- nay, must -- put forth all her available strength, and draw upon all her resources, to check the advance of the Northern hordes that will be hurled upon us the coming Fall.
lead_paragraph: Every day, as well as every indication from the North, serves to impress upon us not only the importance, but the absolute necessity of a formidable forward movement of our armies, and the repossession of our lost ground, before the forces of the enemy shall be strengthened in overwhelming power by the new levies. abstract: The funeral services of Assistant Engineer DANIEL DONOVAN took place yesterday afternoon at St. Andrew's Catholic Church in Duane-street. The services, which were most imposing, were led by Father CURRAN, the Pastor of the church, assisted by Father PIERARD and Father DE CONCILIO, the latter of
lead_paragraph: The funeral services of Assistant Engineer DANIEL DONOVAN took place yesterday afternoon at St. Andrew's Catholic Church in Duane-street. The services, which were most imposing, were led by Father CURRAN, the Pastor of the church, assisted by Father PIERARD and Father DE CONCILIO, the latter of Hoboken. About 1 o'clock the clergy and acolytes received the corpse at the entrance of the church, and escorted it to the front of the chancel. The pall-bearers and relatives were seated in the front pews, and the body of the church was reserved for members of the Fire Department. Every seat in the church was filled, and many who wished were unable to gain admittance.

abstract: About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, two men, one named WM. MCFADEN, a butcher, residing in First-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street, and the other named MARTIN GALLAGHER, had a dispute relative to some trifling matter, which resulted in a desperate struggle between them. There seems to have been some difficulty previously existing between the men, and at the time of the altercation GALLAGHER was under the influence of liquor. While in this condition he began a quarrel with the father-in-law of MCFADEN, when the latter became exasperated and interfered. GALLAGHER still continued abusive, and MCFADEN seized an old-fashioned butcher knife, one of the long, narrow kind, and plunged it with full force into GALLAGHER's neck behind the ear, driving it up to the hill and leaving it in the wound. He then turned and fled. GALLAGHER fell to the sidewalk, from whence he was taken up by citizens and conveyed to the New-York Hospital. It required the united strength of two men to draw the weapon from the wound. The injured man breathed his last in about two hours. He was 22 years of age. The Eighteenth Precinct Police were on the ground a few moments after the murder, and Capt. CAMERON detailed officers to pursue the assailant. Up to midnight, however, [???] of him had been found. It was one of the most [???] affairs that has for a long time occurred to the World.

abstract: The season at the Winter Garden has commenced auspiciously. Every evening through the week there have been large and appreciative audiences, performances of unusual excellence, and a general air of brightness and prosperity, that seems to promise cheerful fortune in the future. The ...
lead_paragraph: The season at the Winter Garden has commenced auspiciously. Every evening through the week there have been large and appreciative audiences, performances of unusual excellence, and a general air of brightness and prosperity, that seems to promise cheerful fortune in the future. The changes which have been made in the decoration and lighting of the auditorium are vast improvements on the previous aspect of those important items of theatrical completeness; the regular company comprises a good deal of acknowledged talent and efficiency, and, now that Mr. HAWTHORNE is engaged in the pictorial department, more artistic scenery than has of late appeared upon the stage may be expected. The success with which the season has been inaugurated, though, belongs chiefly to Miss BATEMAN, whose unquestionable genius infuses vitality enough into plays that have lost the charm of freshness to make them still attractive. It is an achievement of no ordinary magnitude, and one that any actress may be justly proud of, to draw enthusiastic crowds for six consecutive nights to see a piece like the "Hunchback," which every play-goer has seen unnumbered times before, and usually without finding any of those qualities in it which compel especial admiration and delight. Yet Miss BATEMAN, without startling the town by any attempt at a sensational reading of her part in it, has made it a vehicle for the development of so much genuine power, pathos and well-discriminated individuality, as to render it, for the time, a more desirable dramatic study or entertainment than almost any novelty would be. Very wisely, she has had secured for her support the services of actors of established reputation, whose excellence combines with her own to produce the nearest approach to perfection which can be reasonably hoped for under what is called the "star" system. "The Hunchback" will be given again before the close of Miss BATEMAN's engagement; but to-night it gives place to "Rosa Gregorio," the drama by Mr. DEWALDEN, which was received with so much favor at the Winter Garden last Spring. Miss BATEMAN, of course, plays the heroine, and the other leading characters are in the hands of Mr. J.W. WALLACK, Jr., and Mr. EDWIN ADAMS.

abstract: Reports from North Carolina
snippet: Reports from North Carolina
lead_paragraph: A reconnoissance in force to the town of Swansboro set out from this place on Wednesday, 13th inst., under the command of Col. STEVENSON, commanding Second Brigage, First Divison. It consisted of a portion of the Twenty-fourth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, under Licut.-Col. OSBORN, a detachment of the Marine Artillery under Lieut.-Col. MANCHESTER, and a company of the Third New-York Artillery. On that day, the transports Pilot Boy, Ocean Queen, Massasoit, Allison, and Union, carrying a portion of the troops, proceeded through Core Sound to Beaufort, where they were joined by the others, who had come down by rail. Thursday was passed in providing the vessels with coal and water, and in giving the troops an opportunity for a sea-bath; and on Friday the expedition proceeded on its route. The Union, together with the Wilson, (which had joined the rest at Beaufort,) and the launches of the Marine Artillery, went by the way of Bogue Sound; whilst the other transports, accompanied by the gunboat Ellis, Lieut. PORTER, pushed out past Fort Macon into the ocean, and followed the coast to Bogue Inlet. The wind, which was light at daybreak, blew hard by afternoon, and it was with some difficulty that the vessel passed through the narrow, winding inlet, among the breakers. Within was still water, and a broad creek with meadow lands on either side. The boats anchored at its mouth, and waited for the arrival of the Union and the Wilson. Swansboro was seen in the distance, and very soon after their arrival a large white flag was seen to wave from a high brick building. A launch of the artillery was at once sent forward, and its men landed. At nightfall the Wilson arrived, bearing Col. STEVENSON and staff, and proceeded immediately to the town. By this time it was quite dark, and all the vessels lay quietly at anchor during the night.

abstract: Articles on police dept. operations
snippet: Articles on police dept. operations
lead_paragraph: The duties of Prefect of Police of Paris are extremely multiple, and extend not only over Paris but also over the whole Department of the Seine, and the Communes of St. Cloud, Mendon, Sivres and Enghien les Bains. He is under the authority of the Ministers, and is a member of the Board of Directors of the Mont de Piete, or Great Pawnbroking Office, and of the Hospitals. Under his direction are the Commissaries, the peace-officers and the police agents. Passports, permits to hunt, &c., are also issued by him. He has the supervision of prisons, markets, public houses, commerce, the printing and publishing interest, provisions, the distribution of gunpowder, and all that concerns the security of the public thoroughfares and the salubrity of the community. He takes measures in cases of conflagration or inundation, regulates the expenses of the police; the National Guard, the Garde de Paris and the Firemen, are always at his disposal; he causes the arrest of deserters and escaped convicts; he has also jurisdiction over the cattle market of Poissy. (This market is the most important cattle market in the neighborhood. Poissy is in the Department of the Seine et Oise, and its market is specially destined for the provisioning of Poris.) The Prefect of Police has the right to seize and open letters thrown into the Post-office.

abstract: Editorial attacks London press reporting
snippet: Editorial attacks London press reporting
lead_paragraph: The attitude of affected wonder adopted by the London Press in commenting upon what they term "the unfounded hostility of the United States toward England," constitutes quite a psychological curiosity. We are reminded of Mr. GARRIEL RAVEL in one of those innumerable pantomimic situations wherein, after committing some flat burglary, he essays to convince his captors of his innocence by facial alternations of meek ignorance and lugubrious vacuity. Can it be possible that those writers imagine the American public to be ignorant of their long-continued and most industrious efforts to damage and vilify the National cause? It seems hardly credible, yet it is difficult to explain their position upon any other rational basis. We are willing to concede that the bulk of the English ruling classes had a right to change their minds on the subject of negro Slavery. Albeit they had trumpeted their abhorrence of that system for many long years, their conversion was sudden, and rather a singular time was selected for its advertisement. We are ready to allow that it is perfectly natural they should desire a dissolution of the Union, if their reason is convinced -- and they profess it is so convinced -- that such an event would add to the permanency of British institutions, by doing much toward the extirpation of those agitating principles and opinions which have sometimes threatened them. We are prepared to admit that there was and is a powerful if not irresistible temptation to make use of the American rebellion so as to insure the political destruction of those troublesome Liberals and Radicals who are so unlovely in the sight of the British aristocracy. All these concessions it is proper to make, because although the actions so justified are dictated by pure selfishness, they are warranted in a manner by the traditionary arguments and usages of nations, and are not, in a technical sense, inconsistent with the principles of common honesty.

abstract: The law said to be passed by the Richmond Congress, to the effect, that if a substitute deserts, a new substitute must be found, or the original substitutor must march himself, seems to be a sound and fair law. It was the law which prevailed in the French army under NAPOLEON I. If the substitute was killed, or disabled, or captured, all military obligations of the original were annulled, but if the substitute deserted or committed a crime, the punishment of which took him out of the ranks, a new substitute was to be found. We do not know the present French law concerning this point. At present, the French Government fixes the price of substitution all over France, and furnishes a substitute when this price is paid. This is a cunning device of NAPOLEON III. denationalize the army, and to alienate it from the people. The present price is about 1,200 francs. Everyone who can pay about $250 may escape going into the army; while the substitutes are taken from the men who have served their six years, and are willing to become soldiers for life, with the prospect of having ultimately a small office also in the civil service.

abstract: A meeting of the exempt members and friends of the Eighth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., was held yesterday at the armory, over Centre Market. The object of the meeting was to make arrangements to give the Eighth a proper reception on its return. A Committee was appointed to carry out such arrangements, but it not being definitely known when the regiment would arrive, the members adjourned to meet to-day at the armory at 4 o'clock.

abstract: A telegraph was received by Mayor OPDYKE late Saturday evening, to the effect that there had been a very severe battle, and that all the surgeons that could leave New-York should report at once to
lead_paragraph: A telegraph was received by Mayor OPDYKE late Saturday evening, to the effect that there had been a very severe battle, and that all the surgeons that could leave New-York should report at once to the Surgeon-General at Washington. Pursuant to this he at once called a meeting of the New-York medical men at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, at 3 P.M., Sunday. On motion of Dr. CHAS. D. SMITH, Mayor OPDYKE was called to he Chair, and Dr. JNO. W. GREENE was elected Secretary. The purpose of the meeting was stated and gentlemen requested to hand in their names to the Secretary.

abstract: Dr. Nathan Gaither, a Kentucky gentleman of the old School, died at his home in Colombia, Adair County, on Thursday, Aug. 14. Dr. Gaither was born in Rowan County, North Carolino, in December, 1785, but emigrated to Kentucky early in the
lead_paragraph: -- Dr. Nathan Gaither, a Kentucky gentleman of the old School, died at his home in Colombia, Adair County, on Thursday, Aug. 14. Dr. Gaither was born in Rowan County, North Carolino, in December, 1785, but emigrated to Kentucky early in the present century. He studied medicine and graduated at the celebrated Philadelphia school during the professorship of Dr. Benjamin Rush. When the war of 1812 broke out, he went to the field as assistant surgeon. He acquired a very extensive practice, and frequently represented his county in the State Legislature; was a Jackson elector when the Hero of New-Orleans first attained the Presidency. Dr. Gaither was in Congress from 1829 to 1833, during the stormy period of South Carolina Nullification, and he died as he lived, a Democrat of the strictest school, sternly opposed to disunion. While in Congress he was on the Committee of Ways and Means when McDuffie was its chairman, and made the first minority report against the recharter of the United States Bank. Alter his congressional career, he never entered political life again, except as a member of the Constitutional State Convention in 1849, but devoted himself to his profession. He had a surgeon's commission tendered to him in the Mexican war, but, having two sons in the service, he declined the position, and enjoyed the evening of his days surrounded by all the comforts of a home he had ever gladdened, until he sank to sleep placidly, with all his faculties active to the last, and enabling him to give directions as to his medical treatment as steadily as if he had been prescribing for a patient. He was buried with Masonic honors.

abstract: -- There is intenseanxiety everywhere concerning the result of the great battle now going on in front of Washington; but it is not what it would have been a month ago. Although it will have a very marked effect upon the fortunes of the rebellion, it is not felt that an adverse result would be fatal to the Union cause. Our armies cannot be destroyed without leaving the rebels too weak for an immediate advance upon Washington; and, during that delay, we can, if need be, throw forward the half million men who have already been called for, and with them resist any force the rebels can bring against the Capital.
lead_paragraph: -- There is intenseanxiety everywhere concerning the result of the great battle now going on in front of Washington; but it is not what it would have been a month ago. abstract: The Seventy-first Regiment, N.Y.S.M., arrived in this City yesterday morning, the term of three months' service having expired. On landing in this City, the regiment was met by exempt members and friends of the corps. At once the men were marched to the armory, and dismissed. Col. MARTIN has issued the following order relative to the dismissal of the men from the United States service.

abstract: The news of the last fortnight from the battle-ground in Virginia has well tested the popular temper. The moment the retirement of MCCLELLAN from the neighborhood of Richmond was announced, immediately after the President had called for six hundred thousand new men, it became evident that the last chance of the rebels was to reach and overwhelm POPE before MCCLELLAN should join him; and that chance failing, it was only left to crush the combined National army before its numbers should be trebled by the coming of the new levies. These opportunities, and the perils they involved, were unquestionably appreciated by Gen. HALLECK. It had fallen to him to retrieve the tremendous blunder of approaching Richmond over the Peninsula. Could he safely extricate the endangered army of MCCLELLAN from the James River, and place it beside that of Gen. POPE on the Rappahannock, the odds of the war would again turn to the side of the North, and the campaign be renewed with the most encouraging auspices. To effect the salvation of MCCLELLAN, POPE was sent to demonstrate on Richmond. The rebels were not slow to recognize their opportune moment. They neglected altogether to follow the retreating columns of MCCLELLAN down the James; but gathering all their forces, and urging Northward every General and every soldier, they attempted to extinguish POPE before reinforcements could reach him. Their movement was not, however, sufficiently rapid. Some portion of MCCLELLAN's army, with the bulk of BURNSIDE's, had effected a junction with POPE before the great, rush of the rebels came; and thus strengthened, the National commander was enabled to fall back in perfect order from the Rapidan to the Rappahannock, and to contest on the banks of the latter the further advance of the enemy. But the enemy was aware how tardily the divisions of MCCLELLAN were moving to the support of POPE, and knew too well, that unless he could fling his entire force upon our people, while their numbers were still incomplete, and before the combined army had assumed any sort of organization, his hopes of victory were forever lost; and hence the incredible energy with which the legions of LEE, and LONGSTREET and JACKSON were moved to the rear of our lines. Their calculations, unfortunately were too nearly sound. The troops of MCCLELLAN came up slowly; the first ripple of the newly-called troops had not shown itself; and accordingly, the blow struck by our desperate antagonists was nearly fatal. Had not our brave fellows answered to the admirable generalship with which they were handled, and fought grandly and staunchly every inch of those battlegrounds, the traditions of which were so profoundly discouraging, we might have recorded before this the annihilation of our army and the capture of Washington. But with all their haste, and all the ill-understood tardiness of our own reinforcements, the hour struck before the rebels were ready.

abstract: -- Commodore WILKES has done a very good thing in demolishing City Point -- the pity is he did not do it a month ago, when out transports were daily being fired into by the batteries there. Now that our army has abandoned the Peninsula, it is of very little importance whether the water approach to Richmond is kept open or not. To the imbecility of the navy on the James River, we owe it that the rebel Capital was not long ago in our hands; and the ex post facto success of Commodore WILKES is of a piece with the rest of our naval victories in that quarter.
lead_paragraph: -- Commodore WILKES has done a very good thing in demolishing City Point -- the pity is he did not do it a month ago, when out transports were daily being fired into by the batteries there. abstract: Editorial sees recent Confederate activities as "last gasp" of rebellion
snippet: Editorial sees recent Confederate activities as "last gasp" of rebellion
lead_paragraph: are in movement along their entire line, from the Atlantic to the Mississippi. The attack mentioned this morning as repulsed by the Union troops at Bolivar, the previously reported defeat of Gen. NELSON, the advance of BRAGG toward Western Virginia, the threatened investment of Fort Donelson, are parts of the same daring strategy which places the main army of the rebellion in front of Washington. The explanation of this unwonted activity, and also of its apparent delay to the last moment, is obvious. The rebels, as their journals had no hesitation in declaring, never believed in the possibility of the Federal Government placing in the field the additional six hundred thousand men called for as volunteers and conscripts. The North was believed to be weary of the war. All the paupers who could be hired to fill the ranks had been obtained; there was no further material for volunteers; and as for the draft it would meet with resistance almost everywhere. Under these impressions the Confederate leaders remained tranquilly on the defensive, until their error became plain. Then, to strike before those six hundred thousand men should take the field, to extinguish the forces already a-foot, and carry the war as far as practicable from their own territory, became the indispensable policy; and this general onslaught was planned, as we see it in course of execution. What is apparently an exhibition of daring enterprise, is therefore nothing more than sheer desperation -- the agonies, in fact, of dissolution. They are doomed, and they know it. The certainty of this truth should qualify thesorrows of the croaklings who see nothing but ruin for the country in the events before Washington.

abstract: The first month of the operation of the new tariff has passed, and some idea may be formed from the business transacted and the amounts received of what its ultimate effect will be. The last month of the operation of a tariff which is to be superseded by a higher one, is usually a very busy one, and people in the importing business make every effort to obtain their shipments before the new laws take effect. The month of July, the last of the operation of the old tariff acts, was no exception to the rule, but was by far the most busy one for a long time. The large importations of that month would naturally lead us to expect that those of the month just passed would be quite small, the market being already tolerably well supplied, and the high rates of duty having a tendency to prevent importations. Contrary to such expectations, however, the importations have been above the usual average, and the receipts for duty more than ordinarily large. The high rates of duty required by the new tariff have not as yet had the effect of reducing importations below their ordinary limit.

abstract: -- Councilman ORTON is actuated, we cheerfully believe, by the most patriotic motives, in recommending an appropriation of half a million dollars to encourage recruiting -- holding, as he does, that the fate of the war is to be determined in ten days. But is he quite as sound in argument as in purpose? The true, and only way to raise troops in a hurry is to draft them. The process requires no expenditure of time and we suspect the delays which the Government refers to as requiring a postponement of the draft might easily be obviated, if circumstances really required the degree of urgency Mr. ORTON insists upon. If 300,000 troops must be had in a fortnight, let us have the draft, and let us save our half-million.
lead_paragraph: -- Councilman ORTON is actuated, we cheerfully believe, by the most patriotic motives, in recommending an appropriation of half a million dollars to encourage recruiting -- holding, as he does, that the fate of the war is to be determined in ten days. The process requires no expenditure of time and we suspect the delays which the Government refers to as requiring a postponement of the draft might easily be obviated, if circumstances really required the degree of urgency Mr. ORTON insists upon. If 300,000 troops must be had in a fortnight, let us have the draft, and let us save our half-million.

abstract: --The Evening Post is mistaken in saying that Judge WILLARD, who has just died at Saratoga Springs, acted with the Democrats in the State Senate last Winter. He was elected without opposition in his district, but acted throughout with the Unionists and Republicans of the Legislature. No member of either house was more zealous or hearty in the prosecution of the war, and of all measures essential to the support of the Federal Government in carrying it on. His health was feeble when he took his seat, and before the close of the session he found it impossible to go through the performance of his daily duties. He left Albany about a month before the session was over, but took a very warm interest in the Metropolitan Health Bill, and of sundry other measures calculated to increase the efficiency of our laws. Though not present at the Legislative caucus which adopted the address and resolutions which have since been made the basis of the Union Party in this State, he gave them his most cordial acquiescence and support.
lead_paragraph: --The Evening Post is mistaken in saying that Judge WILLARD, who has just died at Saratoga Springs, acted with the Democrats in the State Senate last Winter. He left Albany about a month before the session was over, but took a very warm interest in the Metropolitan Health Bill, and of sundry other measures calculated to increase the efficiency of our laws. Though not present at the Legislative caucus which adopted the address and resolutions which have since been made the basis of the Union Party in this State, he gave them his most cordial acquiescence and support.

abstract: -- Our community is agitated every day by the most agonizing rumors from the field of battle. Yesterday we had it reported from time to time that our army had been utterly routed, -- that our whole force had fallen back upon Alexandria, that Gen. MCCLELLAN had been arrested for treachery, and that the Capital was certain to fall into rebel hands. To a very great extent, the Government has made itself responsible for this unpleasant state of things, by its suppression of all military intelligence. Possibly there may be good reasons for this, which the future will disclose; but thus far it seems only to have been productive of mischief.

abstract: Advices from Greenville state that guerrillas 1,500 strong, under McBRIDE, threaten that place. 1,400 Union troops, under Col. SIMPSON, are there to meet them. The rebels for some days have been congregating all available forces at that point. They hourly make offensive demonstrations. An attack was soon expected. No fears are entertained for the result. There is no further news of raids throughout the State.

abstract: AN UNHAPPY HUSBAND COMMITS SUICIDE. A man named HERMAN BUOKNER, residing at No. 45 Lispenard-street, was found on Sunday in Canal-street, by Officers SPEAR and GAMBLING, of the Eighth Precinct, suffering from a dose of morphine, administered by himself.
lead_paragraph: AN UNHAPPY HUSBAND COMMITS SUICIDE. -- A man named HERMAN BUOKNER, residing at No. 45 Lispenard-street, was found on Sunday in Canal-street, by Officers SPEAR and GAMBLING, of the Eighth Precinct, suffering from a dose of morphine, administered by himself. He was immediately conveyed to the Station-house, where he was attended by Drs. TURNER and FRELIGHT; but, notwithstanding their efforts, he expired at a late hour on the same night. The deceased had just joined the Second New-York Artillery, and was to have left to-day for the seat of war. It is said that for a long time past he lived unhappily with his wife, and his troubles so preyed upon his mind that suicide was the result. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest upon the body yesterday, and during the investigation the following letter, addressed to his wife, was given in evidence:

abstract: Saturday was not, as announced, the last day for the payment of bounties. It was intended to be so; but the quota of the State has been so nearly filled byvoluntary enlistments, and it was so evident the complications of the enrollment would postpone the operation of the draft for two or three weeks longer, that it was thought advisable by the authorities, both at Albany and Washington, to continue every possible inducement that would be likely to make enough men enlist to complete the new regiments and restore those now in the field to their original strength in a manner that promised the least delay. As it is, men are volunteering, and regiments are being completed faster than they can be armed and equipped. Enlistments have attained so settled and apparently certain a daily average as to make the reinforcement of the army from that source a matter of simple calculation. It was seen that if enlistments went on as prosperously as they had been doing for the past month, the different military departments would have as much as they could attend to putting them into the field, without having their hands still further burdened with the sudden exigencies of an immense conscription. It in fact became an economical question whether it would not cost less money to continue the payment of bounties in a gradual and steady stream that could be easily disbursed and managed, than to accept the pecuniary responsibilities of providing for the wants of the new levies in one overwhelming lump. In the former case the present system and appliances of the department would answer all requisite purposes; in the latter, disorder and confusion might ensue, accompanied by consequent waste. Had it, however, been in the power of the authorities to raise the quota required of them by draft immediately, arrangements would most likely have been made for trying the experiment, even though it might have been impossible to use the men thus raised at once. There have been good reasons advanced for taking such a course. But the Empire State may congratulate itself that the opportunity still remains for her to prove that she has enough patriotism to contribute her share of soldiers to the cause freely and willingly -- such of her sons as cannot shoulder a musket themselves, contributing of their substance to influence those in doing so who are able. The Governor's proclamation on the subject caused a marked improvement it in the influx of recruits, during the latter part of yesterday, and will be sure to bring in as many to-day as the enrolling officers have been lately in the habit of passing. Col. BLIES is still the dispenser of these State premiums, and he is doing his best to pay them out as rapidly as they are called for. The United States bounties, which are also continued, Capt. CARR resumed the disbursement of -- pursuant to orders from the War Department to Col. REEVES -- yesterday morning. Recruits for regiments in the field will, therefore, yet obtain their $92, and recruits for the new regiments $63 -- the same sums they were entitled to before.

abstract: The whole of yesterday, Gen. CORCORAN and his Aids were busily engaged in organizing the brigade now being raised by him. From early in the...
lead_paragraph: The whole of yesterday, Gen. CORCORAN and his Aids were busily engaged in organizing the brigade now being raised by him. From early in the morning till quite late in the evening, dispatches were being received at the General's headquarters, Astor House, from various parts of the State, tendering companies and regiments for the Corcoran Brigade. For Col. MCDERMOTT's Regiment, alone, over two hundred men were enlisted yesterday, and from appearances, no doubt, the rush will continue. The war Committee, of Albany, sent in a communication offering to organize a regiment for the "Corcoran Legion," and was accepted by the General. Reports were also received from Col. MCMAHON, who is now raising a regiment in Buffalo, to be called the "Corcoran Guard," to the effect that his regiment is now nearly full. An invitation from the War CommitteeMayor and Common Council of Troy, asking the General to visit that city, and accept its hospitalities, was declined, on account of the numerous engagements of Gen. CORCORAN. The sum of $500 from Mr. A.M. HOYT, White-street, and $50 from an Irishman of the Seventeenth Ward, was banned in to aid enlistments for the brigade. The Sixty-ninth has now commenced recruiting in earnest, the headquarters being at the armory over Essex Market. A large number of men were enrolled yesterday, and, now that the State and United States bounties will continue to be paid, the increase of enlistments will no doubt be most marked, as the men will be enabled to leave their wives and families comfortably not amply, provided for. Authority has been received by the officers of the Sixty-ninth, permitting them to raise 1,800 men for this regiment, which authority has given great satisfaction to our Irish citizens. To-day it is expected that an island in the East River will be selected for a camping ground, so that recruits may be sent there as soon as recruited.

abstract: This gallant regiment, which, for the past three months, has been stationed at Harper's Ferry, left for home (this City) on Sunday night last, reaching Baltimore yesterday morning, and will arrive here this A.M., at about 10 o'clock. The time of service of the regiment expired on the 28th of August last, but being unwilling to come home while there seemed to be need of their services, they offered to remain until discharged by the Government, which discharge it seems they have received. Of the three months' regiments, this is the last to return home.

abstract: -- We have no disposition to canvass the reports concerning Gen. McCLELLAN, which were rife in the City yesterday. If they are true, and he has intentionally withheld any aid which he could possibly give to our gallant soldiers struggling with the rebels within cannon shot of his camp, there is no need of anticipating the punishment which will be inflicted upon him by an outraged and indignant nation. For the present, grave as are the appearances against him, we prefer to believe that his delay in moving forward has been due to other causes than his own will.

abstract: A horrible murder occurred in this village on Wednesday night in a house situated in Skinner's Lane, and occupied by one WILLIAM BARNET and his wife. It seems that about one o'clock, Thursday morning, Barnet aroused a neighbor, a Mrs. ENGLISH,...
lead_paragraph: A horrible murder occurred in this village on Wednesday night in a house situated in Skinner's Lane, and occupied by one WILLIAM BARNET and his wife. It seems that about one o'clock, Thursday morning, Barnet aroused a neighbor, a Mrs. ENGLISH, with the intelligence that his wife had committed suicide by cutting her throat. On returning with him to his house, she found his wife lying on her bed in a small bedroom, in the second, story of the building, weltering in her blood, her throat cut from ear to ear, and a large butcher knife in her right hand with the point outward. The pillow and bed clothing were completely soaked with blood, and the wall spattered with gore, and also marked in one place by the print of bloody fingers. Her throat had several fearful gashes, apparently inflicted with a somewhat dull knife. At the time Mrs. ENGLISH arrived the murdered woman was quite cold, and had evidently been dead some time.

abstract: The Garibaldi uprising has reached that critical stage when it must speedily either die out or light a conflagration throughout all Italy. The theory of those who have claimed...
lead_paragraph: The Garibaldi uprising has reached that critical stage when it must speedily either die out or light a conflagration throughout all Italy. The theory of those who have claimed that there was a secret understanding between GARIBALDI and the Italian Government, and who interpret the opposition of VICTOR EMANUEL as of a piece with the protests he entered against the movement of '59 -- a theory which we have never for a moment entertained -- has received a new and emphatic contradiction in the Senate at Turin, where M. RATAZZI, the Prime Minister, has declared that the Government consider GARIBALDI "in a state of rebellion, and the situation of Italy grave;" though he, at the same time, expressed hopes that the difficulties will be surmounted. But the most curious turn of affairs is the report of the Paris correspondent of the London Times, that NAPOLEON has expressed a very decided condemnation of GARIBALDI's movements, and "was even of the opinion that the Italian Government were not quite blameless in the matter!" Whether the blame attaches to their opposition to the enterprise, or to their supposed secret favoring of it, is not mentioned : but that NAPOLEON is really opposed to the new uprising, is something which we shall believe -- when there is some evidence of it; not till then.

abstract: -- Accordingto the proclamation of Gov. MORGAN, published yesterday, the State bounty of $50 is to be continued to all who shall enlist up to the 6th instant. The object of this measure is doubtless to encourage volunteer enlistments up to the time when the preparations for drafting shall be completed. The offer of bounty made by the Governor on the 17th of July was only intended to apply to enlistments under the first quota of sixty thousand -- the idea being that drafting would then begin immediately. This quota has, we are glad to learn from Gov. MORGAN, been fully made up: but in the meanwhile the enrollment has, we are sorry to learn, not been completed, and hence the extension of the bounty. We regret the occasion for this, as the draft should have been made on the 1st instant, the time appointed: but as it is, it is, no doubt, well to hold out the same inducements to fresh volunteers as have been offered to the former ones.

abstract: The people of Brooklyn seem bent on demon strating to their neighbors that the ardor which has found so emphatic an expression in that pious and patriotic adjunct of the Empire City, shall not suffer diminution until the war for the Uniou be brought to a speedy and triumphant end. They held another war meeting last evening in the City Hall Park, in order that still further impetus may be given to volunteering as preferable to conscription. The attendance numbered some 15,000 persons, whose patience, under a drenching rain, could be attributable only to the warmth of their patriotism.

abstract: -- A scheme for the formation of a brigade of veterans, originated in the teeming and patriotic brain of Mr SAMUEL HOTALING, is given in another column. It is the plan of that gentleman to draw upon the exempts for the material of this useful organization, and to subject the mature frames of his recruits to the same vigorous discipline and drill as have brought the strips lings of the Seventh and Twelfth Regiments to the perfection of soldiership. It is propel to say, Mr. HOTALING brings to the work much salutary experience. He participated largely in the muster of the Home Guard last year, never forsaking the ranks of that public spirited corps, until the shafts of ridicule, launched at it by invidious wits, suborned by the rebel Government, consigned it to an untimely fate. Since that unfortunate period Mr. HOTALING has devoted his energies to recruiting for the old regiments actually in the service, adding, as he is proud to say more than four hundred men, by his own singular exertions, to the rank and file of thearmy. Services so splendid should not be left for posterity to reward. Let all who are too aged and infirm to join the active forces in the field hasten to enroll themselves at the office of Mr. HOTALING.
lead_paragraph: -- A scheme for the formation of a brigade of veterans, originated in the teeming and patriotic brain of Mr SAMUEL HOTALING, is given in another column. It is the plan of that gentleman to draw upon the exempts for the material of this useful organization, and to subject the mature frames of his recruits to the same vigorous discipline and drill as have brought the strips lings of the Seventh and Twelfth Regiments to the perfection of soldiership. He participated largely in the muster of the Home Guard last year, never forsaking the ranks of that public spirited corps, until the shafts of ridicule, launched at it by invidious wits, suborned by the rebel Government, consigned it to an untimely fate. abstract: So far as we are permitted to know, the fighting was not continued yesterday between the opposing forces in front of Washington. Our army, heavily reinforced, holds Centreville and a portion of the Bull Run battle-field, and is confident of its ability to repel the enemy.
lead_paragraph: So far as we are permitted to know, the fighting was not continued yesterday between the opposing forces in front of Washington. Our army, heavily reinforced, holds Centreville and a portion of the Bull Run battle-field, and is confident of its ability to repel the enemy. Accounts of the battles of Saturday and Sunday are varied and conflicting. It appears, however, to be certain that our forces under McDOWELL, HEINTZELMAN and SIGEL were engaged in desperate conflict, and that McDOWELL was compelled to fall back. Our army is, however, reinforced with sixty thousand effective men, including FRANKLIN's, SUMNER's, POSTER's, RICHARDSON's, SEDGEWICK's and COX's Divisions of Ohio veterans from Western Virginia. One account estimates the number of prisoners taken by our forces in the recent battles at seventeen thousand. Nearly two thousand of them have already been forwarded to Washington. From the position of the two armies at latest accounts, we may at any moment have news of stirring interest.

abstract: WM.A. HAMMOND was born in Maryland in 1828, his parents moving to Harrisburgh, Penn., when he was four years of age, where he resided until entering the army in 1849. He studied medicine in...
lead_paragraph: WM.A. HAMMOND was born in Maryland in 1828, his parents moving to Harrisburgh, Penn., when he was four years of age, where he resided until entering the army in 1849. He studied medicine in Philadelphia and New-York. His first services were in New-Mexico, where he was actively engaged on the field for four years, subsequently serving in Florida, at West Point, and in Kansas. He was the most intimate friend of the late Gen. LYON, with whom he served in Kansas throughout the Border-ruffian war. While in Kansas he twice accompanied Topographical Engineers to the Rocky Mountains, and was medical director of the Sioux Expedition under Gen. HARNEY. After this he visited Europe for the purpose of acquiring information relative to the arrangements of the Military Hospitals of France, England, and Germany, and also to witness the workings of the medical organizations of the various armies. He returned in 1839, and after a year's service, resigned to accept the Professorship of Anatomy and Physic in the University of Maryland, Baltimore. The wounded soldiers of the Massachusetts Sixth Regiment, who were the victims of the Baltimore riot of the 19th of April, were cared for by Dr. HAMMOND. After witnessing that scene he immediately applied to headquarters and was restored to the army as an Assistant Surgeon. Since then he has been in active service on the Staffs of Gens. PATTERSON and BANKS, having charge of the large hospitals in Hagerstown, Frederick and Baltimore, and was, at the time of his appointment to his present high position, the Medical Inspector of Camps and Hospitals in Western Virginia. During his many years of service he has written many works on scientific subjects, many of which have been translated and printed in foreign countries. He was appointed Surgeon-General of the United States Army on the 28th of April, 1862, with the rank of Brigadier-General. In stature Gen. HAMMOND is very imposing, being six feet two inches in height weighing 230 pounds, and his demeanor is that of a thorough soldier. His varied capabilities and practical knowledge of the wants of the sick and wounded, and his promptness in personally seeing that all sanitary measures are adopted throughout his department that will tend to alleviate the sufferings of our unfortunate soldiers, will be well appreciated, not only by the Government, but by the people of this country.

lead_paragraph: By telegraph from Cape Race we have a summary of the news brought by the North American from Liverpool on the 21st, via Londonderry on the 22d of August -- five days later. The United States gunboat Tuscarora had returned from Belfast Lough to Kingstown, and anchored outside the bay. The London Globe defends Earl RUSSELL's use of the phrase, "unnecessary and injurious civil war," by showing that it is a citation from the President's reply to the Governors. The London Times treats the conscription as a new act of despotism, and thinks that "involuntary servitude is now the lot of the white race" in the United States. The News and Star continue to defend the cause of the North. It is claimed by the Paris Pays that the harvest in France is the best in ten years, and that no corn will be needed from abroad. It is said that NAPOLEON has expressed decided condemnation of GARIBALDI's movements. The embarkation of troops for Mexico had been suspended. In the Turin Senate on the 20th of August, RATAZZI, in reply to a question by a Senator, declared that the Government consider GARIBALDI in a state of rebellion, and the situation of Italy grave. GARIBALDI had entered Catania. In the London money market the funds were weaker, and the fall is attributed by the London Times to the telegrams in the extras giving the news from America. Money was in good demand at unchanged rates. The Liverpool Cotton market has been excited, with an advance of from 2d.@3d. lb. The sales for three days reached 67,000 bales. Advices from Manchester represent an excited and advancing market. The Liverpool breadstuffs market is generally firm; London upward, with a slight advance. Consols, 93@93 1/4.

abstract: The striking incident of yesterday was the voluntary call of a Committee of Physicians and Surgeons to offer, in behalf of themselves and their colleagues, their services, if needed, at the seat of Government and on the neighboring battle-fields, in tending our sick and wounded soldiers. The meeting held on Sunday afternoon, and the departure of a considerable medical delegation, during the same evening, for Washington, seem to excite general emulation among the fraternity in New-York.

abstract: Gov. ANDREW announces in a proclamation that he is acting so as to avoid any draft, if possible, and with this view he has put it off until the 17th of September. The document announces that this is done "with the consent of the Secretary of War, but upon the responsibility of the Governor of Massachusetts" whatever that odd jumble of all authority may mean. From this and other late...
lead_paragraph: Gov. ANDREW announces in a proclamation that he is acting so as to avoid any draft, if possible, and with this view he has put it off until the 17th of September. The document announces that this is done "with the consent of the Secretary of War, but upon the responsibility of the Governor of Massachusetts" -- whatever that odd jumble of all authority may mean. From this and other late indications, it would seem that the Secretary of War has surrendered the whole question of drafting into the hands of the Governors of the several States. A sort of small State-Rights battle has been waged, and Mr. STANTON retires worsted from the conflict. Each Governor appoints any day he sees fit for the commencement of drafting; the consequence is that there is an utter want of uniformity in a matter where, of all other things, uniformity is most needed. Besides, if each State Governor is to proceed on his own "responsibility," what assurance is there that we shall have a draft at all. At present, we confess, the prospect is hazy. The whole affair has been a muddle from the beginning, and a disgrace to the War Department. We pray Heaven it may not prove anything worse.
headline: {'main': 'Is There to be No Draft?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Is There to be No Draft?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Pennsylvania, to meet a requisition from the President, has issued orders for the formation of three cavalry regiments within twenty days. A similar demand should be made from the other States, as we are beginning to find out our extraordinary deficiency in this important branch of the service. The course of the military authorities with regard to cavalry has been erratic in the extreme. At first it was assumed we should need none at all, and the high authority of Gen. SCOTT has been cited in support of this view. Afterwards, under the CAMERON regime, the tendency was quite the other way, and a violent cavalry-mania took possession of the Government. Presently, however, this subsided, and many regiments of horse were disbanded! Under the late call for six hundred regiments, no provision, strange to say, was made for this branch of the service, though one regiment to five of infantry is the proportion assigned by military authorities. We take it that the War Department has at length found out the mistake, and if STUART and his men have been influential in opening their eyes, let us be thankful for it.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania, to meet a requisition from the President, has issued orders for the formation of three cavalry regiments within twenty days. Presently, however, this subsided, and many regiments of horse were disbanded! Under the late call for six hundred regiments, no provision, strange to say, was made for this branch of the service, though one regiment to five of infantry is the proportion assigned by military authorities. lead_paragraph: We have a brief telegram from Washington, announcing that a severe engagement took place on Monday evening, at Chantilly, about two miles north of Fairfax Court-House, between a portion of Gen. POPE's command and JACKSON'S army. It is stated that our loss was heavy, but that we succeeded in driving the enemy back a mile or more, and occupied the field of battle Tuesday morning. Gen. STEVENS was killed, while gallantly leading his command against the enemy. Gen. KEARNEY was also killed on the field of battle. His body fell into the hands of the enemy, but was subsequently delivered to us under a flag of truce. Beyond the brief telegram announcing the engagement and the loss of the two Generals, we have no particulars of the affair whatever.

abstract: The machinery of that ponderous structure  the new general Tax law seems to be hard to set in motion. Very great uncertainty still prevails among...
lead_paragraph: The machinery of that ponderous structure -- the new general Tax law -- seems to be hard to set in motion. Very great uncertainty still prevails among the reputed officers who are to act under the bill, and although a list of the names of Assessors and Collectors appointed for the Southern District of this State has been published, the great majority of the gentlemen therein designated are yet in ignorance as to the confirmation of their appointments. Of the whole bulk of commissions already due, only a few of those for the rural districts have been received at the office of the United States District-Attorney. These are for the Eleventh, Twelfth, Thirteenth, Fifteentn, Seventeenth. Twentieth, Twenty-first and Twenty-msixth District, or but eight in all. Neither Collectors nor Assessors have had any conference or general meeting nor have they any central office or rallying point whatever. In fact, the greater number of these gentlemen are quite in the dark as to their proceedings, and the questions of anxious inquirers elicit among them only a helpless state of [???]

abstract: Editorial sees Confederate successes as indication war is to be carried to North
snippet: Editorial sees Confederate successes as indication war is to be carried to North
lead_paragraph: The news of a strong rebel force threatening Louisville, is accompanied by news of a force equally strong threatening Cincinnati. The surrender of Clarksville is followed by an attack upon Fort Donelson. A portion of Gen. BRAGG's army has been thrown into Western Virginia; and a body of cavalry, possibly detached from some powerful rebel expedition, is reported as having seized Buckhannon -- a Virginia town, not far from the Pennsylvania line. In front of Washington the main body of the insurgent army pauses for a moment; but declares its purpose to be the passage of the Potomac and the occupation of Maryland. Washington is to be the first fruit of this daring movement.

abstract: THE SOUTH. There are several other regions which one would suppose to be more difficult to govern than the Department of the South. It is not expected of the General who undertakes its charge that he shall seek any new conquests, or enter on any new campaign in that quarter: he will do all that is required of...
lead_paragraph: -- There are several other regions which one would suppose to be more difficult to govern than the Department of the South. It is not expected of the General who undertakes its charge that he shall seek any new conquests, or enter on any new campaign in that quarter: he will do all that is required of him if he hold the territory which the navy won for us ten mouths ago. And yet, if we judge by the frequency with which the commanders of that apartment are changed, we should conclude it to be the very hardest of all hard military nuts to crack. Gen. MITCHEL goes down as the third who has essayed to rule the Sea Island region, succeeding Gen. HUNTER, who replaced Gen. SHERMAN. Unless there be something in the genius of the place that turns the best head, the Government has surely at last found a man fit for the post and the work. Gen. MITCHEL is an educated soldier; but he superadds to this a practical and administrative talent, that the mere soldier rarely shows. If his energetic and versatile mind fails to control the refractory elements of that region, we may well despair of finding any man fit for the task.

abstract: --This work, now in the press of Messrs. HURLBURT, WILLIAMS && Co. of Hartford, is announced for early publication, the first volume of about 1,000 pages to appear in a fortnight -- the second before the close of the year. It is profusely illustrated with steel engravings. The book will be sold to subscribers only, and the canvass for names will be begun in this City forthwith by Messrs. HORACE KING and W. GILL.
lead_paragraph: --This work, now in the press of Messrs. abstract: A correspondent of the Newark Daily Advertiser says: "A council of war was held yesterday (Sept 1.) at Centreville, which was participated in by Gens. Pope, McDowell, Sigel, Banks, Heintzelman, Kearney, Hooker, Porter, Reno, Cox, Summer and Sturgis; and the plans that were determined on are said to have met the complete sanction and approval of Gen. HALLECK, who is perfectly satisfied they will result advantageously. The prospect is pronounced promising that Gen. POPE will soon advance upon the enemy again."

abstract: Since Gen. CORCORAN has returned from Washington, he has had his hands full of business. At the first meeting held of the Sixty-ninth's officers, it will be remembered that all, with the exception of Col. BAG-...
lead_paragraph: Since Gen. CORCORAN has returned from Washington, he has had his hands full of business. At the first meeting held of the Sixty-ninth's officers, it will be remembered that all, with the exception of Col. BAGLEY, at once volunteered for the war. We learn from Lieut.-Col. MURPHY, who deserves, and probably will receive the Colonelcy, that recruiting is going on finely, that very many of the men who were out the first time are now enlisting, and that hundreds of others are anxious to go with Gen. CORCORAN.

lead_paragraph: Coroner NAUMANN was yesterday engaged in holding an inquest upon the body of a German woman, named CATHARINE GALETZRIC, 30 years of age, who was found dead at No.21 West Thirteenth-street, at an early hour yesterday morning. She proves to have been the wife of a soldier who has seen active service for the last year, and the circumstances as detailed by the witnesses upon the inquest, are certainly of a character to excite the sympathies of all whose attention is called to them.

Fifteen thousand people were gathered at the opening services, and we have no doubt that the second session will draw at least fifty thousand of our intelligent and sober-minded brethren from their comfortable homes, to hold council together on the perilous state of the country. lead_paragraph: -- To-night, the great War Meeting, which was commenced on Monday night, will be held in the City-Hall Park. Fifteen thousand people were gathered at the opening services, and we have no doubt that the second session will draw at least fifty thousand of our intelligent and sober-minded brethren from their comfortable homes, to hold council together on the perilous state of the country. A list of speakers, long and appetizing, is published; and although very many of them will be "unavoidably detained," beyond a doubt, rich treats of eloquence most patriotic will be prepared. Money and men are what is needed, and Brooklyn has an abundance of each. At 7 1/2 o'clock, these friends of freedom rally, at the sound of the bell, around the stands, one of which will be in the Park, another in Remsen-street, and a third in Montague-street.

abstract: Giles vs. A.A. Selover and John C. Fremont.  The plaintiff in this case having obtained a judgment against the defendants and execution thereon having been returned unsatisfied, obtained an order for the examination of the defendants on supplementary proceedings. On the failure of the defendant, Gen. ...
lead_paragraph: Giles vs. A.A. Selover and John C. Fremont. -- The plaintiff in this case having obtained a judgment against the defendants and execution thereon having been returned unsatisfied, obtained an order for the examination of the defendants on supplementary proceedings. On the failure of the defendant, Gen. Fremont, to appear and submit to an examination, plaintiff applied for an order of attachment to issue against the General for contempt of Court. Judge Barnard denied the application, but granted an order to show cause why such attachment should not issue. Plaintiff not being able to serve this order upon Gen. Fremont owing to his absence in New-England, he now applies, de novo, for an order for the examination of Gen. Fremont The objection made to the granting of the order is founded on section 312 of Article 477 of the laws of 1862, which provides that "no person belonging to the military forces shall be arrested on any civil process, while going to, remaining at, or returning from any place at which he may be required to attend for military duty." and it is alleged on the part of the defendants that Gen. Fremont is now in this City on military duty. Plaintiff produces the affidavit of one Bradford Jones that Gen. Fremont is not now in actual military service for the United States, but has been deprived of his command by order of the Secretary of War. Judge LEONARD, without deciding in advance the liability or exemption of Gen. Fremont from arrest, granted the order for his examination on supplementary proceedings.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The drama of "Rosa Gregorio" has been revived at the Winter Garden, and will be played through the current week. The piece is a very effective one, and has been received, whenever played, with sufficient commendation to warrant its permanent addition to Miss BATEMAN's repertory. In the part of the heroine Miss BATEMAN has achieved a decided success. She is excellently sustained in the other leading parts by Mr. J.W. WALLACK, Jr., and Mr. EDWIN ADAMS.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The drama of "Rosa Gregorio" has been revived at the Winter Garden, and will be played through the current week. The piece is a very effective one, and has been received, whenever played, with sufficient commendation to warrant its permanent addition to Miss BATEMAN's repertory. In the part of the heroine Miss BATEMAN has achieved a decided success. She is excellently sustained in the other leading parts by Mr. J.W. WALLACK, Jr., and Mr. EDWIN ADAMS.
