abstract: One of the most skillful burglaries which have taken place for a long time in this City, was committed last Sunday, at the store of Messrs. E.H. ARNOLD & Co., Commission Merchants, No. 81 Warren-street. When the porter opened the store on Monday morning last, he found numerous bales and boxes of goods missing, and many of those remaining had been broken open, and a portion of their contents taken away; the remnants were strewed around in great disorder.He was not long in ascertaining the fact that the burglars had entered the store by digging a hole through the wall from the building adjoining, No. 79 Warren-street. The police were immediately notified, and Capt. MOUNT of the Third Precinct, was very soon on hand, and made a thorough survey of the premises. The building No. 79 Warren-street was, previous to last May, occupied as the Third Precinct Police Station. Since that time it has been used as a tenement house. About the middle of last week, a man who said he resided with his family on the corner of Tenth-avenue and Forty-ninth-street, hired a room on the first floor of the building, adjoining the store of ARNOLD & Co., for the purpose, as he represented it, of an office. He soon after moved in the only furniture found in the room, which consisted of an old wardrobe and table. When Capt. MOUNT visited the premises on Monday, he found the door of this room locked, and the only way he could gain an entrance was through the "hole" in the wall" from the store to this office. Here he found twenty-three empty boxes, all of which had been conveyed from the store, through the opening in the partition, to the room of the burglars. In this room there was much to indicate that more than one person had been engaged in the burglary. About $100 worth of goods were found in the apartment by Capt. MOUNT, mostly remnants which had evidently been left by the [???] in their haste to [???] the premises. The Captain also found a large number of burglars' tools, such as jimmies, knives, angers, &c. Detective FARLEY has been associated with Capt. MOUNT in the effort to secure the stolen property and arrest the guilty parties, but up to a late hour last evening no person had been taken into custody. A reward of $800 has been offered by Messrs. ARNOLD & Co. for the recovery of the stolen goods and the arrest of the burglars.

abstract: We regret to announce the death of Mrs. ELIZA BELLA STRIKER, wife of Maj.-Gen. GARRIT H. STRIKER of this City. The deceased was a lady of eminent intellectual qualities, but was equally remarkable for the graces of her personal character, extreme suavity and kindness of manners, and unvarying amiability. A combination of domestic virtues so admirably adapted to contribute to the happiness of the home and social circle has rarely been met with. It is needless to say the death of so attractive a member of society causes wide-spread regret.
lead_paragraph: We regret to announce the death of Mrs. ELIZA BELLA STRIKER, wife of Maj.-Gen. GARRIT H. STRIKER of this City. lead_paragraph: The payment of the State and United States bounties is going on the same as ever. The former will continue to be paid to recruits for new regiments up to Saturday, and to recruits for regiments in the field until further notice. No period has been fixed for the stoppage of the latter. Col. BLISS forwards cheeks for each man's share of the Stats bounty as soon as he can, after receiving the requisite papers from the man's company officer. Capt. CARR dispenses the United States bounty at once, without any needless delay or circumlocution. The bounties hitherto to paid are to be still further increased, from an appropriation made by the Common Council, to the extent of $50 extra for every volunteer joining a regiment from the City. The ordinance making this appropriation was passed yesterday. Whether this $50 is a retrospective bounty, and includes those who have heretofore enlisted, is not stated. Should it be confined to those who enlist only after the date of the passage of the ordinance, some dissatisfaction must be expected from the older volunteers. Besides these public bounties, extra bounties are constantly being offered from private sources to special regiments.

abstract: Dr. SLOAN, Medical Director of this station, has received notice from the War Department to immediately furnish accommodations, if practicable, for 2,600 sick and wounded soldiers. Fortunately, owing ...
lead_paragraph: Dr. SLOAN, Medical Director of this station, has received notice from the War Department to immediately furnish accommodations, if practicable, for 2,600 sick and wounded soldiers. Fortunately, owing to the large numbers that have recently been discharged from the various hospitals in this vicinity, he is able to comply with the requisition, and will still have accommodations left. Beds are now vacant in the different hospitals to the number of 2,200, and within two or three days it is expected that 300 more soldiers will be discharged from David's Island. The following are the number of beds now vacant in the different hospitals: David's Island, 1,200; Newark, 364; Ladies' Home, 20; Brooklyn City Hospital, 90; Bedloe's Island, 150; Jews' Hospital, 5; Bollevue, 200; Long Island College Hospital, 80, besides a considerable number at the hospital on Blackwell's Island.

abstract: Duryee Zouaves forming 2d battalion, NYC
snippet: Duryee Zouaves forming 2d battalion, NYC
lead_paragraph: The war for the suppression of the Southern rebellion has not been signalized thus far by any of those combined movements of masses of troops which won for NAPOLEON the Great his completest victories, which made his Old Guard and his Young Guard famous, and which, in more recent times, gave a name to the famous English Light Brigade. The first efforts of our people, unaccustomed to war-making on a large scale, have given celebrity to single regiments like HAWKINS' and DURYEE'S Zouaves, the Sixty-ninth and other gallant commands; but we have had no overwhelming triumph to record of brigades and divisions, which, uniformly drilled, equipped and disciplined under the eye of a single leader, have decided the fate of battles. It is only because we are new to the business, and have been compelled hitherto to be content with instructing our soldiers in the simple movements which are always preliminary to the combined manaeuvres, that these things are so. The time for greater things, we trust, approaches nearer as we grow older in the business of warfare. But before we can do as the French and English have done, we must imitate more closely their first efforts. Before we can hurl an Old Guard, or a Young Guard, or a Light Brigade upon the foe, and achieve with them a victory or stem a defeat, we must first create divisions and brigades as formidable as these.

abstract: President BARRIOS has finished his tour over the Republic. He was everywhere received with popular demonstrations of favor. The great question
lead_paragraph: President BARRIOS has finished his tour over the Republic. He was everywhere received with popular demonstrations of favor. The great question of the opposition of the Catholic clergy to the Government, which so nearly caused a revolution, and would have caused it had the priests been able to inveigle the people into their support, will be settled amicably, Pope PIUS having directed the priests to take the oath to obey the laws required from them by President BARRIOS.

abstract: -- A telegram from Halifax conveys a startling piece of information. It informs us that the London Herald thinks the draft "will try the temper of the Northern people more than it has ever been tried yet, and strike to its very foundation the tottering edifice of the Union." For once that Secessionist sympathizer is right. The draft does try the temper of the Northern people excessively; but it tries it because the Government does not immediately make it! The strange spectacle is presented of a whole people begging to be drafted. That's a view of the matter that has hardly got through the thick skull of our British cotemporary.

abstract: Our army in Virginia appears to be gradually massing in the immediate vicinity of Washington. The determined attacks of the rebels on our supply trains in the rear of Gen. POPE, which came near being successful on Sunday, were persisted in with such vigor, that a large force was sent to put a stop to it. A company of the Second United
lead_paragraph: Our army in Virginia appears to be gradually massing in the immediate vicinity of Washington. The determined attacks of the rebels on our supply trains in the rear of Gen. POPE, which came near being successful on Sunday, were persisted in with such vigor, that a large force was sent to put a stop to it. A company of the Second United States Cavalry, under Capt. HIGHT, were taken prisoners, but the object of the rebels was temporarily foiled. With a view to secure our trains beyond peradventure, our forces were, on Monday, pushed forward from Centreville to Fairfax Court-house, RENO's Division leading, and McDOWELL's following. Near Fairfax Court-house, about 4 P.M. on Monday, RENO's Division met a detachment of the rebel Gen. HILL's Division, under Gen. STEWART, and a sanguinary conflict ensued. Gens. RENO and STEVENS immediately formed in line of battle, but, while gallantly leading a charge, the latter was instantly killed by a Mine ball. His troops, however, drove the enemy before them. It was in this engagement that Gen. KEARNEY was killed. Skirmishing was kept up about three hours, when the enemy were forced to retire after heavy loss. At another point, on the same day, they were, however, fortunate enough to capture a train of a hundred of our supply wagons.

abstract: Editorial decries Confederate atrocities
snippet: Editorial decries Confederate atrocities
lead_paragraph: In their dawning conviction of the hopelessness of mere civilized warfare to enable them to compass their ends, the rebels have taken a leaf from the annals of the Aborigi- nals of our country, and seem to put their trust in the adoption of those devilish cruelties and terror-striking torments which are always the final resource of savages when fighting a superior foe. They have, however, neglected to turn to the last page of the history, on which is inscribed, as the crowning result of such luminous tactics, the sad but inexorable word -- extermination. Many an unarmed colonist was killed at the plow -- many a Christian, male and female, was tortured at the pitiless stake -- many a babe was wrenched from the mother's breast and butchered before her eyes -- many a scalp with snowy locks adorned the belts of ruthless warriors -- many a roof-tree fell blazing in the bitter Winter's night, and crushed the innocent sleepers in the sanctity of home, yet these horrors brought their legitimate fruit in due season, and the record closes with the sweeping destruction of the perpetrators.

abstract: The United States vs. The Schooner Shark.  This was the case of a vessel seized while abeut to enter the Port of Galveston. When the capture was made the captors sent the crew of the prize on shore and brought the vessel to this port. On her arrival,
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Schooner Shark. -- This was the case of a vessel seized while abeut to enter the Port of Galveston. When the capture was made the captors sent the crew of the prize on shore and brought the vessel to this port. On her arrival, upon the application of the Government stating that none of the crew were here to be examined, an order was made that the testimony of the captors be taken in preparatorio, which was accordingly done. Afterward the Master of the captured vessel appeared to defend the cause, and his evidence was taken in preparatorio.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 23d of August, has reached Halifax, bringing two days later intelligence. The vigilance of the Tuscarora in watching rebel craft shocks the nerves of the authorities in Ireland. The London Times takes a gloomy view of late American advices. The Herald thinks the draft will shake the Union to its very foundation. The English political news is unimportant. Harvest operations were progressing more favorably. The French Minister of War had freighted some English steamers for the Mexican Expedition. The news from Italy is unimportant. Sicily has been proclaimed in a state of siege, and Gen. CIALDINI appointed Civil and Military Chief of the Island. The Ministry have addressed a report to the King, declaring the Garibaldi enterprise to be a rebellion, and urging energetic measures to put it down. The liberty of the Press in Sicily has been suspended. The Madrid journals continue to denounce the terms in which NAPOLEON addressed Gen. CONCHA, when he presented to him his credentials as Ambassador from Spain. Extraordinary activity in cotton at Bombay is announced. In American Stocks, the market held an upward tendency. Consols, 93 1/8@93 1/4.

abstract: Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: "The Federal gunboat Tuscarora, it appears, has been dodging the Ajax for the purpose of getting coals on board in defiance of the orders issued by the Admiralty. The Tuscarora has coaled within three months at a British port, and did not proceed, as she was bound to do, on a voyage to the United States. She remained hovering about the coast on the lookout for Confederate vessels. She put into Kingstown with the view of getting coals. Unable to accomplish this there, partly in consequence of the return of the Ajax, she weighed anchor and steamed with all speed to Belfast Lough, where, according to a previous arrangement, she received a supply of coal amounting to a hundred tons. Having anchored outside of the jurisdiction of the Harbor Commissioners, the Collector of the Customs at once took the matter up and served a notice on the Federal captain to depart within twenty-four hours, and a revenue cutter was placed alongside of the Tuscarora to prevent further violation of the neutrality laws, and at the same time the matter was reported to the Admiralty. The Belfast people ask what would have been done if the Federal captain had refused to leave?"

abstract: Each mail brings renewed confirmation of the imminence of the crisis in Italy; and the telegraphic intelligence by the Asia, published to-day, is of a still more serious cast than any yet received. All illusions taking the shape
lead_paragraph: Each mail brings renewed confirmation of the imminence of the crisis in Italy; and the telegraphic intelligence by the Asia, published to-day, is of a still more serious cast than any yet received. All illusions taking the shape of a supposed complicity of the Turin Government in the enterprise of GARIBALDI must disappear before the developments that have now arisen. The vote of the Senate, pronouncing the movement a rebellion, has been followed by an order in the official Turin Gazette, of the 21st August, declaring a state of siege in Sicily, and nominating Gen. CUGIA Extraordinary Commissioner. Gen. CUGIA immediately issued a proclamation, announcing that the state of things in Sicily must be put an end to; declaring that every armed band or tumultuous meeting will be dissolved by force; and, furthermore, suspending the liberty of the Press. It is also stated that Gen. CIALDINI has been appointed Civil and Military Chief of Sicily, with the fullest powers.

abstract: It has been sagely said, that to most men experience is like the stern-lights of a ship, which illumine only the track it has passed. It will be a very sad thing for this Republic if those who now direct its destinies are recorded by history in such a category. Never
lead_paragraph: It has been sagely said, that to most men experience is like the stern-lights of a ship, which illumine only the track it has passed. It will be a very sad thing for this Republic if those who now direct its destinies are recorded by history in such a category. Never the life of a nation was there greater need of that peculiar sagacity which employs the acquired light of yesterday in the selection of a path for to-morrow, than in the United States to-day. On its presence or its absence in the places of power depends our whole future destiny. It is to decide whether we remain a great people, homogeneous, united and powerful, or take the first fatal step of disintegration which will lead us to the position of those petty States, whose weight in the world's councils is represented by a cypher, and whose little quarrels only provoke a smile.

abstract: In referring to Mr. SAMUEL HOTALING's projected brigade of exempts, a day or two since, the "aged and infirm" were named as likely to present themselves for enlistment. Our attention has been directed to an apparent assumption in these words, that men over forty-five are to be properly described as advanced in years, and necessarily disabled. We distinctly disclaim any such meaning. Those who survive middle-age are quite likely to do so by the help of stout constitutions; and when stout constitutions are the possession of the exempts, they are, perhaps, better prepared for the hardships of war than the untried and unseasoned frames of the more youthful. By all means let the Hotaling Brigade of Veterans be raised. The corps will find broad fields for service.
lead_paragraph: In referring to Mr. SAMUEL HOTALING's projected brigade of exempts, a day or two since, the "aged and infirm" were named as likely to present themselves for enlistment. abstract: The selections made by the telegraph yesterday from the confused medley of dispatches in the Philadelphia papers, excited momentarily the profoundest alarm is the City. POPE, it was stated, was in full retreat to Washington, while JACKSON, having chosen
lead_paragraph: The selections made by the telegraph yesterday from the confused medley of dispatches in the Philadelphia papers, excited momentarily the profoundest alarm is the City. POPE, it was stated, was in full retreat to Washington, while JACKSON, having chosen Edwards' Ferry as the proper point for crossing the Potomac, was already urging his march upon Maryland. Later information served to correct these rumors. The very telegraph, which always sympathizes curiously with the bear movements of Wall-street, seems to have repented at the end of an hour or two the mischief it had done in catching up and exaggerating a foolish and baseless rumor, and came halting in with corrections and explanations. It was true Gen. POPE was arranging to render his lines of communication more secure from a flank attack, and was, therefore, drawing in his army so as to rest upon the lines of Arlington; and it might have been true that JACKSON had designs upon Maryland; but the latter statement was purely a bit of street gossip, originated doubtless among the panic-makers of the Capital, and greedily gathered up and sent flying all abroad by a correspondent, whose faculty of inventing news happened at the moment to be costive. At the hour we go to press there is nothing to indicate the departure of JACKSON from the main rebel force at Bull Run. For once that active officer has been outmarched by a lying rumor. Hereafter the public will do well to receive all stories circulated immediately before and during the sessions of the Stock Exchange with great caution. The principal business of the morning Press has been for a long time to contradict the telegraphic bouncers of the evening papers; and with this obvious fact patent in the experience of every reader, and with the equally obvious certainty that falsehood is especially profitable from 12 M. to 4 P.M. daily, they who lose coin or courage on the faith of fallacious reports, must console themselves with the reflection that they have only themselves to blame.

abstract: A portion of the Thirteenth Regiment Militia, under command of Col. ROBERT B. CLARK, arrived at the foot of Canal-street, New-York, about noon yesterday, on board the steamer Baltic, Capt. COMSTOCK. Reports has been circulated that the vessel had been wrecked, and much excitement was caused in consequence. It appears they had a narrow escape from shipwreck, but not a man was lost.

abstract: Invaded by Colombia Reactionary Party troops
snippet: Invaded by Colombia Reactionary Party troops
lead_paragraph: I wrote you, a month since, that the troops of Gen. ARBOLEDA, the leader of the reactionary party in the State of Cauca, in the new Republic of the United States of Colombia, formerly known as New-Granada, had entered on the territory of Ecuador in pursuit of some Mosqueristas, who had sought refuge over the frontier at Pasto, and when ordered off, had killed or badly wounded, an Ecuadorian officer. For this act, you already know, the President of Ecuador, Senor GARCIA MORENO, had demanded the dismission of the Colonel who commanded ARBOLEDA's troops, and also an indemnity of $100,000. This having been refused, the Province of Pasto was invaded by MORENO, it is said by 2,500 men, but it could scarcely have been by so many. A private letter from Guayaquil says that "ARBOLEDA, who was at Popayan, the capital of the State of Cauca, having heard of this invasion, marched immediately into Pasto, and on the 30th of July, in the vicinity of Tulcan, found himself in front of the Ecuatorian force. On the 31st, at 10 in the morning, he commenced to man�uvre, and outflanking the Ecuaorians, made a bayonet charge upon them with a part of his force in solid columns, and was received by a shower of balls from six pieces of cannon. At this moment Gen. ZARAMA, whose division had succeeded in flanking the Ecuatorians, advanced upon them, the two parties completely encircling them, President MORENO, 'who performed prodigies of valor.' was taken prisoner, as also did the Commandant General and Secretary of War, Senor DANIEL SALVADOR. Thirteen hundred prisoners also fell into the hands of ARBOLEDA, including nearly all the Ecuadorian officers. Seventeen hundred muskets and seven pieces of cannon also fell into ARBOLEDA's hands."

abstract: -- Recruiting was quite brisk yesterday. Col. JOURDAN's First Regiment of the Empire Brigade required 47 men the night previous, to fill up two companies, (the others having their quota,) and these were procured before noon. The Colonel and several Captains proceeded to Albany last night to obtain their commissions. Col. CONK's Second Senatorial Regiment has been full for nearly a week, and is encamped on the Park near the Navy-yard. One or two companies are still engaged in recruiting, however. There are about 1,100 names on the muster-roll. The men of neither regiment are yet fully uniformed, and have not muskets enough for guard duty. The headquarters of Col. BLUNT's Third Senatorial Regiment have been opened in the marble building on the corner of Joralemon and Court streets. Recruiting agents were sent out on Long Island and to Staten Island yesterday. The Fourth Metropolitan Regiment, Col. MORTON, are doing a good business. Yesterday 50 men were enlisted, which makes a total of over 260 since Saturday. Some of the recruits have been sent to camp on Riker's Island. Should the State bounty be continued for two weeks longer both these new regiments will be filled up.

abstract: Andrew C. Ferris vs. Edward Soley et al. The plaintiff began his action against the defendant by the service of a money-demand summons on the 12th of May, 1862, and at the same time obtained an order of arrest, upon which order the defendant was arrested.
lead_paragraph: Andrew C. Ferris vs. Edward Soley et al. -- The plaintiff began his action against the defendant by the service of a money-demand summons on the 12th of May, 1862, and at the same time obtained an order of arrest, upon which order the defendant was arrested. Defendant's attorney served a notice of appearance on plaintiff's attorney, superadding the words, "And require that all papers be served on me at my office, No. 11 Wall-street, in the City of New-York." The plaintiff, not regarding such notice as a sufficient demand of a copy of the complaint, omitted to serve a copy thereof, but entered judgment against the defendant, on his default, on the 19th day of June.

abstract: The Vermont State Election for the choice of Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, Treasurer, and Members of the Legislature, was holden to-day. As was expected, the vote is very light, and the result indicates that party lines have been almost entirely ignored. Two tickets only were run, viz: the Re- publican Union ticket, headed by the present Governor, FREDERICK HOLBROOK, and the Peace Democratic ticket headed by Hon. B.F. SMALLEY.

abstract: The appointmentof Gen. MCCLELLAN to the command of the Army of Virginia, will be received with a very general feeling of surprise; and possiblywith distrust and dissatisfaction. It will be remembered, however, that while the army is defending Washington, the command is immediately in the hands of Gen. HALLECK, and that practically Gen. MCCLELLAN is no more than the medium through which the orders of the General-in-Chief are communicated to subordinate officers. Not only the plan of operations, but its execution, will be due to Gen. HALLECK. Upon his shoulders will rest the entire responsibility. The alarmists, who detect in the nomination of MCCLELLAN matter of fresh apprehension, have small capital to go upon.

abstract: Gen. NELSON at Richmond, Ky., is the severest reverse that has befallen the Union arms in that State. It opened the richest portion of that fine agricultural Commonmealth to the enemy. He will find there
lead_paragraph: -- The defeat of Gen. NELSON at Richmond, Ky., is the severest reverse that has befallen the Union arms in that State. It opened the richest portion of that fine agricultural Commonmealth to the enemy. He will find there abundance of corn, and the finest beeves in the West, and no stint of horses and mules, to facilitate his transportation. The most of this abundant and valuable property belongs to loyalists, and it will be not the leas acceptable to the rebels on that account.

abstract: THE ABORTION CASE IN THIRTEENTH-STREET  THE CORONER'S INQUEST NOT CONCLUDED Coroner NAUMANN yesterday continued the inquest in the case of Mrs. CATHARINE GALETZKIE, whose body was found
lead_paragraph: THE ABORTION CASE IN THIRTEENTH-STREET -- THE CORONER's INQUEST NOT CONCLUDED. -- Coroner NAUMANN yesterday continued the inquest in the case of Mrs. CATHARINE GALETZKIE, whose body was found on Tuesday morning at a house in West Thirteenth street, under circumstances which rendered it almost certain that a great crime had been committed, an account of which we gave in yesterday's TIMES. Very little evidence tending to throw light upon the dark mystery was elicited yesterday. Several witnesses were examined, among them Mrs. JOHNSON, the proprietor of the house, where the body was found. She testified that the deceased was sent to her house by Dr. Cox; that she had previously made an arrangement with him to take a lady who was coming from the country to be nursed, and she supposed it was this country lady, until deceased had been in her house for several hours. The burial certincate, which was given by Dr. SHERRILL, states that the deceased died of inflamation of the bowels. The post-mortem examination, made by Dr. ROBINSON, Deputy Coroner, shows that she died from a very different cause. The inquest will be resumed at 9 o'clock, this morning, when it is believed that some very startling evidence will be given. Coroner NAUMANN, aided by the Police, has been engaged in working up the case, and ail believe that there is evidence enough to convict some of the parties who have been apprehended.

abstract: His Honor the Mayor, S.S. POWELL, presided, and, on taking the chair, was received with three cheers, and proceeded, in a few remarks, to comment upon the present extraordinary position of the armies of the Union. He urged the immediate enlistment of the
lead_paragraph: His Honor the Mayor, S.S. POWELL, presided, and, on taking the chair, was received with three cheers, and proceeded, in a few remarks, to comment upon the present extraordinary position of the armies of the Union. He urged the immediate enlistment of the stalwart men before him, saying that though very likely they might meet wounds and death, yet if by it they would aid in the maintenance of the supremacy of the law, this would not have been in vain. He eulogised the bravery of the common people, and ridiculed the cowardice of the monied men of Wall-street, whose tremulous actions were controlled by the news and lying reports which came daily by the telegraph. We hope to make this meeting a practical one, and will go at once about it.

abstract: The doubts as to the death of Gen. PHILIP KEARNEY seem to be set at rest. In the contest of Monday, that gallant officer, always forgetful of his own safety, fell mortally wounded while leading his men into action; and the country has to deplore the loss of one of its most accomplished, experienced and enterprising officers. Gen. KEARNEY was
lead_paragraph: The doubts as to the death of Gen. PHILIP KEARNEY seem to be set at rest. In the contest of Monday, that gallant officer, always forgetful of his own safety, fell mortally wounded while leading his men into action; and the country has to deplore the loss of one of its most accomplished, experienced and enterprising officers. Gen. KEARNEY was peculiarly a professional soldier. To a thorough elementary training in the art of war, he had added careful studies of all the great military authorities, with reference to every department of the profession. These studies had been the business of his life; and to give them experimental value he served throughout the Mexican war, it is needless to say, with the highest distinction, and subsequently participated in the Algerian campaigns, and yet more recently in the war of Italian liberation. From the leading French Generals of the time he has received testimonials of the most flattering description, attesting his intrepidity and skill. Had his bravery been attempered with the slightest dash of personal prudence, a career so splendid and so promising would not have been so untimely ended.

lead_paragraph: RENO was dipatched by Gen. POPE to Fairfax Court-house. It was also deemed prudent to commence the evacuation of Centreville, to cover our base of operations, inasmuch as Gens. HILL and LONGSTREET were known to be in force some distance toward Washington from the battle-field of Saturday, and as a reconnoissance to the front had revealed an anticipated movement in the same direction by the enemy.

abstract: The Government is very slow in putting the new small-change currency into the hands of the people. In this City, it has not made its appearance yet, and the dirty, sticky, inconvenient postage stamps are still in universal use. We were promised that we should have the new currency on the first of last month, five weeks ago; and on this ground, all private shinplasters were on that day excluded from circulation, under severe penalty; but the Washington functionaries have failed in this, as they fail in so many other things they promise -- though we do not pretend to doubt the literal correctness of the statements we periodically receive, that the laborious persons employed in this branch of service are hard at work upon it night and day. We judge it would be better if they would sleep at night and work in daytime only; for in that case, we should, in a reasonable space of time, expect some result from their efforts. We suppose, too, that the labor involved in getting out the currency is "tremendous," and all that sort of thing. Still, we can't see why it was not ready a month ago, as per act of Congress, or at least why it is not ready now. A few hundred thousand of dollars of it would be of very great service and convenience in the City at present. And, when it is ready, we trust that this great centre of trade and currency will be furnished with the first issues of the paper rather than the villages and smaller places, which do not suffer from the want of change to any such extent as we do. Will Mr. CHASE hurry up the small change currency?
lead_paragraph: The Government is very slow in putting the new small-change currency into the hands of the people. In this City, it has not made its appearance yet, and the dirty, sticky, inconvenient postage stamps are still in universal use. We were promised that we should have the new currency on the first of last month, five weeks ago; and on this ground, all private shinplasters were on that day excluded from circulation, under severe penalty; but the Washington functionaries have failed in this, as they fail in so many other things they promise -- though we do not pretend to doubt the literal correctness of the statements we periodically receive, that the laborious persons employed in this branch of service are hard at work upon it night and day. We judge it would be better if they would sleep at night and work in daytime only; for in that case, we should, in a reasonable space of time, expect some result from their efforts. We suppose, too, that the labor involved in getting out the currency is "tremendous," and all that sort of thing. Still, we can't see why it was not ready a month ago, as per act of Congress, or at least why it is not ready now. A few hundred thousand of dollars of it would be of very great service and convenience in the City at present. And, when it is ready, we trust that this great centre of trade and currency will be furnished with the first issues of the paper rather than the villages and smaller places, which do not suffer from the want of change to any such extent as we do. abstract: THE ABORTION CASE IN THIRTEENTH-STREET  VERDICT OF THE CORONER'S JURY. The Coroner's inquest in the case of the death of Mrs. CATHEARINE GALETZKIE, heretofore reported in the TIMES, was concluded last evening. The following verdict was rendered ...
lead_paragraph: THE ABORTION CASE IN THIRTEENTH-STREET -- VERDICT OF THE CORONER'S JURY. -- The Coroner's inquest in the case of the death of Mrs. CATHEARINE GALETZKIE, heretofore reported in the TIMES, was concluded last evening. The following verdict was rendered by the Jury: "We find that the deceased, CATHARINE GALETZKIE, came to her death by metro peritonitis, supervening upon abortion; and we believe, as far as the evidence elicited, that Dr. COX is instrumental in producing the abortion; and we censure Dr. SHERRILL for neglect of duty as a physician, in giving a certificate of death for inflammation of the bowels, and in secreting the fact of deceased having had a miscarriage." Upon the rendition of this verdict, Dr. COX was brought up for examination but by the advice of his counsel, Mr. C.S. SPENCER, he refused to answer the questions put to him by Coroner NAUMANN, except those as to his name, age and occupation. He was thereupon conveyed to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury. Dr. SHERRILL, Mrs. JOHNSON, who kept the house in Thirteenth-street where Mrs. GALETZKIE died, also a servant of the latter, and Mrs. TRUEHEART were detained as witnesses in the case, and sent to the house of Detention. Dr. SHERRILL is a practicing physician in Hudson-street, aged about 70 years, and upon his examination yesterday he testified that he had been fifty-three years engaged in the duties of physician and surgeon. Much of the evidence adduced upon the inquest is wholly unfit for publication, and other portions of it are at present withheld from the public, in the belief that the ends of justice might be defeated if it were made known.

abstract: Garrett T. Terhune vs. William H. Mills. -- The plaintiff, in April, 1861, was a merchant, doing business in Galveston, Texas, but owing to the difficulties and excitement following the fall of Fort Sumter and the commencement of hostilities, he concluded it best to leave the country, and thereupon secured the services of the defendant to take the charge and custody of his stock of goods, valued by him at $9,000. It is alleged that the defendant, Mills, was to take the goods as the agent or clerk of Terhune, sell them on his account, and out of the net proceeds of the sale of the goods to retain $50 per month. In pursuance to this agreement, Mills entered upon the discharge of his duties, and proceeded to sell the goods, but he alleges that, in order to avoid the agents of the rebel Government, he was compelled to ship them to San Antonio; that he was obliged to sell them at a low rate, and that the goods which he did not succeed in so disposing of were seized and confiscated by the Confederate Government, in October, 1861. Defendant also alleges that he succeeded in saving $300 worth of paintings, which he shipped on board a vessel, on which Mills was arrested, and held to bail in the sum of $9,000.
lead_paragraph: Garrett T. Terhune vs. William H. It is alleged that the defendant, Mills, was to take the goods as the agent or clerk of Terhune, sell them on his account, and out of the net proceeds of the sale of the goods to retain $50 per month. In pursuance to this agreement, Mills entered upon the discharge of his duties, and proceeded to sell the goods, but he alleges that, in order to avoid the agents of the rebel Government, he was compelled to ship them to San Antonio; that he was obliged to sell them at a low rate, and that the goods which he did not succeed in so disposing of were seized and confiscated by the Confederate Government, in October, 1861. Defendant also alleges that he succeeded in saving $300 worth of paintings, which he shipped on board a vessel, on which Mills was arrested, and held to bail in the sum of $9,000.

abstract: The War Committee met, yesterday afternoon, with closed doors, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, corner Cedar and William streets.
lead_paragraph: The War Committee met, yesterday afternoon, with closed doors, at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, corner Cedar and William streets. It is rumored, however, that the subject of discussion were the resolutions passed on Wednesday asking the Government's consent to Gens. FREMONT and MITCHEL raising a division of 50,000, and if the Government refused, to ask permission of the State. It is also rumored that quite a strong debate arose, but nothing definite was done, the majority of the members being in favor of rescinding the resolutions. The following communication was also received from Lieut.-Col. LLOYD ASPINWALL, relative to the correspondence, published in yesterday's TIMES, between the members of the Chamber of Commerce and Gen. HALLECK:

abstract: YACHT RACE FOR A PURSE OF $1,000. -- A yacht race, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Yacht Club, took place yesterday afternoon, from the foot of Court-street, for a stake of $1,000. The boats entered were the Commodore, owned by H. SMEDLEY, and the Nonpareil, owned by G.L. FRENCH. The course was from the Club-house to Buoy No. 9, Lower Bay, ten miles and return. Two minutes were allowed to the first. The wind, from the southeast, was very strong -- the boats beating against it going out, and the tide and wind in their favor on the return. The contest was all on one side -- the Commodore taking the lead, and keeping it. They started at 1:13 o'clock, and the Commodore rounded the last stake-boat at 4:43, and the Nonpareil at 4:44. A large number of spectators were present, who took a lively interest in the contest.

abstract: Editorial sees G Garibaldi rebellion in Italy replacing Civil War as foremost subject of European attention; editorial sees rebellion replacing US Civil War as foremost subject of European attention
snippet: Editorial sees G Garibaldi rebellion in Italy replacing Civil War as foremost subject of European attention; editorial sees rebellion replacing US Civil War as foremost subject of European attention
lead_paragraph: For some time to come the Italian question bids fair to displace the American question as the foremost subject of European attention. This is a gratifying turn of affairs. When an individual is afflicted with a monomania, there is nothing so desirable as a good distraction; and the same law holds with nations. Now, the American question had come to be a positive mania with the European Governments. No doubt they have a serious interest in it; doubtless, the commercial disturbance which it produces causes them a certain amount of real suffering; but they are not half as much interested in it as they imagine, or at least not in the way they imagine, and not a tithe of the evils which they trace to this cause are justly chargeable thereto. The fact is, there is a not inconsiderable element of hallucination in their notions of the American war. They have talked and written, plotted and diplomatized, so much about it that they can see nothing else; and then it is for these Governments, so convenient a horse on which to place all sorts of burdens, that they are not disposed to see anything else. The troubles in Italy will call off their attention from the all-absorbing subject.

There is a possibility of a contest in Vermont between the Government and the Federal Judge of that District. It seems that some parties had been arrested by the United States Marshal for discouraging enlistments, and were put in jail in Burlington. abstract: The fourth annual auction sale and letting of Southdown sheep, from the farm of Mr. J.C. TAYLOR' near Holmdel, N.J., took place on Wednesday, the 3d inst. The name of Mr. TAYLOR has become so familiar
lead_paragraph: The fourth annual auction sale and letting of Southdown sheep, from the farm of Mr. J.C. TAYLOR' near Holmdel, N.J., took place on Wednesday, the 3d inst. The name of Mr. TAYLOR has become so familiar to the agricultural as well as the general reader, in connection with the importation and breeding of Southdowns, as to render a recapitulation of his efforts in that line entirely unnecessary. What JONAS WEBB is in England, Mr. TAYLOR is fast getting to be in America, and the lovers of good mutton have reason to thank him for the day -- not far distant -- when their favorite dish shall be as common in the one country as in the other.

abstract: So far as we are informed, our army in Virginia is mainly located in its old quarters of last Winter in the immediate vicinity of Washington. The new levies are arriving at the rate of several thousand a day, and a thorough reorganization of our vast force is being made. There are rumors ...
lead_paragraph: So far as we are informed, our army in Virginia is mainly located in its old quarters of last Winter -- in the immediate vicinity of Washington. The new levies are arriving at the rate of several thousand a day, and a thorough reorganization of our vast force is being made. There are rumors from many sources of the intention of the rebels to invade the North by crossing the Potomac near Poolsville. It is even stated that the tories of Maryland are in full communication with the enemy, and doing much to aid them in their project of cursing Northern soil with the horrors of war. We are, however, assured that the military authorities fully appreciate the plans of the rebel Generals, and are prepared to thwart them.

abstract: The sick and wounded soldiers in the numerous hospitals in Washington, Georgetown and Alexandria, are generally well cared for, but there are certain "little nameless comforts" which no Government, however thoughtful, can, or can be expected to provide. To furnish these, so far as possible, and ...
lead_paragraph: The sick and wounded soldiers in the numerous hospitals in Washington, Georgetown and Alexandria, are generally well cared for, but there are certain "little nameless comforts" which no Government, however thoughtful, can, or can be expected to provide. To furnish these, so far as possible, and by systematic visitation, to cheer and console the suffering men of New-York in these hospitals, is the object of the NEW-YORK SOLDIERS' RELIEF SOCIETY, formed in January last of citizens of New-York resident in Washington, it has quietly but steadily prosecuted its humane work. Its committees have visited all the hospitals, and enough has been accomplished to establish the great propriety of such an association, and its capacity for usefulness. Hitherto the irregular supplies of clothing and articles of nourishment furnished from different parts of the State of New-York, have been sufficient to meet the demands upon the Society, but now that disease and the battle-field have stricken down so many of our gallant volunteers, a more regular and abundant provision is required. The executive Committee believe it only necessary to state this fact to the patriotic people of New-York, in order to have their store-room well and constantly stocked with such articles as the following, which are at present most needed, vis.: shirts, drawers, stockings, slippers; linen pantaloons and coats, straw hats; letter paper, envelopes and postage stamps; lemons, oranges, dried fruit; jellies of all kinds, (very desirable;) ale and porter. Such articles, sent by express, (prepaid,) directed to the "New-York Soldiers' Relief Society, Washington, D.C.," will be promptly acknowledged, and prudently distributed, at the various hospitals, through the members of the Society, two of whom are designated to regularly attend at each. Parties preferring to send money are assured that it will be very acceptable, as the demands upon the Society for ready funds are frequent. A list of all the hospitals, and the New-York soldiers therein, is kept and corrected weekly, at the rooms of the Society. No. 12 Washington Building, Pennsylvania-avenue, corner of Seventh-street, which are open to the public every evening, Sundays excepted.

abstract: Editorial urges Cabinet changes because of continued Union defeats in war; Editorial urges changes in US Cabinet and of generals in face of continuous Union defeats
snippet: Editorial urges Cabinet changes because of continued Union defeats in war; Editorial urges changes in US Cabinet and of generals in face of continuous Union defeats
lead_paragraph: The Summer campaign, which was to have given us the rebel capital, has come to a disastrous end. Richmond is relieved, and Washington is besieged. That magnificent army, organized and drilled with so much care by MCCLELLAN a year ago, repulsed first on the Peninsula, has been again repulsed in its advance upon Richmond from the North, and now seeks safety for itself behind the forts which line the Potomac. Disguise it as we may, the Union arms have been repeatedly, disgracefully and decisively beaten. The whole campaign against Richmond has proved a failure. The rebels have resumed the offensive, and have driven our troops back to the precise position they held after the battle of Bull Run, more than a year ago. Our Generals do not seem to be aware whether they intend to attack us there, or push forward on some other line of operations. One thing may be deemed certain, -- they will not sit down in front of Washington and attempt to reduce it by siege. They will either attempt a flank movement upon it, or, what seems to us still more likely, they will push a powerful column directly into Pennsylvania and strike a blow at the Union cause on loyal soil.

abstract: TO THE LOYAL WOMEN OF HOBOKEN. -- An appeal for aid for our sick and wounded soldiers having been made by the Surgeon-General of the United States, an association, in response to this call, has been formed in the City of Hoboken, to meet at the Engine house No. 2, corner Washington and Sixth streets, every day, from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., (the first Wednesday of each month excepted.) Contributions, especially of old linen and of lint, will be thankfully received; but those who have nothing to give but their time, are earnestly requested to volunteer their services and help in this much needed work. The patriotic men of Hoboken have so worthily and generously come forward, that the loyal women should not be wanting in any effort to relieve and mitigate the sufferings of those who have risked comfort, safety and life for their country in this hour of trial.

lead_paragraph: Advices from Hilton Head state that "the gunboat Magnolia arrived Aug. 28 from a cruise, bringing intelligence to Admiral DUPONT of the total loss of the steam-frigate Adirondack, Capt. GANSEVOORT, on the morning of Saturday, the 23d inst., at Man-ofWar Point, Abaco Island, about one hundred miles north of Nassau. No particulars of the disaster were forwarded. Capt. GANSEVOORT stated in his dispatch that his men were all safe, and had taken refuge upon a small island in the vicinity of the wreck. He was of opinion that his armament could be saved."

abstract: Editorial sees Confederates planning attacks in Ohio, western Pennsylvania and elsewhere while Union forces concentrate around Washington
snippet: Editorial sees Confederates planning attacks in Ohio, western Pennsylvania and elsewhere while Union forces concentrate around Washington
lead_paragraph: with treason scattered throughout the country affords them unlimited facilities for this sort of deception; and whether the exigency demands that the rebel force should be exaggerated or depreciated, or that its location and projects should be stated fairly or falsely, the agents of the rebellion find no difficulty in producing the required impression upon the public mind. No better illustration of this fact is needed than their ability to hold Manassas for eight months with 40,000 men, while not only the people at large, but the leaders of the National army were made to believe that a force four times that strength were latent behind those formidable intrenchments. An instance of more recent date is notable in the rumor of Stonewall JACKSON advancing upon Maryland by way of Edwards' Ferry -- a rumor calculated to produce the profoundest alarm in the North and no doubt designed to weaken the force in front of Washington by causing the dispatch of two or three divisions to defeat the pretended movement of the rebels. Of the same character, in all probability, is the present reiterated declaration of an intention to surround and capture Washington, and dictate conditions of peace in the White House. It is doubtless the mask of a possible, and probably effective blow to be stricken in some other quarter. Washington, surrounded as it is by magnificent works, and filled with 150,000 men, is impregnable to any force that can lay siege to it, unless indeed the Union commanders play false, and surrender without a contest. The gunboats patrol the river, rendering a crossing impossible any where below the Lower Falls of the Potomac; while higher up a crossing would be hazardous in the extreme, seeing the liability of a retreat being cut off; and ineffectual, because Washington is fortified and guarded on the eastern as well as on the western side. Equally absurd is a proposition to surround the capital, cut off the railroads and telegraphic wires, and starve out its garrison; for not only is a second blockade of the Potomac impossible in the presence of our iron-clads, but a diffusion of the rebel squadrons around the long circuit of the fortifications would expose them to certain destruction, for the besieged would have no difficulty in cutting off the entire investing force in detail. Washington is threatened, and must, therefore, be defended. But we have no idea that it is the immediate object of the rebel operations. From the experience, long and lamentable, we have had of rebel strategy, we may expect to find a blow struck in some quarter where a deluded people least expect to receive it. The conjuror always diverts the attention of his rustic audience from the method of the immediate wonder he is achieving by some more striking and attractive by-play. The rebels have caught the trick, and we are the constant victims. It is quite possible that while every eye is fixed upon Washington, the rebels may have their attention riveted upon a line of operations four hundred miles away. In fact, the plan of severing the Western from the Eastern States, by the occupation of the Ohio and Pennsylvania frontier, has been a favorite idea with leading Southern papers, and has possibly found favor with the insurgent leaders. The Alleghanies would furnish a safe basis of operations; the exuberant granaries of the two great States would feed the starved army, weary of half rations of salt pork and corn-bread; Pittsburgh with its shops and founderies would replenish their stock of cannon, arms and munitions, and send mailed iron boats and rams to recover the Ohio and the Mississippi. And the rebel ken may extend yet further. If from the river to the lake the line of rebel troops be drawn impenetrably, they may calculate upon opening negotiations with the Northwest, with a view to a union of the latter with the States of the Lower Mississippi, in preference to its present connection with the East. They may argue that, weary of an unpopular and hopeless contest, and stripped of all confidence in the Washington Government, the Northwest may listen to terms heretofore scorned, for the bribe of freely navigating the Mississippi, and an indefinite promise of gradual emancipation, yielding to the offered alliance as an only escape from the evils of war and the burdens of National taxation. With the probable upshot of such diplomacy we have nothing to do. It is enough that such dreams have been thought worthy of grave discussion at the South, and may reinforce other arguments for an occupation of the region we have referred to. If in the course of a few days we hear of the enemy showing himself along the Upper Potomac; seizing the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and gradually withdrawing the army before Washington to the shelter of the Blue Ridge, we may be assured the scheme mentioned is in a fair way to realization. Indeed, if we are not greatly mistaken, the advance of KIRBY SMITH and HUMPHREY MARSHALL through Kentucky; the rumored presence of BRAGG with a considerable force in Western Virginia, intending to reach the Ohio by descending the Kanawha; the cavalry demonstrations at Buckhannon and near Philippi, close to the Pennsylvania line, are all indications of a purpose to seize, hold and occupy Ohio and Western Pennsylvania.

abstract: The large population with which the strategy of Gen. POPE has filled the hospitals set in new activity all the machinery of charity. The sick and the wounded are in need of a thousand comforts, which Government does not provide for them. Under-clothing and outer-clothing, slippers, socks, jellies, and the smaller luxuries craved by convalescent appetites, the stimulants necessary to recruit the faded strength -- everything, in short, demanded for the sick room, is needed for the soldiers' hospitals. In another column will be found an appeal from the Soldiers' Relief Association of New-York, for contributions of the kind referred to. The organization of the Association and the names of the Executive and Financial Committees, are warrants of its entire reliability, and that contributions of money or specific articles will be judiciously and faithfully applied.

abstract: -- Much ill-feeling exists in military circles here, in consequence of Gen. HALLECK's telegram to the National Committee, relative to the three months' men. So far from any New-York regiment having been invited to remain, and declining to do so, it appears that nearly all, if not every one of those regiments, tendered its further services to the Secretary of War, and had them declined. This is unquestionably true of the Sixty-ninth, the Seventy-first, the Twenty-second, and the Seventh regiments. The latter regiment, fully appreciating the critical aspect of events, was urgent to stay; and twice through its Colonel pressed upon Mr. STANTON the advisability of retaining it. The offer was promptly rejected, the Secretary assuring Col. LEFFERTS that the Government had all the men it needed to meet the crisis, and would prefer to dispense with the services of regiments whose term had so nearly expired. When, therefore, Gen. HALLECK speaks of these troops as "declining to remain at a moment when the danger was more imminent than at present," he speaks either without knowledge or at random; and in either case inflicts an unpardonable insult upon courageous and patriotic men. If he is the victim of misinformation, it is within the power of Mr. STANTON to set him right. We shall wait to see if the candor of the Secretary is equal to the emergency.

abstract: Ship carrying returning NY troops runs aground on New Jersey shoals; all safe
snippet: Ship carrying returning NY troops runs aground on New Jersey shoals; all safe
lead_paragraph: The vast majority of our citizens are, as yet, unaware of the mortal perils that beset two of the finest volunteer regiments this State can boast, on their way back from the seat of war, where they have just served out their three months' term, under the President's call of May last. In order to relieve the anxiety of thousands of the relatives and friends of these deserving soldiers, and gratify the public at large with the details of an incident which has come to their knowledge hitherto only by rumor, we have prepared a succinct statement of the facts, procured from the officers and men of the Baltic, and the regiments she bore from Hampton Roads.

abstract: The Governor of Penn.  sylvania has called for the immediate formation of volunteer companies and regiments throughout the State. Extravagant and incredible as it may appear, the State of Pennsylvania is threatened with invasion by the rebels. Stonewall JACKSON is quite as likely
lead_paragraph: -- The Governor of Penn. sylvania has called for the immediate formation of volunteer companies and regiments throughout the State. Extravagant and incredible as it may appear, the State of Pennsylvania is threatened with invasion by the rebels. Stonewall JACKSON is quite as likely to push directly for Harrisburgh, -- or to cooperate with KIRBY SMITH, in his movement upon Ohio, as he is to cross the Potomac at Harper's Ferry. The rebels, either from policy or from desperation -- possibly from both -- have evidently resolved to invade the North, -- and the North must meet them.

abstract: Editorial on US Sen. Simmons resignation; Editorial on resignation of Rhode Island Sen. Simmons
snippet: Editorial on US Sen. Simmons resignation; Editorial on resignation of Rhode Island Sen. Simmons
lead_paragraph: -- Senator SIMMONS, of Rhode Island, has had virtue enough to do voluntarily that which the United States Senate had not virtue enough to compel him to do -- vacate his seat in the Senate. Nominally, at least, he resigned his position, though we judge that the pressure brought to bear upon him by the public sentiment of his own State, since he got home, was so strong as to make his resignation partake of the nature of at least moral compulsion. From the astounding confessions of personal corruption which he made at the last session of Congress, and from the fact that he confessed he could see no harm in the downright bribery he owned to, it is clear that neither his conscience nor his sense of propriety had anything to do with the matter. It has been purely the result of local and national opinion, and of the universal disgust expressed at his course by the Press. It was said, after the adjournment of last session, that the reason the Senate refused to expel him, after his confessions of corrupt conduct, was that he had threatened to make exposures in many other Senators' cases, which would be far more infamous than those he made in his own. In this view, we may have lost something by his resignation; for though details of Governmental corruption, yet there is nothing more essential to public well-being than that Congressional knavery be exposed. Mr. SIMMON's term only lasted till the 4th of March next; but we are glad that for over the brief Winter session an honest man will occupy his seat. After that time, the noblest of all Rhode Island's modern sons, GOV. SPRAGUE, will adorn the place in the Senate which SIMMONS has disgraced.

abstract: The rest of the Second Battalion of the Twelfth Infantry, U.S.A., has left Fort Hamilton for the seat of war. The Third Battalion is now being organized under the superintendence of Major BRUEN, and re- ...
lead_paragraph: The rest of the Second Battalion of the Twelfth Infantry, U.S.A., has left Fort Hamilton for the seat of war. The Third Battalion is now being organized under the superintendence of Major BRUEN, and recruits are coming in pretty rapidly from the Western States. Major CLETZ and Adjutant MINIMACK, of the First Battalion, are still at the Fort -- the former wounded and the latter sick. The Twelfth is one of the eleven new regiments ordered, the raising of which was authorized by Congress in 1861. We are not permitted to give the destination of the above troops.

abstract: The advertising columns of the TIMES contain ample proof that while the war goes on, education does not stop. Something like a hundred different schools, in their various forms of seminaries, collegiate institutes, etc., announce themselves as about to open during the coming and subsequent week. These, it will be observed, are private educational establishments, and are altogether aside from our great public schools, which have already begun their new year. There should never be any but a healthful rivalry between the two, for both are needed. Excellent though the advantages be which the public schools present, there will always be many parents who prefer that their sons and daughters shall enjoy the more immediate care and the more enlarged advantages which private establishments afford. It will be hard, indeed, if from the copious choice our advertising columns present, they are not able to suit themselves.

abstract: By the steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 27th and Queenstown on the 28th  ult., we have advices from Eprope three days later than those by the Asia. The steam-frigate Tuscarora had put into Falmouth and Plymouth and ...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 27th and Queenstown on the 28th ult., we have advices from Eprope three days later than those by the Asia. The steam-frigate Tuscarora had put into Falmouth and Plymouth and had been ordered away from both places without the privilege of coaling or repairing. A paragraph in the Paris Moniteur, attributed to the Emperor himself, declares that France will defend the Pope. It was reported that GARIBALDI and a portion of his followers had got away from Catania in two steamers, and had landed at Milito in Calabria. There was great excitement in the latter province, and several towns had pronounced in favor of GARIBALDI. The Neapolitan Provinces had been declared in a state of siege. Cotton had again advanced in the Liverpool market. Breadstuff's were declining, and provisions were very dull. Consols closed at 93 1/4@93 1/4.

abstract: The telegraphic announcement from Cape Race, to the effect that the British authorities have ordered away the United States gunboat Tuscarora from the British coast, without allowing her the privilege of coaling, and while, ...
lead_paragraph: -- The telegraphic announcement from Cape Race, to the effect that the British authorities have ordered away the United States gunboat Tuscarora from the British coast, without allowing her the privilege of coaling, and while, too, she was in a leaky condition, will doubtless be read with mingled indignation and surprise. The only possible justification that can be presented for this gross violation of international comity, is the fact that the British authorities some months ago decided that the vessels of both belligerents should be excluded from British ports. This was a most oppressive stretch of the rights of neutrals, as what would fall lightly on the insignificant marine of the rebels must necessarily be fell most severely by our numerous and widespread navy. However, as the English sensibilities were so dreadfully shocked by the simultaneous presence at Liverpool of the Nashville and the Tuscarora, and at Gibraltar of the Sumter and the bull-dog of Uncle Sam set to watch the rebel craft, we were fain to yield without remonstrance.

abstract: There are very few new developments relative to army movements in Virginia, though there are plenty of rumors. There appears to be no doubt, however, that the rebels are extending their lines into the Shenandoah Valley, with a view to cross- ...
lead_paragraph: There are very few new developments relative to army movements in Virginia, though there are plenty of rumors. There appears to be no doubt, however, that the rebels are extending their lines into the Shenandoah Valley, with a view to crossing into Maryland, and carrying out their favorite programme of invading the North. Indeed, one of our dispatches has it that they have already actually crossed in some force below Point of Rocks, but subsequently recrossed into Virginia, as though hesitating to make the experiment of effecting a lodgment in Maryland. They are also stated to have thrown shells across the Upper Potomac, but without doing any damage. Meantime quiet continues in Washington, and no apprehension is felt in regard to the movements of the rebels.

abstract: editorial on McClellan command
snippet: editorial on McClellan command
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN, in a general order, "assumes command of the fortifications of Washington and of all the troops for the defence of the Capital." His appointment to this post is eminently judicious. The position is one which he is especially qualified to fill with ability and success. He is confessedly one of the most accomplished engineers in the army, and has no superior in a thorough mastery of the science of war. He is vigilant, laborious, careful of his troops, and quite certain to hold a fortified position committed to his care. He believes in earthworks and is preeminently skilled in the whole art and mystery of entrenchments. We have no fears for the safety of Washington while it remains under his charge.

abstract: -- The Evening Post has an article explaining how it is that the law is powerless to suppress the notorious swindlers known as "Peter Funks." The technicalities of the law, it seems, are in their favor, -- and the arm of the Government is, therefore, powerless against them. Can it not be shown that their business hinders enlistments? If it could, the Government would deal with them very summarily.

abstract: -- We continue to receive assurances that the forts on the Potomac are so strong that Washington cannot possibly be taken. We have no doubt of that fact. And, furthermore, we have not the slightest suspicion that the rebels intend to test the strength of those fortifications by, attempting to take them. They have not been in the habit hitherto of assailing our strongest points, and they are not likely to change their habits at this late day. They will leave just enough men in front of Washington to keep us watching them; and then, with their main force, they will go to some point where the roads are not so rough. We trust Gen. HALLECK will keep his eye on them.

abstract: Editorial weighs profits and losses of carrying on war for preservation of Union
snippet: Editorial weighs profits and losses of carrying on war for preservation of Union
lead_paragraph: The great mass of our people are unquestionably in favor of a vigorous prosecution of the war. Yet amidst the loyal throng can be found here and there a few dissenters, the most conspicuous of whom are a little knot of philosophers whose views are plausible enough to challenge comment and deserve refutation. We allude to the people who do not see the good of carrying on the war for the preservation of the Union. They admit the Government to be all right, and the rebels all wrong. They would gladly see our troubles at an end, and all the States reunited under the old flag. They detect the principle of secession, and cleave to that of undivided nationality. But, to restore things as they were, our reasoners claim, will cost too many lives and too much money. The result, if achieved, will not defray the inevitable expense of attaining it. They say, therefore, with the optimist, "The game is not worth the candle."
headline: {'main': 'Profit and Loss.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Profit and Loss.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In re Emily Megrath. In this case, as it appears from the papers, the parties had, after threats of divorce, on one side or both, signed a deed of separation, in which, among other things, the husband stipulated that the child, Emily, should remain under ...
lead_paragraph: In re Emily Megrath. -- In this case, as it appears from the papers, the parties had, after threats of divorce, on one side or both, signed a deed of separation, in which, among other things, the husband stipulated that the child, Emily, should remain under the charge of her mother. Subsequently, however, Mr. Megrath was led to believe that his wife had formed, and was maintaining, a guilty intercourse with Dr. Malcolm Ives, who at one time officiated in Milwaukee, as a Roman Catholic Priest, and has since been well known in this city as a contributor to the Press, and as a State prisoner in Fort Henry. Under the impression, however, that, in contravention of the terms of the deed, the wife was not only receiving improper attentions from Dr. IVES, but that the endeavor was being insidiously made on the Doctor's part to wean the child from the Protestant faith, Mr. Megrath seized the first favorable opportunity, took possession of his daughter's person, and thereby provoked the proceeding through which the mother hopes to have her child restored to her protection.

abstract: Judge Advocate General ANTHON expects to have the enrollment of the names of persons liable to the draft in this City and Brooklyn finished by Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Judge Advocate General ANTHON expects to have the enrollment of the names of persons liable to the draft in this City and Brooklyn finished by Tuesday. His enrolling officers have already obtained the names of more persons than it was thought the population of the two cities would have yielded; but this the Judge-Advocate accounts for by supposing either that the last census was deficient or that since the census was made there has been a great influx of new residents. Instead of this City having only 800,000 inhabitants, it is found to held close upon 1,000,000. The arrangements made by the Judge-Advocate for quietly and efficiently executing the arduous duty devolved upon him have proved his possession of high administrative ability, tact and shrewdness. No better system for achieving the object intended could have been devised. The enrollment, when done, will be seen to be more comprehensive and complete, than any one could have anticipated. There will be far fewer evasions of it than are generally calculated upon; and portions of it have been framed in such a way, as to insure a much more equitable, and satisfactory enforcement of the draft man has heretofore been deemed likely or possible. Very little trouble is now experienced by the emolling officers in the course of their rather disagreeable duties. The stringent measures taken with people who tried to be obstinate and awkward, when the enrollment first began, have had a salutary effect, and saved a great deal of subsequent trouble. The speedy detection, too, and punishment of the enrolling officer who was discovered taking bribes for omitting the names of persons in his district, has been a warming to his fellows, and no evidence of further corruption has comt to light. The Enrollment Police (whose business it is to follow the enrollment officers, and find out if efforts have been made to deceive them in the way of names, ages and addresses) are a faithful, energetic body of men, and have performed good service. The force of clerks employed by Gen. ANTHON number about 50. Some thought was entertained of putting on an extra night relay of 25, but it was found that progress was little expedited by the results of this nocturnal pressure. Well regulated day work is more reliable and efficacious. Yesterday, Bedloe's Island was visited by the enrolling officers. To-day, Wall-street will be canvassed. It is intended to take the names of resident porters in that locality to commence with. Then those of clerks, bookkeepers and others will be ascertained, and a comparison instituted between the names and addresses given from their places of business and those given in the parts of this City and Brooklyn where they live. This is one of the many checks against fraud which the cowardly or unpatriotic will find it hard to get over. How any one can escape all the cunning devices applied to prevent the evasion of his duty to his country of every able-bodied man. would seem a mystery. As an instance of how perfect are the meshes and how wide-spread the ramifications, of the great enrollment net that Gen. ANTHON has cast over the community, may be mentioned the statement of a well known citizen, who says he has a store down town, not very far from the Post-office, a store in one street up town, a wholesale factory up town, in another street, and a private residence up town in still a third street. Every one of these places is in a different district; and yet in each district his name has been obtained with full and true particulars concerning him to the remotest necessary detail. A fish here and there will slip through the net no doubt, but, in face of all the precautions taken, not very many.

abstract: The United States Frigate Tuscarora put into Falmouth on the 23d of August, and was ordered to leave in twenty-four hours. She sought permission to remain and repair her damages, she being reported leaky. The authorities referred her Captain to the Ministers, but it is said that the Captain declined to make any application in that quarter. She was allowed to remain while one of her officers went to London, but she was ordered to leave on his return, without repairs and without coal.

abstract: Gen. CASSIUS M. CLAY has been, (not fighting a battle, but) making a speech in Kentucky. As happens occasionally with him he said some sensible things, -- though he ran upon a hobby or two with less success. He thought England's proclamation of neutrality would have justified us in declaring war, and that the Times correspondent ought to have  sent home much sooner than he was. -- which is possible, inasmuch as he was not sent home at all.

abstract: It is pretty evident to everybody by this time that our armies have been out-generaled by the rebels. The fact is humiliating, and one which we should rejoice to see refuted.
lead_paragraph: It is pretty evident to everybody by this time that our armies have been out-generaled by the rebels. The fact is humiliating, and one which we should rejoice to see refuted. But the logic of results proves it. In almost every instance where the two armies have met, the rebel Generals have out-manoeuvred or out-managed ours. They have known precisely where our weak points were, while we have not known theirs. They have got upon our flanks or in our rear, in spite of all our efforts to prevent it. They have turned our positions, -- misled us as to their own movements, -- anticipated and thwarted ours, -- outnumbered us at specific points, whatever the comparative aggregates might be, -- deceived us by pretended retreats, and managed, by some device or other, to get the better of us in nearly every engagement.

abstract: About 11 o'clock last night a very destructive fire broke out in the carpenter shop and planing mill of G.S. MYER, in West Twenty-seventh, near Seventh-avenue, which resulted in the entire destruction ...
lead_paragraph: About 11 o'clock last night a very destructive fire broke out in the carpenter shop and planing mill of G.S. MYER, in West Twenty-seventh, near Seventh-avenue, which resulted in the entire destruction of the building, and also several others adjoining. Mr. MYER's building was of brick, 4 stories high, and cost the sum of $32,000 to construct it. In addition to this he has lost a large quantity of stock, to what amount, at this late hour, it is impossible to say. He is insured for $12,000 in the Park, Pacific, St. Mark's, Merchants' and Williamsburgh City Insurance Companies. Geo. Low, toy maker, occupied the same premises. His loss is about $1,500. Mr. DOUGHERTY, a glass-cutter, lost about $1.000 worth of stock, and JOHN SHAFFER, turner, $500. The most of the latter in insured.

abstract: The United States Sanitary Commission steamship Daniel Webster, Capt. BLETHEN, arrived at this port last night from Alexandria bringing 588 sick and wounded soldiers. The Daniel Webster left New-York, Aug. 19, and has been since then transporting troops from Yorktown and Newport's News to Alexandria. There were four deaths during the passage, three of which were buried at Fortress Monroe, as follows: Edward Koontz, Co. A, Tenth Pennsylvania, died 4th; A. Shurweann, Minnesota, died Sept. 3; John York, Co. F, Tenth New-York, died Sept. 3; Lieut. H.S. Wright, of New-York, died Sept. 5, body on board. The following are the officers attached to the ship: F.H. BLETHEN, Commander; N.S. Drake, M.D., Surgeon in charge; James Ash, M.D., Assistant Surgeon; A.K. Starkweather, Commissary.

abstract: -- Rev. Geo. Junkin, D.D., publishes the following card in the Philadelphia North American: "In your notice, a few days since, of Mrs. Stonewall Jackson, there is a slight mistake. My daughter, the first wife of Maj. Thomas Jefferson Jackson, has been dead eight years. His present wife is a daughter of Rev. Dr. Morrison, late President of Davidson College, N.C., and sister to Maj. Daniel M. Hill, Maj. Jackson received the soubriquet of 'Stonewall' from the fact that the hardest fight he had at Bull Run was near to the stone bridge, which they had blown up before the 21st July. The Rockbridge boys, almost all personally acquainted with him, hence called him 'Stonebridge Jackson,' which, after the battle of Winchester, in which he used largely the stonefences which line the road and inclose the fields about three or four miles west of Winchester, they changed to 'Stonewall.'"

abstract: A letter dated Corinth, Miss., Aug. 29, says: "Government is engaged in erecting the fourth freight house at this place, all of which are 400 feet long. This is evidently to be the base of military operations for the whole Southwest. Nature and railroads have combined to make Corinth a point of incalculable advantages. No wonder that Gen. HALLECK expressed such gratification when he achieved a bloodless victory of almost inconceivable results -- when he marched an exultant army quietly into Corinth. I saw Gen. GRANT to-day. He wears a hale, self-possessed mien beneath a broad brimmed Panama. Three cavalry boys were his only escort, while his fine, dandy, brushed broadcloth has given place to a suit that gives some evidence of camp life. Gen. GRANT will yet establish his claims to Generalship of the highest order."
