abstract: Byxby vs. Wood. GOULD, J. Some of the grounds here urged for reversing this judgment are of little moment. Such is the point that the referees erred in refusing to allow the defendant's set-off or counter-claim as to certain moneys paid by him. To which point it was sufficiently answered below that the pleadings set up neither counter-claim nor set-off, and therefore none could be allowed.
lead_paragraph: Byxby vs. Wood. -- GOULD, J. -- Some of the grounds here urged for reversing this judgment are of little moment. Such is the point that the referees erred in refusing to allow the defendant's set-off or counter-claim as to certain moneys paid by him. To which point it was sufficiently answered below that the pleadings set up neither counter-claim nor set-off, and therefore none could be allowed. The claim of error in admitting evidence as to the letter of T.O. Larkin is manifestly unfounded. Since, if fraud were the foundation of the action, it was clearly admissible, and it fraud were not the foundation, the evidence was so utterly valueless that it could not have influenced the minds of the referees, and no finding of even inducement to the agreement between the parties is based on it, and no inference is drawn from it.

abstract: This battle took place Aug. 17, between 800 men, composed of Companies C and A of the Second Battalion State Militia, an artillery company (F) of the Seventh Missouri, having two 12-pounders, and a small part of MERRILL's cavalry, and 4,000 men, under Col. COFFEE and Col. UPTON HUGHES. The command has parsed through Lone Jack -- a small town, divided into two parts culled the old and new town. About 11 o'clock at night they had a skirmish, and then fell back to the new town, and encamped. The cannon were posted in and commanding a lane, but were surrounded by high corn. The pickets northwest of the town found before daylight that they were within a half mile of the picket of the enemy. At sunrise the enemy, under COFFEE and HUGHES swarmed in toward the cannon, firing irregularly. The Texas Rangers soon picked off the cannoniers and shot the horses, then charged and took the cannon. The militia, under FOSTER, rallied and retook the cannon, drove the enemy through the new town to the old town, and out of that. At this moment a large body of men were seen coming from Independence. The order war given to retreat. The cannon was dragged away by hand, but being without harness had to be left. The other cannon had been taken to pieces by the rebels, dismounted and scattered, to that parts could not be found. The fire of the enemy is represented as terrible, but the militia stood to their work without flinching. A soldier says the balls flew like bees. The small balls sharp toned, the large ones with a whiz; Minie balls mostly flying over. I have not seen a man yet who does not show bullet holes in his clothes. Lieut. ANDERSON, of Company ----, shows four holes in his coat, had his shoulder snap shot off, and was wounded slightly in two places. The buckshot penetrate but little. I saw one man with a shot in his scalp which he says he'll keep there for a trophy.

abstract: Among the very meanest systems of swindling, hundreds of which pollute our large cities, is the mock "intelligence office" business.
lead_paragraph: Among the very meanest systems of swindling, hundreds of which pollute our large cities, is the mock "intelligence office" business. The plan of operation is to advertise in some cheap paper that has a wide circulation among the poorer class, an enticing call for all sorts of domestic servants. Poor girls out of place throng to the "office" thus advertising, and having been induced to deposit a dollar fee, are "registered," i.e., their names are noted in a greasy book of imposing magnitude, and they are then sent upon their way, rejoicing over the fine promises made to them of good, permanent places, high salaries and pleasant work. In a day or two they return by appointment, are put off with excuses, and after another interval again return, this time to find the office closed, or to be told that they are too early, or too late, that the parties have engaged some one else, that they have misunderstood the statements made to them, etc., etc. At length, wearied out with their fruitless efforts, or intimidated by the harsh words and demeanor of the "intelligence" mongers, they, in despair, abandon the pursuit, and with it, of course, their money paid in. Such was the treatment awarded to ELLEN MORTON during the past week by one THOMAS SPINK, of No. 13 Chatham-street. ELLEN made affidavit before Mr. HINCHMAN, and THOMAS was arrested. He restored the $1 fee, and begged very hard, with many promises of amendment, but the Mayor thinking an example necessary to correct so glaring an evil, revoked his license.

abstract: Accounts show that three or four hundred rebel cavalry endeavored to cross the Potomac into Maryland about noon on Friday, at Edwards' Ferry, approaching from Leesburgh. Our forces, consisting of one infantry and one cavalry regiment and a battery, opposed the passage, and repulsed them after a sharp contest. About 2 o'clock this morning the attempt was successfully renewed, the enemy crossing at several different points.

abstract: We trust there will be no delay in giving to the public the official reports of the various commanders in the late battles and movements in Virginia, now that our army has got quietly and safely encamped before Washington. The only accounts of the battles we have had thus far, have been written by those who did not see any part of any of the actions, nor take any part in the movements; but were from stragglers and others, picked up mostly in Washington and Alexandria, and as a consequence have been extremely confused. The reports of Gen. SIGEL, for example, would be very valuable just now, and would be universally believed, if published unmanipulated; and so with the reports of HEINTZELMAN and many other officers, while not a man in the country would doubt a word that proceeded from the pen of Gen. BANKS. Why cannot the public have the reports of these and other General officers? It would help greatly to an understanding of a most confused matter, and could not possibly do any damage. If the public are forbidden the vivid narratives of the Press correspondents, let them, at least, have early copies of the official documents. We learn that Gen. POPE's report is nearly ready; but its credibility would be much helped by the publication, at the same time, of the reports of some of the other officers actively engaged.

abstract: Editorial says Confederate Gen. Smith invasion of Kentucky failed because citizens remained loyal to Union
snippet: Editorial says Confederate Gen. Smith invasion of Kentucky failed because citizens remained loyal to Union
lead_paragraph: The condition of things in Kentucky is beginning to be more clearly seen, and matters have a more hopeful look. It is evident that the rebels have again counted on a general rising of Secessionists in Kentucky and been disappointed. Gen. KIRBY SMITH, in his present invasion, went through the same form of issuing a "proclamation" to Kentuckians that SIMON BOLIVAR BUCKNER did when he occupied Bowling Green one year ago, and that MORGAN did in his recent raids. Gen. KIRBY SMITH said to the Kentuckians: "Let no one make you believe we come as invaders to coerce your will or to exercise control over your soil. Far from it. The principle we maintain is, that Government derives its first powers from the consent of the governed. * * I shall enforce the strictest discipline, in order that the property of citizens and non-combatants may be protected. I shall be compelled to procure subsistence for my troops among you, and this shall be paid for. Kentuckians, we come not as invaders, but as liberators."
headline: {'main': "KIRBY SMITH'S INVASION A FAILURE.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "KIRBY SMITH'S INVASION A FAILURE.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Regiment New-York Volunteers, arrived here yesterday morning in the steamer Oregon, from Hudson, and took up their quarters at the Park Barracks. This regiment has been recruited during the last four weeks, mostly in Columbia and Dutchess Counties. It numbers over a thousand men, and is in every respect one of the finest regiments that have left the State during the war.

abstract: Samuel Ford vs. Samuel P. Townsend et al. -- This was a motion to send the case prepared on appeal back to Ex-Judge Pierrepont, before whom the motion was tried, for resettlement, upon the ground that the appellant's counsel inadvertently omitted to insert in the case, at the time it was presented to the judge for settlement, the fact that plaintiff's counsel duly excepted upon the trial to the filling of the Court dismissing the complaint. Plaintiff's counsel produces an affidavit, and a statement of Judge Pierrepont, which the Court helds satisfactory proof that such exception was probably duly taken, and that it would be unjust to deprive the plaintiff of the benefit, upon appeal, of that exception. An order was therefore entered referring the case to Judge Pierrepont with directions to insert, in its proper [???] was really so taken. But the omission being the fault of plaintiff, $10 costs are awarded to defendant.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Ford vs. Samuel P. Townsend et al. -- This was a motion to send the case prepared on appeal back to Ex-Judge Pierrepont, before whom the motion was tried, for resettlement, upon the ground that the appellant's counsel inadvertently omitted to insert in the case, at the time it was presented to the judge for settlement, the fact that plaintiff's counsel duly excepted upon the trial to the filling of the Court dismissing the complaint. Plaintiff's counsel produces an affidavit, and a statement of Judge Pierrepont, which the Court helds satisfactory proof that such exception was probably duly taken, and that it would be unjust to deprive the plaintiff of the benefit, upon appeal, of that exception. An order was therefore entered referring the case to Judge Pierrepont with directions to insert, in its proper [???] was really so taken. But the omission being the fault of plaintiff, $10 costs are awarded to defendant.

abstract: The affair at Bolivar creates considerable sensation. It appears that the rebels first made their appearance in the vicinity of Bolivar on Friday afternoon. They debarked from the cars a few miles below Bolivar, and then moved off to the west, taking up a position on a little stream tributary to the Hatchie, about four miles west of Bolivar.

abstract: -- The rebels cannot refuse to invade the loyal States, if it be practicable, and yet their wisest leaders feel that the act will be desperately dangerous. The unyielding policy of JEFF. DAVIS heretofore has been, not to invade, but to stand on the defensive. He knew the immensity of advantage thus gained. First, it nerved the rebels to fight better, as men always will do in defense of their homes. Second, it shortened their lines, made rapid concentrations easy, and thereby strengthened their forces. Thirdly, it appealed to the world's sympathies. They did not wish to fight or hurt anybody; they only wished to be "let alone."
lead_paragraph: -- The rebels cannot refuse to invade the loyal States, if it be practicable, and yet their wisest leaders feel that the act will be desperately dangerous. The unyielding policy of JEFF. DAVIS heretofore has been, not to invade, but to stand on the defensive. He knew the immensity of advantage thus gained. First, it nerved the rebels to fight better, as men always will do in defense of their homes. Second, it shortened their lines, made rapid concentrations easy, and thereby strengthened their forces. Thirdly, it appealed to the world's sympathies. They did not wish to fight or hurt anybody; they only wished to be "let alone."

abstract: It is universally conceded that, of all the causes which have brought disgrace or failure on the National arms, the weakness or incompetency of officers has been the most conspicuous and lamentable.
lead_paragraph: It is universally conceded that, of all the causes which have brought disgrace or failure on the National arms, the weakness or incompetency of officers has been the most conspicuous and lamentable. The military history of older countries might have taught us that nothing is more conducive to the efficiency of an army than that the men should entertain a well-founded respect for the moral and intellectual, as well as scientific qualities of those who command them; but in this, as in too many other cases, we insisted on buying our own experience. Now that the purchase has been dearly made, it is to be hoped that people may be willing to profit by it. It is true that the democratic character of our society is in some respects unfavorable to the relation which should exist between officer and soldier, and the circumstance affords an additional reason for seeking in the selection of officers those personal characteristics which, in such a society, are the proper substitutes for distinctions of caste. Such discrimination has hitherto been unfortunately rare. Instead of being intrusted to the coolest, wisest, best educated and most conscientious men who could be found, the shoulder-straps have too often fallen to the lot of the brawling and dissipated, who are most "popular" with the unthinking crowd, -- in other words, to those who can and do pay for most, drink at the corner grocery.

abstract: The Boston Transcript states that orders have been received from Washington to expedite, in every possible way, the work upon the iron-clad vessels now building at various places at the North, so that they may be ready for service at an early day. In obedience to this order. Mr. HARRISON LORING, of South Boston, who is building one of these vessels upon the plan of the Monitor, but of larger dimensions, has now about four hundred men employed upon her, and expects to have his portion of the work completed in the course of two or three weeks.

abstract: We have the statement from our Special Washington Correspondent, corroborated by the National Republican of yesterday morning, that Gen. POPE was on Friday relieved of his command at his own request, in order to give him an opportunity to prefer charges against Gen. FITZ JOHN PORTER, Gen. FRANKLIN, (the Republican says SUMNER,) and Gen. GRIFFIN, of the Artillery. Gen. POPE, it is understood, has nearly completed his report of the recent actions, and a portion of it has already been submitted to the President.

abstract: CRICKET. -- The two grand matches, which have been the topic of conversation among cricketers for some time past, are appointed to take place on the St. George grounds, at Hoboken, on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday next, commencing at 11 A.M. on the 11th inst. Next week will, therefore, be a gala time among the cricketers, and it is expected that clubs from other cities will help to fill up the crowd of spectators on the occasion. No such important or interesting games have been played since the international contests of 1859.

abstract: About 7  o'Clock, yesterday morning, a fearful boiler explosion occurred in the manufactory of J. M. SINGER  Co., on the corner of Delancey and Mangin streets, from the effects of which three men have already died, and four others are scalded so badly that the physicians state it will be impossible for them to recover.
lead_paragraph: About 7 1/2 o'clock, yesterday morning, a fearful boiler explosion occurred in the manufactory of J.M. SINGER & CO., on the corner of Delancey and Mangin streets, from the effects of which three men have already died, and four others are scalded so badly that the physicians state it will be impossible for them to recover. The names of the deceased are CHRISTOPHER SHIELDS, of No. 232 Delancey; PATRICK GILSON, of No. 110 Goerickstreet, and ROBERT S. WILEY, corner of Stanton and Lewis-streets; WILLIAM FORD, of Greenpoint, and THOMAS CONNOLLY, of Rivington-street were in a dying condition, at the New-York Hospital, at a late hour last evening. CHRISTOPHER SHIELDS was so horribly scalded that he survived but a few moments after the accident. There are several other persons who are much injured, both by the steam and the bricks which fell upon them, but it is thought they may be saved.

abstract: Some of our friends, not unmindful of the importance of drawing good out of evil, are looking forward to an irruption of the rebels into the Northern States as a means of increasing the vindictiveness of the North, so that our leaders, our Generals and our soldiers should be brought to conduct the war with something of the ferocity which characterizes the rebels.
lead_paragraph: Some of our friends, not unmindful of the importance of drawing good out of evil, are looking forward to an irruption of the rebels into the Northern States as a means of increasing the vindictiveness of the North, so that our leaders, our Generals and our soldiers should be brought to conduct the war with something of the ferocity which characterizes the rebels. We hardly see how that will give us more skillful Generalship, which is our greatest want, but we are very willing that whatever good is to be obtained in that way may come if the evil comes. In the meantime, however, while the wheels of Stonewall JACKSON's chariots still tarry, the best thing which we know of to produce the results which we are thus expected to obtain, is Dr. SWINBURNE's report of the treatment of our sick and wounded by the rebels at Savage's Station after the battles before Richmond. Such inhumanity and barbarism would be almost incredible, even in the history of the inhumanities and barbarisms of this monstrous rebellion, were it not vouched for by the statements of the official report to our State authorities.

abstract: The greatest point of interest noticeable in the Comptroller's Office for some days past has been the payment of the $50 extra bounty awarded by the City authorities to our local volunteers. From 12 o'clock on Friday, up to the close of business yesterday evening, ninety-six applicants received their money in United States Treasury $50 bills, making an aggregate sum of $4,800 paid out on the two days. The recipients are described as a very superior class of men. Among them were a large proportion of Germans.

abstract: A dispatch that has passed the scrutiny of the Government censor comes from Washington, through Philadelphia, to the effect that Gen. POPE has been relieved of his command; and the meaning of the remainder of the telegram we suppose to be that he has demanded a court of inquiry into the causes of the disasters which befell the army while recently under his orders. It is the best thing he could do, and we trust the statement is true. At and since the battle of Cedar Mountain his military management has been so extremely bad that even half-blind civilians could not fail to comprehend its stupidity and atrocity. There need neither be criticism nor argument about it so far as the public and the great body of the army are concerned. His exclusion of correspondents from his lines could not conceal it; his bulletins could not cover it up. The fact was too great and glaring for any petty effort to be able to hide it long from the public eye. We trust that the entire truth will now be brought to the light of day, so that an intelligent judgment may be formed on the facts, and so that Gen. POPE and whoever else is to blame, may have such punishment, meted out to them as their conduct demands. The price we have paid for military blunders in Virginia of late, is tremendous -- a price seen and to be seen only in the terrible columns of "killed and wounded," not to speak of prisoners, -- the price in national honor, in public disheartenment and disgust, and in the new power given to the rebellion. It will not do to run anymore risks under such leadership; and if the blunderers do not, as in the earlier time of the First French Revolution they would have done, pay the penalty with their heads, they must at least be prevented from trifling any longer with other men's heads, or with the life of the nation.

abstract: You will, undoubtedly, be surprised to receive another letter from your correspondent, written in this hot-bed of secession. I am surprised myself. But Stonewall JACKSON, Col. LEE, or some other dashing rebel commander, is responsible for my unwilling detention here. Gen. Somebody proposes, but some other military chief on the other side of the house disposes  at least seriously interferes with the movements of correspondents particularly just now, on the Orang and Alexandria Railroad.

abstract: Editorial urges more iron-clad ships; Editorial urges additions to iron-clad navy
snippet: Editorial urges more iron-clad ships; Editorial urges additions to iron-clad navy
lead_paragraph: -- The destruction of the ram Arkansas, the last of the rebel iron-clad gunboats afloat, has drawn public attention temporarily away from the subject of our own iron-clad navy. But we trust the energies of the Government are not at all relaxed in the construction of the many iron-plated batteries that we have under way. These defences will be needed none the less because the rebels of the South have nothing to pit against them. They will be worth more than the most elaborate protests and State papers that our Government can send to Europe against intervention in our affairs. There is a moral strength in physical power which our bitterest enemies among foreign Governments will not be blind to, and while we hope for peace, we will wisely seek it by making war doubly dangerous to those who would risk it.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday continued the investigation in the case of the three men, SHIELDS, GILSON and WILEY, who lost their lives on Saturday, by the explosion of a boiler in the establishment of I.M. SINGER & Co., on the corner of Delancey and Mangin-streets, a detailed account of which we gave in yesterday's TIMES. Owing to the fact that two of the victims had died at the New-York Hospital, after the Jury were impaneled at the Thirteenth Precinct Station-house, it was deemed best to adjourn the inquest on Saturday night over to the dead-house of the hospital, at which place the evidence, of which the following is the substance, was taken yesterday. It is quite voluminous, and we have merely given an abstract of it. We do so in the belief that it will be read with interest, if not with alarm, especially when it is considered how exposed the citizens of New-York are to calamities of this nature. Let the authorities read, and then say why they do not enforce the law, as passed by the last Legislature of the State:

abstract: -- Harpe's Monthly for September, opens with a very timely and instructive article, which everybody will be sure to read, treating of the construction of iron-clad vessels. It is a subject which will well bear the additional discussion and illustration which it is proposed to bestow upon it. Lieut. BREWERTON's "Adventures in the Buffalo Country," the first chapters of which were given in Harpers in 1853 and 1854, are pleasantly sketched; but the pressure of four serial stories -- the adventures of "Philip," "Orley Farm," "Mistress and Maid," and "Romola" -- of necessity curtail the space which can be devoted to shorter sketches and tales. It needs a skillful juggler to keep four balls in the air at the same time, and we feel confident that the readers of Harpers will gladly see the end even of "Philip's Adventures," which are closed with the present number, if the pages which they leave vacant are to be hereafter devoted to miscellaneous articles.

abstract: is out in a card, stating that he has been solicited to accept a Colonelcy in one of the regiments now forming. He thus modestly advances his qualifications for the position. "In anticipation of a call for my services upon the field at some period of the contest, I have, during my term of service, devoted my leisure hours to the study, observation and practice of military movements, besides having had some three months' active service on the Peninsula, so that I now feel myself entirely competent to command a regiment, brigade or division; and should my services be needed at any time, in any position, I trust I shall not be found wanting in either zeal or capacity."

abstract: "Monopolies," it has been said, "as they are necessary evils, require in the interest of the people to be jealously watched and wisely kept under stringent control." If the Manhattan and New-York Gas Companies had wished to invite the legislative application of this maxim to themselves they could scarcely have adopted a more effective means than by their recent attempt to charge the War tax to their customers.
lead_paragraph: "Monopolies," it has been said, "as they are necessary evils, require in the interest of the people to be jealously watched and wisely kept under stringent control." If the Manhattan and New-York Gas Companies had wished to invite the legislative application of this maxim to themselves they could scarcely have adopted a more effective means than by their recent attempt to charge the War tax to their customers. Their issue of the circular, in which this modest proposal is announced, has thus rendered a service to the City, which, in the prospective depression of all kinds of business, is, no doubt, fully appreciated and will elicit in due time a fit response.
headline: {'main': 'The Gas Companies and the War Tax.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Gas Companies and the War Tax.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- We are glad to see that while the State bounty to recruits has ceased, the bounty of fifty dollars to all who enlist in the old regiments is to continue. There is only one practicable way of filling up the skeleton regiments, and that is by recruits who volunteer to join these organizations. Mr. STANTON thought he could do it by draft. But after he had issued his order to this effect, he found he was barred by Constitutional limitations he had not thought of. The National Government can draft only through the State authorities, and these authorities have the power of officering the militia, so that it is impossible to fill up existing regiments by this means.
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad to see that while the State bounty to recruits has ceased, the bounty of fifty dollars to all who enlist in the old regiments is to continue. There is only one practicable way of filling up the skeleton regiments, and that is by recruits who volunteer to join these organizations. Mr. STANTON thought he could do it by draft. But after he had issued his order to this effect, he found he was barred by Constitutional limitations he had not thought of. The National Government can draft only through the State authorities, and these authorities have the power of officering the militia, so that it is impossible to fill up existing regiments by this means.

abstract: -- Where is the CORCORAN Brigade, that it is not on its way to the seat of war? We do not understand the cause of tardiness, for we know that the gallant General would not delay an hour beyond the time when his boys were ready to march. It can hardly be that he finds any difficulty in raising his men, for even while on his way North he was offered enough for two or three brigades. We have no doubt, however, that Gen. CORCORAN is quite as anxious to get to the work of fighting as the people are to have him. But we hope that no zeal to raise soldiers will blind him to the necessity of haste. A single brigade, or even his own regiment of war-worn, fire-tempered veterans is worth more than a dozen regiments will be after the delay needed for their enlistment has passed. We hardly think the gallant Irishman will be able much longer to resist the bugle-call.

abstract: Editorial on failure of Union military movements to date; sees further dangers; Editorial says selection of commanding gens. should be decided by their proven ability in field
snippet: Editorial on failure of Union military movements to date; sees further dangers; Editorial says selection of commanding gens. should be decided by their proven ability in field
lead_paragraph: The Journal of Commerce "takes issue" with the TIMES as to the position of the war. It "denies absolutely" that the Government thus far in the conflict, has been beaten by the rebels, and insists, on the contrary, that we have achieved a long series of brilliant and glorious victories. The Journal may be simply playing upon words, and praising the valor of our troops and their success in individual engagements. We are inclined to put this interpretation upon its language, because any other would be disparaging to its judgment. We join the Journal mostheartily in commending the heroic endurance and the splendid courage which our soldiers have evinced in every battle. It can have no issue with us upon this point.

abstract: Prob  ably few have looked into the present condition of maritime law with sufficient attention to know how the treatment of the Tuscarora is to be judged by the principles of that code. All they see is the gross violation of international comity involved in the refusal of hospitality to the war vessel of a friendly nation, and her dismissal from British ports without the privilege of coaling, and while in a leaky state.
lead_paragraph: Probably few have looked into the present condition of maritime law with sufficient attention to know how the treatment of the Tuscarora is to be judged by the principles of that code. All they see is the gross violation of international comity involved in the refusal of hospitality to the war vessel of a friendly nation, and her dismissal from British ports without the privilege of coaling, and while in a leaky state. A moment's inquiry into the law of the matter, though it may show that according to the cold formula of neutrality the British authorities have a species of technical right to do what they have done, will not tend to diminish the impression that it is, to say the least, a very unfriendly proceeding.

abstract: -- Gen. POPE has been relieved from command in the Army of Virginia, and has been assigned to duty in the Northwest, while Gen. MCDOWELL has been granted leave of absence for fifteen days. We hope there will be no delay whatever in the trial which Gen. POPE has demanded for certain of his subordinate officers, or in his own trial. If commanders are to be allowed to destroy armies one after another, and, instead of being condemned to severe punishment for their crimes, receive appointments to commands only less lofty, we shall soon be destitute of armies to destroy. A few wholesome examples of just severity in high quarters would do infinite good to the army just now, and would give to the nation more confidence in those who are guiding its military destinies.

abstract: editorial laments Confederate seizure of Frederick
snippet: editorial laments Confederate seizure of Frederick
lead_paragraph: The seizure of Frederick, the Capital of Maryland, by the rebel army, which to the shame of our military authorities, is on record to-day, inaugurates the rebel invasion of the loyal States. The programme opens audaciously, and it is not difficult to conceive what is intended to be the next step. The rebels have a way of carrying out military movements to their logical conclusion, which, unhappily, our Generals have never possessed. From Frederick, by the Baltimore and Ohio railroad, which they command, they are within striking distance of Baltimore. This they will undoubtedly aim to seize, and if they succeed they will really have such a tourniquet round our necks as the London Times said the capture of New-Orleans would be in the case of the rebel cause. They there tap the great artery leading from the whole system of the loyal States to their heart in Washington. By holding Baltimore they completely cut off communication with the Capital, and thus prevent the forwarding of reinforcements on whose forthgoing our entire national safety depends. It is a brilliantly audacious scheme, and is worth any sacrifice if it should prove even temporarily successful. That the success will be anything more than temporary, we, of course, do not dream. So far the rebels have but a few thousand men in Maryland; and a force sufficient to grind them to powder can immediately be hurled upon them.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Invasion of Maryland.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Invasion of Maryland.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: -- Brig.-Gen. TAYLOR, who died recently at Alexandria, of wounds received in battle, was born near Clinton, Hunterdon County, N.J. He was a cadet in the Military School of Col. ALLEN PARTRIDGE, in Connecticut, until he was eighteen years of age and then entered the navy as a Midshipman. After making several cruises he resigned his commission and returned home from the Mediteranean, where he was serving. Family troubles were the cause of this step, and immediately on reaching home hie made it his business to seek out the author of his difficulties and administered him severe personal chastisement. He raised a company of Volunteers for the Mexican war and acted as their captain, and upon the outbreak of the present rebellion, was named Colonel of the Third New-Jersey Regiment. This regiment was in the reserve at the battle of Bull Run, and did good service in attempting to check the rout of the National forces. In the reorganization of the army, he was made Brigadier-Greneral, and in this capacity did good service on the Peninsula. The Newark Advertiser says of him:

abstract: There is no doubt that the public will have o be indebted to Mr. NIXON for the first Italian opera of the season. As soon as the Autumn nights get cool, and the Palace of Music in Fourteenth-street becomes too airy and well-ventilated a place to hear CARLOTTA PATTI comfortably in, Mr. NIXON will change his base to the Academy, receive strong reinforcements, open a campaign in his usual vigorous manner, and prosecute it with the energy and enterprise that have heretofore crowned nearly all his pranagerial adventuress with success. Of course the debut of CARLOTTA PATTI in the regular lyric drama will be the great attractive feature of his programme. In the musical world there has not been for years so much anticipated excitement about the first appearance of a new prima donna as now exists concerning this accomplished, charming singer.

abstract: The rebels have at last executed their threat to invade Maryland. They crossed the Potomac on Friday night and Saturday morning at several points above and below Point of Rocks, and before noon on Saturday were in possession of Frederick, the capital of the State. It is also reported that they have crossed the Potomac west of Harper's Ferry, but this report is not confirmed. Fugitives, who left Frederick on Saturday night, reported the city to be in possession of about five thousand rebels, under Gen. HILL, who had issued a proclamation, promising protection to private property, and appointed a Provost Guard. Our latest reports from the vicinity are to yesterday morning, when the rebels still held the place in heavy force, under command of Gen. JOHNSTON, while JACKSON was reported to be fifteen miles below Point of Rocks. Poolesville was also said to be in rebel possession -- their forces being arrayed in line of battle, awaiting an attack. The rebels are represented to be very exultant, and to express the determination to capture Washington, but say they will first go further North to procure supplies. We know nothing of the arrangements of the Government to resist this movement of the rebel forces.

abstract: -- The destruction of bridges by the rebels, on the railroad between Frankfort and Louisville, shows that they are in complete control of the capital and entire interior of that State. The Governor had previously removed to Louisville, with the Legislature; and we presume the State archives are all safe. Still, the fact that the capital of Kentucky is in the hands of the rebels, as well as the present capital of Maryland, is a mortifying fact, and should certainly inflame the patriotism of the two States and beget a feeling of resentment that the loyalists in no part of the country have yet manifested.

abstract: -- The distribution of the new Government "postage currency" as it is absurdly styled, commenced yesterday. As no one person, however, was allowed to purchase more than $5 worth, the amount put into circulation was comparatively small. We trust it may be distributed as rapidly as possible, for a more contemptible and disgusting substitute for small change was never authorized by any respectable Government than the patches of gum arabic which have been doing duty for the past few weeks. No greater proof of patience and patriotism has ever been furnished by any community, than has been afforded by our people in the toleration of these sticky nuisances.
lead_paragraph: -- The distribution of the new Government "postage currency" as it is absurdly styled, commenced yesterday. As no one person, however, was allowed to purchase more than $5 worth, the amount put into circulation was comparatively small. We trust it may be distributed as rapidly as possible, for a more contemptible and disgusting substitute for small change was never authorized by any respectable Government than the patches of gum arabic which have been doing duty for the past few weeks. No greater proof of patience and patriotism has ever been furnished by any community, than has been afforded by our people in the toleration of these sticky nuisances.

abstract: Very full details of the rebel movement into Maryland, and their operations in Frederick and vicinity, will be found in our special correspondence and dispatches this morning. They do not differ in the facts from the accounts which have already been published. The Government authorities received the news of the invasion on Saturday evening, in documentary form, and during that night and Sunday, immense bodies of our troops were put in motion for the Upper Potomac and elsewhere. The authorities at Washington appear to be at fault as to the next movement likely to be made by the rebels, but we receive assurances that proper precautions have been taken to guard against damage "in certain quarters." The rebels appear to have captured no Government stores whatever at Frederick. All the National forces stationed there fell back to Harper's Ferry, but before doing so destroyed all the hospital and commissary stores they could not remove, and took away with them the sick and wounded. Communication with Harper's Ferry is of course cut off by the rebels, but there is no danger of the National force there being starved out, as has been feared, so long as they can receive supplies from the West over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which the recent skirmish at Martinsburgh indicates is still in our possession in that direction. It appears to be doubtful whether the rebels intend to make a movement on Harper's Ferry. With the Maryland Heights in our possession, such a movement could hardly be successful, unless in overwhelming numbers. It appears more probable that they contemplate a raid into Pennsylvania, by way of Hagerstown; a direct march upon Washington, or an attack upon Baltimore. At any rate, there is no doubt of their presence in the State in heavy force. A paroled prisoner who arrived in Washington yesterday reports that about 150,000 had crossed the Potomac, the main body of them at the Monocacy; and this report is credited by the military authorities. There has been very little if any fighting yet. There is a rumor of a skirmish yesterday morning in the neighborhood of Poolesville, but it is not confirmed.

abstract: Brownlow sends patriotic lr. to govs. of loyal states; text; Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Brownlow sends patriotic lr. to govs. of loyal states; text; Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: GENTLEMEN: I do not wish to figure as "a busybody in other men's matters," but feeling and knowing that the crisis of our national affairs is now upon us, and believing that the next sixty days will determine the question whether we are to maintain the supremacy of the Government, or whether the rebellion is to prevail (I have a personal acquainttance with many of you -- Govs. Curtin, Morton, Tod, Morgan, Buckingham, Andrew, and others -- and I bear testimony that you have done much, and done it well, wisely, and in due time, to promote the best interests of our country in this the day of her trial; much remains to be done; and you, gentlemen, representing more than twenty States, have it in your power to do more than any other class of men) -- In the impress upon your minds the alarming fact that the rebels have now more men in the field, and in camps of instruction than we have -- having brought all their white men into requisition, and having made Slavery an element of strength by retaining the slaves upon their plantations to raise supplies for their armies. Let me further impress upon your minds the startling fact that the rebel advances are simultaneous all over the country, and exhibit system and concert of action, with a zeal and talent displayed in the execution of their plans worthy of a better cause than that in which they are engaged. New-Orleans, Memphis, Nashville, Louisville, Cincinnati, Washington, Baltimore, Harrisburgh, and Philadelphia, are all threatened by an enemy that shows prodigious activity, talents and strength. Indeed, they have us now where they had us thirteen months ago, with this addition, that they have invaded Maryland and Ohio. If they march upon us, and their daring plans are not properly met and most signally defeated, it will be our fault.

abstract: We have advices from Europe to the 31st ult., bf the arrival off Cape Race of the steamships Australasian and Norwegian. The most important item of news is the defeat, wounding and capture of GARIBALDI by the Government forces of Italy. He was put on board an Italian frigate and conveyed to Spezzio. The Liverpool Cotton Market was buoyant, with a further advance. The market for Breadstuffs and Provisions was dull. Consols were quoted at 93 5/8@93 3/4 for Money.

abstract: Editorial fears Morgan and his forces are stranded at Cumberland Gap
snippet: Editorial fears Morgan and his forces are stranded at Cumberland Gap
lead_paragraph: GAP. -- About a fortnight ago we pointed out the perils that were gathering around the Union force at Cumberland Gap, under Gen. MORGAN; that he was isolated from help or relief, that he was cut off from supplies, that the enemy was gathering in his front and rear, and that unless succor by some means soon reached him, his destruction or starvation was inevitable. Since then, by the rebel successes in Kentucky, Gen. MORGAN's dangers have been increased a thousand fold, and his position looks now all but hopeless.

abstract: The excitement in Baltimore has been more manifest to-day, and though we have had no disturb  ance worthy of mention, a variety of small affairs has kept the authorities busy. Crowds have been stationed about the principal newspaper office all day, and little knots of people have centered here and there on Baltimore-street, eagerly canvassing the probabilities of Stonewall JACKSON's appearing, and giving expression to their feeling in reference to such an event.

abstract: Gen. POPE has gone West to take command of his new Department. We believe he has assured the President that the charges preferred against him are entirely untrue, and that his failure to destroy the enemy in front of Washington was not his fault. It is evident, from the fact of his receiving so promptly a new command, that he retains the undiminished confidence of President LINCOLN.

abstract: LISTMENTS. -- If the powers that be had designed to put a clog on enlistments in the State of New-York, they could hardly have contrived a condition of things more favorable to that end than that we now suffer under. The State bounty of $50, which was extended by a special order of Gov. MORGAN from the 1st to the 6th inst., ceased on Saturday, and, meanwhile, there is no prospect, for weeks to come, of a draft. The interval is likely to be one of practical paralysis of volunteering. And this, we beg the Government to note, will not be owing to any want of patriotism on the part of the people, but is simply the natural result of the confusion which the authorities have introduced into the method of raising soldiers. Now that the bounty is no longer to be paid, it is very certain that neither that class who enlist purely for the sake of the bounty nor that other class to whom the offer of bounty is an inducement will be available; while with many the conviction of the absolute and immediate necessity of a draft is so paramount that there will be little disposition to encourage its delay by inducing the authorities to believe that, after all, volunteering may suffice.

abstract: Few, we imagine, will read without emotion the telegraphic words that tell of the defeat and capture of GARIBALDI, and his confinement, wounded, in the prison of Spezzia. To this tragic finale has come the mad, mistaken enterprise into which the Italian Liberator was betrayed, and which, but a moment ago, threatened to compromise the destiny of Italy. The movement, and all it potentially contained of weal or of woe for Italy and for Europe, is brought to naught; and the spark is quenched which might have kindled a conflagration throughout a Continent.

abstract: By a letter from the United States Consul at Matanzas, we learn that the privateer steamer Oreto now called the Florida, arrived at Cardenas on the 19th of August. Her commander, JOHN N. MAFFIT, is reported to be down with fever. A Spanish was steamer is there to prevent her going out in pursuit of American vessels.
lead_paragraph: By a letter from the United States Consul at Matanzas, we learn that the privateer steamer Oreto now called the Florida, arrived at Cardenas on the 19th of August. Her commander, JOHN N. MAFFIT, is reported to be down with fever. A Spanish was steamer is there to prevent her going out in pursuit of American vessels.

abstract: The London Times is a miracle of patience and of faith. It indulges a hope that the Americans will soon come to appreciate the disinterestedness of the British nation in its treatment of our rebellion. We cannot fail, the Times thinks, sooner or later to perceive that the controlling impulse of the British Government, and the paramount sentiment of the British people, in all their dealings with foreign Powers, is a profound, simple-hearted, almost angelic devotion to principle. The temptations have been very great, the Times bids us observe, to meddle with our affairs. There is no nation on earth capable of resisting them without help, except the English. France would have pitched in long ago if the excellent British had not prevented. The United States ought to be very grateful to the good English Government, which has not interfered in their affairs -- which has resisted all temptations to break the blockade, and to help the Southern rebels destroy the great Republic; and in course of time, this admirable exponent of British character is quite certain the Americans will not fail to make due acknowledgment for all their kindness.

abstract: There is a disagreement of doctors on official circles. Certain medical men are standing on some very sharp points of etiquette, much to their own inconvenience and still more to the [???] of the [???]. The [???], has arisen to this [???]. When the Governor issued his proclamation, offering on behalf of the State to any volunteer an additional bounty of [???] at the same time appointed special disbursing and inspecting officers, whose duty it should be to authorize and effect its payment. The inspecting officer for this City was a Dr. THOMSON, without a certificate of health and physical soundness from whom no recruit could claim, or, at any rate, obtain his money. But, before passing the ordeal of inspection from Dr. THOMSON, the recruit had to be examined and passed by other doctors, appointed by the War Department, to see that none but able-bodied men received the bounty offered by the United States. It would naturally be thought that one inspection by a competent medical man would be sufficient for all useful purposes: but it seems there is a sort of irrepressible conflict between the respective authorities of State and nation, and that their respective dignities demanded the exercise of separate and independent jurisdiction. Heretofore this condition of affairs has been productive of incipient trouble; but actual conflict was avoided up to yesterday, when things came to a crisis, the doctors openly quarrelled and the country had in consequence to suffer from the temporary stoppage of enlistments. Of course each casts the blame upon the other, and, of course also, there must be more or less of blame attaching to both. It seems that the United States Doctors pass the men first, whereupon they are sworn, in by the mustering officer, and are, to all intents and purposes, regularly enlisted soldiers, beyond the chance of escape, and liable to punishment for desertion or mutiny if they revolt or run away. The only bounty they are so far entitled to, however, amounts to $29. To get the other bounties ($100 now -- $50 State and $50 City) -- they must satisfy the further critical judgment of Dr. THOMSON. Dr. THOMSON appears to be hard to please. Certificates signed by Dr. MOTT, Dr. GAHAN, or Dr. KERRIGAN, are not with him conclusive evidence of a recruit's fitness. He must see for himself, and is not to be deterred by feelings of professional courtesy from differing with the other Doctors in opinion. On several occasions he has thus differed with them, and declined to grant a certificate entitling the recruit to the State and City bounties. This is mortifying to the United States Surgeons; but is especially hard on the unfortunate recruit. Dr. THOMSON's rejection of him does not discharge him from the service; it only deprives him of $100. Very reasonably he feels himself swindled and outraged, and from that moment his mind is made up to desert. To remedy the matter. Col. REEVES, U.S.A., the chief mustering and disbursing officer here for the War Department, issued an order requiring recruits to pass through Dr. THOMSON's hands first, as his (Dr. THOMSON's) approval did not make soldiers of them, and no harm would follow if they were afterward rejected by the other doctors. This arrangement did not suit Dr. THOMSON, WHO issued a counter proclamation, refusing to have anything to do with recruits that had not been mustered into the United States service before they were brought to him. The result of all this bickering antagonism is that, yesterday afternoon, no men could be passed at all. Both offices were crowded for hours with Captains and Lieutenants and the recruits they had been procuring; but, between the two orders, enlistments fell to the ground. It is a scandalous and objectionable piece of business altogether, and should somehow be settled very speedily. The country's emergency is too serious to permit of such consideration being shown to mere personal self-esteem or obstinacy. It is recruits that are wanted, and no one cares by whom they are inspected, so long as it is known that the duty is assigned to a capable medical man. Every one knows Dr. MOTT to be this, and few will be likely to attribute any fault in the premises to him.

abstract: It seems to be settled that a force of at least 40,000 rebels has crossed the Potomac and taken position at Frederick, in Maryland, about sixty miles west of Baltimore, and about forty north from Washington. They have been permitted by the Government to cross without resistance. Telegraphic reports from the Capital would almost lead us to believe that they had been invited there, -- for we are assured that the Government is perfectly satisfied with their position, and that none of them will ever return. We hopethis may prove to be true; -- but we would rather see it proved than give full credence to it in advance. As we remarked yesterday, we have too many of these official assurances already on hand unredeemed, to be especially eager for more.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be settled that a force of at least 40,000 rebels has crossed the Potomac and taken position at Frederick, in Maryland, about sixty miles west of Baltimore, and about forty north from Washington. They have been permitted by the Government to cross without resistance. Telegraphic reports from the Capital would almost lead us to believe that they had been invited there, -- for we are assured that the Government is perfectly satisfied with their position, and that none of them will ever return. We hopethis may prove to be true; -- but we would rather see it proved than give full credence to it in advance. As we remarked yesterday, we have too many of these official assurances already on hand unredeemed, to be especially eager for more.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Australasian, from Liverpool on the 30th, via Queenstown on the 31st of August, arrived off Cape Race at 9 o'clock on Sunday morning. She was boarded by the News Yacht, and a synopsis of her news was obtained, which is two days later than that per the Norwegian, which passed Cape Race Sept. 6.

abstract: -- While the rebel army remains in and on the borders of Maryland, enjoying the fat things of Montgomery and Frederick Counties, restoring its exhausted energies, and gathering up stores of supplies for future use, it will also be able to largely recruit its thinned ranks from among the rebels of Maryland. The large rebel element in the State will no doubt rush to the Confederate standard, now that the Stars and Bars is unfurled so near by. The Maryland rebels have been greatly afraid of the operations of the Federal conscription of late, and have been adopting every ruse to get southward into Virginia or somewhere within the rebel lines, -- many of them declaring that they were willing to remain neutral at home, but if they were to be forced to fight, they would certainly fight for their rebel friends.
lead_paragraph: -- While the rebel army remains in and on the borders of Maryland, enjoying the fat things of Montgomery and Frederick Counties, restoring its exhausted energies, and gathering up stores of supplies for future use, it will also be able to largely recruit its thinned ranks from among the rebels of Maryland. The large rebel element in the State will no doubt rush to the Confederate standard, now that the Stars and Bars is unfurled so near by. The Maryland rebels have been greatly afraid of the operations of the Federal conscription of late, and have been adopting every ruse to get southward into Virginia or somewhere within the rebel lines, -- many of them declaring that they were willing to remain neutral at home, but if they were to be forced to fight, they would certainly fight for their rebel friends.

abstract: SIR: Your correspondent "Geographer' will pardon me for again setting him right in reference to Southern conscription. He is entirely in error.
lead_paragraph: SIR: Your correspondent "Geographer' will pardon me for again setting him right in reference to Southern conscription. He is entirely in error. There has been no occasion for a forced service of citizens or compulsory attendance of men in the field;" and it is not a "notorious truth that all over the South since the beginning of the war, men have been enlisted whenever the number of volunteers were deficient." Such "notorious truths" are simply the unblushing falsehoods of the New-York journals, so often reiterated that it is no wonder your correspondent should be deceived. He has also been misled by an affair that happened at New-Orleans in May, 1861 which he cites as follows:

abstract: News received at headquarters last night states that Clarksville has fallen into the hands of the Nationals. Col. LOWE left Fort Donalson Saturday, with the intention of attacking there on Sunday. He was met by them, 1,100 strong. The rebels quickly dispersed. Twenty-five prisoners were taken.

abstract: Editorial on W H Hurlbert serial Fifteen Months at the South, to appear in NY Times; account of civil and military operations of Confederate government
snippet: Editorial on W H Hurlbert serial Fifteen Months at the South, to appear in NY Times; account of civil and military operations of Confederate government
lead_paragraph: We shall to-morrow commence the publication, in the columns of the TIMES, of a series of letters under the caption of "Fifteen Months at the South," written by Mr. W.H. HURLBERT, formerly of this city, and well known as a literary man and an attache of the New-York Press. Mr. HURLBERT went to Richmond from the North about the time that the Confederate Government was removed there from Montgomery; and until he left that city, a week or two ago, he was in constant and close observation of the civil and military operations of the Rebel Government. Of the movements of affairs, and of many of those things which have appeared inexplicable and mysterious, he has had an inside view; while of the private opinions and designs of the rebel leaders, as well as of the past and present condition of Southern sentiment and Southern affairs, he has a more ac curate knowledge than is possessed by any one who has yet undertaken to enlighten the public on these topics. His sketches will, of course, be as different as is possible, from the mass of undigested rubbish we have had in the newspaper, professing to give the result of personal observation on events in the South. They are the work of one accustomed to observe affairs as wall as to philosophize upon them; and who, in his former writings, has shown himself possessed of an unsurpassed brilliancy of style and vigor of diction. They will be the first glimpse the public has had behind the scenes of the great Secession rebellion; and as such will be appreciated by the readers of the TIMES.

abstract: The purpose of the rebels in invading Maryland continues to be discussed with interest and industry by all classes of our population.
lead_paragraph: The purpose of the rebels in invading Maryland continues to be discussed with interest and industry by all classes of our population. There is something to be gained by our military authorities in knowing the aim of the movement; but for that very reason the enemy will use his utmost exertions to conceal his design. Whatever the leading purpose of the rebels may be, there are a number of incidental advantages to be gained, whether they achieve their main object or not. For instance, they gain prestige in having transferred the war from their own soil to ours. They gain subsistence in the capture of commissary stores at the various Union posts they have occupied, and in foraging on the farmers wherever they march. If they fail therefore, to take Baltimore, or Washington or Harrisburgh, or Philadelphia, but retreat now to the south bank of the Potomac as expeditiously as they came, they will, nevertheless, have inflicted a burning disgrace on the Union cause. The fact will give us more humiliation and trouble in Europe than all our other reverses put together.

abstract: The payment of the new postage stamp currency was resumed last Monday. Although several weeks have elapsed since the notes were first issued,  and since they have been disbursed in Washington...
lead_paragraph: The payment of the new postage stamp currency was resumed last Monday. Although several weeks have elapsed since the notes were first issued, and since they have been disbursed in Washington by army paymasters, but few had found their way into circulation in this City. About a fortnight since the Sub-Treasurer paid a very small number to people desirous of obtaining them; but so few were disbursed that they are seldom met with. They have been received at the Custom-house, in sums less than five dollars, for fees, &c., and a few have been returned to importers, by the Cashier, in making change. The Sub-Treasury was the scene of great activity on Monday, the number of applicants for the new notes being very large -- a long line extending from the entrance, through Wall-street to Nassau. The announcement was made, by advertisement, that the payment would be resumed on that day, but that the notes would be disbursed only in sums of five dollars.

abstract: The Naval Department of the Federal Government has acted throughout on the maxims of defiance and Insolance which have been enunciated in...
lead_paragraph: The Naval Department of the Federal Government has acted throughout on the maxims of defiance and Insolance which have been enunciated in the dispatches of the Secretary of State. Mr. GIDEON WELLES, it must be remembered, approved and accepted the responsibility of Capt. WILKES' egregious outrage on the Trent; and, in restoring the Confederate Commissioners, Mr. LINCOLN was obliged to administer the severest and most stinging of practical rebukes to the offending Minister. But Mr. WELLES knew the advantage, of his office too well to resign; and, after the storm had blown over, he continued the course on which he had entered, without regard to the humiliation he had so recently brought upon himself and upon the President. The malpractices of the Tuccrora need not now be recapitulated. From her first appearance in our waters she has incessantly busied herself with attempts to carry on hostile operations within British jurisdiction, and even in British ports, and has obliged the Admiralty to employ vessels of superior force constantly to watch her movements, and prevent her from committing, under our eyes, depredations which we should have been compelled either to punish as breaches of municipal law, or to avenge as invasions of public right by a declaration of war.

abstract: Louisa Morgan, Ezecutrix, vs. William Young. -- The plaintiff having obtained judgment against the defendant, and on return of execution, supplementary proceedings having been had and concluded, at which Hill, Courtney & Monell appeared as defendant's Attorneys, the plaintiff's Attorneys served an eight-day notice upon defendant's Attorneys to show cause on the 8th inst. why a receiver should not be appointed. The attorneys upon whom the same was served, and who had appeared on the supplementary proceedings as defendant's Attorneys, returned the notice, after the lapse of six days, saying they were not authorized to appear for the defendant in the proceedings, and that the defendant was the party to be served with such notice.

abstract: Editorials warning Union to be on lookout for ship Merrimac No. 2 said to be ready for action
snippet: Editorials warning Union to be on lookout for ship Merrimac No. 2 said to be ready for action
lead_paragraph: Though the reports of the advent of the rebel Merrimac No. 2 prove to have been premature, it is a dead certainty that we shall have her out one of these days. And when she comes the country may as well prepare to hear of some startling news. The announcement which the naval authorities kindly send us from Fortress Monroe, to the effect that they are "ready for her," is an assurance which has small value. We have not so much fear for the shipping in Hampton Roads -- for that can be brought under protection of the guns of the Fortress or retired to shoal water. But there are several directions in which a vessel of the formidable character which the Merrimac No. 2 is said to present, is capable of doing us infinite damage. Most of cut iron-clads, which alone can pretend to encounter her, have been removed to the Potomac, and the whole Southern coast is clear for her to descend in a destroying avalanche on our blockading vessels. Instead of putting herself in the way of our Monitors and Galenas, she will probably go down in a raid of this kind -- and looking along the line of what it is possible for her to do, we can scarcely see power to cause us. We hope our naval authorities are "ready" for this contingency.
headline: {'main': 'LOOK OUT FOR THE MERRIMAC No. 2.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOOK OUT FOR THE MERRIMAC No. 2.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday morning, at an early hour, the Fortieth Massachusetts Regiment, under command of Lieut.-Col. DALTON, arrived at Jersey City, by the steamer Bay State, of the Fall River line, en route for Washington. The men, numbering over a thousand, are fine, stalwart-looking young fellows, all of whom are thoroughly uniformed and equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. The commander of the regiment, Col. PORTER, is an experienced officer, having seen active service while a member of Gen. FREMONT's staff. It is also stated that the majority of the line officers are men of experience, who will no doubt enable the men of the Fortieth to give a good account of themselves.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, at an early hour, the Fortieth Massachusetts Regiment, under command of Lieut.-Col. DALTON, arrived at Jersey City, by the steamer Bay State, of the Fall River line, en route for Washington. The men, numbering over a thousand, are fine, stalwart-looking young fellows, all of whom are thoroughly uniformed and equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. The commander of the regiment, Col. PORTER, is an experienced officer, having seen active service while a member of Gen. FREMONT's staff. It is also stated that the majority of the line officers are men of experience, who will no doubt enable the men of the Fortieth to give a good account of themselves.

abstract: The payment of the new postage stamp currency was resumed last Monday. Although several  weeks have elapsed since the notes were first issued,...
lead_paragraph: The payment of the new postage stamp currency was resumed last Monday. Although several weeks have elapsed since the notes were first issued, and since they have been disbursed in Washington by army paymasters, but few had found their way into circulation in this City. About a fortnight since the Sub-Treasurer paid a very small number to people desirous of obtaining them; but so few were disbursed that they are seldom met with. They have been received at the Custom-house, in sums less than five dollars, for fees, &c., and a few have been returned to importers, by the Cashier, in making change. The Sub-Treasury was the scene of great activity on Monday, the number of applicants for the new notes having very large -- a long line extending from the entrance, through Wall-street to Nassau. The announcement was made, by advertisement, that the payment would be resumed on that day, but that the notes would be disbursed only in sums of five dollars.

abstract: Intelligence has been received from various sources that the enemy has succeeded in evading or forcing the lines of the Confederates between Manassas and...
lead_paragraph: Intelligence has been received from various sources that the enemy has succeeded in evading or forcing the lines of the Confederates between Manassas and Washington, and reached Arlington Heights with the wreck of his army. This story lacks confirmation, but it comes from so many quarters that we fear it contains but too much truth. We know from the Northern Press that it was the intention of their Generals, if defeated on the Rappahannock, to retire to Arlington Heights, there to renew the war of the spade, and reform their broken legions and new lines during the Winter. But it was the hope and belief of the country that the arrangements of the Confederate leaders had been such as would have completely failed that plan. If the news of their successful retreat to Arlington Heights is confirmed, it will be another of those many disappointments which we have had to support, much resembling and nearly as great as the escape of McCLELLAN after the battle of Cold Harbor and Malvern Hill.

abstract: Mr. LAWSON and Mr. POTTER, the members for Carlisle, were present at the annual fish dinner to the Mayor of Carlisle, on Friday last, at King Garth.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LAWSON and Mr. POTTER, the members for Carlisle, were present at the annual fish dinner to the Mayor of Carlisle, on Friday last, at King Garth. In responding to the toast of "The Health of the City Member," Mr. LAWSON said he was afraid not much had been done for the public good in the late session. Lord PALMERSTON had told the people at Dover that the session was quite remarkable for the number of public benefits enacted, but with that tact for which he was celebrated, the noble lord had taken good care not to enumerate them. [Laughter.] After referring to some of the measures which had been before Parliament, Mr. LAWSON alluded to the prevailing distress. He said: We feel that distress in Carlisle, through I do not know that it is yet so bad as in some parts of Lancashire; but I know it is very great. It behooves us all to do what we can for the relief of that distress; but I do not know that much can be done in the way of legislation. A bill has been passed in meet the difficulty, and I trust it will have the intended effect. The cause of that distress we all know, is the sad state of affairs in American. What are the causes of that war -- that fratricidal war, or who is to blame, are not topics on which we can properly descant at present. There are different opinions on the subject -- some think one right and some think the other right -- and we can hardly discuss it without becoming partisans. I can only say that I saw with very deep regret, the speech made by an honorable member of the House of Commons a short time since, in which he said he positively rejoiced at the war in America. I did not think such a sentiment could be uttered by any Englishman. [Cheers.] I am sure I only utter the sentiment of every one here when I say that we deeply grieve that state of things and hope and trust it may soon be brought to a termination, so that peace may reign again on the other side of the Atlantic, and our own suffering population may again have a return of prosperity. [Cheers.]

abstract: Little or nothing has been added to the scant stock of information regarding the recent great battle on the plains of Manassas. A number of gentlemen...
lead_paragraph: Little or nothing has been added to the scant stock of information regarding the recent great battle on the plains of Manassas. A number of gentlemen who participated in the engagement reached this city last evening, but they know absolutely nothing, except that our army had achieved a great victory on the same ground on which it was before victorious on July 21, 1861. They know neither our loss nor the enemy's; the number of prisoners captured by us, nor the route of the enemy's retreat. The most of them say in vague terms that the enemy fled before our men toward Alexandria, or Arlington Heights, or Leesburgh, they don't know which, and they can give no explanation of how he effected a retreat in this direction, our lines being confidently asserted to have extended across all the roads leading to Washington, from Union Mills to Thoroughfare Gap. Some, however, maintain that the enemy retreated through Centreville. If this be true, he must have broke through LONGSTREET's lines on the Warrenton turnpike. But all of LONGSTREET's men with whom we have conversed assert that the enemy, so far from breaking our lines, was driven back a distance of two miles. From all we have been able to learn we think it most likely that the enemy, during Saturday night, escaped toward Alexandria by passing to the east of JACKSON's extreme left. If, in the fight of Saturday, we drove him before us, as there seems little doubt that we did, and there has been no subsequent fight, there were but two ways by which he could have passed our army -- by hugging the Potomac on JACKSON's left, or passing clear around our army by a detour to the westward. But with our present scant information, the discussion of this subject is profitless indeed.

abstract: "Thus far," writes Gen. GEORGE B. McCLELLAN  page 8 of his Military Commission to Europe "the allied Generals displayed none of the qualities of...
lead_paragraph: "Thus far," writes Gen. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN -- page 8 of his Military Commission to Europe -- "the allied Generals displayed none of the qualities of great commanders -- their measures were half-way measures, slow and blundering -- they failed to keep constantly in view the object of the expedition, and to press rapidly and unceasingly toward it." This criticism refers to the period when, on the 27th of September, the allied Generals had got to Sebastopol, having landed their armies on an open beach on the 14th of September, fought and defeated the enemy at the Alma, sent their sick and wounded away, buried their dead, and taken up a position never afterward abandoned till their object was achieved. "Although (he says, page 5) fully aware that it is much easier to criticise operations alter the result is known than to dirrect them at the time, I shall not hesitate to invite attention to what appear the evident mistakes on either side. This not for the purpose of finding fault or of instituting comparisons," (though the very next sentence contains a comparison between the petty operation of landing near Vera Cruz and the disembarcation of the Allies in the [???]) "but with the hope that it may serve to draw its intention of our officers to the same [???] perhaps, assist in [???] similar [???] own part hereafter." It is almost cruel to the young officer to proceed with these quotations, and we shall only add one more: "If a deficiency of men and means is assigned as a reason for the early operations of the Allies, it is but another proof that in undertaking this affair they neglected one of the clearest rules of war -- that is, to undertake no important operation without full and reliable information as to the obstacles to be overcome, and the means of resistance in the hands of the enemy." "We cannot afford," he says, "a Moscow campaign." How little, when he wrote these lines in January, 1857, did the American officer imagine that he should be at the head of an enormous army levied for the purpose of invading a State once incorporated in the country he served, and of destroying the city in which his enemies, once his countrymen, were assembled to defend their homes and their liberties! The deductions he draws from his observations in the crimes are applied to the effect of a foreign invasion or the United States, and he remarks that, though a small army could he crushed by the superior numbers of the people, a force of 100,000 disciplined men would be quite invincible, because the multitude brought to bear against them work their own destruction, for "if without discipline and instruction they cannot be handled, and are in their own way." There is a sort of analogy between Sebastopol and Richmond. Neither Williamsburgh nor White Oaks was quite equal in results to the Alma, it is true, but the covering force was obliged to retire. The enemy blocked up the water entrance to their city; the Federals command the sea, as the Allies did, and they have not been able to force the water batteries. The Confederates are said to be as strong as the Eussians were. Their Gortschakoff is in the field outside. The Federals, too, have been attacked on their right before the place. Are they quite as proud of their Inkerman? Does Gen. McCLELLAN stand the test of his strictures on those who were in a position somewhat like his own? We make the Americans a present of the comparison. The latest news we have from his army is, that it is moving somewhere or other, having made a fiasco in the advance to Malvern Hill. MCCLELLAN has now been more than a month in his place of refuge at Harrison's Landing. At last he "prepared for a great battle." On Tuesday, Aug. 5, he moved out and took possession of Malvern Hill, and sent back for the greater part of his army, but the messengers took the wrong road and the troops did not come up till it was too late. "The enemy were not asleep," but came out in force. Gen. McCLELLAN went back to his camps again, and the Confederates took possession of Malvern hill, and are, we suppose, there now. All that comes from the Federal army, is the same intelligence of great sickness, aggravated by intense heat, and certified by boat loads of sick soldiers, and promises of something going to happen. We must wait with patience for the march of events, which move more rapidly than the Federal arms, as it is nearly always the case that the initiative is taken by the Confederates.

abstract: Editorial notes number of slaves in South who voluntarily stay in bondage while masters are fighting in war; Editorial urges rout of Confederates now on Union soil; Editorial notes Confederate troops need for food and clothing
snippet: Editorial notes number of slaves in South who voluntarily stay in bondage while masters are fighting in war; Editorial urges rout of Confederates now on Union soil; Editorial notes Confederate troops need for food and clothing
lead_paragraph: No one who studies in a philosophic light the scenes and acts of the great drama of civil war now witnessed in this country, can believe that the struggle will cease without affecting a vast, if not a total revolution in the relation previously existing between the white and black races in the South. But yet those who have with most prophetic confidence announced the early delivery of the blacks from bondage, are beginning to be surprised at the dead quiet on this subject that prevails in the South, and the apparent fearlessness with which the rebels rely on the loyalty and labor of their slaves, in the midst of social tumult and the unavoidable demoralization of war.

abstract: Archbishop HUGHES has been and is noted for the paternal interest which he takes in the welfare of children. His addresses to them are marked by a...
lead_paragraph: Archbishop HUGHES has been and is noted for the paternal interest which he takes in the welfare of children. His addresses to them are marked by a simplicity of thought and clearness of word rarely equalled by public men of any age, and his always kindly manner to the poorest and weakest of them has endeared his name and enshrined his memory in the hearts of thousands of the pupils of our schools, and yesterday the children of St. Bridget's Parochial Schools, under charge of the well-known and greatly-beloved Father MOONEY, the Christian Brethren and the Sisters of Charity, prepared a grand surprise for His Grace, and in long procession repaired to his residence for the double purpose of seeing His Reverence and presenting him with a token of their love and regard.
