abstract: The accounts of the position and numbers of the rebels in Maryland are still conflicting so much so that the contradictions can hardly be reconciled, except under the supposition that the...
lead_paragraph: The accounts of the position and numbers of the rebels in Maryland are still conflicting -- so much so that the contradictions can hardly be reconciled, except under the supposition that the several divisions of the rebels have gone in different directions. We are assured on the one hand that JACKSON is on his way with a heavy force to Gettysburgh, Penn., so as to be within striking distance of Chambersburgh and York while on the other hand it is asserted that he has marched to Westminster, and will move on Baltimore in that direction. The National Intelligencer, of yesterday morning, states that the rebels in great force occupied the western bank of Seneca Creek, from its mouth at the Potomac, twenty-two miles above Washington, to Middlebrook Mills -- a line some ten miles in extent. We find very little in the Baltimore papers which throws light on the rebel movements. With regard to the position of our own troops' who, under Gen. MCCLELLAN, are following up the rebels, we have no information, except that they are moving rapidly forward in large force and confident spirits. A short time will probably develop the whereabouts of both armies and enable us to better understand the position of affairs.

abstract: The organization known as the Constitutional Union Party held its State Convention at Troy yesterday, assembling at 1 o'clock P.M. Hon. B...
lead_paragraph: The organization known as the Constitutional Union Party held its State Convention at Troy yesterday, assembling at 1 o'clock P.M. Hon. B.D. NOXON, of Syracuse, was appointed temporary Chairman; and in a short speech set forth the objects of the organization -- a change of rulers, in order to a more speedy ending of the war. Committees on Organization and Credentials were appointed, and the Convention took a recess until 3 o'clock. On reassembling a permanent organization was effected, and a Committee was appointed to consult with the Democratic Convention, to assemble at Albany to-day.

abstract: Editorial cites successful Confederate use of cavalry, particularly Stuart's cavalry, to point up Union need for same
snippet: Editorial cites successful Confederate use of cavalry, particularly Stuart's cavalry, to point up Union need for same
lead_paragraph: The rebels have of late succeeded in deriving from their cavalry, advantages similar to those we long derived from our gunboats. Wherever there was water enough to float one of our armed invincibles, it was sufficient to bring it upon the enemy's flank to secure his discomfiture or surrender. In like manner, the rebel cavalry where they approach a division of our forces in defensive position anywhere, select one wing or the other and charge, turning the flank of our whole force, throwing it into confusion, and forcing a defeat; or else they choose some exposed position in our flank and rear, and by a rapid raid, make themselves masters of it long before reinforcements can be sent.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebels and Their Use of Cavalry.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebels and Their Use of Cavalry.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: editorial on lack of satisfactory information
snippet: editorial on lack of satisfactory information
lead_paragraph: Ample time has elapsed since the burning at sea of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer Golden Gate, yet we are without any satisfactory explanation of that terrible catastrophe. We know, generally, that the alarm of fire was sounded in broad day-light, during calm weather, while the vessel was steaming gaily along within three and a half miles of the shore. We are assured that the ship was amply provided with boats and life-preservers; that her fire apparatus was abundant and in good order; that her officers were cool and collected, exerting their best efforts for the rescue of their human charge from the impending peril; -- and yet we find that about one hundred and seventy-five passengers perished, and only some seventy-five were saved! Among the rescued were only eight women, while twenty-six were lost, and of the children only nine were saved and twenty-one lost!

abstract: The headquarters of Gen. CORCORAN, at the  Astor House, present daily a busy appearance. Officers are constantly coming and going with dispatches, reports, , so that the General and his...
lead_paragraph: The headquarters of Gen. CORCORAN, at the Astor House, present daily a busy appearance. Officers are constantly coming and going with dispatches, reports, &c., so that the General and his Secretaries are kept constantly engaged. Two regiments, which are to be attached to this brigade, are already full, and the others are rapidly filling up. If Gen. HALLECK desires it, Gen. CORCORAN will at once take the field, and enter into active service, as he most earnestly desires, with the two completed regiments, and Col. MCDERMOTT's, which is nearful full. The General and his officers are extremely anxious to be placed in Gen. HUNTER's Division. The following are the regiments that will be attached to Gen. CORCORAN's Brigade:

abstract: Correspondence from the vicinity of the rebel armies, and the reports of all those who visit their lines under flags of truce, concur in...
lead_paragraph: Correspondence from the vicinity of the rebel armies, and the reports of all those who visit their lines under flags of truce, concur in stating that "extreme destitution" prevails among them. The men are found with rags tied around their feet instead of shoes; they are seen eating ears of green corn, cob and all; they search for, pick up and eat the bits of hard bread that our own troops throw away; while for clothing and tents a set of vagabond gipsies would excel them.

abstract: Henry W. Ward vs. Elisha Ruckman and Welcome R. Beebe. The plaintiff obtained a judgment for $600 against the defendants as principal and surety, and execution was issued thereon against Beebe.
lead_paragraph: Henry W. Ward vs. Elisha Ruckman and Welcome R. Beebe. -- The plaintiff obtained a judgment for $600 against the defendants as principal and surety, and execution was issued thereon against Beebe. On the return of the execution unsatisfied, the plaintiff obtained an order to examine Beebe on supplementary proceedings, returnable the 5th inst. On the return day, counsel appeared for Beebe and made objections to the order, which the Court overruled, whereupon plaintiff's counsel moved for an attachment to issue against Beebe for contempt of Court in failing to appear and submit to an examination. The Court granted an order to show cause, returnable the 7th inst., but after the service of such order and before the return day the defendant applied to the Court, and on an affidavit made by himself, as the attorney of his codefendant, Ruckman, that Ruckman had, some time since, obtained a judgment against Ward, the plaintiff, in another proceeding, asked for an order directing him, Beebe, to pay to the Sheriff the amount of that judgment, under the provisions of section 293 of the Code. The Court granted the order, and Beebe paid the amount of such previous judgment to the Sheriff. On the return day of the order to show cause, adjourned from the 7th to the 10th inst., the defendant, Beebe, appeared and offered to pay the balance of the judgment, on being credited with his payments to the Sheriff under the order of the Court abovementioned.

abstract: The public has already been informed of the serious outbreak at Camp Scroggs, near the Red House, on the Harlem road. The uproar began with a general growl on Monday, when an order to pre-...
lead_paragraph: The public has already been informed of the serious outbreak at Camp Scroggs, near the Red House, on the Harlem road. The uproar began with a general growl on Monday, when an order to prepare for departure Southward was promulgated without the expected accompaniment of long-delayed and much-needed back pay. On Tuesday the difficulty culminated, and before midnight, resulted in a complete sack of the regimental headquarters, and a promiscuous affray, in which some of the participants passed a disagreeable half-hour.

abstract: The position occupied by the rebel invaders of Maryland becomes better defined. We earn from our correspondent at Harper's Ferry that none of the horde has made its appearance in the neighborhood of that cardinal...
lead_paragraph: The position occupied by the rebel invaders of Maryland becomes better defined. We earn from our correspondent at Harper's Ferry that none of the horde has made its appearance in the neighborhood of that cardinal position; a circumstance indicating that for the present, at least, the advance into Western Pennsylvania is postponed. On the east, Gen. MCCLELLAN has occupied Barnesville, in the immediate neighborhood of the Monocacy, not far from the point where that stream pours into the Potomac. An advance toward Washington and Baltimore is thus pretty effectually barred; and alarm about the instant and urgent danger of those two capitals reasonably quieted. The rebel strength appears for the moment to be concentrated between the Catoctin and the Monocacy. At the head of the ridge dividing the two creeks the advance of the invading army has already shown itself, no further than eight miles distant from the Pennsylvania line; while to the right of this column, raids and demonstrations push hourly nearer the railroad connecting Philadelphia with Baltimore. Whatever may be the ultimate meaning of the rebel movements, it suffices for the present to know that Central Pennsylvania, with the capital of the Commonwealth, are threatened on the one hand, while there is great danger of the rebels getting to Havre de Grace, where the indispensable line of communications between Washington and the North may most conveniently be severed. In short, having cut off Washington from direct intercourse with the West by seizing the Baltimore and Ohio road, the next step has been to possess themselves of other lines of communication with the loyal States. There were but two of these, the Northern Central and the Philadelphia and Baltimore lines. The Northern Central is already in their hands. We are at present unadvised of any steps on the part of the National Government to save the only remaining line, that through Philadelphia, from a similar appropriation.

lead_paragraph: The Democratic State Convention met in Albany yesterday, the attendance being very large Hon. HENRY C. MURPHY, of Kings, was temporary Chairman, and ALONZO C. PAIGE, of Schenectady, permanent Chairman. After some preliminary business, Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR was nominated by acclamation for Governor, amid great enthusiasm. After a speech by Mr. SEYMOUR, and another by FERNANDO WOOD, the Convention adjourned until 10 o'clock this morning.

abstract: "The King is dead, long live the King." Ethan Allen is beaten. Hurrah for Robert Fillingham! For weeks the entire sporting community has been on  the tiptoe of expectancy, the verge of curiosity, and the anxious seat of determination, concerning an an-...
lead_paragraph: "The King is dead, long live the King." Ethan Allen is beaten. Hurrah for Robert Fillingham! For weeks the entire sporting community has been on the tiptoe of expectancy, the verge of curiosity, and the anxious seat of determination, concerning an announced match for $10,000, between the Morgan stallion Ethan Allen and a Hamiltonian stallion, with the ridiculous cognomen of Robert Fillingham. Private showings, it was said, had developed wonderful speed in Robert, and a report was current that he had made his little mile in 2 min. 18 sec., all of which was very far from being believed, though it went far toward making public sentiment.

abstract: A secret meeting of the National War Committee was held in the City Hall, yesterday, Mayor OPDYKE in the Chair, during which the correspondence between the Mayor and Gen. FREMONT in regard to the proposed raising of 50,000 men, to be placed under the command of Gen. FREMONT, was submitted. Gen. FREMONT, it appears, expressed his willingness to accept the proposed command, but the Secretary of War, in a letter in reply to the resolutions of the Committee, says that the raising of volunteers has been assigned to the Governors of the States, and no other officer could be allowed to interfere with his authority.

abstract: Editorial deplores military officers becoming politicians; says their sole objective should be to defeat enemy
snippet: Editorial deplores military officers becoming politicians; says their sole objective should be to defeat enemy
lead_paragraph: The worst result of incapacity on the part of the civil authority in times of peril and disaster such as now beset our country, is the hasty and desperate resort to military leaders for counsel and command, which such incapacity is almost sure to breed. The experience of the world is full of instances of national ruin thus precipitated, and although we have no positive fear of any similar catastrophe as impending directly upon ourselves, still we think it well to note the least beginnings of evil in this as in all other directions. What policy the Government of the Union shall pursue in dealing finally with the great rebellion, is still a legitimate matter of discussion for loyal men who are determined only that suppressed the rebellion shall be, and if it shall appear on grave and full consideration, that the life of the nation can only be preserved by the death of Slavery, he is a traitor double-dyed who would oppose the exhibition of the decisive remedy, be its operation never so painful and never so stern. It is necessary, therefore, for us to call the attention of the loyal public to the insidious efforts which are making in certain quarters to create a sort of vague and passionate public feeling in favor of the usurpation by "Constitutional" Generals of absolute control over the issues of this war. Hints have been recently thrown out in one and another quarter, of the "determination" which is said to exist in "military quarters" to assume the control of public affairs rather than permit that control to pass into the hands of "Abolition schemers," the said "schemers," so far as we can understand, being the legally constituted political representatives of sundry loyal States of the Union. This talk may be idle -- it is certainly dangerous and disgraceful, so far as it means or can mean anything at all. The military arm of the Republic is its arm and not its head. The final voice upon the policy of the great struggle we are making rests with the people and their representatives. It cannot and it shall not be taken from them by any clique whatever, be that clique Executive or Military. The people of the United States intend to be victorious in this war upon which they have staked such tremendous values of treasure and of life. They intend to preserve not only the present unity, but the self-respect, the liberty, and the future of the nation, and they intend to preserve these, at whatevar cost to local institutions and provincial passions. From the rank and file of the National Army they have no fears. These men are blood of their blood, and one flesh with them. But if (which we by no means yet believe) there exist among the accidental leaders of the army any disposition to mistake the objects of their commission, any delusion as to the power vested in them, and any tendency to believe that the American people of the Free States will accept a military settlement of their score with the rebellion, patched up without reference to the convictions of any great section of the Free States, it will be well for the victims of so perilous a hallucination to emancipate themselves at once from its fatal sway. We have had enough of the cobbler transgressing his last. We have suffered enough from politicians assuming to be Generals. We have not so much patience left as will tolerate experiments of State made by Generals turned politicians. Our commanders in the field have one plain duty to do -- to find and beat the armies of the rebellion. They have not done this work yet so handsomely that we can afford to spare them for new exertions in another quarter. And when they shall have done it, the issues of victory, we beg leave emphatically to say, will remain to be controlled by the people themselves, and by the explicit delegates of their explicit will.

abstract: At a time when so many thousands of our sick and wounded soldiers appeal to our sympathies for aid, and when the resources of the whole country are drawn upon to supply their wants, every article of large consumption in our hospitals becomes a matter of serious consideration.
lead_paragraph: At a time when so many thousands of our sick and wounded soldiers appeal to our sympathies for aid, and when the resources of the whole country are drawn upon to supply their wants, every article of large consumption in our hospitals becomes a matter of serious consideration. The ingenuity and industry of the North have proven to be quite equal to the task of supplying nearly every necessary substance used by the surgeon or physician, with the exception of those rare drugs which are the growth of other climes only. All the ordinary articles of hospital use we can ourselves furnish, by far the greater proportion of them of better confection too than those imported from abroad. This discovery has been fully made since the beginning of the present war, whose ravages are still daily revealing to us fresh capacities and resources, the existence of which was only conjectured or hoped for before.

abstract: In a late note of Secretary  SEWARD'S to Mr. GAMBLE, of Cincinnati, mention was made of a circular addressed by him to our diplomatic agents in Europe, instructing them to set forth the inducements afford-...
lead_paragraph: -- In a late note of Secretary SEWARD's to Mr. GAMBLE, of Cincinnati, mention was made of a circular addressed by him to our diplomatic agents in Europe, instructing them to set forth the inducements afforded in the United States to the advent of industrious foreign laborers and artisans. We find this interesting document in the Liverpool Post, and reproduce it among our European extracts. That journal accompanies it with a highly approbatory article, in which it urges the value of the offer to Lancashire and Ireland at this moment. Half a million workmen are starving in Lancashire; an equal number in Ireland -- a million of human beings, eager to work, are excluded from it.

abstract: All goes well with our splendid new Reservoir. From the moment the water was turned into it, there has not been a break or hindrance in the stream which is pouring in at the rate of a foot of bulk per diem. Both sections of the Reservoir should hold a billion gallons of water, the maximum height of the fluid allowed in the calculation being 36 feet. One section now contains 15 feet of the sparkling element, and there being perfect assurance that all the arrangements are complete, both sections will speedily be filled.

abstract: If a great fire were to break out to-day on Broadway, the Fire Department would not call out fifty thousand men to extinguish it. The men might all be able-bodied, earnest to...
lead_paragraph: If a great fire were to break out to-day on Broadway, the Fire Department would not call out fifty thousand men to extinguish it. The men might all be able-bodied, earnest to do their part, willing to receive orders, and ready to obey. They would rush to the spot with alacrity, and ask only to be told what to do. But these numbers and this zeal would not extinguish the fire. It would only insure its aggravation. The men would soon be in confusion -- they would get in each other's way -- they would not understand the use of hose, bucket or ladder, and before they learned their task or could settle themselves into working gangs, the fire would have accomplished its devastation. But if only a Fire Brigade were called out, and room allowed them for work, a few hours would find them victors over the devouring element. Such is the advantage of skill and discipline over mere numbers and naked force.

abstract: The famous Massachusetts Sixth Regiment the same that was attacked by the mob in the streets of Baltimore an the 19th of April, 1861 arrived in this City yesterday, on their way to the seat of war, having enlisted under the call for nine months' militia.
lead_paragraph: The famous Massachusetts Sixth Regiment -- the same that was attacked by the mob in the streets of Baltimore an the 19th of April, 1861 -- arrived in this City yesterday, on their way to the seat of war, having enlisted under the call for nine months' militia. They came in the steamboat Plymouth Rock, from Stonington, and were escorted from the wharf to the Park Barracks by a deputation of the Sons of Massachusetts, which would have been much larger had it not been for a misunderstanding as to the place the regiment was to land.

abstract: The One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Regiment of New-York State Volunteers, known as the "Monitors," left their camp yesterday afternoon for the seat of war by the way of Elizabethport, N.J.
lead_paragraph: The One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Regiment of New-York State Volunteers, known as the "Monitors," left their camp yesterday afternoon for the seat of war by the way of Elizabethport, N.J. The Monitors have been encamped for several weeks past near the old Quarantine Ground, Staten Island, and they were taken directly from there to Elizabethport in the steamer Red Jacket. This regiment, in respect to the character and standing of its members, is probably the best that has yet been raised in this City. It originated in the Christian Young Men's Association, whose design, at first, was to recruit a company simply, which should be composed of young men desirous of avoiding the evil associations which too often attend camp life; but recruits came in so rapidly that it was concluded to raise a regiment. This was soon done, and the corps now numbers 970 men. Another regiment started on the same plan, is now recruiting in Brooklyn, with every prospect of similar success.

abstract: The Government Hospital for sick and wounded soldiers, established during the past season on David's Island, is getting to be an institution of such magnitude and importance as to deserve a more extended notice than it has yet received from the public Press.
lead_paragraph: The Government Hospital for sick and wounded soldiers, established during the past season on David's Island, is getting to be an institution of such magnitude and importance as to deserve a more extended notice than it has yet received from the public Press. Already the largest in the United States, its accommodations are rapidly increasing, and its location sanitary advantages, and general management, are such as to justly entitle it to the distinction of being in every respect a model institution of its kind.

abstract: We are still without reliable intelligence of the movements of the rebel forces in Maryland, though we have plenty of rumors and conjectures.
lead_paragraph: We are still without reliable intelligence of the movements of the rebel forces in Maryland, though we have plenty of rumors and conjectures. The Baltimore American, of yesterday, says the enemy are scouting in the neighborhood of Frederick for horses, cattle, &c., and that they will probably enter Pennsylvania, if sufficient time is afforded them. The National Intelligencer announces that they have fallen back before Gen. MCCLELLAN's advance, which had on Tuesday afternoon reached to within six miles of Poolesville. A dispatch from Harrisburgh, received late last night, states that the rebels, under JACKSON, entered Hagerstown in force yesterday afternoon. The telegraph operator is stated to have left as the rebels were entering the town. Accounts relative to the presence of the rebels before Washington are conflicting, and the opinion prevails to a considerable extent that the movement into Maryland and toward Pennsylvania is only a feint to cover an advance upon the Capital. A short time will probably develop the true condition of affairs.

abstract: The indefatigable daughters of this threatened Union, that are putting through matters for the creature comfort of our soldiers, at No.11 Cooper Union, certainly have earned for their place of business the above title.
lead_paragraph: The indefatigable daughters of this threatened Union, that are putting through matters for the creature comfort of our soldiers, at No.11 Cooper Union, certainly have earned for their place of business the above title. Ten or fifteen ladies, assisted by the manual labor of several of the sterner sex, have, during the last ten days, unpacked, repacked and sent off to our army hospitals, no less than five hundred boxes of stores and clothing. The neglected few who were left upon the field of Bull Run, in the confusion of affairs, were first relieved by aid received through the Sanitary Commission, from the various country societies of our own State. These country associations have never shown so much interest as at present, when the most urgent demand is made upon their sympathy and active cooperation. On Saturday last 79 boxes were received at No. 11, and an average of 60 have arrived every day since. Applications are constantly being made to the Executive Committee by persons resident of the adjacent counties, to suggest ways by which associate organizations may be formed in their neighborhoods. It would seem that the country is alive with sympathy, and aroused to any extent of self-sacrifice for our noble cause and suffering heroes.

abstract: THE ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-NINTH REGIMENT. This regiment, familiarly known to our citizens as the Second Senatorial Regiment, received orders yesterday to proceed to the seat of war forthwith. The day previous the officers and men were formally mustered into the service by the United States mustering officer, Major JONES.
lead_paragraph: THE ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-NINTH REGIMENT. -- This regiment, familiarly known to our citizens as the Second Senatorial Regiment, received orders yesterday to proceed to the seat of war forthwith. The day previous the officers and men were formally mustered into the service by the United States mustering officer, Major JONES. The companies averaged eighty-two men each, making a total of 820, exclusive of officers. The uniforms and equipments were distributed yesterday afternoon, and every arrangement was made to start at once. The Union Ferry Company generously offered the use of one if their boats, by which the regiment will be conveyed in the foot of Canal-street, New-York, where they are to embark on an ocean steamer. They were to have left last evening, but were unable to get away. They will embark this morning. The following is a list of the principal officers:

abstract: It has already been stated by one of our regular correspondents at Hilton Head, in a letter which we published yesterday, that President LINCOLN has sent out orders to that Department to organize, drill and arm a body of 5,000 negroes, and to organize 50,000 more, ostensibly to be employed as laborers, but probably with a view to their use, sooner or later, as soldiers. In view of the previous action of the President on this subject, such an announcement will very naturally excite some surprise, and lead to inquiry as to its meaning. Without trying, at present, to satisfy curiosity on this point, we beg to direct attention to another which it seems to involve.

abstract: Parties coming direct from Poolesville and Barnesville, report that a large force of rebels under JACKSON crossed the Potomac last Thursday at a point near the mouth of the Monocacy River. On the following day another force, under LONGSTREET,  crossed at the same point. Gen. PLEASANTON, Chief of Cavalry, has received information corroborating the above statement. It is estimated that the rebels have no less than 50,000 men on the Maryland side of the Potomac.

abstract: There is no doubt that the rebels occupied Hagerstown, Maryland, in force, yesterday evening. They are estimated at twenty thousand strong, with forty-eight pieces of artillery. Since then their movements are unreported, as the telegraph operator left that locality.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that the rebels occupied Hagerstown, Maryland, in force, yesterday evening. They are estimated at twenty thousand strong, with forty-eight pieces of artillery. Since then their movements are unreported, as the telegraph operator left that locality. The exact whereabouts of our forces is not known, but it is announced that Gen. MCCLELLAN had on Wednesday advanced as far as Damascus, thirty-four miles from Washington. Gen. BURNSIDE is supposed to be operating in some other direction.

abstract: The public awaits, with breathless interest, the progress of the rebel invasion of the loyal States. It is universally felt, that, if it be met with the vigor and ability which the crisis demands, the rebels will have been betrayed by their rashness to their destruction.
lead_paragraph: The public awaits, with breathless interest, the progress of the rebel invasion of the loyal States. It is universally felt, that, if it be met with the vigor and ability which the crisis demands, the rebels will have been betrayed by their rashness to their destruction. They have advanced far from their base of operations, and by a long line, which exposes their flank to the enemy, and renders a defeat, properly followed up, equivalent to their destruction. The first impulse of every one is to predict their utter annihilation; and this would be the general feeling of the public but for the frequent and terrible trials to which its faith has been subjected during the past year. Our people have made up their minds to indulge more moderate expectations in regard to military movements, hereafter, and not to exult in victory before the battle has actually been fought.

abstract: Editorial on views of French newspaper Paris Moniteur
snippet: Editorial on views of French newspaper Paris Moniteur
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN QUESTION. -- The Paris Moniteur has been for some time past publishing a series of letters concerning military operations in the United States, written by a man evidently conversant with his subject. These letters, which have attracted a great deal of attention, have been reproduced by the majority of the French newspapers at Paris and in the provinces. Lately, however, a partiality for the North, which was at first perceptible in these comments, disappeared. The South gradually gained ground in the mind of the writer, and soon his correspondence clearly indicated a change of views and sentiments, which, owing to the official character of the paper in which they were inserted, affected more or less the other organs of the Press. In one of its latest issues, the Moniteur, as if it wanted to remove all doubts about its conversion, translated and indorsed an article in the London Times, in which that paper advises Mr. LINCOLN to give up the prosecution of the present war, and to make peace with the South. These various symptomshave been interpreted by the Secessionists and their friends as a tendency on the part of the French Government to favor their cause, and as preliminary to the recognition of the Southern Confederacy. It will require a few weeks to determine how nearly correct this impression may be.

abstract: The match between officers of the British Army.  from Canada, and cricketers of the United States,  was resumed yesterday morning, at Hoboken, with Lieut. Patten and Capt. Slate at the wickets, who were not out, and well in for 38 runs on the previous  evening. The play was opened with great spirit on
lead_paragraph: The match between officers of the British Army. from Canada, and cricketers of the United States, was resumed yesterday morning, at Hoboken, with Lieut. Patten and Capt. Slate at the wickets, who were not out, and well in for 38 runs on the previous evening. The play was opened with great spirit on both sides, the fielding being sharp, and the bowling of Creighton -- underhand -- and Sadler -- round-arm -- quite effective, while H. Wright kept wicked; the result was that the change of bowling and ill lack on the part of some of the officers together with some fine catches by the fielders, brought the innings to a close for 84 runs. In Lieut. Patten's 27 were three 4s, a 2 and singles, well got. Capt. Slade's 23 comprised a 4, three 3s a 2 and singles, in obtaining which some very fine play was shown. Capt. Phillips played well for a 2 and three singles, and Capt. Beresfords 6 were got by a 2 and 4; the rest did nothing. Sadler's 5 wickets were obtained at an expenditure of 60 balls for 21 runs; Creighton's, 5 wickets for 60 balls and 16 runs. The United States sent in Messrs. Sharp and Hudson to the bowling of Messrs. Cholmely and Hamilton; the bowling was not up to the previous day's play, and it was consequently mastered by the batsmen, and Mr. Cholmely was changed for Capt. Slade, and again for Capt. Pemberton, who was remarkably fast, and at times rather wide of the wickets -- the byes counting up in consequence. Mr. Cholmely was again put on, and remained till the match terminated -- as it did in favor of the United States, with five wickets to go down. Mr. Hamilton was not changed during the match. The wicket-keeping was in no way to be compared to that of the day previous, as Sharp ought to have been caught three times, H. Wright once, easy, and Mr. Gibbes once from a sharp chance. The fieldings were not as good as on the first day, with the exception of Capt. Phillips at point, whose fielding drew down repeated applause.

abstract: A NEW BAPTIST CHURCH.--The corner-stone of the new edifice for the Bloomingdale Baptist Church in Forty-second-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, was laid yesterday with appropriate ceremonies. The building will measure 98 feet 9 ...
lead_paragraph: A NEW BAPTIST CHURCH. -- The corner-stone of the new edifice for the Bloomingdale Baptist Church in Forty-second-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, was laid yesterday with appropriate ceremonies. The building will measure 98 feet 9 inches long by 61 feet wide, and will be two stories high. The basement will be 11 1/2 feet high, and will be devoted to Sabbath-school and lecture-room purposes. The auditorum will be 35 1/2 feet high, and will seat one thousand persons. The front will be of Dorchester stone, and the remainder of brick. HENRY VOLK & Co. are the masons, and D. GRINSTEAD does the carpenter work. In the box which was deposited in the corner-stone, was placed the box which has for nineteen years remained in a perfect state of preservation in the corner-stone of the Old Church, corner of Forty-third-street. To the old records were added the names of the present officers, as follows: Pastor -- Rev. Isaac Westcott, Deacons -- M. Stamels, A. Lathrop, J. Sparks, Wm. H. Dean, Trustees -- F.B. Grist, President; Richard Mott, Secretary; S.T. Smith, Treasurer; J.B. Niblo, Jas M. Deitz, Jas. A. Allen, Jas. Scott, Jas. Van Buren Wm. Wilson. The church and lot will cost about $50,000, and be finished about May next. The foundations are laid, and the upper walls are in a fair state of progres. Among the clergymen present, and participating in the exercises, were Dr. Wescott, Dr. Dowling, Rev. Mr. Weston, Rev. Mr. Bucklin, Rev. Mr. Pendleton, and others. The platform was tastefully decorated with flags, and a large audience assembled to witness the interesting occasion.

abstract: Another splendid regiment from Gov. SPRAGUE'S small, but gallant State, passed through the City yesterday, on its way to the seat of war. Quite early in the morning not much past 7 o'clock this regiment,the Seventh Rhode Island, arrived. By 10 o'clock they were aboard the cars on the Camden and Amboy Railroad.
lead_paragraph: Another splendid regiment from Gov. SPRAGUE's small, but gallant State, passed through the City yesterday, on its way to the seat of war. Quite early in the morning -- not much past 7 o'clock -- this regiment,the Seventh Rhode Island, arrived. By 10 o'clock they were aboard the cars on the Camden and Amboy Railroad. The Tenth Rhode Island is a full regiment, mustering near a thousand men, and is magnificently armed and equipped. It is commanded by Col. ZENAS R. BLISS, who is a graduate of West Point, and has served as Captain in the regular army. The Lieutenant-Colonel is W.B. SAYLES, formerly editor of the Providence Daily Post. The Major and other officers have smelt gunpowder. The Doctor has been a prisoner in Richmond, and is an efficient and experienced surgeon. Subjoined is a list of the [???] and staff:

abstract: New-Jersey, in his address to the Line officers of the State Militia, has set an example which the other Governors would do well to imitate. They are about to select the Field officers of the regiments into which their companies are to be organized; and he addresses them in a sort of judicial charge, setting forth the high responsibility involved in the choice, pointing out that none but the purest and most patriotic motives should be allowed to influence them, and urging upon them the importance of selecting for their officers only the best and most competent men. Gov. OLDEN has done well to direct attention to this momentous matter, and the spirit of his counsel should be heeded wherever a regiment is being officered.

abstract: All uniformed and ununiformed recruits of Gen. MEAGHER'S Irish Brigade, now in this City, have been notified, by Special Order, to report at the head recruiting office, No. 398 Broadway, on this and tomorrow (Saturday) mornings, to receive State and City bounties, and be sent on to their brigade.
lead_paragraph: All uniformed and ununiformed recruits of Gen. MEAGHER's Irish Brigade, now in this City, have been notified, by Special Order, to report at the head recruiting office, No. 398 Broadway, on this and tomorrow (Saturday) mornings, to receive State and City bounties, and be sent on to their brigade. By the way, it is important and should be known -- for the sake of the wives and families, as well as of the poor recruits themselves -- that the bounties given to Gen. MEAGHER's Brigade exceed by $50 -- the State allowance -- those given to all other organizations, save the other old regiments being recruited for amongst us. No new organizations -- and they are most numerous around us -- can draw the State bounty. It is reserved and paid alone to those gallant State volunteers who fought throughout the past year, and who, with pride speak of what conflicts they have been through. To such standards as tell of our triumphs from Fair Oaks to Malvern Hill patriotic recruits should rally; and it is to the men who have periled all in a dozen battles that our merchant-princes should give relief. The officers of Gen. MEAGHER's Brigade say, with pride, that they have never begged for assistance. That is right of them, but as the State, in giving them the additional fifty dollars, recognizes their preeminent claims, so ought the patriotic and wealthy merchants; and recruits themselves should recollect where the largest bounties are to be had. Col. NUGENT, who has been in charge of the recruiting since Gen. MEAGHER's departure, is daily in expectation of other recruiting officers from the brigade, when he will at once return to the command of his regiment.

abstract: rebel army which has advanced so boldly from Tennessee and across the entire State of Kentucky, is still menacing Cincinnati, which seems to be enjoying a renewal of the panic it had ten days ago. All the arms-bearing citizens of Cincinnati are mustered into service and nearly the whole fighting population of the State of Ohio seems to have rushed to the relief of the State's chief city. There cannot certainly be less than seventy-five thousand men now in the immediate vicinity of Cincinnati ready for its defence. Nevertheless, the rebels are pushing up to it boldly, and the telegraph this morning announces that they are only about two miles from our lines, and that yesterday they drove in our pickets. Beside the troops in front of the invading rebel army, the loyal Kentuckians on its flank and in its rear are rushing to arms; and if any less than twenty-five thousand Kentucky Unionists have shouldered their rifles since their State was entered by the invaders, there must be tremendous exaggerations in the statements made and published in Kentucky. In addition to these raw troops which have been hastily got together for the occasion, Gen. BUELL has an army far in the rear of the invaders, which, a fortnight ago, was sixty, and is now nearly ninety thousand strong; and Gen. GRANT has enough men in Memphis to make a round hundred thousand upon this line. Take it all in all, in front and rear, and there are certainly not less than two hundred thousand Union soldiers in position, to-day, to advance upon the rebels who have so audaciously marched into the bowels of Kentucky without impediment. How big the invading rebel force may be we have no means of precisely knowing, but we do not believe that KIRBY SMITH, HUMPHEY MARSHALL, and all the other rebel commanders between the Cumberland Mountains and the Ohio River could muster fifty thousand men. This force is mostly the fragments of BEAUREGARD's old army at Corinth, which, according to his own intercepted dispatch, was but 35,000 strong, and which melted away like mist, added to some recent victims of the rebel conscription, and the recruits who have been obtained in Kentucky.

abstract: We mentioned a few days since the fact of a habeas corpus being issued by Judge SHARLEY, in Vermont, in the case of a person charged with discouraging enlistments and arrested therefor. We see by the Cooperstown Republican, that a similar case has arisen in this Slate, Judge NELSON having also issued a habeas corpus in favor of a man named HERKIMER, who was arrested for aiding in removing his son and another beyond the reach of the draft, and for discouraging enlistments.

abstract: THE MURDER AT SEACAUCUS. The inquest on the body of JOHN EISELE, who was murdered at Seacaocus, N.J., on Tuesday morning last, was adjourned to-day, (Thursday,) until to-morrow afternoon. Three or four young men who were on a
lead_paragraph: THE MURDER AT SEACAUCUS. -- The inquest on the body of JOHN EISELE, who was murdered at Seacaocus, N.J., on Tuesday morning last, was adjourned to-day, (Thursday,) until to-morrow afternoon. Three or four young men who were on a carousal at ENGELLERECHT's house with the supposed murderer, were subpoenaed to be present at the inquest, but from some cause failed to make their appearance, Coroner BOHNSTEDT issued a warrant for the arrest of the soldier, WASHINGTON MASTERS, against whom there is strong grounds for suspicion that he is the guilty party, and placed it in the hands of Chief of Police GILSTON, of Hoboken, and Constable DAVIS. The officers at once proceeded to New-York, where it is supposed that MASTERS is lurking, and will use every effort for his arrest. MASTERS is about five feet eleven inches in heighth; rather slim built, dark complexion, dark hair, stoops slightly.

abstract: Since the war commenced, the American Tract Society has expended nearly $40,000 in furnishing religious reading for the Army and Navy, a most blessed work in its known results. To meet the constant and most urgent appeals now made to the Committee for the new troops, and the thousands of sick and wounded in the hospitals, at least $30,000 is needed. Every dollar received for this purpose will be promptly expended in supplying these brave men with instruetive, sustaining and comforting truth. Two hundred publications have been issued expressly for them by the Society. They need, deserve and will appreciate our effort. The Committee plead for immediate aid. Without it they cannot meet the hourly and earnest calls made upon them. May we not ask pastors of churches to make special collections for this object; and all who love their country and the souls of her soldiery to forward their benefactions, great or small, to O.R. KINGSBURY, Assistant Treasurer, No. 150 Nassau-street, New-York.

lead_paragraph: Recruits for the various regiments connected with this brigade are coming in thick and fast. During the whole of Wednesday the recruiting stations were crowded, and the recruiting officers were busy in making out the papers preparatory to the men being examined and mustered into the service of the United States. It is requested that all persons who wish to hold personal communication with the General -- excepting commanding officers, and officers connected with the brigade -- will call on him between the hours of 10 and 12 A.M. Dr. DWYER has been officially notified that he has been nominated regimental surgeon of the Sixty-ninth. abstract: Judging from the Baltimore papers of this morning, quite as little definite is known in that city of the numbers and movements of the rebel army in Maryland as is known here, outside of the War Department.
lead_paragraph: Judging from the Baltimore papers of this morning, quite as little definite is known in that city of the numbers and movements of the rebel army in Maryland as is known here, outside of the War Department. We feel sure that the authorities here are constantly in receipt of the most contradictory in formation upon both those points of so absorbing interest just now. The unreliability of estimates made by persons who are not experts, relative to the number of forces, was never better exemplified than on this occasion; some estimating a force passing under their view at five thousand or ten, while others set the same force down as being a hundred thousand strong. The Government here and Gen. MCCLELLAN, we apprehend, are prepared for a due reception of quite the latter number in Maryland, and we think our military authorities believe there are that number either over the river, or ready to ford it at an hour's notice.

abstract: Editorial on war in Maryland
snippet: Editorial on war in Maryland
lead_paragraph: The hatless, shoeless, coatless army of the rebel Gen. LEE, about whose movements and intentions so much vague speculation has for a week past exercised the calm observers of passing events in Washington, are at last beginning to exhibit their presence and their purposes with a plainness which ought to open the eyes even of the most self-satisfied military critic in that abode of strong delusions. This "rabble rout," whose passage of the Potomac we were gravely notified by telegraph, was regarded with satisfaction in "well-informed circles," has so far established itself in the very heart of Maryland that its leader -- the commanding General, be it noted, of the whole Confederate army -- has thought the time ripe for issuing his proclamation to the people of that State. That any man in his senses should read this proclamation and fail to appreciate the extent of the peril with which the Republic is now threatened, would surprise us, had not the faculty of astonishment been well high exhausted by the events of the last eighteen months.
headline: {'main': 'The Ragged Raid of Lee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Ragged Raid of Lee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Wednesday was a gala day at the camp of the Stanton Legion at New-Dorp, Staten Island. The men who have heretofore belonged to two regiments, were cosolidated into the one, (the One Hundred and Fortyfifth New-York,) and the preparations were in active progress to proceed to the seat of war on Friday next. Many of the line officer s have been transferred.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was a gala day at the camp of the Stanton Legion at New-Dorp, Staten Island. The men who have heretofore belonged to two regiments, were cosolidated into the one, (the One Hundred and Fortyfifth New-York,) and the preparations were in active progress to proceed to the seat of war on Friday next. Many of the line officer s have been transferred, and will remain behind to recruit the second regiment, which is expected to start soon for the seat of war. The announcement that several presentations would take place attracted a very large attendance of families and friends of members of the regiment, among whom were many, very many, young and fair representatives of the gentler sex. The fact of Col. ALLEN's former connection with the Seventh Regiment brought many friends of that favorite corps, and, altogether, the assemblage was one of which any regiment might well be proud. About 3 P.M. the Legion was paraded, with nearly a thousand men in the ranks, and was reviewed by Col. ALLEN. They were without muskets, and only partially uniformed, but presented a very creditable drill in the marchings. At the conclusion of the parade, regimental line was formed at parade rest, when a series of presentations took place.

abstract: There is something imperatively required in the thousands of new officers that are now being ushered into service beside a familiarity with HARDEE, and an ability to pass the examining board. We are not sure that common
lead_paragraph: There is something imperatively required in the thousands of new officers that are now being ushered into service beside a familiarity with HARDEE, and an ability to pass the examining board. We are not sure that common sense and social respectability should carry more weight in the selection of officers than a knowledge of tactics, but we are sure that an officer who is to be intrusted with the lives of one hundred men, or of one thousand, should know enough to preserve their health in camp as well as to save them upon the field.

During the day the City
lead_paragraph: DEPARTURE OF THE SECOND SENATORIAL REGIMENT FOR THE SEAT OF WAR. -- This Regiment, designated as the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth, finally left Camp Arthur, near the Navy-yard, last evening, and after marching up Nassau to Bridge-street, up Myrtle-avenue to Pearl-street, and down Pearl to the river, embarked on the Union Ferry-boat Montague, by which they were conveyed to an ocean steamer at the foot of Canal-street. During the day the City Park, in which the regiment was encamped, presented a busy and exciting scene. Thousands of persons thronged the inclosure, many the wives and relatives of the soldiers, who came to bid them good bye. The men were provided with overcoats, knapsacks, canteens and three days' rations. Meantime the officers assembled at the headquarters, corner of Nassau-street aud Hudson-avenue, and presented Col. CONK with an elegant sword, sash, belt and haversack. A brief address was made by Dr. THOMAS P. NORMS, and an appropriate and patriotic response on behalf of the recipient, by S.D. MORRIS, Esq. During the day, a sword was also presented to Capt. THOMAS MULCAHY, of Company K.

abstract: Hardly had the news of the wreck of the United States steam sloop-of-war Adirondack been confirmed, when the South Carolina is reported to have gone down. For several days no intelligence has been received confirming or contradicting the painful announcement, and naval people have begun to give up all hopes of hearing of the vessel again. It should be
lead_paragraph: Hardly had the news of the wreck of the United States steam sloop-of-war Adirondack been confirmed, when the South Carolina is reported to have gone down. For several days no intelligence has been received confirming or contradicting the painful announcement, and naval people have begun to give up all hopes of hearing of the vessel again. It should be borne in mind, however, that the Niagara, Sabine, Seminole, Congress and Wabash were all, at different times, reported lost, when they were actually on their way to their designed destination. The saddest part of the rumor about the South Carolina, is the fact that no particulars are given even of the safety of her officers and crew. It is stated merely that "she followed, too accurately, the fatal lead of the Adirondack." The fact that Capt. GANESVOORT, of the latter, and Capt. ALMY, of the South Carolina, were especially detached from the Brooklyn Navy-yard for the express purpose of commanding both the vessels named, which were finished out, previous to their last voyage, in the most careful manner, adds interest to the report.

abstract: questioning whether Confederate goal is to take Philadelphia, then NY and Boston
snippet: questioning whether Confederate goal is to take Philadelphia, then NY and Boston
lead_paragraph: The persistency of the rebel leaders in their advance upon Pennsylvania gives ground for the belief that they do in reality expect to occupy the City of Philadelphia, and then in due course of time the cities of New-York and Boston. The vainglorious boasts of the rebels that such was to be the closing scenes of their campaign against the North have always passed as mere gasconade, sound and fury signifying nothing.

abstract: The rebels' eight days' military occupancy of Maryland does not serve to develop, in other than hazy outline, the programme which they aim to carry out in this audacious raid on the soil of the loyal States.
lead_paragraph: The rebels' eight days' military occupancy of Maryland does not serve to develop, in other than hazy outline, the programme which they aim to carry out in this audacious raid on the soil of the loyal States. Indeed, without more definite knowledge than we at present possess of the magnitude of the invading army, it is impossible to form a precise idea of the leading object of the movement. If the force were but a limited one, the motive at first assigned to the raid would be all-sufficient -- namely, that the army which crossed the river were to act as purveyors, sending over supplies to the main body on the other side of the Potomac, who should keep guard while the others rifled the house. This notion is not borne out by the facts. For, first, it is known that though supply trains of the rebels have for days continued to cross into Maryland, none are known to return. And, secondly, the rebel army have pushed their advance so far North, and left their rear so unguarded, as to preclude the possibility, even if they had the desire, of keeping their lines of communication open with a force on the south side of the Potomac. If, on the other hand, the rebel army in Maryland be really of the formidable proportions now represented -- if it number anything like a hundred thousand men -- it is vain to blink the inference to which their audacious advance leads up. They have, in that case, given up all care for communication with the Potomac; and having, as CORTES did when he burned his ships, voluntarily cut themselves off from retreat, they are now determined to push their invasive march on to the great State of Pennsylvania.

abstract: It is known to but few persons that the Police Commissioners have in the course of construction and in a fair way toward completion, a splendid model Police headquarters, which then intend shall surpass everything of the kind in the world.
lead_paragraph: It is known to but few persons that the Police Commissioners have in the course of construction and in a fair way toward completion, a splendid model Police headquarters, which then intend shall surpass everything of the kind in the world. They have not applied to the Supervisors or the Legislature for permission to build or for the money to defray the expense. They have, since their organization, at least, so Mr. BOWEN says, saved up the odds and ends of appropriations the shavings and scrapings and candle-ends, which might have been expended or squandered and nobody been the wiser, and quietly laid by the pile for the purpose of erecting a commodious and convenient headquarters for the Police Department and all its concomitants. They have purposely conducted the affair in secret with the design, if possible, of surprising the City when the building should be completed ready for occupation. They wanted to show by a brilliant exploit what prudence, economy, honesty and a wise forethought could accomplish in the conduct of a vast public trust, and hit upon this plan of doing it.

abstract: The Harrisburgh correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer, reports that the rebel advance has reached Greencastle, Pa., but we do not find the report verified, and are inclined to doubt it. There is no doubt, however, about the occupation of Hagerstown, and the approach of the rebels in force toward the Pennsylvania border.
lead_paragraph: The Harrisburgh correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer, reports that the rebel advance has reached Greencastle, Pa., but we do not find the report verified, and are inclined to doubt it. There is no doubt, however, about the occupation of Hagerstown, and the approach of the rebels in force toward the Pennsylvania border. They are, also, it will be seen, operating in considerable force further east, with a view, probably to a movement upon Baltimore, should circumstances be found favorable. On Thursday evening, at 7 1/2 o'clock, they made a cavalry raid into Westminster, about five hundred strong, with two pieces of artillery. Westminster is in a northwesterly direction from Baltimore, at the junction of several county roads, one of which leads directly to the city. Greencastle, mentioned above, is a village in Franklin County, Pa., about three miles from the Maryland line, and about equidistant from Hagerstown and Chambersburgh. It is intersected by the railroad from Chambersburgh to Hagerstown. Meantime the National forces are not idle. New-Market, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, only ten miles from Frederick, was occupied by them on Thursday. We also learn, from the National Intelligencer, of yesterday, that on Thursday Gen. MCCLELLAN had advanced his headquarters some miles beyond Rockville, and that the army had approached the Monocacy River. A Philadelphia dispatch, received last night, mentions that favorable rumors had reached that city from Gen. MCCLELLAN's army. It seems hardly possible that a great battle can much longer be delayed.

abstract: The heavy rains this morning caused an overflow in the Twenty-first Ward, which extended to the Seventeenth and Sixteenth Wards, doing an immense amount of damage, some estimating the loss at $1,000,000. The flood was caused either by a defective culvert, or the overflow of a body of water which had congregated on the Lamb Tavern Road and Broad-street. The flow of water was very powerful, carrying trees, lumber, and, in some cases, even houses, with it. Its track, which covered an area of five squares, is marked by complete devastation of property. The water was nine feet deep.

abstract: -- John Slidell, the rebel Ambassador to France left a nephew or cousin in the Military Academy at West Point, who graduated a few weeks ago, and [???] the United States Army. The [???] man was in one of the late battles, on Gen. Reno's Staff, was wounded and left for dead on the field. He was stripped of his watch, money, &c., by the rebels, but revived and crawled to the Union lines. His mother went to Washington to recover his body, but found him alive, and arrived with him yesterday morning or the day before, at her home near this City. His name is Mackenzie, one of the Slidells having taken the name of Slidell Mackenzie.

abstract: THE BROOKLYN FOURTEENTH. -- During the past three weeks, 280 men have been enlisted for this sterling regiment, and to-day another detachment will be sent off. Their ranks are greatly thinned, and were it not for the new recruits, would number not much more than 200 fighting men. Exertions are making to fill it up to the maximum standard. The Third Ward, on Thursday night, appropriated $1,000 toward this object, and a number of prominent men have taken the matter in hand to push the good work along. The recruiting-office is open daily at the City Armory, corner of Cranberry and Henry streets.

abstract: PROSPECT OF A BATTLE. -- There is, of course, daily prospect of a great battle in Maryland. While the rebel army in that State has its base of operations about Frederick and is pushing a strong column northward in the direction of Pennsylvania, the army of Gen. MCCLELLAN is slowly approaching that position and advancing in the rebel rear. The possession by our troops of Sugar Loaf Mountain, and their occupancy of Barnesville, Poolesville and other places held in the beginning of the week by the rebels, shows how close the National forces are now getting to the enemy. A dispatch received late last night intimated that our advance yesterday occupied the town of Frederick itself.
lead_paragraph: PROSPECT OF A BATTLE. -- There is, of course, daily prospect of a great battle in Maryland. abstract: THE RIGHT GROUND AT LAST. -- The National War Committee, appointed at the last public meeting in the Park, has had considerable difficulty in getting to work properly. One of their earliest acts was to adopt a resolution resolving to raise 50,000 men, to be commanded by Gens. FREMONT and MITCHELL, under authority of the Federal Government, or if that should prove impracticable, under State authority. Gen. FREMONT promptly signified his willingness to accept such a command.

abstract: A letter has been received in Boston from an officer of this vessel, which states that she had arrived at Fort Royal, Aug. 31, coaled, and sailed for the vicinity of Charleston -- all well. From this it would appear that the vessel is safe. A schooner arrived at this port on Thursday also, and reports having spoken the South Carolina, two days after the date on which the Boston paper said she was lost. It is almost certain, as we anticipated, that this canard is of a piece with those which reported the Congress and Seminole lost.

abstract: So great is the amount of travel upon this railroad at present that often seventy-five individuals are stowed, packed or jambed into the narrow compass of one of the smaller cars, while the canopied excursion cars know no rule of repletion, save inability of the would-be passenger to "scrouge in."
lead_paragraph: So great is the amount of travel upon this railroad at present that often seventy-five individuals are stowed, packed or jambed into the narrow compass of one of the smaller cars, while the canopied excursion cars know no rule of repletion, save inability of the would-be passenger to "scrouge in." The folly of thus overstraining the poor horses, and falsely economizing rolling stock, was yesterday exemplified. One of the small cars had unluckily slipped the track, and was consequently thrown quite out of time, when, just as she righted, one of these great community arrangements came along with streamers flying, and all in gay array.

abstract: The Fifty-third Regiment, or Vosburgh Chasseurs, whose tribulations we feelingly described a day or two since, are now represented by a fragment or nucleus, amounting to about 350 men, the majority of whom remain at the Park barracks, where a por tion of them have made the last night or two hideous  with bacchanal songs, dances and gymbastic performances.
lead_paragraph: The Fifty-third Regiment, or Vosburgh Chasseurs, whose tribulations we feelingly described a day or two since, are now represented by a fragment or nucleus, amounting to about 350 men, the majority of whom remain at the Park barracks, where a portion of them have made the last night or two hideous with bacchanal songs, dances and gymbastic performances. The Indian element, original and half-breed, which is largely intermingled with the corps, has been peculiarly obstreperous. On Thursday night and yesterday morning their demonstrations were so vigorous that a detail of 100 policemen, from the first seven precincts, under command of Capt. SQUIRES, were stationed in and around the barracks to preserve order, not without incurring ferocious threats, and in one or two instances, actual menace with arms. The more unruly of the privates desired to "break bulk" and get into the streets where they would speedily have disappeared.

abstract: The wholesale grocers met in considerable strength yesterday, at 1 P.M., in the Sales Rooms corner of Wall and Front sts., for the purpose of adopting measures preliminary to the organization of a special military force to serve the country for the term of three years or until the close of the war.
lead_paragraph: The wholesale grocers met in considerable strength yesterday, at 1 1/2 P.M., in the Sales Rooms corner of Wall and Front sts., for the purpose of adopting measures preliminary to the organization of a special military force to serve the country for the term of three years or until the close of the war. Notwithstanding a severe thunderstorm raging without, more than one hundred gentlemen, representing the wealth and intelligence of the trade, were present.

abstract: From careful observers it is ascertained that there is no force of the enemy at Dranesville, scarcely a picket; that JACKSON, FITZ-HUGH LEE and LONGSTREET came up behind Hunter's Mills from near Fairfax, remained Wednesday and Thursday last at Leesburgh, and then crossed at Edwards' Ferry into Maryland with 40,000 men. abstract: The steamship Edinburgh passed Cape Race last evening, with advices from Europe four days later GARIBALDI had arrived at Spezzia, and his wounds were doing well. It was not known what disposition would be made of him. The new rebel steamer, "290," had received a heavy armament at sea, and was expected to cruise against Northern commerce.

abstract: Editorial says Confederates now aim to overthrow Adm. rather than establish own independence; predicting imminent battle in Maryland; Editorials on Confederate occupation of Maryland, urging Union counterattack
snippet: Editorial says Confederates now aim to overthrow Adm. rather than establish own independence; predicting imminent battle in Maryland; Editorials on Confederate occupation of Maryland, urging Union counterattack
lead_paragraph: We stated the other day that the real danger which now menaces the country is not so much a permanent division of the Union, as the forcible overthrow of the Government. The progress of this war has developed the fact that the great mass of the people throughout all the Northern and Border States, are immovably hostile to disruption. The public sentiment of the whole country is more nearly unanimous on this point than on any other political sentiment or principle whatever. The South see clearly that the North will never consent to a division of the Union, --and that any peace which they may conquer based upon such division would be only a hollow truce, -- laying the foundation for bitter and endless wars in the future.

abstract: A few weeks since, this community was thrown into some alarm by the starting intelligence that the large military organization encamped at East New-York, and known as the Empire Brigade, under the command of Gen. SPINOLA, had become openly mutinous, and had committed disorders of the gravest kind. Prompt and stern measures were taken, at the time, to suppress the outbreak, the greater portion of the men who had dispersed were again got together, and the ringleaders of the rioting were arrested and held for court-martial. This, for a time, produced quiet and order, and recruiting has been going on briskly and regularly, until on Tuesday last the number of men appearing on parade was no less than 3,008. Throughout that day and the next, symptoms of disorder were again noticed, and, on Thursday, became so violent as to call for the determined interference of the brigade officers. Gen. SPINOLA and his Staff went among the men, reasoning with them and exhorting them to return to duty, but with only indifferent success. The sources of trouble appeared to be as follows: Of the older enlistments, only a few have received their full pay and bounty money, and are consequently, as they have been for a long time, discontented. Under recent action, the War Committee of Queens County have been paying an additional and extra bounty of $60 to new recruits; and as the latter received the money at once, and made no niggard use of it in the nearest dram-shops, their jovial demeanor on returning to camp nettled the earlier members of the brigade, who were on comparatively short commons, to no light degree. In fine, from bandying words, the rival parties soon came to blows, and what with liquor and rage, the entire camp presented one scene of riot and confusion on Thursday morning. Strong guards of sober and reliable men were speedily detailed and put under arms at every available point, but as the men were move or less tinctured with the feelings, of their comrades, they could not be held to the mark, and the brigadesmen began to leave camp in large numbers without permission. Their drinking and return soon made matters worse; continual and ferocious affrays became the order of the day; men were beaten and officers outrageously defied, insulted, and in some cases driven from the ground.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks since, this community was thrown into some alarm by the starting intelligence that the large military organization encamped at East New-York, and known as the Empire Brigade, under the command of Gen. abstract: The nearer the rebels get to us the less we seem to know of their movements. The mystery that has enshrouded their numbers, their course of march, and their purpose since they entered Maryland, was intensified yesterday afternoon by the very contradictory dispatches from Baltimore and Philadelphia -- one announcing their abrupt departure southward and their recrossing of the Potomac into Virginia; the other maintaining their continued advance upon Pennsylvania and the actual occurrence of a battle near Hagerstown.
lead_paragraph: The nearer the rebels get to us the less we seem to know of their movements. lead_paragraph: Late on Saturday night, Sept. 6, a telegram was received by His Honor the Mayor, from the Secretary of War, to the effect that there had been a very severe battle at Bull Run -- that there were immense numbers of wounded upon the battle-field, and that all surgeons who could be spared from New-York should report at once to the Surgeon-General at Washington.

abstract: The students of Princeton Theological Seminary have resolved to drill for military service if occasion for it should arise. They have elected H.H. WHITE of Pennsylvania captain. Dr. MOFFATT, Professor of Church History, declares himself ready to lead them it need be. He has a son already in the Ninth Regiment N.Y. Volunteers. In Princeton College one or two companies have already been formed.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, a portion of the command of Gen. FKANKLIN drove the rebels out of Sugar Loaf Mountain (in Frederick county, Md.,) a point of much military importance, as oommanding a view of a large scope of country in all directions. Some resistance was made by the rebels posted there, which was overcome in a few moments, with a loss of not more than half a dozen National killed and wounded. We do not know the rebel loss in the affair.

abstract: It isa well-established political fact that external pressure upon a country has a tendency to unite all parties and factions in it, so as to present a single front to the enemy. The assault of the rebels on Fort Sumter extinguished almost entirely the former party divisions, that had been known under the names of Republican, Democrat, Native American. So far as the masses of the people were concerned, the beginning of war did blot out all trace of party lines.

abstract: The undersigned has accepted the position of Correspondiug Secretary of the Prison Association of New-York. This society way formed in December, 1844, under the auspices of such men as BENF. F. BUTLER, JOHN DUER, THEODORE FRELINGHDYSRN, JAMES MILNOR, GARDINER SPRING, and other no less eminent and worthy citizens. Whatever had been done before ...
lead_paragraph: The undersigned has accepted the position of Corresponding Secretary of the Prison Association of New-York. This society way formed in December, 1844, under the auspices of such men as BENF. F. BUTLER, JOHN DUER, THEODORE FRELINGHUYSEN, JAMES MILNOR, GARDINER SPRING, and other no less eminent and worthy citizens. Whatever had been done before for the reclamation and care of persons amenable to the penalty of the law, was the work of benevolent individuals, acting with reference to particular cases. There was no systematic, organized method of reaching the discharged convict with elevating and remedial influences. But, previous to that time, the attention of benevolent and thoughtful persons had been directed to this subject. It had become a problem how, on the one hand, to screen the innocent and the unfortunate, arrested through mistake or malice, from undeserved punishment; and how, on the other, to save the released prisoner from relapsing into crime? This problem was the providential occasion of the Prison Association. The formation of this society was the solution of both the difficulties involved in the problem.

abstract: Very early indeed yesterday morning the Twenty-first Connecticut Regiment arrived at Jersey City, coming in by the steamer City of New-York, instead of on the railroad. abstract: It is a matter of surprise that the government does not pay off its soldiers more punctually. It may be that the Government has paid over the gross amount; and in these times, when all persons handling money of the Government are trying to make the most money, the Paymasters may be putting out at interest money which should be paid over to the soldiers. Look at the Seventh Regiment, mustered out long since. Are they paid off? Look at the Twenty-second Regiment, mustered out and not yet paid off. Whose fault is it? Pay in paper -- the Government have that. The poor excuse, the pay-roll is not made out, or if made out, is not correct; the soldiers stayed a few days over their time, and should be paid. Very well, pay them. But does it take a week or more to calculate what a few days' extra pay comes to, or is that the excuse for holding on to the money and making interest at the soldiers' expense?

abstract: Editorial holds naval attack needed because of discouraging conditions in Kentucky and Tennessee
snippet: Editorial holds naval attack needed because of discouraging conditions in Kentucky and Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The situation of the campaign in the West is almost, if not altogether, as discouraging as it is in the East. Kentucky, excepting in the immediate vicinity of Louisville and Covington, seems to be overrun and given up to the possession of the enemy. We read of guerrilla bands in every part of the interior where Union sentiment has heretofore been almost unanimous; and in addition to these predatory gangs we know that heavy columns of rebel soldiery under KIRBY SMITH, HUMPHREY MARSHALL and JOHN MORGAN are pressing close to vital points on the Ohio River, threatening to carry the war beyond that line.

abstract: -- The physicians have succeeded in healing the attack of typhoid which had a serious hold upon Gen. BUTTERFIELD, consequent upon exposure, &c. The General has been granted leave of absence for a short time, and goes to his home on the North River for rest and recuperation. He has taken an active and efficient part in all the recent engagements, both in front of Richmond and of Washington, and has won distinguished honor, not only by his personal gallantry and skill, but by the admirable training and discipline he has given his troops. We trust he will speedily be restored to health and the army.
lead_paragraph: -- The physicians have succeeded in healing the attack of typhoid which had a serious hold upon Gen. BUTTERFIELD, consequent upon exposure, &c. abstract: A very agreeable match was played on the St. George grounds on Saturday in place of the return game, "Canada vs. United States." between the St. George eleven and nine of the Canadian players, with SADLIER und HUDSON, of New-York, given. As it was but one day's play, the match was decided by the result of the first innings -- the Canadians winning. They played their second innings, but it was too late for the St. George to play theirs. The fielding of the latter Club was very good indeed, and their bowling tiptop, but nevertheless the Canadians batted well against them. Capt. PHILLIPS made the best score of the match, beside making the finest hit of the week's play, a drive for 6 over the stone wall that bounds one side of the field. We give the score below:

abstract: citizens and military battle Indians
snippet: citizens and military battle Indians
lead_paragraph: St. Paul papers, of the 5th instant, bring news of a terrible battle with the Indians, on Tuesday of last week, near the Lower Agency, between Capt. GRANT's company of infantry, Capt. ANDERSON's cavalry, and a detail of soldiers and citizens -- in all about 150 men -- who had been sent out by Col. SIBLEY to bury the dead. The Indians nearly surprised the camp early on Tuesday morning. Some of the soldiers were shot while yet in their tents.

abstract: Those towns in Connecticut which had not filled up their quota by volunteers were compelled to furnish the requisite number by draft, on Wednesday. Waterbury, having sent nearly 100 over her quota, escaped the draft; so also did most of the towns in that vicinity -- Naugatuck, Watertown, Plymouth, Prospect, Woodbury, Bristol, &c. About half the towns in the State were equally fortunate, having raised their full quota of volunteers -- among them, Bridgeport, Norwich, New-Haven, Meriden, Wallingford, Madison, Branford, New-Hartford. Norfolk and New-Britain. In Hartford 415 were drafted; in Middletown, 96; in Cheshire, 33; in Hamden, 68; in Morris, 36; in Bethany, 17; in Bethlem, 16. In Middlebury 12 names were drawn out.

abstract: Mr. CHARLES PONTEZ, a Scientific Engineer, is the inventor and constructor of a new and singular method of erecting iron-clad fortifications, which are claimed to combine, in an unusual degree, strength, durability and economy, and deserve serious consideration. He terms them his "Mid-water Batteries," and for simplicity and effectiveness, exceed anything of the kind which has hitherto been suggested. The object of the inventor has been to offer the most perfect resistance to the invasion of any hostile naval force, however formidable, that can be brought to bear against as.

abstract: There had been no fighting reported here up to noon to-day. As the enemy knew well that the lower fords of the Potomac have been practically seized by Gen. MCCLELLAN, (whose movements of yesterday and the day before put his troops in positions, giving him the command of them,) we take it for granted that ere nightfall we shall hear that they are being massed much nearer the upper fords (between the Menocacy and the Point of Rocks) than the position held by their main fore up to yesterday afternoon. The threatening state of the weather makes such a change of position indispensable for them, unless they, too, "take no thought of lines of retreat."
