abstract: THE LATE MURDER AT SEACAUCUS -- VERDICT OF THE JURY. -- The inquest on the body of JOHN EISELE, who was murdered on the highway at seacaucus on Tuesday morning last, was concluded before Coroner BOHNSTEDT, of Hoboken, on Friday afternoon. Additional evidence of two witnesses was taken, CORNELIUS HOLCOMB and JOSEPH STURGES, who were at the ball at ENGELBRECHT's, and identified GEORGE WASHINGTON MASTERS as the soldier who was there and had his face blacked in imitation of whiskers. They knew nothing about the murder, neither did they [???] any fighting. The jury rendered the following verdict:

abstract: THE WAR-FUND COMMITTEE OF BROOKLYN AND KINGS COUNTY. -- The Committees of the Second andThird Senatorial Districts, appointed by the Governor to raise regiments to fill the Brooklyn quota, recently held a meeting, with the view of promoting the cause of the Union by appointing a Central Committee, who shall exert their power and influence in a more combined, systematic and energetic manner, in aid of the war against treason and rebellion. abstract: Editorial holds strict, stern responsibility of gens, needed to win war
snippet: Editorial holds strict, stern responsibility of gens, needed to win war
lead_paragraph: Responsibility! strict, stern responsibility, is what the whole people demand now from the Government. That tens of thousands of our young men should be slaughtered through the incompetency or stupidity of individuals who have set themselves up as leaders and Generals; that property should be destroyed by the millions -- property paid for by the muscle and sweat of every man among us; that we should be plunging into an abyss whose depth no eye can measure, simply because this officer must be retained from politicalmotives, or that from personal reasons, is a disgrace and damage beyond anything even that we have yet passed through. Who is Gen. POPE, or Gen. MCDOWELL, or Gen. MCCLELLAN, or any other General, that for a moment the interests of this vast country and the lives of tens of thousands should be risked, because his personal feelings or those of his supposed clique may be injured by a severe investigation?

abstract: editorial on Garibaldi defeat and US press reactions to rebellion
snippet: editorial on Garibaldi defeat and US press reactions to rebellion
lead_paragraph: We receive a report from Harrisburgh -- which however, is not verified from Baltimore or Washington -- that a heavy battle was in progress yesterday afternoon south of Hagerstown, Md., supposed to be between JACKSON and the National forces at Martinsburgh. We have another report -- which we consider the more probable -- that the entire rebel force is retreating from Maryland into Virginia. LEE and JACKSON are said to have crossed the Potomac near Martinsburgh, and LONGSTREET was expected to cross further up the river. Firing was heard yesterday in that direction, supposed to be from the rebels in covering heir retreat, which has, no doubt, been steadily progressing since the evacuation of Frederick, on Thursday last.

abstract: editorial blames construction and management for loss of life
snippet: editorial blames construction and management for loss of life
lead_paragraph: In discussing the loss of the Golden Gate, a few days ago, and endeavoring to fix responsibility for the lamentable loss of life on that occasion, we pointed to the self-evident fact that the vessels of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company are not properly constructed or fitted out for the business in which they are employed, or else that the discipline of the ships is far less perfect than it ought to be. The latter proposition is sustained by the fact that, in the case of the Golden Gate, a portion of her boats were burned at their tackles, that nobody in the hour of peril and panic seemed to have any special charge of the means of rescue, and that these means were consequently in part destroyed, while the remainder were made efficient to the saving of many less lives than they were capable of rescuing from an awful and sudden death.
headline: {'main': 'The Golden Gate Disaster.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Golden Gate Disaster.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial notes Confederate recruiting of military in Maryland and Kentucky
snippet: Editorial notes Confederate recruiting of military in Maryland and Kentucky
lead_paragraph: The rebel army has made but a small addition to its numbers during its brief stay in Maryland. That part of the State which it occupied, though not entirely loyal, is its most loyal section; and the lines held by our army pretty effectually prevented recruits rushing from Baltimore, or from the southern and secession counties. We hear of several villages in Frederick County sending their companies of volunteers, and of an entire regiment in one town arming and equipping itself, and marching to join the invaders.

abstract: If we learn rightly all the lessons the rebellion is calculated to teach, one of its indirect benefits will be to tone down that licentious habit of mind which has generally led Americans to throw their sympathies on the revolutionary or anarchical side of political movements in other, and especially in European countries. A notable proof that we have not yet learned this lesson as well as we should is afforded by the line of comment of the American Press on the late enterprise of GARIBALDI, which has just come to a disastrous end. The majority, probably, of journals in this country hailed this uprising as highly proper and meritorious, applauded GARIBALDI in his various acts in opposition to the Government, and finally, when conflict was actually precipitated, threw their sympathies on the side of the Red-Shirted revolter.
lead_paragraph: If we learn rightly all the lessons the rebellion is calculated to teach, one of its indirect benefits will be to tone down that licentious habit of mind which has generally led Americans to throw their sympathies on the revolutionary or anarchical side of political movements in other, and especially in European countries. A notable proof that we have not yet learned this lesson as well as we should is afforded by the line of comment of the American Press on the late enterprise of GARIBALDI, which has just come to a disastrous end. The majority, probably, of journals in this country hailed this uprising as highly proper and meritorious, applauded GARIBALDI in his various acts in opposition to the Government, and finally, when conflict was actually precipitated, threw their sympathies on the side of the Red-Shirted revolter.

abstract: To those of our readers who have friends in the Fifty-first New-York Regiment, the following story of its marches and battles, told by Mr. G.G. SCHOONMAKER, Orderly-Seargent of Co. B, will be of interest. The regiment is attached to the second brigade of RENO'S Division. On the 12th of August it broke camp at Fredericksburgh to march for Culpepper, where It arrived at 3 P.M., on the 14th, having traveled a portion of the distance by rail. On the 15th itmarched to "Cedar Mountain," remaining there that night and the following day. Here the regimental band was discharged. From Cedar Mountain the regiment marched to Kelly Fort and thence to Suffolk Springs and Warrenton, reaching the latter place Aug. 24; from Warrenton to Manassas Junction again, and thence, on Aug. 29, to the old Bull Run battle-ground. Until now the regiment had not met the enemy in all its marches and countermarches, though several times drawn up in line of battle. But it took part in the engagement of the 29th ult., and also in the one of the following day, the brigade being brought into action about sundown. At 9 o'clock on the evening of the 30th the second brigade, in common with the rest of the army, began to look to its line of retreat, and fell hack upon Fairfax Courthouse, Alexandria and Washington, reaching the latter goal at 1 1/2 o'clock on the afternoon of Sept. 6. In both fights in which it was engaged the Fifty-first suffered severely, once saving a battery from falling into the hands of the enemy, thus maintaining the reputation whose groundwork was laid at Roanoke, and worked out in permanent colors at Newbern.
lead_paragraph: To those of our readers who have friends in the Fifty-first New-York Regiment, the following story of its marches and battles, told by Mr. G.G. SCHOONMAKER, Orderly-Seargent of Co. On the 15th itmarched to "Cedar Mountain," remaining there that night and the following day. Here the regimental band was discharged. From Cedar Mountain the regiment marched to Kelly Fort and thence to Suffolk Springs and Warrenton, reaching the latter place Aug. 24; from Warrenton to Manassas Junction again, and thence, on Aug. 29, to the old Bull Run battle-ground. Until now the regiment had not met the enemy in all its marches and countermarches, though several times drawn up in line of battle. But it took part in the engagement of the 29th ult., and also in the one of the following day, the brigade being brought into action about sundown. At 9 o'clock on the evening of the 30th the second brigade, in common with the rest of the army, began to look to its line of retreat, and fell hack upon Fairfax Courthouse, Alexandria and Washington, reaching the latter goal at 1 1/2 o'clock on the afternoon of Sept. 6. In both fights in which it was engaged the Fifty-first suffered severely, once saving a battery from falling into the hands of the enemy, thus maintaining the reputation whose groundwork was laid at Roanoke, and worked out in permanent colors at Newbern.

abstract: The artist CARPENTER is that somewhat rare specimen -- a successful man who grows. He won flattering meeds of credit and profit at an age when most men in all professions are just putting their harness on. Still he has kept improving with every year' since, as a boy of sixteen, he painted a head which was one of twelve selected from three hundred offers for purchase by that day's Art Union; and emboldened with his success moved from the centre of the State into a little studio over DUPUY's, on Broadway.

abstract: Our advices from Maryland this morning are of the highest importance. They indicate that the rebel army is retreating from that State much more expeditiously than they came into it, and that they are not making their escape unscathed. A dispatch from Harrisburgh states that yesterday morning heavy cannonading was heard at Hanover, Greencastle and Chambersburgh, proceeding from some point south of Hanover, no doubt across the Maryland line. From Baltimore we learn that cannonading was heard all day on Saturday in the direction of Harper's Ferry, and a dispatch from Frederick gives the explanation that it proceeded from an engagement at the foot of the mountains, on the road to Sandy Hook, with a rebel force of two thousand cavalry and three batteries of artillery. Gen. BURNSIDE passed through Frederick on Saturday morning, and the whole National army pushed on after the retreating enemy by every available road, and even crossed the fields. The reception of Gen. BURNSIDE in Frederick was a perfect ovation, the people turning out with the wildest enthusiasm; and when Gen. MCCLELLAN entered the place, the streets and sidewalks were perfectly blocked with the enthusiastic masses, including a large proportion of ladies. Our latest advices from Frederick are to yesterday forenoon. They account for the tiring heard on Friday. It was an artillery duel between Gen. PLEASANTON and the rear guard of the rebels, who were so hard pushed that they were forced to fall back to Middletown, from which place they were also driven in the afternoon. On Saturday our cavalry had two affairs with the enemy, and so pushed them that they were forced to burn half a mile of their wagon trains. This, in addition to a train of a hundred ammunition and subsistence wagons, captured by Gen. FRANKLIN, will prove quite a serious loss for the rebels. LONGSTREET is said to have been repulsed at Harper's Ferry on Saturday afternoon, but at 8 o'clock yesterday morning the battle had been renewed in that direction, and the firing, as heard at Frederick, was rapid and heavy. It was expected that our main column would come up with the retreating enemy yesterday afternoon, and force them to a general engagement. Our troops were in fine spirits, and much elated at the cordial reception extended to them by the people of Maryland. All danger of an invasion of Pennsylvania may now be considered past, as the rebels will no doubt have enough to do to escape the destruction which they have courted. Gov. CURTIN, however, does not relax his preparations, out is determined to put the State upon a thorough war footing.

abstract: UNION TRIUMPHS IN NORTH CAROLINA -- It was part of the scheme of the rebel leaders, in setting their whole line in motion, to attack our force in North Carolina also. Relying on the fact that the always, victorious BURNSIDE had been withdrawn, with the greater part of his army, to the Potomac, they doubtless expected to fall foul of and chaw up the little force remaining, In this nice plan they have been most signally disappointed, and if all the joints of the anaconda had been as stout as that in North Carolina, the rebels would by this time have been pretty effectually used up.

lead_paragraph: The rebel military leaders are obviously hard pushed to reconcile their invasion of Maryland with the political theory on which they profess to be waging war. They set forth as their fundamental principle the absolute "autonomy" of the States, and yet at every step they are forced to violate that principle in some of its most essential features. They undoubtedly entered Maryland with the desire to be particularly "sweet" on that State, and to treat her population in the most delicate and affectionate style. "No restraint upon your free will," declared Gen. LEE, in his Proclamation, "is intended; no intimidation will be allowed within the limits of this army at least Marylauders shall once more enjoy their ancient freedom," etc., etc.

abstract: The First Metropolitan Regiment, Col. [???], left Riker's Island yesterday afternoon, for Washington, under Lieut.-Col. NOTT. The regiment mustered full ranks, and in one hour and forty minutes from the time the order was given, the entire command was on board the steamers. Several of the men are absent on passes, and these will leave this evening with Col. TURNBULL. It is only six weeks since the regiment first began to recruit. It is officered mostly from the Seventh and Seventy-first Regiments.

abstract: The political campaign may be considered fairly open. One political party (perhaps not to be unjust we ought to say one and a-half,) has its candidates in the field, and is preparing for a strenuous effort to take the State Government from Republican hands. They hope to make capital for themselves out of the disasters which have befallen us. They expect to get many votes for Mr. SEYMOUR from those who have hitherto sustained the Administration, but who, as they think, will be sufficiently dissatisfied with it to vote against its friends. They may get some such votes, but their candidate's strength will be in another direction, and among other classes of voters. We can specify some votes that he is quite sure of:

abstract: We have already mentioned the fact that a sword, the gift of the citizens of Brooklyn, was to be presented to the gallant Admiral FOOTE this evening. The weapon has been on exhibition for some days at No. 16 Court-street, and a large number of citizens have called to take a look at it. It is, perhaps, the most magnificent sword that has ever been made in this country -- is gracefully proportioned, rich and artistic in design, with scabbard and hilt of gold.

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS OF KANSAS: The rebellion inaugurated for the overthrow of the Government seems more formidable than ever; the rebels have largely increased in numbers and hostility, having, after more than a year's struggle, returned to the Capital of the nation, threatening its capture or destruction, while foreign intervention is imminent, and the cause of the war remains intact. Under present circumstances, it is impossible to foretell the result either to the nation or our own State.

abstract: The rebel invasion of Maryland has evidently proved a failure; and the proof is now ample that the army which ten days ago crossed the Potomac near its junction with the Monocacy, has already recrossed or is now recrossing the same river some fifty miles higher up.
lead_paragraph: The rebel invasion of Maryland has evidently proved a failure; and the proof is now ample that the army which ten days ago crossed the Potomac near its junction with the Monocacy, has already recrossed or is now recrossing the same river some fifty miles higher up. If the object of the invasion was to arouse Maryland to revolution -and the proclamation of the rebel Commander-in-Chief to the people of the State seems to indicate this as a main object -- then it was a signal and total failure; for there has been not a sign or symptom that it was possible to stir up the embers of rebellion in Maryland; while the loyal element has been greatly strengthened in its loyalty as well as increased in its magnitude. If the design of the movement was an assault on the National Capital, that, also, has proved abortive; for, not only have we now a defensive force behind the circuit of forts around Washington sufficient to repel the rebel army but one-half of our army has marched out to meet the rebels on their own ground, has driven them from their most important positions' has taken possession of Frederick, which they had established as their base of operations, and has compelled them to flee by every available route toward the Potomac. If the purpose was to march upon Baltimore, they have been foiled in that; for we have driven them from all the points they seized on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, between the Potomac and the Relay House, and now hold this line strongly and securely. If the rebel aim was an invasion of Pennsylvania, a march to the Susquehanna, and the capture of Harrisburgh, it is evident that they have now no hope of success in that scheme; for all Pennsylvania has flown to arms, and there is already an improvised army on the southern line of the State, sufficiently powerful to make any attempt at invasion fatal. The telegrams of this morning from Frederick state that the movements of the rebel army indicate that there is no fear whatever of the invasion of Pennsylvania; while even from Harrisburgh, where the excitement has been so wild, we have a dispatch to the effect that the rebel pickets have retired from the State line. Whatever may have been the primary or ultimate object of the rebel movement across the Potomac, there is no doubt that the whole thing is an utter failure, and while the fact that they have been permitted even for a brief time to occupy loyal soil and ravage a loyal population, is disgraceful to our military authorities and a disaster to our cause, there is nothing but this for them to glorify themselves with.

abstract: It is reported that a young man who has been employed as a clerk in the private office of Marshal MURRAY has recently departed very suddenly in consequence of unpleasant inquiries which were about to be made as to a check for $750 presented by him in the name of the Marshal at one of our banks, the check being a forgery. It is also reported that an examination showed other forgeries out of which the young man had realized about $1,200.

abstract: THE GAS COMPANIES AND THE COUNCILMEN. --  At the last meeting of the Board of Councilmen a resolution was adopted directing the Counsel to the Corporation to initiate the necessary measures for taking possession of the property and machinery of the New-York and Manhattan Gas Companies, in accordance with the provisions of their charters, by which the City has a right at any time to assume proprietorship upon paying the Gas Companies a fair valuation for their property. There is no good reason why the city should not undertake the business of supplying the people with gas as they do with Croton water; and we trust the movement thus inaugurated by the Councilmen for squelching out these arrogant monopolies will be pressed to a speedy consummation. The indignation of the people toward these gas companies on account of their attempt to saddle their customers with the National tax upon their manufactures, knows no bounds, and will not be appeased until they are crushed out. Legislative action at Albany may he necessary for the complete protection of the people, and the present feeling in the public mind warrants the belief that any laws necessary to secure their deliverance from the cupidity of these monopolists will be enacted without hesitation. The stock of the New-York Gas Light Company is very seldom found in market, but there have been some recent sales at a premium of one hundred and eighty per cent. above par. In the face of this, the attempt of the directors to impose their paltry National tax upon the poor consumers of their gas, is a piece of the most consummate impudence and cheek on record. In Brooklyn the companies are divided in their action; the Citizens' Gas Company announces to its customers that it is not its intention to exact from them the Government tax on gas. The Brooklyn Gas Company and the Williamsburgh Company will imitate the example of the overgrown monopolies in this City and make their customers pay the tax that should come out of the profits of the soulless Corporations.
lead_paragraph: THE GAS COMPANIES AND THE COUNCILMEN. -- At the last meeting of the Board of Councilmen a resolution was adopted directing the Counsel to the Corporation to initiate the necessary measures for taking possession of the property and machinery of the New-York and Manhattan Gas Companies, in accordance with the provisions of their charters, by which the City has a right at any time to assume proprietorship upon paying the Gas Companies a fair valuation for their property. There is no good reason why the city should not undertake the business of supplying the people with gas as they do with Croton water; and we trust the movement thus inaugurated by the Councilmen for squelching out these arrogant monopolies will be pressed to a speedy consummation. The indignation of the people toward these gas companies on account of their attempt to saddle their customers with the National tax upon their manufactures, knows no bounds, and will not be appeased until they are crushed out. Legislative action at Albany may he necessary for the complete protection of the people, and the present feeling in the public mind warrants the belief that any laws necessary to secure their deliverance from the cupidity of these monopolists will be enacted without hesitation. The stock of the New-York Gas Light Company is very seldom found in market, but there have been some recent sales at a premium of one hundred and eighty per cent. above par. In the face of this, the attempt of the directors to impose their paltry National tax upon the poor consumers of their gas, is a piece of the most consummate impudence and cheek on record. In Brooklyn the companies are divided in their action; the Citizens' Gas Company announces to its customers that it is not its intention to exact from them the Government tax on gas. The Brooklyn Gas Company and the Williamsburgh Company will imitate the example of the overgrown monopolies in this City and make their customers pay the tax that should come out of the profits of the soulless Corporations.

abstract: Editorial holds Confederate campaign in Kentucky and Tennessee shows signs of unsteadiness

lead_paragraph: The rebel campaign in the West is beginning to show signs of unsteadiness. After very vigorous push of considerable armies through Kentucky, almost to the bank of the Ohio River -- accompanied with the usual threats of invading the North -- the enemy's columns are seen to waver, and now they are reported falling back precipitately and in some confusion.

abstract: The regular Fall and Winter theatrical season may be said to be fairly commenced with the present week, when Mr. WALLACK and Miss KEENE open their respective houses, and announce the engagement of stock companies that can satisfactorily represent the very highest class of drama. Mr. WALLACK makes few changes in the personal composition of his forces. He loses Mr. BLAKE, but secures in that great comedian's place an actor of acknowledged talent and popularity. Mrs. Hoey, Mr. Mark Smith, Mr. C. Fisher, Mr. George Holland, Miss Gannon, Mrs. Vernon, Miss Fanny Morant, Miss Madeline Henriquez, and, of course, Mr. Lester Wallack, again rally around him on the stage, and the front of the house is still under the superintendence of Mr. MOSS. Miss KEENE is the gainer by Mr. WALLACK's loss of Mr. BLAKE. In other respects she has materially strengthened her company, and will be able to give the best of standard comedy with excellent effect, if she can only find some one capable of playing the heroes of that kind of piece.

abstract: What is mortifying in the rebel invasion of Maryland is not so much the military movement itself as the standard [???] shows the leaders set on the capacity of our Generals. If they did not have an almost boundless faith in the timidity, slowness and imbecility of our military leaders, they never surely would have ventured to place themselves in a situation which, in the Napoleonic style of war, must result in their utter annihilation. It is profitless to inquire how far their past experience justifies this contemptuous criterion, enough that they have formed it, and that they act upon it. They have perfect confidence that our splendid scientific strategy will expend itself in moves which should have been successful, but were not; and, though all lines of retreat be cut off, confidently rely on being able, if need be, to whisk themselves off, bag, baggage and booty, through some loop-hole, by which they should never have gone, if they had had a decent respect for the opinions of strategic mankind. It remains to be seen whether the event will bear them out in the opinion they have formed of our Generals, or whether they will be taught in Maryland a new lesson. It is a test which, in all fairness, we cannot refuse to accept.

abstract: gunboats help defeat Confederates; Report on Confederate retreat from Cincinnati area; Reports on war in Kansas
snippet: gunboats help defeat Confederates; Report on Confederate retreat from Cincinnati area; Reports on war in Kansas
lead_paragraph: Rev. THEODORE L. CUYLER, who has just returned from a three months' vacation in England and on the continent of Europe, gave to a large audience at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening, the result of his observations during his absence, with respect to the opinions entertained abroad touching the American Rebellion. His narrative was highly interesting, and was received with every demonstration of delight, but did not present any new or different aspect of European opinion regarding American affairs from that well known to exist by most readers of the newspapers. In England, he said, the aristocratic influence in the main was against us; so was the commercial influence, and as for the press, with the exception of the Daily News, Star, BRIGHT's paper, and the Edinburgh Mercury, it was all hostile to the North. Still we had a few friends among the nobility, among whom he mentioned Lord SHAFTSBURY, who had stated that if the North would only raise the standard of God and Liberty, they would not lack for sympathy in Europe. Earl RUSSELL had likewise frequently expressed a similar sentiment, and he gave that nobleman the credit, notwithstanding the harsh criticism he had encountered on this side the water, of being a conscientious Anti-Slavery man, of having no sympathy with the South, and of having stood thus far, as a breakwater, against the tremendous pressure brought to hear upon the Government in favor of intervention and recognition. The religious element of Great Britain contained a large substratum in our favor. At all the religious meetings he attended, our civil war was alluded to in the prayers, and the invariable petition was that it might result in the downfall of oppression, the spread of civil liberty, and in a speedy termination.

abstract: PARADE OF THE EMPIRE BRIGADE. -- The regi-ments composing the Empire Brigade, paraded yesterday afternoon, at East New-York, and were reviewed by the Commanding General and staff. The men presented a creditable appearance, and all passed off satisfactorily. The throng of visitors was immense. Every car leading to the camp was crowded to its utmost capacity; while many persons who were unable to find room walked to the grounds. There were probably two hundred private vehicles about the camp during the day. The First Regiment is under orders to march, and will probably leave for the seat of war on Tuesday. It is barely possible that they will start to-day. The recruits on furlough are coming in, and from appearances, the regiment will march with full ranks. Officers and men are alike anxious to be off.

abstract: On the third day of this month, a messenger from Gov. OLDEN apprised the authorities at Washington that the quota of New-Jersey under the draft, amounting 16,478 men, were at their several rendezvous in the State, a waiting the commands of the Government. The public will learn with amazement that notwithstanding this fact, the War Department has not taken the first step toward putting these troops in the field! Twelve days, the most momentous in the history of the Republic, have passed, and these ten thousand are still allowed to remain idle in camp -- unarmed, unequipped, unused.

abstract: editorial holds Garibaldi will not remain imprisoned; speculates on his being sent to US
snippet: editorial holds Garibaldi will not remain imprisoned; speculates on his being sent to US
lead_paragraph: We do not suppose that the imprisonment of GARIBALDI is intended to be other than temporary. Being taken in the act of rebellion, he had to be disposed of in some way for the time being. But his speedy liberation may be taken for granted. RATAZZI cannot bring clean hands to the task of punishing the man whom he invited into the field of dangerous enterprise. And even if he could, it is not to be supposed that the Italian people would permit harsh measures to be used toward a man whom they adore as they do GARIBALDI.

abstract: Editorial reply to Commercial Advertiser charge that NY Times threatens with "forcible overthrow,"
snippet: Editorial reply to Commercial Advertiser charge that NY Times threatens with "forcible overthrow,"
lead_paragraph: The Commercial Advertiser is a well-meaning journal, but it is sometimes betrayed, by its extreme simplicity of character, into doing things that are very unjust and very unwise. It says that the TIMES is "threatening the Administration with forcible overthrow." Nothing could be further from the truth than this; and the Commercial never would have brought such a charge against us, if it had not failed for the moment to distinguish between a threat and a warning. We have WARNED the Government that it stands in extreme peril of being forcibly overthrown by rebel machinations, aided by allies in the Northern States; -- and in this the Commercial agrees with us. It repeats our warning, almost in our own words. "Reluctantly," it says, "we are forced to the conviction that there are those at the North who care more for the overthrow of the Government, meaning thereby the present Administration, than for the defeat of the rebels and the forcible crushing of the rebellion." "Many facts," it adds, "point to the existence of such a plot in our midst. There is far more danger to us in it than there is in a conflict with half a million of men whose object is honestly and exclusively the setting up and perpetuating of a really independent nationality." This is the Commercial's language, and it echoes our own. If to expose and denounce the plot is "threatening" the Government, the Commercial shares the guilt which it imputes to us.

abstract: Rev. Dr. FRENCH, of the Port Royal Freedmen's Relief Association, lectured last evening to an immense audience, in the Church of the Puritans. His theme was the condition and prospects of the negroes lately received into freedom on the Southern coast. This was very strikingly and effectively illustrated, the deductions being in every respect most favorable to Gen. HUNTER's experiment. ROBERT SMALLS, the "hero of the Planter," was introduced, with several other noted colored refugees, and the impression made by all was very agreeable.

abstract: -- The dispassionate and elaborate letter of the TIMES correspondent at New Orleans, published in our columns a few days ago, conveys the cheering assurance that no danger need be apprehended to the National cause in the chief city of the South. Whatever reverses may attend the occupation of rebel territory elsewhere, the Crescent City, at least, won with so much gallantry and held with so much firmness, will still be preserved to the Union that purchased it and made it what it is.

The General officers of the rebel army are of three grades -- Brigadiers, Major-Generals, and full Generals. abstract: It was stated, some days ago, that the soldiers arriving in Washington, of the new levies, were united by Gen. MCCLELLAN with old regiments as fast as received. The army that has pursued and fought the rebels, driving them from Maryland, must have been composed in very large part of these new and raw troops. We are glad to find that Gen. MCCLELLAN, in his dispatch yesterday, does not forget to honor the courage and steadiness of these improvised soldiers, but gives them equal praise with the trained troops for their gallant and invincible spirit. Let the new troops hurry up. They may gather laurels from the start.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: We have highly encouraging news from the army in Maryland. Gen. MCCLELLAN's forces overtook the rebels in position on the heights commanding the approaches to Hagerstown, on Saturday -- Gens. HOOKER and RENO commanding our right and Gen. FRANKLIN our left. Both wings were successful, driving the enemy before them and taking possession of the ground. Gen. MCCLELLAN's dispatches are somewhat lacking in precision, and embody what are evidently the first vague reports which reached him from the front. We place little reliance on the rumor that Gen. LEE confessed to having lost fifteen thousand men, or that he acknowledged publicly that he had been "shockingly whipped." But the more important statement, that the rebel forces were retreating in confusion, is quite likely to be true; and is not more gratifying than the assurance that our men are pursuing as rapidly as they can move.

abstract: Dies
snippet: Dies
lead_paragraph: -- We begin to have with reference to Merrimac No. 2 the same sort of intimations which preceded the advent of her illustrious prototype. Merrimac No. 1. We were told that she was topheavy; that she hogged and logged, and drew more water than there was in all Hampton Roads; and just in the middle of the general chuckle she dashes out and does -- what all the world knows she did. Now, we don't say that, because the same kind of rumors are set afloat with reference to the new iron-clad, she is therefore on the point of appearing; but we do say that all such reports are to be distrusted. What we know is, that the rebels have been finishing at Richmond, with great secrecy and much enterprise, a mailed war vessel of some sort which was commenced at Norfolk; that they evidently put great reliance upon her power, and that there is momentary danger of her appearance. The same men that made the first Merrimac a success are perfectly capable of making the second one a success.
headline: {'main': 'LOOK OUT FOR MEERIMAC NO. 2', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOOK OUT FOR MEERIMAC NO. 2', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- It will be noticed that Gen. MCCLELLAN's latest dispatch yesterday, was dated at Bolivar, (Va.) This is a point in the immediate vicinity of Harper's Ferry, and the fact would indicate that the Union army had pushed away the rebels from near the Ferry, and relieved Gen. MULES, who has so gallantly held and defended this Pass. If this is correct, and the railroad bridge is safe, it affords a practicable crossing for MCCLELLAN's army, and may place it in the Shenandoah Valley ahead of LEE's retreating columns. The rebels, in that case, would be effectually circumvented, and their condition far more perilous than it has ever before seemed. They could not retreat toward Richmond, nor advance upon Washington, or again move toward Pennsylvania, but would be driven to the mountains westward, where, in their naked condition, their sufferings at this season, from cold as well as hunger, would be extreme.

abstract: RATHER TOUGH. -- A soldier, named DAVIDSON, discharged through illness from a Pennsylvania regiment, arrived in this City on Saturday, with his papers to draw the balance of pay due to him before proceeding home. On landing at Courtlandt-street, a man, respectably attired, offered to conduct him to the "Quartermaster's Office" to receive his pay, representing that he had been appointed by the Government for that purpose. The soldier accepted the offer, and in the meantime was taken to a restaurant, where, as his new friend stated, he could leave his baggage and receive board free. The soldier was then brought to the Paymaster's Office, where he received a check for $27, and gave it to the swindler to collect, who promised he would return with the money to the hotel where the soldier left his baggage.
lead_paragraph: RATHER TOUGH. -- A soldier, named DAVIDSON, discharged through illness from a Pennsylvania regiment, arrived in this City on Saturday, with his papers to draw the balance of pay due to him before proceeding home. abstract: Our highly honorable and "neutral" British cousins have lately let fly to this side of the Atlantic a dove, in the shape of a powerfully armed rebel steamer, which Mr. Secretary WELLES will probably hear of some fine morning smashing around among our blockaders along the Southern coast. This is the famous gunboat "290," about which we have had so many intimations, and which, having abandoned its figurative title, is now known as the Alabama. An item in the intelligence by the steamship New-York, published elsewhere, informs us that she is completed, has sailed, and had been spoken by the West India mail steamer steering westward.

This is the famous gunboat "290," about which we have had so many intimations, and which, having abandoned its figurative title, is now known as the Alabama. An item in the intelligence by the steamship New-York, published elsewhere, informs us that she is completed, has sailed, and had been spoken by the West India mail steamer steering westward.

abstract: A series of dispatches from Gen. MCCLELLAN to Gen. HALLECK, published this morning, give brief outlines of the important events which have occurred in Maryland during the last two days. The first, dated at 9:40 P.M., of Sunday, announces that, after a very severe engagement, the corps of Generals HOOKER and RENO had carried the height commanding the Hagerstown road by storm, the troops behaving in the most magnificent manner the action continued until after dark, and left us in possession of the entire crest -- a glorious victory. Gen. FRANKLIN, at the same time, was hotly engaged on the extreme left. In the battle for the possession of the Heights, Gen. RENO was killed. The second dispatch, dated at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, announces that FRANKLIN's success on the left was as complete as that on the centre and right, and resulted in his gaining an important position, after a severe engagement all along the line. The troops, old and new, behaved with the utmost gallantry, carrying strong positions with but very little help from the artillery, and without severe losses. The enemy had disappeared during the night, and our troops were advancing in pursuit. The Third dispatch, dated at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, announces the reception of the information from Gen. HOOKER, in the advance, that the enemy was making for the river in a perfect panic, -- Gen. LEE acknowledging that he had been shockingly whipped. The fourth dispatch, dated "Bolivar, 10 o'clock A.M.," announces the receipt of information completely continuing the report of the rout and demoralization of the rebel army. LEE, who was reported wounded, stated his loss at fifteen thousand, among whom was Gen. GARLAND killed. Gen. HOOKER alone had captured over a thousand more prisoners, seven hundred having already been sent to Frederick. This is a glorious record of success for the National army. It will be noticed that the fourth dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN is dated at Bolivar, which is on the lower side of the Potomac, a little below Harper's Ferry. This would seem to indicate that a portion of our army is operating with a view to intercept the retreat of the rebel army across the river.

abstract: The London Times correspondent at Blackburn says: "I find that my estimate of the total number of people here entirely dependent on relief is considered to be much below the real truth, and I have heard it put as high as 30,000. I am told that there are at least  30,000 worth of articles in pledge at the different shops of the town."

abstract: We are informed by Marshal MURRAY that the proceeds of the sales of the Hiawatha, as well as of all other prize property sold by him, have been paid into the Sub-Treasury, as required by law. Our information that they had not came from a very direct source, and the mistake arose from the fact that the moneys arising from such sales have been deposited in gross and not to the credit of the particular vessels and property sold.
lead_paragraph: We are informed by Marshal MURRAY that the proceeds of the sales of the Hiawatha, as well as of all other prize property sold by him, have been paid into the Sub-Treasury, as required by law. abstract: A special dispatch to the St. Louis Union says, Bloomfield was attached on Thursday morning by the rebels. It was defended by 1,500 enrolled militia, including a detachment from here. The fight lasted two hours. The rebels tools one 24-pound howitzer and withdrew. The militia abandoned the place with one iron 12-pounder, but spiked it two miles from Bloomfield.

abstract: According to Gen. MCCLELLAN's dispatches we have now a considerable number of rebel prisoners in our hands, taken in the recent fight at Hagerstown. We trust our Government will lose no time in retaliating upon them the treatment extended to the prisoners captured from POPE, and now in confinement at Richmond. The rebel authorities ostentatiously announce that sixty-eight commissioned officers belonging to his army are now there, -- not held as prisoners of war, but kept in close confinement.
lead_paragraph: According to Gen. MCCLELLAN's dispatches we have now a considerable number of rebel prisoners in our hands, taken in the recent fight at Hagerstown. We trust our Government will lose no time in retaliating upon them the treatment extended to the prisoners captured from POPE, and now in confinement at Richmond. The rebel authorities ostentatiously announce that sixty-eight commissioned officers belonging to his army are now there, -- not held as prisoners of war, but kept in close confinement.

abstract: Full details of the combat in which the GARIBALDI rebellion began and ended, will be found among our European intelligence to-day. It does not reflect much credit on the military genius of the Red Shirted leader, for he held a very strong position in the gorges of Aspromonte, and his followers, it is said, outnumbered the Royal troops. But the fact is, his cause was inherently weak. It is impossible to read the history of the affair without feeling respect for the vigor and energy with which the Italian Government acted in this emergency.
lead_paragraph: Full details of the combat in which the GARIBALDI rebellion began and ended, will be found among our European intelligence to-day. It does not reflect much credit on the military genius of the Red Shirted leader, for he held a very strong position in the gorges of Aspromonte, and his followers, it is said, outnumbered the Royal troops. But the fact is, his cause was inherently weak. It is impossible to read the history of the affair without feeling respect for the vigor and energy with which the Italian Government acted in this emergency.

abstract: The retreat from Maryland of the grand army of the rebellion, commanded by Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, commenced even before their recent defeat in battle at Hagerstown, seems to be fully authenticated. The withdrawal, so far from being well ordered and successful, appears to have been compulsory and to no small extent disastrous. The burning of a half mile's length of their army train by themselves, and the capture of one hundred of their ammunition and subsistence wagons by Gen. FRANKLIN, on Saturday, followed by the very furious and apparently sucessful assaults of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army on the rear on Sunday, are incidents not of successful marching and maneuvering, but of embarrassed and hazardous retreat. Such casualties were not in the rebel programme. They bear too great a similitude to the occurrences that befel the Union army recently about Manassas for their untoward character to be mistaken.
lead_paragraph: The retreat from Maryland of the grand army of the rebellion, commanded by Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, commenced even before their recent defeat in battle at Hagerstown, seems to be fully authenticated. The withdrawal, so far from being well ordered and successful, appears to have been compulsory and to no small extent disastrous. They bear too great a similitude to the occurrences that befel the Union army recently about Manassas for their untoward character to be mistaken.

abstract: The very elite and crime de la creme of Brooklyn comprising the fairest daughters and bravest sons of the City of Churches, congregated at the Brooklyn Athenaeum last evening, on the occasion of the sword presentation to Rear-Admiral FOOTE. The auditorium fairly glittered with the array of bright-eyed beauties, and the sparkling uniforms of the naval officers, who graced the occasion with their presence. The Navy-yard Band furnished the music, and a detachment of marines added their martial presence to the resplendent tout ensemble.

abstract: By the steamship Bohemian, which passed Cape Race on Sunday morning, we receive advices from Europe one day later. The news is not important. Italian affairs remained unchanged. It was still uncertain what disposition would be made of GARIBALDI. Cotton had advanced only 2d, on the week, owing to expected heavy arrivals. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and provisions dull. Consols were held at 93 3/8@93  for money.

abstract: Gen. JESSE L. RENO who was killed on Sunday while gallantly capturing the Heights on the Hagerstown road, was born in Virginia in 1825, and was consequently 37 years of age at the time of his death. He was a graduate of West Point of the class of 1846, in which year he was commissioned a brevet Second Lieutenant of Ordnance. In the Mexican war he was greatly distinguished for gallant bearing and meritorious conduct, and while still a Second Lieutenant, was honored with the brevet ranks of First Lieutenant and Captain, which he won at the battles of Cerro Gordo and Chapultepec, in the latter in which he was severely wounded.
lead_paragraph: Gen. JESSE L. In the Mexican war he was greatly distinguished for gallant bearing and meritorious conduct, and while still a Second Lieutenant, was honored with the brevet ranks of First Lieutenant and Captain, which he won at the battles of Cerro Gordo and Chapultepec, in the latter in which he was severely wounded.

abstract: -- That Tory-Secessionist sheet, the London Morning Herald, makes an indecent, but impotent, assault on Secretary SEWARD's emigration circular, and winds up by saying that "it is better to be a starving operative in Lancashire than to be a thriving citizen of the Northern States at the present time." The "starving operatives" of Europe do not themselves seem to think so,as something over fifty thousand of them have sought hospitality and a refuge from starvation in the United States within the past six months.
lead_paragraph: -- That Tory-Secessionist sheet, the London Morning Herald, makes an indecent, but impotent, assault on Secretary SEWARD's emigration circular, and winds up by saying that "it is better to be a starving operative in Lancashire than to be a thriving citizen of the Northern States at the present time." The "starving operatives" of Europe do not themselves seem to think so,as something over fifty thousand of them have sought hospitality and a refuge from starvation in the United States within the past six months.

abstract: Very many thousands of our soldiers and their families will be interested in the notice published in another column, of Messrs. NETTLETON, GILBERT  CAMP, a respectable law firm of this City, who offer to make collections of pay, bounties, pensions, , due to soldiers, at greatly reduced rates.
lead_paragraph: Very many thousands of our soldiers and their families will be interested in the notice published in another column, of Messrs. NETTLETON, GILBERT CAMP, a respectable law firm of this City, who offer to make collections of pay, bounties, pensions, , due to soldiers, at greatly reduced rates. Soldiers are very frequently subjected to the most outrageous impositions in this matter, which is deemed to be one of such general interest that a Benevolent Association has been formed in Chicago for the express purpose of making these collections for the lowest possible compensation. The rates they have established are precisely those fixed by Messrs. N., G& Co., whose terms and references will be found in our advertising columns.

abstract: -- "The whole rebelarmy in Maryland will be annihilated or captured this night," was the inspiriting dispatch that came to us over the telegraph wires last night, just as the City Hall clock indicated the hour of twelve. We learned then that yesterday Stonewall JACKSON had recrossed the Potomac, that Gen. MCCLELLAN had engaged him with "tremendous force," and that the result would be as already quoted. We earnnestly hope that this day will bring us confirmation of the prophecy. There seems to be little doubt that the enemy on Monday and yesterday threw into Maryland the great bulk of his army, and, knowing Gen. MCCLELLAN's strength, assaulted him with a hope of his destruction. We hope that Gen. HALLECK has seen to it that Gen. MCCLELLAN was provided with forces sufficient for the contingency. We do not see why the Pennsylvania volunteers might not have gone forward to temporarily aid Gen. MCCLELLAN until the rebels were driven across the Potomac. By this only can Pennsylvania be rendered safe.
lead_paragraph: -- "The whole rebelarmy in Maryland will be annihilated or captured this night," was the inspiriting dispatch that came to us over the telegraph wires last night, just as the City Hall clock indicated the hour of twelve. We learned then that yesterday Stonewall JACKSON had recrossed the Potomac, that Gen. MCCLELLAN had engaged him with "tremendous force," and that the result would be as already quoted. We earnnestly hope that this day will bring us confirmation of the prophecy. There seems to be little doubt that the enemy on Monday and yesterday threw into Maryland the great bulk of his army, and, knowing Gen. MCCLELLAN's strength, assaulted him with a hope of his destruction. We hope that Gen. HALLECK has seen to it that Gen. MCCLELLAN was provided with forces sufficient for the contingency. We do not see why the Pennsylvania volunteers might not have gone forward to temporarily aid Gen. MCCLELLAN until the rebels were driven across the Potomac. By this only can Pennsylvania be rendered safe.

abstract: Editorial urges draft be effected immediately
snippet: Editorial urges draft be effected immediately
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arabia arrived at Halifax early yesterday morning, with advices from Europe two days later than were received by the Bohemian. The news is not specially important. JEFF. DAVIS' recent message to the rebel Congress had reached England, and was variously commented upon by the London Press. It was reported that at the last council of the French Ministers on Italian affairs, it was decided that the statu quo should be maintained in Rome for some time to come. The fate of GARIBALDI was yet undecided. There was a rumor that VICTOR EMANUEL would take advantage of the occasion of the marriage of his daughter to the King of Portugal to pardon him. The third division of the French Expedition to Mexico, consisting of three steamers, had left for Vera Cruz, News had reached England that another attempt had been made upon the life of the British Minister at Yeddo, Japan. The Liverpool cotton market was unchanged. Breadstuffs were quiet and Provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 93 1/2@93 5/8 for money. American Stocks were steady.

abstract: The telegraph brings us from Harrisburgh, a brief but important account of proceedings had in the "Confederate Congress," upon the receipt of the news of Gen. LEE's successful passage of the Potomac. Imperfect as it is, this account throws a significant light upon the real objects of this movement of the rebel forces, and indicates very distinctly what we may expect in case the "glorious victory" of Sunday last over the rear guard of LEE should result, as so many of our "glorious victories" have been permitted to do, in the retreat of our own forces to a "formidable position," and the liberation of the defeated rebels to pursue the devices of their own hearts.

abstract: There will be a grand demonstration on Thursday evening, 17th inst., at 7 1/2 o'clock, at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh-avenue near Fourteenth-street, for the purpose of recruiting for Capt. WOODWARD's Company, of the Ironsides Regiment. A number of eloquent clergymen and laymen will add fire to the occasion, among whom are Rev. Drs. GILLETTE, COOKMAN, MICKELS, NEWMAN, BURCHARD, Prof. LINDSAY and Hon. BENJ. F. MANIEBEB. This regiment is being organized under the auspices of the New-York Young Men's Christian Association, and bids fair to number among its members many who, following the advice of the originator of the Ironsides, of the Seventeenth Century, will "Trust in God and keep their powder dry."

abstract: -- In accordance with their acknowledged policy of an advance along the whole line, the rebels in overpowering force have fallen upon the Union troops left at Gauley Bridge to defend the entrance to the Kanawha Valley, and driven them away in much haste, and with very serious loss of provisions and army stores. Our men in retreating seem to have made repeated stands, and to have dealt the enemy some damaging blows. But it was all of no avail. Charleston, the flourishing county seat of Kanawha, has been shelled and burned, the Kanawha Salt Works, among the most productive sources of saline supply in the country, have been destroyed, the entire Kanawha Valley evacuated, and towns on the Ohio River near its mouth, threatened.
lead_paragraph: -- In accordance with their acknowledged policy of an advance along the whole line, the rebels in overpowering force have fallen upon the Union troops left at Gauley Bridge to defend the entrance to the Kanawha Valley, and driven them away in much haste, and with very serious loss of provisions and army stores. abstract: editorial lauds Union victory
snippet: editorial lauds Union victory
lead_paragraph: The clear and graphic account of a special correspondent of the TIMES, in our columns this morning, of the recent battle between the forces of Gen. McCLELLAN and the retreating rebel army, removes all doubt as to the character of the engagement. It was a deliberately-planned assault by the Union army upon the rebels in force, holding the most formidable position known in war a mountain pass, overlooked and flanked by heavily wooded heights. The enemy held this pass, had planted his batteries in the gorge, and the woods on the mountain tops and sides were filled with his infantry. He had evidently chosen this stronghold with a view to administer a bloody repulse to the pursuing army.

abstract: A dispatch reached us at midnight last night, from Harrisburgh, announcing the reception of intelligence at headquarters in that city that JACKSON had recrossed the Potomac, and that Gen. McCLELLAN had engaged him with tremendous force about ten miles from Sharpsburgh, on the Potomac, and between that place and Middletown. The dispatch expresses the belief that the entire rebel army in Maryland would be annihi- lated or captured last night.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch reached us at midnight last night, from Harrisburgh, announcing the reception of intelligence at headquarters in that city that JACKSON had recrossed the Potomac, and that Gen. McCLELLAN had engaged him with tremendous force about ten miles from Sharpsburgh, on the Potomac, and between that place and Middletown. The dispatch expresses the belief that the entire rebel army in Maryland would be annihi- lated or captured last night. A previous dispatch from Harrisburgh gave a rumor that another battle was in progress, and it seems likely that a tremendous struggle was going on all day yesterday.

abstract: We have this morning the intelligence that the bulk of the rebel army in Virginia crossed into Maryland yesterday, and effected a junction with the force already in that State. A battle, of which we have yet no details, was fought between our army under Gen. McCLEL- LAN and these combined forces, at Sharpsburgh, a few miles from the line of the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: We have this morning the intelligence that the bulk of the rebel army in Virginia crossed into Maryland yesterday, and effected a junction with the force already in that State. A battle, of which we have yet no details, was fought between our army under Gen. McCLEL- LAN and these combined forces, at Sharpsburgh, a few miles from the line of the Potomac. What the result of the battle may have been, we shall doubtless know in the course of the day. While the rebel army in Maryland was thus reinforced after the battle of Sunday at Hagerstown Heights, we are glad to learn that our army also received reinforcements. The rebel movement has been rapid and daring, but Gen. MCCLELLAN's we believe was no less so; and we confidently trust that a glorious victory rested upon our arms.

abstract: The greatest irregularity seems to prevail with reference to the draft in the several States. In Pennsylvania it has been appointed for the 25th inst.; Massachusetts has put it off till the 1st of October; and in our own State, after being set down for three distinct dates, it seems now to be adjourned sine die. Then, again, three or four of the States are making a draft now, while as many more will need no draft at all, having filled up their quotas by volunteers, under both calls.
lead_paragraph: The greatest irregularity seems to prevail with reference to the draft in the several States. abstract: -- Correspondentswriting to the Pacific Coast should not overlook the announcement that letter mail service via the overland route is resumed. The fear of interruption to this service by Indian depredations, appears to have been a false alarm, for the overload coaches are arriving daily at the Missouri River, bringing passengers and local mails in only seventeen days from Placerville, California, or about twenty-one or twenty-two days between San Francisco and New-York. Of late the overland mail regularly beats the steamers of corresponding dates. Thus, on Monday last, we received San Francisco dates to the 23d ult. overland, while the Champion, which arrived yesterday, brought us dates only to the 21st. Of course the daily mail, with this quick time, greatly increases the facilities for correspondence.

abstract: APPRAISEMENTS OF PRIZE STEAMERS -- The four steamers recently captured by our blockading squadron, being of prospective use to the Government, have by its order, been appraised. The Bermuda, the most valuable of the four, has been appraised by the Court Appraisers at $120,000, by the Government Appraisers at $110,000. The captors and claimants will no doubt agree to the Government taking the vessel at the larger sum, but as it is $10,000 above the value fixed upon by the agents for the Government, it is doubtful if the vessel will be taken at that figure. With respect to the steamer Lodona, the Court Appraisers put her value at $75,000, the Government Appraisers at $80,000, and the claimants and captors allege her to be worth $85,000. This vessel will be allowed to be taken by the Government, no doubt, at the appraisement of $80,000. The steamer Florida, which is a wooden vessel, and has seen ten years' service, has been valued by the Court Appraisers at $38,000, by the Government agents at $10,000. It is supposed that the captors and the claimants will both agree to the Government having her for $40,000. The Government appraisement of the steamer Emilie values her at $10,000, the Court appraisement at $15,000. The Emilie is old and nearly worn out. She sailed for a number of years as the Wm. Seabrook, between Charleston and Savannah. It is thought that the vessel is not worth more than the Government agents say she is.

abstract: In compliance with orders from the Navy Department, two new men-of-war were commenced yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. They are to be side-wheel wooden steamers, and must be completed as soon as all the availble workmen in the Yard can do the work on them. Their names are to be the Mackinaw, and the Shamrock. The Mackinaw will not be a large vessel. She is intended to carry a battery of three guns only, will be 974 tons burden, and about 200 feet long. The ship housesbeing all occupied, her keel-blocks are being laid in the open air, between the dry-dock and the launching ways. Carpenters will be kept on the blocks without intermission until they are ready for the keel.
lead_paragraph: In compliance with orders from the Navy Department, two new men-of-war were commenced yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. abstract: THE BOARD OF SUPERVISORS -- This body met at the County Jail, in Raymond-street, last evening, Supervisor TUTTLE in the Chair. The business was mostly of a routine character. Supervisor BOOTH stated that the Bounty Committee had paid out up to Aug. 30, 3,470 bounties, and since then, up to Sept. 16 1,487. They have paid $297,420 out of a total appropriation of $390,000. A resolution was adopted, authorising the County Treasurer to issue bonds to the amount of $100,000, payable, $50,000 in 1879, and $50,000 in 1850, bearing interest at the rate of six per cent. per annum. The money is to be appropriated to the Court-house account -- the new building being now in course of erection.

abstract: My whole trip from New-York to this beautiful city was of the most cheering character. Passing through New-Jersey, I was surprised to find numbers of people collected at every station, cheering vociferously, and at every window ladies waving their handkerchiefs as we passed. I soon found out that it was owing to our having a large number of soldiers on board, going to the war portions of the Second, Fifth and Sixth New-Hampshire regiments.

abstract: Editorial speculates on Confederate plans in West with appointment of Gen. J E Johnston to command area west of Mississippi River
snippet: Editorial speculates on Confederate plans in West with appointment of Gen. J E Johnston to command area west of Mississippi River
lead_paragraph: Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON, so long the preeminent military leader of the rebels in Virginia, has been assigned to command west of the Mississippi River, having under him Gens. PRICE, HOLMES and MAGRUDER. This implies one of two things. Either the Rebel Government is about to commence a new and more serious campaign in that remote region, or it is disturbed by military rivalries at home growing out of the accession of Gen. ROBERT E. LEE to the command lately held by Gen. JOHNSTON. The latter is probably the moving cause of JOHNSTON's transfer. JEFFERSON DAVIS has always found his relations with the Virginia aristocracy doubtful and unpleasant. He did not meet their ambitious expectations of controlling the Confederate Government on the establishment of its Capital at Richmond, and he has not yet fully overcame their prejudices against him. He has never had in his family the cordial sympathy of Richmond society; and lately, when that city was in danger and disorder, his wife and children were said to be removed to Raleigh, N.C., for refuge.
headline: {'main': 'Rebel Designs West of the Mississippi.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rebel Designs West of the Mississippi.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: After the lapse of several days, your correspondent has at length reached his destination from Baltimore, which place he left last Saturday morning, for Harper's Ferry; a considerable time to occupy in getting to the distance of eighty-eight miles, yet I have considered myself fortunate in reaching this beleaguered village by any route, no matter how circuitous. Many changes have taken place since I left two weeks since.
lead_paragraph: HARPER's FERRY, Thursday, Sept. 11, 1862.

abstract: On sundry and divers occasions we have, in a mild and gentle way, called the attention of our great Gas Companies to certain little facts already sufficiently impressed upon the public mind; but, so far as response is concerned, with no effect. In the same genial manner, and with the same general groundwork of fact, we improve this morning's issue by asking if the Gas Companies whose stock is now rating respectively at 70 and 120 per cent. above par, really intend to carry out the cheerful programme which announces the imposition of the National tax upon the monthly bids of their customers?

abstract: At last our Generals in the field seem to have risen to the grandeur of the National crisis. The desperate attempt of the rebel leaders to force their way into the heart of the North, has been fairly met with the whole strength of the National armies before Washington, and before the sun goes down upon this day we shall learn the issue of the greatest battle ever fought upon American soil -- a battle which, in the numbers of the troops engaged, in the fierce energy with which the prize of victory has been contested, and in the tremendous importance of that prize itself, must take its place among the grand decisive conflicts of history.

abstract: David McElreary vs. James Fannin. -- This is a motion on the part of the defendant to vacate a judgment entered in this Court in favor of plaintiff in April, 1860, for $377 47, on the ground that no summons or complaint was ever served on him in this action. The defendant's counsel read an affidavit of defendant that the first intimation he ever had of a judgment against him was by the service of an order supplementary to an execution; also, the affidavit of one James Stevenson, who swears that on the 5th of April, 1360, he was the person served with the summons and complaint.
lead_paragraph: David McElreary vs. James Fannin. -- This is a motion on the part of the defendant to vacate a judgment entered in this Court in favor of plaintiff in April, 1860, for $377 47, on the ground that no summons or complaint was ever served on him in this action. The defendant's counsel read an affidavit of defendant that the first intimation he ever had of a judgment against him was by the service of an order supplementary to an execution; also, the affidavit of one James Stevenson, who swears that on the 5th of April, 1360, he was the person served with the summons and complaint.

abstract: [The following letter, though written previous to the battle, will be read with interest.]  At an early hour yesterday morning, Gen. abstract: ANNUAL REPORT OF THIS PRISON ASSOCIATION OF NEW-YORK. -- The sixteenth annual report of this Association has just been issued. In the act incorporating this Association, it was made the duty of its Executive Committee to visit, inspect and examine all the prisons in the State -- a duty which until the past year has, so far as practicable, been performed; but the failure of the Legislature to make any appropriations to defray the expenses of such examining Committee, and the volunteer contributions, on which alone the Association depends, having, as was to be expected, fallen off largely since the commencement of the war, the Executive Committee have been compelled to restrict their labors to the City of New-York and vicinity, their original field of operations. Their labors in this field, like those of former years, have been great, and have contributed largely to the great end for which prisons are instituted, which is, or ought to be, the reformation of the criminal. The faithful and [???] agent of the Association, Mr. ABRAHAM BEALE, has looked after the welfare of the unfortunate prisoners with his usual [???], and not a few young men are now following [???] who have been saved from disgrace, [???] from unjust imprisonment through his efforts. There are few [???] which better to-serve the [???] did management of the public than this. The [???] of the Association for the past your were $1,942 10; documents, $1,935, 25, leaving a balance in the treasury of $ 5 85.

abstract: The only account of the battle fought on Tuesday, near Sharpsburgh, comes to us by way of Harrisburgh, and is too brief to enable us to judge of the character of the struggle, further than that it must have been a most desperate one. It closed without a definite result, though it is reported by way of Washington that our army rested for the night on the battle-field, with the expectation of renewing the engagement yesterday morning. It was renewed, as expected, and the rumors which have reached us -- they can hardly be called anything better -- indicate that the lighting all day was most terrific. Our right wing rested on Sharpsburgh, and our left this side of Antietam Creek, near Paterstown, (probably Petersville, opposite Harper's Ferry.) All the dispatches agree in stating that the rebels were being hard pushed, and falling back. We hope to-day to be able to announce the result of this, the greatest battle of the war.

abstract: The draft in Pennsylvania was to have taken place on the 15th instant, but before the appointed time, a different kind of call from that of Secretary STANTON made another sort of draft, on the patriotism of that State. The imminent danger of invasion by the rebel army roused the whole population to arms, and the call for fifty thousand men, made by Gov. CURTIN, was responded to by seventy-five thousand, who rushed to form a wall of steel against rebel intrusion on the sacred soil of freedom.

abstract: THE MORRIS AND ESSEX RAILROAD. -- At the present time the Morris and Essex Railroad Company are making rapid progress on their road, which intersects with the old road at East-Newark, and runs parallel with the New-Jersey Transportation Company's line over a mile. Thence it runs in an Easterly direction across the Newark meadows, over the Hackensack River to the Erie Railway tunnel, making Hoboken its terminus. The rails have been laid, but some time will be required to make the road level. Dirt trains are running daily for filling-in purposes, and it is the desire of the company to commence running over their new route by the first of January. Spacious brick buildings have been erected in Hoboken, which will be occupied as depots and for freighting houses. The passenger depot will be supplied with all the modern improvements for the accommodation of the traveling public, while the ingress and egress to the ferry will be arranged in the most satisfactory manner.

abstract: ZACHARIAH CHARLES PEARSON has come to grief. Our readers may possibly remember him. He is an Englishman who, watching the course of events on this Continent, and the noble struggle which those fast friends of England, the Southern slaveowners, were making, for the establishment of a purer social state throughout, this country, saw the difficulties which they experienced in their undertaking in consequence of the lack of supplies, arms and munitions, which their hitherto lofty independence of labor had prevented them from making, and of which they had not succeeded in stealing a sufficiently large quantity. Having seen it, with the proverbial philanthropy of John Ball he desired to take means to help these struggling martyrs.

abstract: One of the most disastrous blows inflicted upon the Union cause -- though happily it has already been partially relieved by the recapture of the position -- was the surrender of Harper's Ferry to the rebels on Monday morning last, after it had resisted a vigorous assault for three days. Our special correspondent, who was present during the whole siege, and who was surrendered with the rest of the Union forces, succeeded in making his escape on Monday night, and gives in another part of this morning's paper a very detailed and complete account of the whole affair.

abstract: Another serious reverse has overtaken the National arms. Harper's Ferry, the Union stronghold on the Upper Potomac, has been overwhelmed by the rebel hordes, and on Monday morning, at 8 o'clock, surrendered, after three days' fighting. What so many feared was successfully accomplished; the heavy siege guns on the Maryland heights were successfully attacked in the rear, and we lay at their mercy.
lead_paragraph: Another serious reverse has overtaken the National arms. Harper's Ferry, the Union stronghold on the Upper Potomac, has been overwhelmed by the rebel hordes, and on Monday morning, at 8 o'clock, surrendered, after three days' fighting. What so many feared was successfully accomplished; the heavy siege guns on the Maryland heights were successfully attacked in the rear, and we lay at their mercy.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. This evening Mr. WALLACK reopens his beautiful theatre for the reular Fall and Winter season. To look at the bill of entertainment offered, one can searcely believe the house has been, for more than three months of the Summer, given up by him to the temporary management of others. There is one of the (comparatively) old comedies.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- This evening Mr. WALLACK reopens his beautiful theatre for the reular Fall and Winter season. To look at the bill of entertainment offered, one can searcely believe the house has been, for more than three months of the Summer, given up by him to the temporary management of others. There is one of the (comparatively) old comedies. "The Love Chase," to be played, and the parts in it are distributed precisely as they were last May. There is Mrs. HOEY as Constance; Miss GANNON as The Widow Green; charming Miss HENRIQUEZ as Lydia; Mr. C. FISHER as Master Waller; Mr. MARK SMITH as Sir Wm. Fondlove, and Mr. LESTER WALLACK as Wild-ake. In the company, beside, are still to be found the names of Mrs. Vernon, Miss Fanny Morant, Mr. Georg Holland, Mr. Morton, Mr. Reynolds, Mr. Young, Mr. Floyd, and Mr. and Mrs. John Sefton. Instead of Mr. BLAKE, Mr. JOHN GILBERT, certainly the next best representative of "old men" upon the stage -- has been engaged. Mr. GILBERT makes his first appearance on Monday. To-morrow evening, "London Assurance" will be given, and, on Saturday, "The Wonder." The orchestra, as heretofore, will be under the direction of Mr. ROBERT STOEPEL. During the recess the old act-drop (which, though a fresh and lively, was not an elaborately artistic production) has been replaced by a "magnificent, new and classical" effort from the palette of Mr. BERGER. In other ways the theatre has been renovated and improved in appearance. Of course, this evening there will be as brilliant and fashionable an audience in attendance, as is usual on the occasion of Mr. WALLACE, commencing a season.

abstract: The whole number of men which New-York City has to contribute to fill up the requisition made upon the States is still several thousand short. Of 25,000 required, less than 20,000 have, as yet, been obtained; but no doubt is felt by official persons, who ought to be acquainted with the matter, that the balance will be forthcoming before the Judge Advocate-General can complete his preparations for putting the draft into execution. Of the 20,000 that have enlisted, over 6,000 have selected old in preference to new regiments. Lately, especially, there has been marked tendency to join the veteran ranks of those which have already covered themselves with glory. One reason for this is that the new regiments that held our the greatest inducements to recruits have many of them marched for the seat of war; another, that only volunteers for the old regiments now receive the State and United States bounties. Strange as it may seem, though the excitement immediately attending the President's call for more troops has passed away, recruiting is steadily on the increase. There is no rush of eager thousands as in Pennsylvania, for the fear of invasion has not yet reached us; but men come in faster than ever. All the encampments in the neighborhood of the City receive encouraging accessions of strength daily, and business at the United States mustering-office in White-street is almost too pressing to be dispatched by the Government employes there. This pressure is aggravated by the complicated regulations of the State and United States Medical Departments. The duplicate examination now required is a cause of general dissatisfaction and delay, and should be remedied at once.

abstract: Susannah B. Young vs. Gilbert F. Ackerman et al. -- The defendants are the executors of the last will of David Brush, deceased, who was the executor of the last will of Catharine C. Young. The plaintiff, on the death of David Brush, was appointed executrix of the estate of Catharine C. Young, with the will annexed. The action was brought to recover the money, &c., of the estate of Catharine C. Young, in the hands of the defendants as executors, &c., of David Brush. The reference to whom the case was referred, reported in favor of plaintiff for $5,179 29, and the defendants now appeal to the General Term principally on the ground that the findings of the Reference were clearly contrary to the weight of evidence. Decision reserved.
