abstract: Acting Brig.-Gen. DIXON H. MILES, lately in command at Harper's Ferry, and who was killed on Monday morning last at that post, was a native of Maryland, and was about sixty years of age at the time of his death. He graduated at West Point on the 30th of June, 1324, and on next month was made full Second Lieutenant of the Seventh Infantry. He held the position of regimental Adjutant from 1831 to 1836, having, on the 30th of April, 1833, been promoted to a First Lieutenancy. On the 8th of June, 1836, he was further promoted to a Captaincy. On the 16th of January, 1839, he was made an Assistant-Quartermaster, with the rank of Captain on the Staff.

abstract: The United States Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows assembled a Baltimore on Monday, delegates from all the States except those in rebellion being present. R.W. Deputy Grand She MILTON HERNDON, of Indiana, presided, the Grand Sire ROBERT B. BOYLSTON, of South Carclina, being absent. The total receipts for the State Grand Lodges for the past year amounted to $7,501,88.

abstract: Fully 15,000 people were collected on and around the Union Ball Grounds, Brooklyn, on Thursday, to witness the grand contest for the silver ball and the championship, between the Eckford and Atlantic clubs, the greatest interest throughout the ball-playing community being manifested in the result. Heavy bets were laid, the Atlanties being the favorites, as in the last encounter between them, they defeated the Eckfords by a run of 37 to 5. The game...
lead_paragraph: Fully 15,000 people were collected on and around the Union Ball Grounds, Brooklyn, on Thursday, to witness the grand contest for the silver ball and the championship, between the Eckford and Atlantic clubs, the greatest interest throughout the ball-playing community being manifested in the result. Heavy bets were laid, the Atlanties being the favorites, as in the last encounter between them, they defeated the Eckfords by a run of 37 to 5. The game played yesterday was the third and test match, and the victory the Eckfords have obtained, for they won by a score of 8 to 3, gives them the palm of superiority, and deprives the Atlantics of the title of the champions, one they have borne ever since their organization almost.

abstract: The news from Hagerstown, via Philadelphia, of the capture of LONGSTREET and his division, with six batteries of artillery, as also of the successful progress of our army generally which was issued in an Extra TIMES at 14  o'clock A.M. was brought to the Produce Exchange, by noon yesterday, by the
lead_paragraph: The news from Hagerstown, via Philadelphia, of the capture of LONGSTREET and his division, with six batteries of artillery, as also of the successful progress of our army generally -- which was issued in an Extra TIMES at 11 1/2 o'clock A.M. -- was brought to the Produce Exchange, by noon yesterday, by the representative of this journal, and repeatedly read by him to eager crowds of merchants. The excitement and enthusiasm of the usually staid business men were unbounded. Our representative, having become quite hoarse, handed the extra to Mr. EDWARD BILL, who ascended a table, and by unanimous request, read the news for the whole assemblage. Rounds of cheers were given for Gens. MCCLELLAN, BURNSIDE, and our gallant soldiers. Business was scarcely thought of. To add to the enthusiasm of the merchants, a body of some hundreds of recruits for SICKLES' Brigade, in marching up Whitehall-street, came to a stand in front of the Exchange, and gave three cheers for these patriotic operators in produce, who had provided additional bounties for the bulk of this noble band of soldiers, now going forward to share the dangers and glories of the battle-field.
headline: {'main': 'The War News at the Produce Exchange.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The War News at the Produce Exchange.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial sees great battle impending in Kentucky
snippet: Editorial sees great battle impending in Kentucky
lead_paragraph: Kentucky has been emphatically the field for manoeuvering in this war. Her soil has been alternately marched over and held by opposing armies of great strength. Twice have the rebels, full 50,000 strong, advanced and occupied such places as Bowling Green and Columbus, first -- Lexington and Glasgow, now. And these latter they still hold. KIRBY SMITH recently had his headquarters at Lexington, with 20,000 men extended toward Covington and Cincinnati, and Gen. BRAGG is now at Glasgow with 30,000 men, commanded by himself and Gen. POLK, the ex-Bishop. But with all the marching and countermarching of the rebels in Kentucky, and the advance of great Union armies for their expulsion, no battle of any general character or great severity has yet taken place in her borders. The fight at Mill Spring, where Gen. THOMAS defeated the rebel Gen. CRITTENDEN, and ZOLLICOFFER lost his life, is the most important that has occurred.
headline: {'main': 'A Great Battle in Kentucky Impending.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Great Battle in Kentucky Impending.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Staten Island has responded, with unexpected emphasis, to the calls of the Government. The town of Southfield has completed its quotas, with a surplus, and tenders the extra men to its neighbor, Middletown. The northern shore has done nobly, and it is probable that no draft will be required in any part of the county. Large and enthusiastic war...
lead_paragraph: Staten Island has responded, with unexpected emphasis, to the calls of the Government. The town of Southfield has completed its quotas, with a surplus, and tenders the extra men to its neighbor, Middletown. The northern shore has done nobly, and it is probable that no draft will be required in any part of the county. Large and enthusiastic war meetings have been held at short intervals for a month past, in every town, and men of all parties have cordially united in the patriotic work of forwarding enlistments and making provision for the relief of volunteers' families. In the wealthier parts of the Island, several gentlemen have made liberal contributions; among them, JOHN C. GREEN, who gave $1,000; Messrs. Pendleton, Westervelt, Bacon, Shaw and Ward, $300 each; Nathaniel Marsh, $250; Messrs. Bryant, Bonner, Morris, Tyson, Du Bois, Martin, and many others, $100 each, besides numerous smaller sums. Over $6,000 were subscribed to the war fund in Southfield alone, and two or three gentlemen advanced the sum of $1,100, (in addition to their subscriptions of $100 to $500 each,) in order to insure the prompt payment of bounties. In Middletown, $5,000 or $6,000 were subscribed, and in Castleton the fund, thus far, is officially announced at $5,796. In addition to this, the Board of Supervisors have voted to raise the sum of $20,000 by a war loan.

abstract: The Twelfth Regiment New-York State Militia,  Col. W.L. WARD among the troops captured and paroled by the rebels at Harper's Ferry arrived in Baltimore yesterday, (Thursday,) and will be in Philadelphia this forenoon. The regiment will reach New-York this afternoon or on Saturday morning. The Board of Councilmen, at its meeting yesterday, passed a resolution tendering to the regiment the hospitalities of the City.
lead_paragraph: The Twelfth Regiment New-York State Militia, Col. W.L. WARD -- among the troops captured and paroled by the rebels at Harper's Ferry -- arrived in Baltimore yesterday, (Thursday,) and will be in Philadelphia this forenoon. The regiment will reach New-York this afternoon or on Saturday morning. The Board of Councilmen, at its meeting yesterday, passed a resolution tendering to the regiment the hospitalities of the City.

abstract: Maragaret Moncrief vs. John Moncrief This action was brought by the plaintiff against her husband, the defendant, for a limited divorce on the ground of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment. The cause was tried before Justice
lead_paragraph: Maragaret Moncrief vs. John Moncrief. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff against her husband, the defendant, for a limited divorce on the ground of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment. The cause was tried before Justice Leonard in December, 1860, when the Judge found, as matter of fact, that the allegations of cruel treatment, &c., of the plaintiff by defendant, were not proven; and, as conclusion of law, that the complaint should be dismissed without costs to either party.

abstract: editorial likens London Times reporting and backing of Garibaldi cause to its attitude on Civil War; Editorial says London Times reporting and backing of Garibaldi cause in Italy shows similarities with attitude on Civil War
snippet: editorial likens London Times reporting and backing of Garibaldi cause to its attitude on Civil War; Editorial says London Times reporting and backing of Garibaldi cause in Italy shows similarities with attitude on Civil War
lead_paragraph: -- When an advocate loves his cause a great deal better than he loves truth, it is idle to expect him to be consistent. He will blunder right on in his blind advocacy, apparently forgetful that his arguments and conclusions on other matters daily brought under his judgment may furnish complete refutation of what he urges in behalf of his bad cause. The London Times, in its determined purpose to place the United States Government in the wrong in its present trouble, is a striking example in point.

abstract: The accompanying map will give a succinct view of the scene and localities of the great battles of the present week, and of the course of the rebel movements from the time they crossed the Potomac, until Wednesday night. On Friday evening last, one week ago to-day, our army entered Frederick, having driven the rebel forces up to and beyond the place, from the point at which they crossed the Potomac, above and below the Point of Rocks. Our forces followed the retreating rebels from Frederick across the Catoctin Mountains, and on Sunday HOOKER and RENO came up with their rear guard at the gap in South Mountain, indicated in our map, (incorrectly called "Hagerstown Heights,") while Gen. FRANKLIN engaged another body of them on the same day, at a point to the southeast. Of these battles, the TIMES on Wednesday and Thursday gave by far the fullest and best accounts that have been published. The different bodies of the rebels seem to have then swept around southwesterly on Monday from these localities and from Hagerstown -- skirmishing briskly as they retired -- until on Tuesday all their forces were concentrated in the neighborhood of Sharpsburgh, at a point east of Antictam Creek, and probably at the intersection of the roads leading from Middletown to Sharpsburgh, and Rohersville and Williamsport. Here was fought the great but indecisive battle of Tuesday; and during the day's fighting, we drove the rebels south and west for some distance -- our army at night occupying the ground where the battle closed. The tremendous engagement of Wednesday was fought closer to Sharpsburgh, or between Sharpsburgh and Rohrersville; and though we do not definitely know the course and result of the battle, we know that at night we occupied Rohrersville, and that Gen. Mc. CLELLAN had destroyed the aqueduct at the mouth of the Antietam Creek, and the bridge across that creek upon the road leading to Sharpsburgh. So that from all we can gather, it would appear that the rebel army is now collected in the great bend of the river, (see map,) which will be observed as running some ten miles north from the junction of Antietam Creek with the Potomac. There are mountain ridges on both sides of the creek, and the whole country in this vicinity is thickly covered with hills, so that it is necessarily slow work pursuing the rebels, and they are able to contest many points. One dispatch asserts that the greater part of the rebel army, instead of being west of Antietam, has retreated southward in the direction of Harper's Ferry. When it is considered, however, that Gen. BURNSIDE, with a large force, holds Harper's Ferry, and that other troops, under Gen. SIGEL, are moving; in this direction from Washington, it would seem that wherever the rebel army may be placed, or in whatever direction it may be retreating, it will find escape a difficult matter if our troops are thrown upon it with skill and vigor. There will likely be another, and a decisive, battle fought speedily on this part of the line off the Upper Potomac; and on the space covered by our little map is, very probably, located the ground which will see the death, as it is now seeing the dying, struggles of this great rebellion.

SIGEL, are moving; in this direction from Washington, it would seem that wherever the rebel army may be placed, or in whatever direction it may be retreating, it will find escape a difficult matter if our troops are thrown upon it with skill and vigor. There will likely be another, and a decisive, battle fought speedily on this part of the line off the Upper Potomac; and on the space covered by our little map is, very probably, located the ground which will see the death, as it is now seeing the dying, struggles of this great rebellion.

abstract: Mary Megrath vs. Charles E. Megrath In this case, which is a distinct proceeding from Mrs. Megrath's application on habeas corpus for the custody of her child, which has been before fully stated in the TIMES, a motion was made for alimony, pending a suit for divorce, commenced by the plaintiff in August last. Mr. Megrath opposes the application,
lead_paragraph: Mary Megrath vs. Charles E. Megrath. -- In this case, which is a distinct proceeding from Mrs. Megrath's application on habeas corpus for the custody of her child, which has been before fully stated in the TIMES, a motion was made for alimony, pending a suit for divorce, commenced by the plaintiff in August last. Mr. Megrath opposes the application, and charge his wife with criminal intercourse with Dr. Malcom Ives, whose name is already prominent in the habeas corpus case mentioned. After argument by counsel, the Judge granted the motion allowing $8 a week alimony to the plaintiff, and if the child is restored to her by the Court in the habeas corpus case, an additional sum of $5. A counsel fee of $75 is also allowed her.

abstract: 1/4 o'clock last evening Officer CORVIN, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, discovered fire issuing from a window on the larboard side of the steamer Francis Skiddy, lying at pier No. 14 North River. The alarm was promptly sounded, when the officer proceeded on board the boat and assisted in putting out the fire, which was extinguished before the arrival of the firemen. The origin of the fire was traced to the explosion of a kerosene lamp, which had been left burning in the barber's saloon. Damage about $50.

abstract: It is clear, from the narrative of our correspondent, published in the TIMES of yesterday morning, that the evacuation of Maryland Heights on Saturday afternoon in fact compelled the surrender of Harper's Ferry, although the battle did not take place until Monday morning. As long as those Heights
lead_paragraph: It is clear, from the narrative of our correspondent, published in the TIMES of yesterday morning, that the evacuation of Maryland Heights on Saturday afternoon in fact compelled the surrender of Harper's Ferry, although the battle did not take place until Monday morning. As long as those Heights remained in our possession, it was utterly impossible for the enemy to seize the Ferry. In his yesterday's report, our correspondent abstained from any attempt to fix the responsibility of this surrender either upon Col. T.H. FORD, of Ohio, who commanded our forces on the Heights, or upon Col. MILES, who commanded him. We have, however, since received from him the following note on that subject:

abstract: On a noted occasion in sacred history, a wicked king of a wicked people was sore afraid and distressed when he saw the Children of Israels coming up out of their house of bondage in Egypt, pitch their tents in the plains of Moab.
lead_paragraph: On a noted occasion in sacred history, a wicked king of a wicked people was sore afraid and distressed when he saw the Children of Israels coming up out of their house of bondage in Egypt, pitch their tents in the plains of Moab. They were numerous and warlike, and had dealt roughly with many other people not more wicked than these frightened Moabites. So this King sent off in all haste for a prophet to come and curse these Children of Israel for him, promising him a great reward.

abstract: The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company of this City deserves to be pitied. When it began operations it had the moderate capital of $250,000, on which it traded with such beneficial results that its coffers ran over with the gold and silver taken from the people. It resolved, in view of its dilapidated condition, to issue additional stock to the amount of $750,000, and upon this, too, it traded with unexampled good fortune, until now it stands before the public with plethoric purse, and stock a long way above par. abstract: Editorial says war has improved tone of newspapers; reminds them of their power over movements of society and duty they have to protect it
snippet: Editorial says war has improved tone of newspapers; reminds them of their power over movements of society and duty they have to protect it
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondence of yesterday reported a conversation between LOUIS NAPOLEON and Mr. SLIDELL, in which the Emperor suggested to the "Ambassador Plenipotentiary" from New-Dahomey that France could hardly intervene in behalf of those whom he represented, unless she knew what arrangements were proposed to be made with reference to the destruction of that peculiar institution for the preservation of which the slave aristocracy have kindled the flames of civil war over this land. That they may be willing to agree to the future destruction of Slavery as a condition of active assistance from the European Powers, is possible, but very improbable. It would be a very bitter pill for them to swallow. They have undertaken to set up a separate Government for themselves expressly to preserve their social state, and they would then have overthrown the social state to enable them to set up the separate Government. Every one would ask them why, since they were now ready to abolish Slavery, they had not done it in the first place, and saved all the misery and ruin which they have wrought.
headline: {'main': 'The New Kingdom of Dahomey.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Kingdom of Dahomey.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Report on London Peace Society address on war to people of US

lead_paragraph: FRIENDS AND FELLOW-CHRISTIANS: More than sixteen months have elapsed since we ventured to address to you a few words of respectful and earnest entreaty against referring the dispute which agitated your country to the decision of the sword. Since then the evils of the war have been brought home to your own experience with an impressiveness and force which make the language of respectful admonition we then employed -- and, indeed, all human language -- poor and powerless in comparison with the reality.

abstract: Report on military movements from Middletown, Md
snippet: Report on military movements from Middletown, Md
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at its camp on Staten Island, was mustured into the service of the United States the Second Regiment of the Metropolitan Brigade. The occasion was celebrated by the presentation to the regiment of a magnificent stand of colors, given by certain citizens of New-York, through Capt. MOUNT. of the Third Precinct Police. There are, as usual, four flags in the "stand" altogether -- a handsome regimental flag, a National flag, and two guerdous. BALL, BLACK & Co. were the manufacturers. Speeches was made by the presenter and the Colonel, and the ceremonies were enlivened by music from Dodworth's Band. The Second "Metropolitans" are numbered One Hundred and Thirty-third New-York Volunteers. They are commanded by Col. CURRIE and muster nearly 900 men. All are uniformed, and most of them armed and equipped, and every member of the regiment is anxious to exchange the monotony of the camp for the excitement of the battlefield.

abstract: There seems to have been a pause in the great battle that has been going on in Maryland during the week. Our information from the field is yet too meagre and unreliable to warrant any positive statements as to its specific character or results, though all we do know encourages us to hope for the best.
lead_paragraph: There seems to have been a pause in the great battle that has been going on in Maryland during the week. Our information from the field is yet too meagre and unreliable to warrant any positive statements as to its specific character or results, though all we do know encourages us to hope for the best. There seems to be little doubt that the fighting on Tuesday and Wednesday was between the great mass of both armies, and that it was on both sides of the most desperate and determined character. The language of the few official dispatches that have reached us, as well as of the outside reports, warrants the belief that the world has seen very few more hotly-contested fields. On Wednesday there seems to have been a mutual suspension of hostilities, -- whether from exhaustion, or for the burial of the dead, or from both causes, we are unable to say. But we have no reports of any serious fighting yesterday.
headline: {'main': 'The Maryland Battles.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Maryland Battles.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are still without official details of the great battles of Tuesday and Wednesday, but sufficient is known to indicate that the advantages were all on our side. lead_paragraph: We are still without official details of the great battles of Tuesday and Wednesday, but sufficient is known to indicate that the advantages were all on our side. It appears, according to the best information received, that the battle of Tuesday did not commence until about 5 o'clock in the afternoon, but it raged until late at night, and closed, as before stated, without any definite result, the two armies resting upon the field. On Wednesday morning the general engagement was resumed, and lasted until 5 o'clock in the afternoon. It is understood that both armies were engaged in their full force -- the corps of JACKSON having recrossed the Potomac and joined the army of LEE. The battle was obstinate and bloody, but at its close the advantage remained with the National army, the position for which it fought having been gained, and no doubt being entertained of final victory. One account states that the rebels retreated, leaving Gen. LONGSTREET and the remnant of his division in our hands as prisoners, together with six batteries of artillery. It is stated, also, that at least 15,000 prisoners had been captured since Sunday, and the belief was expressed that the entire rebel army would be captured, as the Potomac was rising and our troops were pushing them continually. Accounts from the vicinity of the battle-field yesterday, up to 9 o'clock A.M., say nothing of the engagement having been renewed up to that time, and the inference is that both armies were engaged in burying the dead. A dispatch from Gen. HOOKER, dated at Centreville on Wednesday -- the day on which he was wounded -- states that the battle was fought with great violence on both sides, and that the carnage was awful.

lead_paragraph: This steamer, which has been built by Capt. DEGROOT, of well-known steamboat fame, was launched yesterday afternoon from the yard of MICHAEL ALLISON, head of Greene-st., Jersey City. The vessel is called after Mr. JACOB H. VANDERBILT, one of the principal owners and managers of the Stonington line of steamers, who commanded at one time the celebrated steamer Lexington. The Vanderbilt is of the following dimensions: Length over all, 200 feet; breadth of beam, 29 feet; depth of hold, 9 feet 3 inches. She is arched and diagonally braced in a peculiar manner, thereby giving the great strength for either river or ocean service. In her construction neither pains nor expense have been spared to make her the best vessel of her class afloat. Her engine combines all the modern improvements, and of a size capable of going to their unequaled speed with great strength in addition. Her internal fittings are to be of a gorgeous character.

abstract: MEETING OF THE JOINT BOARD, -- A meeting of the Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors was held last evening for the purpose of determining the sums to be raised for different city purposes during the next fiscal year. Mayor KALBFLESSCH presided. The Committee to whom the Mayor's statement had been referred, submitted their report in which they recommended an increase in the amount for lighting the streets, and a decrease in the sum for building new school houses, etc. The introductory portion of the Committee's report contained the following sentence, in connection with educational matters: "Another year's war may, perhaps, determine whether our children will be permitted to enjoy present facilities, or whether the education of the masses must be discouraged, as inimical to the existence of a barbarous institution." This gave rise to an acrimonious discussion, in which Alderman TERNAN, STRONG, FISHER and PERRY participated. Alderman TERNAN objected to the sentence, and desired to have it stricken out, as he did not believe that negro slavery, as it existed in America, was a barbarous institution. He had requested Alderman STRONG to attach his name to the report, but he was not aware of its contents at the time, or he would not have done so.

abstract: Our victory was complete! Such was the word which came from Gen. MCCELLAN at 10 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time he announced that our cavalry were driving the retreating enemy across the Potomac. On Thursday no fighting except skirmishing took place, the day being occupied in burying the dead and caring for the wounded. The rebels sent in a flag of truce in the morning, asking permission to bury their own dead, which was granted. At daylight, yesterday morning, it was discovered that the rebels had abandoned their position, leaving their dead and wounded behind. It was uncertain whether they were crossing the river or taking up a new position, but a pursuit was immediately ordered, and the truth was soon discovered, and announced by Gen. MCCLELLAN as above. It can hardly be possible that the rebel army could escape across the Potomac with all its paterisl, without being severely punished by the pursuing victors, and we shall not be surprised to hear, to-day, the news of its utter route. It is understood also, that we have a heavy force on the south side of the Potomac, under command of SIGEL and HEINTZELMAN, who will, no doubt, give a good account of themselves.

abstract: Volunteering, all over the City, was brisk on Thursday, and has been lately. Recruiting officers generally had about as much as they could do to attend to all the willing applicants who called upon them, and both regimental Adjutants and the United States officials in White-street were kept busy from early morn to sunset enroling and passing the men thus brought into them. At White-street, in particular, Capt. LARNED, Lieut. KENISTON, and Dr. MOTT and his assistants have almost more work upon their shoulders than they can get through with. They have such an immense (and, as everybody thinks, unnecessary) number of papers to sign to pass single individual into Uncle Samuel's service. Sixteen papers per volunteer certainly does savor a little of Circumlocation Department. Matter-of-fact people might fancy the thing could be done more promptly, and with not quite so much inconvenience.
lead_paragraph: Volunteering, all over the City, was brisk on Thursday, and has been lately. Recruiting officers generally had about as much as they could do to attend to all the willing applicants who called upon them, and both regimental Adjutants and the United States officials in White-street were kept busy from early morn to sunset enroling and passing the men thus brought into them. At White-street, in particular, Capt. LARNED, Lieut. KENISTON, and Dr. MOTT and his assistants have almost more work upon their shoulders than they can get through with. They have such an immense (and, as everybody thinks, unnecessary) number of papers to sign to pass single individual into Uncle Samuel's service. Sixteen papers per volunteer certainly does savor a little of Circumlocation Department. Matter-of-fact people might fancy the thing could be done more promptly, and with not quite so much inconvenience.

abstract: BOXES OF PACKAGES TO THEM BY EXERCISES. -- Government has recently placed Inspectors in the express offices at Washington, Alexandria, Georgetown, Baltimore, Newbern, Port Royal, and other offices near the Army, for the examination of soldier's parcels and other freight going within military lines. They open and inspect each package, and when found to contain liquor of any kind -- even one bottle -- they seize and confiscate the whole contents. These Inspectors likewise open and examine all return freight sent from within military lines, in search of contraband articles stolen or improperly obtained by the shipper, and seize all such articles.

abstract: By the arrival off Cape Race of the steamship Borussia, from Hamburg via Southampton on the 10th inst., we receive advices from Europe two days later. The death of the Archbishop of CANTERBURY and the Earl of HARRINGTON is announced. It is stated that Spain had offered to send a force to Mexico to cooperate with that of France, but the offer had been declined. France, it is understood, will send 30,000 men. The fate of GARIBALDI is yet undecided. His is wounds are said to be severe. There was a prospect that the difficulty between the Turks and the Montenegrins would be settled, as a telegram states that MONTENEGRO had accepted all the conditions offered by OMAR PACHA. The sales of cotton in the Liverpool market for two days had been only 3,000 bales. The market was irregular and dull, and prices had receded ld. Breadstuffs and Provisions continued dull. There was no change in Console.

abstract: HOW IS THIS? Soon after the last battle of Bull Run, a most urgent appeal was put forth by Surgeon-General HAMMOND, calling, upon all devoted and patriotic women and children throughout the land to spread themselves in preparing lint for the supply of the army hospitals in and around. Washington; thus giving the impression of an unfold amount of suffering among our wounded soldiers from the unforeseen lack of this indispensable article. The Medical Purveyor of this City. Dr. SATTERLEE, was telegraphed, at the same time, to send on all he could supply, Dr. S., on the same day, forwarded a ton of lint with the assurance that he could supply a ton per day of lint for a week to come and had machines at work that could keep up a supply far better than any that can be made by hand. We are credibly informed that at the time this call was made, the vouchers were undoubtedly in the office of Surgeon-General HAMMOND, showing there were many other tons of lint in this and other cities subject to his order, and yet to this day this appeal for lint remains undescended, while there are hundreds of ladies coughing themselves horse with lint discuss in their threats in consequences of this most ridiculous call.

abstract: CIRCULAR: Maj.-Gen. FOSTER, commanding the Department of North-Carolina, has called attention to an article in the New-York Evening Post, of september 4, in which is published the numbers and positions of his troops. He remarks that the New-York papers always reach the enemy in a few days after publication, and that such information from our friends is more injurious than that gained by the rebel spies.

abstract: This camp, now situated a short distance from Newark City, on the road to Orange, presents a very animating and busy aspect. There are at present nearly three thousand men in camp, anxious to hasten to the war, but are kept still in camp until they are fully equipped and armed. The State Government, with that at headquarters in Washington, have determined that this barrier to loyal loving Union men, shall not long lie in the way of the heroes of the State of New-Jersey, who, since the campaign commenced, have never flagged one inch in encountering the fee. These brave fellows, whose conduct in camp life has been so creditable, will not much longer be detained from taking an active part in the present momentous struggle. Everything that can be done is being done to have them at once transported to the seat of war in full compliance with the President's call; and they will go forward in the course of a fortnight or three weeks to form an able adjunct with the great army of the Union, which is at present so gallantly distinguishing itself in the cause of constitutional liberty. The soldiers are in the best of health and spirits, and express an ardent desire to be forwarded as soon as possible to participate in the honorable [???] which are now crowning the heads of the Union troops. They are principally young men, robust and stalwart, and cannot fail to do good service in the field when transported there. No drafting, it is said, will be necessary inthe whole State.

abstract: The United States vs. The Steamer Ella Warley. -- In this case an order was made for the appraisal of the cargo of arms on board the vessel, but the appraisal made under the order having withdrawn the appraisers, the United States District Attorney gave notice of a motion for the appointment of new appraisers, and the delivery of the arms to the Government at the appraised value, which the claimants opposed, claiming that the Court could only dispose of the property by a sale at auction.

lead_paragraph: The conviction we have often expressed of late as to the approaching collapse of the re- bellion, are based partly on our National strength, and partly on the weakness of the rebels. Of this weakness, the chief cause is a bankrupt exchequer.

abstract: Among the killed in this week's terrible battles in Maryland, is Col. MCNEIL, the commander of the justly celebrated "Bucktail" Regiment, while leading a charge at the head of his men, near Antietam Creek. HUGH WATSON MCNIEL was a son of Rev. A. MCNEIL, a Cameronian clergyman, and was born in Seneca County, New-York, in 1860. He was educated at Yale College, and entered upon the study of the law in the office of [???] W. SEWARD, at [???] with the [???] Regiment. In a short time he was chosen [???] led the regiment in a magnificent bayonet charge at Drainesville. The exploits of the regiment are familiar to all. While with MCDOWELL on the Rappshannock; while in pursuit of Stonewall JACKSON up the Shenandoah Valley, under FREMONT, and particularly at the spirited battle of Cross Keys, the Bucktails gained the foremost name for valor and vigor. And since then they have not ceased for a day to harrass the enemy. They accompanied Gen. HOOKER in the recent expedition up the Potomac in quest of Stonewall JACKSON. On Tuesday they came up with the enemy under LEE, near Sharpsburgh. The National troops were disposed in order of battle. The Bucktails were at the front. The action commenced at dark and lasted two hours. Col. MCNEIL had just charged upon the rebel forces, driving them back half a mile, when he received his death wound.

abstract: Gen. MCCLELLAN's dispatches, which bear date as late as noon of yesterday, are decisive as to the main result of his protracted and desperate engagement with the rebels. He has driven them out of Maryland, back upon the soil of Virginia, after having engaged their whole force and inflicted upon them a complete and bloody defeat. Whatever may have been their force in Maryland at the outset, it is very clear that the progress of the engagement satisfied them that its result must be decisive, -- and that they therefore brought over all the troops they bad within reach with the desperate determination to stake everything on the hazard of that battle.
lead_paragraph: Gen. MCCLELLAN's dispatches, which bear date as late as noon of yesterday, are decisive as to the main result of his protracted and desperate engagement with the rebels. abstract: Brig.-Gen. J. K. F. MANSFIELD, killed at the battle of Sharpsburgh on Wednesday, was a native of Connecticut, from which State he was appointed a cadet to the West Point Military Academy in Oct., 1817. He was at the time of his death about sixty years of age.
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. J.K.F. MANSFIELD, killed at the battle of Sharpsburgh on Wednesday, was a native of Connecticut, from which State he was appointed a cadet to the West Point Military Academy in Oct., 1817. He was at the time of his death about sixty years of age. He graduated on the 30th of June, 1822, standing No. 2 in a class of forty members, among whom are the names of Gens. HUNTER, MCCALL, and others noted during the present war. On the 1st of July, 1822, he was brevetted a Second Lieutenant of a corps of Engineers, and received his full rank the same day. On the 5th of March, 1832, he was promoted a First Lieutenancy, and on the 7th of July, 1838, became Captain. He served in the Texan and Mexican wars, and on the 9th of May, 1846, was brevetted Major for gallant and distinguished services in the defence of Fort Browne, in Texas. On the 23d of the following September, he was brevetted Lieutenant-Colonel for gallant and meritorious conduct in the several battles of Monterey, in Mexico, on the 21st, 22d and 23d of September, 1846.

abstract: At 1 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the brick building, corner of Water and Norton's street, used as a grain drying house.  The fire spread rapidly to the Evans and Sterling Elevators, which, with their contents, were destroyed. The fire then crossed Norton-street, communicating to BELL'S foundry, KLEIN  DOBSON'S pump and  block factory, and a number of tenement houses on Evans, Fly and Leconlaleux streets, all of which were burned.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, Friday, Sept. 19.

abstract: CIRCULAR: Maj.-Gen. FOSTER, Commanding the Department of North-Carolina, has called attention to an article in the New-York Evening Post, of Sep- tember 4, in which is published the numbers and positions of his troops. He remarks that the New-York papers always reach the enemy in a few days after publication, and that such information from our friends is more injurious than that gained by the rebel spies.

abstract: Contrary to the expectations of many of our merchants, the importations continue to be heavy, and the amounts received for duty large, notwithstanding the new Tariff.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to the expectations of many of our merchants, the importations continue to be heavy, and the amounts received for duty large, notwithstanding the new Tariff. The rates of duty were thought to be so high that the quantity of goods imported would be much less than under the operation of the other Tariff laws. During the months of August and September, in which the new law has been in operation, however, the receipts have been more than usually heavy, and the quantity of goods imported greater than ordinary.

abstract: Editorial on his background
snippet: Editorial on his background
lead_paragraph: shall history ever be written? Here is a man, Stonewall JACKSON to wit, whose ways and works are matters of daily interest to us all -- a man of our own times, about whom the truth is comparatively easy to be known -- and yet the origin, antecedents and training of the man are debated over as if he were a dead Egyptian, or one of Artaxerxes satraps turned to dust. Not civilians only but soldiers, and not only volunteer soldiers but West Pointers, whom popular superstition invests with all kinds of wisdom, quarrel and make bets as to the man's history while he is yet alive and most vigorously kicking. What will they not do when he is dead?

abstract: -- A Doylestown (Penn,) paper, with commendable enterprise, publishes, in neat roman type a list of persons in that town claiming exemption from draft, and the reason assigned in each case. The list is a long one, and unveils pages of human infirmity and novel diseases that are not met with in the chirurgeon's ordinary practice. A more dismal mustering of the "maimed, lame, half and blind" it would be difficult to imagine, unless one had the roster of the unfortunates who in olden time were went to gather around the waters of Bethesda on dewy mornings.

abstract: About a year ago, Mr. JOHN A. MACHADO, a merchant of this City, was arrested on a charge of fitting out the bark Mary Francis, and divers other vessels, for the Slave-trade; and from representations made by the United States Marshal, it was supposed that in the person of MACHADO the law had at length got possession of the ringleader of the Slave-traders who have so long plied their vocation in this City.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, Mr. JOHN A. MACHADO, a merchant of this City, was arrested on a charge of fitting out the bark Mary Francis, and divers other vessels, for the Slave-trade; and from representations made by the United States Marshal, it was supposed that in the person of MACHADO the law had at length got possession of the ringleader of the Slave-traders who have so long plied their vocation in this City. The examination, however, utterly tailed to substantiate the charge against the prisoner, either as respects the bark Mary Francis or any other slave-craft; and, after a few days' detention, he was discharged. There was abundance of testimony inculpating one Mrs. WATSON, the reputed paramour of the prisoner; but as for MACHADO himself, he appeared in the transaction like the echo of his name -- a mere shadow. Since that time the Marshal has been on the look-out for evidence to sustain the charge against MACHADO, and on Thursday last he succeeded in arresting the Captain of the Mary Francis, who, it is said, is prepared to make a full expose of the whole affair. This Captain, whose name is JOHN W. PERKINS, on hearing of the first arrest of MACHADO, made himself scarce, and his whereabouts could not be ascertained until within a few days, when a person who had been arrested for uttering treasonable language, in order to get the favor of the Marshal, informed him that Capt. PERKINS, for whom he had so long been in search, was at Peoria, Illinois. Deputy-Marshal J.A. SMITH was at once dispatched after the Captain; but on arriving at Peoria, he was informed that the object of his search had just got married at that place, and was then absent on a wedding tour. The deputy traced the happy couple to Philadelphia, where the Captain was arrested while in bed with his new bride.

abstract: title of a sheet, about fifteen by eighteen inches in size, which is published at Port Royal, S.C., every Saturday morning, at 5 cents per copy. Its assortment of miscellaneous reading displays good judgment, its collation of local news industry, and its editorial page more sense and spirit, without the venom, than the newspapers of Charleston and Columbus combined. That so small a sheet should be marked by so many excellences is sufficiently explained by the fact that its editor, Mr. H.J. WINSER, is a graduate of the TIMES Office.

abstract: It appears from the latest accounts, issued by the Board of Trade in London, that the value of the imports into the United Kingdom from the United States during the first half of the present year was £10,536,357 from the Northern ports, and £370,565 from the Southern ports, against £10,694,613 from the former and £21,082,161 from the latter in the corresponding period of last year, and £25,618,472 from both sections of the Union in that of 1860. The Northern ports took in return British manufactures to the amount of £6,301,457, and the Southern ports to the amount of £27,630 only, against £5,066,228 exported to the North, and £228,789 to the South in the corresponding half of last year, and £9,366,647 to both sections in that of 1860. This great difference of value in the imports and exports has been met by remittances of bullion and specie from this side to the extent of £5,538,831 during the seven months ended July 31, against £53,711 in the corresponding portion of last year, while the exports of gold and silver from England to this country amounted, during the same period, to only £31,062, against £6,819,770 in the first seven months of last year. The increase which is shown in the exports to England from Northern ports seems due to the large shipments of corn and flour which have taken place, 1,572,012 qrs. of wheat and 2,975,000 cwts. of wheat, meal and flour having been exported to England in the seven months -- these quantities being considerably in excess of those of the corresponding period of last year. The blockade explains the comparative insignificance of the exports from the South. Only 40,482 cwts. of raw cotton were exported to England during the whole period, against 6,714,499 cwts. in the first seven months of last year, which gives a value (computed for six months only as yet,) of £226,937, instead of the large sum of £20,706,200, which the Southerners received for their cotton in the first half of last year.

abstract: The enrollment of the City of New-York, so far as the enrolling officers are concerned, is now completed, and all that remains to be done is the copying and examining of the three sets of corrected books.
lead_paragraph: The enrollment of the City of New-York, so far as the enrolling officers are concerned, is now completed, and all that remains to be done is the copying and examining of the three sets of corrected books. This is an important work, and cannot be too highly estimated. Upon its correctness depends the equitable nature of a draft, and hence the greatest care has beer exercised by Gen. ANTHON in the preparation of this portion of the system. Set A is finished, with the exception of transfers. By transfer is meant that system by which the names or parties who have been enrolled at their places of business is transferred to their places of residence. The examiner, when the copyist has furnished his transfer list, takes up the book and erases the name of the party enrolled where it appears more than once on its appropriate page. Thanks to this plan, a man may be enrolled four times, as was done in some cases, yet in the engrossed books from which the draft will be made up, his name will appear only once, and that at his place of residence only. The cases, However, where the residence has been given in an indefinite manner, such as "Brooklyn," "Jersey," &c., without designating the precise locality, the party has been put down at his place of business, so that if he has two chances of being drafted, the shrewd citizen has but himself to blame. The entire work of copying, transferring, &c., will doubtless be finished about the 1st of October, making the entire time occupied in enrolling; New-York and Brooklyn with 400,000 names about six weeks. The labor required to do this work, though laborious, has been done at, comparatively speaking, almost a "trifling" expense. The entire job will cost about $1,500, or about four cents a name, which fact reflects great credit upon the economical administrative abilities of Gen. ANTHON and his efficient assistant, Mr. SORIBER. The economy of this enrollment may be fairly judged when it is stated that the bills presented for enrollment expenses in country towns have thus far averaged from 40 to 70 cents per name. The fact speaks volumes.

abstract: Who has heard of an Agriculturul Fair at the South since the beginning of the war? Nobody. Yet we have plenty of them at the North, and the Twentyfirst of the Queens County Agricultural Society, opened at Fashion Course on Thursday, was the most creditable yet held by that organization.
lead_paragraph: Who has heard of an Agriculturul Fair at the South since the beginning of the war? Nobody. Yet we have plenty of them at the North, and the Twenty-first of the Queens County Agricultural Society, opened at Fashion Course on Thursday, was the most creditable yet held by that organization. Never have these favorite grounds appeared to greater advantage, for, from far and near, from Long Island and Manhattan Island, thousands who delight in agriculture congregated to see the sights. The roads in the vicinity were fairly blocked with carriages, while even the extensive accommodations of the Long Island Railroad were inadequate to meet the requirements of the many visitors. The same scene was repeated on Friday with a much larger attendance.

abstract: HENRY R. MCIVOR, a paroled prisoner, who arrived in this city on Tuesday, gives us some interesting information of the treatment of our prisoners who were captured by the Yankees on the 28th.
lead_paragraph: HENRY R. MCIVOR, a paroled prisoner, who arrived in this city on Tuesday, gives us some interesting information of the treatment of our prisoners who were captured by the Yankees on the 28th. After they received the news of their final disaster, they placed the prisoners behind SIGEL's Division in the retreat, exposing them to the fire of the Confederates. Messrs. SICKLET and SANFORD PICKET, two gentlemen over 70 years of age, were forced to march through the rain to Alexandria. On arriving at Alexandria some ladies brought some food to the prisoners, who had eaten nothing for four days, save three crackers, but were driven away from them at the point of the bayonet, the officer telling his men to "clear those secesh bitches" away from there. The Federals refused to parole C. BALDWIN, Assistant-Surgeon to the Thirty-third Virginia. At Fortress Monroe several Germans took the oath, and when their fellow-prisoners taunted them with their shame, the Federal officer threatened to thrust his sword into them.

abstract: The week that has just passed away will, for all coming time, be one of the most memorable in our history, and in the progress of this gigantic war.
lead_paragraph: The week that has just passed away will, for all coming time, be one of the most memorable in our history, and in the progress of this gigantic war. It has seen three great battles less than a hundred miles from the National Capital, and involving the ownership of that capital; while there has not been a day, nor hardly an hour, when there was not brisk, though desultory, fighting going on along some part of our extended line. It opened with the rebel army planted on Maryland soil, vast in numbers, defiant in spirit, and exultant in the assured hope of victory. It closed, we hope and believe, with Maryland free from the polluting tread of the rebel army; and with that army so fearfully cut up in battle, disappointed in hope and broken in spirit, that it will never be able to present such a front again, and, if properly proceeded against, never be able to reorganize itself at all.
headline: {'main': 'The By-Gone Week Its Battles and Its Triumphs.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The By-Gone Week Its Battles and Its Triumphs.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It has not unfrequently been seen that two powerful men would wrestle together and one bring the other down with a heavy fall. The two would quickly rise again, but instead of renewing the struggle, one would turn away in silence from the ring. To the eye it might seem at the moment that no hurt was done, but that a like contest might any day be renewed between them.

abstract: A dispatch from the headquarters of Gen. MCCLELLAN'S army, dated yesterday morning, states that the rebel army had succeeded in making its escape from Maryland.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from the headquarters of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army, dated yesterday morning, states that the rebel army had succeeded in making its escape from Maryland. It appears that they commenced to move about dusk on Thursday evening, and by daylight on Friday they were all over the Potomac, with the exception of a small rear guard. They got over all their transportation, and all their wounded with the exception of about three hundred. Quite a number of stragglers were captured during the day by our advance of cavalry. At last accounts the rebels were still visible on the opposite shore in force, and they had posted a large number of cannon to prevent our troops from crossing. Our troops were all in excellent spirits. Our Washington dispatches inform us that a portion of them crossed the Potomac yesterday in pursuit of the flying rebels.

abstract: At a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a communication was received from  the Corporation Counsel, giving it as his opinion that the removals of Heads of Departments made by the Board at its previous meeting was per- fectly legal, and within the province of the Board.
lead_paragraph: At a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a communication was received from the Corporation Counsel, giving it as his opinion that the removals of Heads of Departments made by the Board at its previous meeting was per- fectly legal, and within the province of the Board. The Mayor returned a veto of the ordinance establishing a Military Hospital in the Central Park. A semi-monthly report of the disbursements in aid of the families of volunteers was received from the Comptroller, from which it appears that the number of families relieved was 13,295, comprising 13,154 adults and 18,351 children. The amount of money disbursed was $56,694. The first secession flag that was raised in Florida was presented to the Board by the Mayor, and ordered to be placed in the Governor's Room.

abstract: Editorial gives resume of Jackson background as tribute of respect; Editorial reviews past week of war; Observations from Great Britain
snippet: Editorial gives resume of Jackson background as tribute of respect; Editorial reviews past week of war; Observations from Great Britain
lead_paragraph: The Confederate Government is evidently advancing in civilization. Its Senate, a few days ago, defeated a bill which proposed to legalize the guerrilla warfare and bush whacking, which have been practiced by their predatory bands of murderers for a year past, under the polite name of partisan ranging. And now we learn that their Congress has adopted resolutions authorizing negotiations with the United States Government, on the manner of conducting the war so as to "mitigate its horrors!"

abstract: The first meeting of the Common Council of our sister city, Brooklyn, which once delighted to be called "rusurban," since their vacation will be held Monday night.
lead_paragraph: The first meeting of the Common Council of our sister city, Brooklyn, which once delighted to be called "rusurban," since their vacation will be held Monday night. Several ineffectual attempts have been made to call a special meeting of the Board of late, but the members were making the best of their advantages, and it was found impossible to convene a quorum in the city, as the members were scattered in every direction, some even sailing on a European tour. The Mayor, however, has been anxious to present some communications of importance for the consideration of the Board, and it is difficult to state the extent to which they may have accumulated by the delay. The Mayor's peculiar notions of economy apparently do not agree with the liberal views of the Board, and they had the presumption, at their last session, to pass measures on which the Mayor had placed his official vetoes. The Mayor, of course, was not at all pleased with this action, and reports at the City Hall have it that he had threatened to call in the aid of the law to uphold the dignity and power of his office against the refractory members of the City Government. The story soon assumed a shape which gave it a degree of probability. The Mayor was, so the report of the Aldermanic jokers runs, to imitate in a minor degree no less a personage than OLIVER CROMWELL, by depriving the municipal authorities who practically questioned his authority of the functions of their office. The Grand Jury were to be called on to indict them. The guardians of the City were to be compelled to vacate their snug and cosy chambers for the cells of the Penitentiary. The story, strange and improbable as it may appear, has obtained some credence.

abstract: Editorial, noting abundance of youth in new regiments, warns against recruiting them too young
snippet: Editorial, noting abundance of youth in new regiments, warns against recruiting them too young
lead_paragraph: cannot help noticing that in the regiments now passing to the seat of war, there is a greater proportion of very young men than have been enlisted any time during our national trouble. If this occurred from a scarcity of older and consequently more able-bodied recruits, it should meet with no protest from us, but the case is not so, and their appearance in the ranks must be attributed alone to the ardor of youth and the anxiety of each recruiting officer to fill his command.

abstract: The second day's races took place yesterday. The first race was for three-year olds, one mile, sweepstakes. Jack Homer, Miss Jessie, aed Blackbird, were entered. The race was won by Blackbird. The first heat was won by Jessie by a nose Blackbird second; time, 1:49 . Second heat Blackbird came in two lengths ahead of Jessie; Homer distanced; time, 1:48. Third heat Blackbird won easy; time, 1:51 .

abstract: The prize steamship Columbia, Acting-Master CHARLES SMITH, arrived at this port yesterday morning, in seven days from Key West. She is consigned to the United States Marshal of Florida, who is on board. She spoke on the 14th inst., off Cape Carnival, British brig Nancy, RILEY, of London, from Minatillan for London, in distress, all hands down with fever, and supplied her with medicine, ice, &c. On Friday last, off Capes of the Chesapeake, made a steamer ahead, and altered our course to speak her and obtain late New-York papers; upon seeing our change of course, she suddenly, and to our great surprise. veered about and steamed off to the eastward at a rapid rate. The Columbia showed her colors and dipped them gracefully to her, but she took no notice of the compliment, but putting on all steam was soon beyond the reach of our 2-pounder cannonade. The unknown steamer evidently supposed the Columbia to be a Confederate gunboat, and, believing discretion to be the better part of valor, tried the virtue of her wheel. The steamer was supposed to be the Columbia from New-York for Havana.
lead_paragraph: The prize steamship Columbia, Acting-Master CHARLES SMITH, arrived at this port yesterday morning, in seven days from Key West. abstract: A SKEDADDLE AT CAMP FRELINGHUYSEN. -- Some 600 or 800 of the New-Jersey nine months volunteers, encamped at Camp Frelinghuysen, took French leave on Saturday morning. There were some 2,300 soldiers in the camp, and, as we learn from one of the Corporals who did not skedaddle, they had been promised a furlough to enable them to visit their homes before marching to the seat of war. The furlough was promised for Wednesday last; when the time came, they were requested to wait until they got their uniforms. The uniforms were furnished on Friday, when, to their surprise, they were informed that they were under marching orders, and could not have a furlough at all. This caused much ill-feeling in camp, but the soldiers, although they were determined to have their promised furlough, yet decided to proceed in a quiet and orderly manner. They therefore held a mass meeting, and appointed a Committee to wait upon the commanding officer and inform him that they should leave camp yesterday morning, with or without a furlough, and that they would all return again at any reasonable time that he would fix. Morning came, and, as the Colonel in command had decided that he had no power to grant furloughs while they were under marching orders, about a third of the men, as above stated, skedaddled. Through the exertions of Capt. WALTER H. DODD, and Capt. MORRIS, of Newark, the remainder were persuaded to remain until arrangements could be made for their departure in a more soldier-like manner. Col. VAN VORST was finally prevailed upon to grant the men furloughs until 9 o'clock Monday morning, although he protested that he had no authority so to do. Furloughs were accordingly given to the remainder, and they departed quietly. It was stated in some of the evening papers that during the stampede of the skedaddlers one of the men was shot in the arm by Maj. BABCOCK. This is a mistake. The Major fired his pistol, hoping to intimidate the men and induce them to return, but it was not loaded with ball and nobody was hurt. The affair did not partake of the nature of a riot in any respect, and there is no doubt that nearly all the skedaddlers will quietly return to camp to-day. They are expected to leave for the seat of war on Wednesday.

abstract: The United States transport steamer Patuxent leaves this port at 7 o'clock A.M., for Roanoke Island, to connect with the mail steamer for Fortress Monroe. The sad disaster at Washington, N.C., by the accidental explosion of the magazine in the gunboat Picket leaves a perfect wreek of that noble boat. The loss of lives is not quite so great as first reported, while the number of wounded is more 18 being killed and 12 wounded.

abstract: Under any circumstances the advent of a new prima donna is matter of absorbing interest to that large and ever increasing class of the community who have had their senses cultivated to a love of, or respect for, the delicious mysteries of operatic art. Under the peculiar circumstances attending the debut of CARLOTTA PATTI, that class of the community, and a good many people beside, who do not generally care much about the lyric drama, are excited to a degree of interest such as could not be aroused by the appearance of a stranger -- however great that stranger might, by reputation, be. In the case of a strange, the applause of foreign audiences, and the eulogy of foreign critics, might provoke an immense deal of curiosity. There, however, until that applause and eulogy were known to be deserved, the attractive power of the new candidate would rest. But curiosity is not the current feeling about CARLOTTA PATTI. Everybody knows how she can sing. Everybody admits her possession of ease, and grace and beauty. No one has the least doubt that she will bear herself as charmingly upon the stage as she has always borne herself in the concert-room. What lends such special interest to her debut is the fact of its being the fulfillment of a long-cherished hope, the consummation of a tediously-deferred desire on the part of all who are acquainted with her wealth of vocal endowment, to see her make the first grand step toward achieving those triumphs which all feel in store for her -- triumphs which would long since have shed their lustre on her but for an unkind accident of Nature, that threatened to forever deprive her of the opportunity that she will have this evening.

abstract: The funeral obsequies of the late Father SCHNELLER, Pastor of St. Paul's (R.C.) Church, in Court-street, were celebrated in that Church, at 10 1/2 o'clock Saturday morning. The body of the venerable deceased, inclosed in a handsome rosewood coffin, and dressed in his robes of office, was placed at 4 o'clock Saturday morning on a handsome catafalque, in the centre aisle of the church, opposite the main altar. The lid of the coffin was open, exposing the face of the dead, on which rested such a serene and benignant expression that it seemed but the semblance and not the reality of death. The altar and other portions of the church were draped in deep mourning, and from an early hour in the morning the church was filled by a mourning throng of the late congregation of the lamented deceased clergyman, who, each in their turn, passed by the open coffin, and cast a sorrowful and lingering gaze at the pastor they all knew so intimately and loved so well. The pupils of the Convent of the Sisters of Mercy, and the inmates of the Orphan Asylum, both of whom had reason to mourn the loss of one who had exercised such a paternal care over them, occupied one of the side aisles of the church, habited in white coiffures, presenting an imposing view. The services commenced at half-past ten, with Father KEEGAN as celebrant, Father FAGAN as deacon, Father MCKENNA as sub-deacon, and a large concourse of clergymen, assisted in the ceremonies, among whom were the Right Rev. Bishop LAUGHLIN, of this diocese; Revds. Messrs. CONSTANTINE PISE, D.D.; MULLANE, MCGUIRE, DELAVAN, MCGOVERN, O'FARRELL, YEANCES, MALONE, MCCLOSKEY, MCDONNELL and O'NEAL. Just before the final ceremonies, the Rev. Dr. PISE ascended the pulpit, and delivered an eloquent and feeling eulogy on the deceased. He laid particular stress upon his charitable disposition, and during the delivery of the preacher's eloquent remarks, very many of the congregation were moved to tears, and stifled sobs were heard from all parts of the building. The musical portion of the services were conducted by Mr. MAX BRAUN, the competent organist of the church, and consisted of SCHMIDT's requiem Mass, which was excellently rendered by Madame ANCHUTZ and Miss NEWMAN as soprani, Mr. WEINLECH as basso, Mr. JOHN BROWN and Mr. HOFFMAN, tenorii, and Miss NEWMAN as contralto. At the conclusion of the exercises the body was conveyed to the Cemetery of the Holy Cross, at Flatbush, for interment, followed by a large cortege of the parishioners of the deceased and others.

abstract: Our late dispatches from the vicinity of the late terrible battle of Antietam, inform us that the rebel army had succeeded in making its escape from Maryland. It appears that the rebels commenced to move about dusk on Thursday evening, and by daylight on Friday they were all over the Potomac, with the exception of a small rear guard. They got over all their transportation, and all their wounded with the exception of about three hundred. Quite a number of stragglers were captured during the day by our advance of cavalry. At last accounts the rebels were still visible on the opposite shore in force, and they had posted a large number of cannon to prevent our troops from crossing. Our troops were all in excellent spirits. Our Washington dispatches inform us that a portion of them crossed the Potomac on Saturday in pursuit of the flying rebels.

abstract: Editorial on Confederates safe retreat into Virginia speculates on why Union did not pursue them in force; Editorial sees recent Union successes in Maryland demoralizing South
snippet: Editorial on Confederates safe retreat into Virginia speculates on why Union did not pursue them in force; Editorial sees recent Union successes in Maryland demoralizing South
lead_paragraph: It is not easy, perhaps, to estimate the effects of a victory until we have accurately ascertained its extent; and until we have received satisfactory intelligence of the character and fortunes of our operations upon the line of the rebel retreat into Virginia, elaborate speculations upon the results at the South of Gen. MCCLELLAN's recent successes in Maryland must be regarded as premature. It is hardly safe, for instance, to assume with an enthusiastic cotemporary, that the battle of Antietam will be followed at an early day by the downfall of England and France, the invasion of Canada, and the conquest of Mexico. But we have facts enough before us to justify a brief consideration of the moral influence which the great conflict of the past week is likely to exert upon the temper and the policy of the Southern leaders.

abstract: Two more battalions of the Black River Light Artillery, numbering about 1,200 men, arrived here last evening, and were quartered at the Park Barracks. One of the two battalions that arrived three days ago took their departure for Washington on Saturday evening. The other still remains at the Park Barracks and will go into a camp of instruction on Staten Island to-day. The battalions which arrived last evening will probably accompany them. The Black River Light Artillery were recruited principally in Jefferson and Lewis Counties, and have been for some time past in garrison at Sackett's Harbor. Another battalion still remains there, and will be on in a few days.

abstract: Amen to the order of the Navy Department, dismissing from the service Commander GEORGE HENRY PREBLE, senior officer in command of the blockading force off Mobile, for allowing the armed steamer Oveto to run the blockade at that point a short time since. The report of Commodore FARRAGUT makes the neglect of duty palpable, and the justice of the punishment will be universally acknowledged. This, is, we believe, the first instance, since the outbreak of the war, of the Navy Department's punishing an officer for doing too little, though it has been claimed that some officers have been dismissed for doing too much.

abstract: A SUSPICIOUS CASE OF DROWNING -- A COLORED MAN FOUND IN THE WATER WITH HIS FEET TIED. -Coroner COLLIN on Saturday held an inquest upon the body of JOHN COOPER, (colored,) aged 29 years, who was found in the water at the foot of Harrison-street, at a late hour on Friday evening, under circumstances which render it almost certain that the deceased had been the victim of foal play. The evidence, as developed upon the inquest, is briefly and substantially as follows: Late on Friday evening, Capt. HARDY, of the barge N.F. Whitby, heard a man, who was then in the water near the stern of his barge, shouting and halloing as if he were in a drowning condition. The Captain soon procured a light, and then he found the deceased was struggling in the water and trying to seize hold of some part of the barge to save himself from sinking. A boat-hook was procured, and with the assistance of others, the unfortunate man was raised to the deck of the barge, in a very exhausted condition. It was then ascertained that his feet were tied firmly together with a quantity of thread. The Police of the Fifth Precinct were notified, and COOPER was taken to the Station-house, where he died yesterday morning. The jury rendered a verdict that "deceased came to his death by congestion of the lungs, caused by immersion in the water." The whole transaction has a very suspicious appearance, and the police are trying to ferret out the mystery. The deceased, on his way to the Station-House, told the officers that some smart fellow had tied his feet and then threw him overboard.

abstract: Editorial says military draft in US improves job opportunities and wages for immigrants; Editorial says draft improves immigrants wage and job opportunities; Editorial holds immigrants wage and job chances improved by Union Army draft
snippet: Editorial says military draft in US improves job opportunities and wages for immigrants; Editorial says draft improves immigrants wage and job opportunities; Editorial holds immigrants wage and job chances improved by Union Army draft
lead_paragraph: Mr. SEWARD was quite right in stating, in his recent circular to foreign Governments that this country never presented such advantages to the immigrant laborer as it does at this very time. Of course, a popular impression abroad among the ignorant would be that fire and sword and civil wrath were desolating all those rich broad lands of the West, which once so attracted the foreigner; that neighbor was waylaying neighbor, burning his crops and carrying off his cattle; that there was no sure payment of, labor and no safety for property; that even in safe districts the poor immigrant was still liable to conscription, and was exposed to the heavy taxation of the war.
headline: {'main': 'Advantages to the Immigrant.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Advantages to the Immigrant.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial notes Union surrender of Munfordsville puts Union in more dubious position in Kentucky
snippet: Editorial notes Union surrender of Munfordsville puts Union in more dubious position in Kentucky
lead_paragraph: The confirmation of the news of the surrender of Munfordsville, Ky., to the rebel army of Gen. BRAGG, upsets all previous information as to the nearness of Gen. BUELL's pursuing columns. Gen. ROUSSEAU, whose rapid advance down the Louisville and Nashville railroad, last Summer, stopped the rebel advance at Munfordsville, was said to have followed Gen. BUCKNER back to Glasgow, one week ago, after the latter had failed in his assault on Munfordsville. And Gen. ROUSSEAU was leading BUELL's advance in pursuit of BRAGG. But now we are told that BRAGG's whole army came up two days later, surrounded Munfordsville and forced it to surrender. ROUSSEAU was not a General to suffer that result, if he had been so near. We are, therefore, obliged to conclude that BUELL's army is not so near to BRAGG's as we had been led to believe.
headline: {'main': 'The Position in Kentucky.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Position in Kentucky.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: of the reports of last week's battles in Maryland, or the correspondence from the field, are there any of those accusations of misbehavior on the part of individual regiments, or brigades, or officers of any grade, that have frequently sullied the reports of previous battles. Every regiment seems to have done its duty to the death -- none flinching; every General and subordinate officer appears to have honored his rank. The applause for valor, endurance, and patience were merited by every man wearing the Nation's uniform.

abstract: Editorial notes Union is always successful when on offensive
snippet: Editorial notes Union is always successful when on offensive
lead_paragraph: ous when it is the attacking party. The battles of Gen. MCCLELLAN last week are the first for a long time in which we have assumed the offensive. In the battles on the Peninsula we were always on the defensive; in Gen. POPE's battles in Virginia he was on the defensive. In the West, in the battle at Shiloh, and in other instances of ill-success or dubious success, we were on the defensive; while at Donelson and other glorious fields we were the attacking party. In the victory of ROSECRANS over PRICE, officially reported this morning, the Union officer was on the offensive. And a hundred other examples and illustrations might be found. Gen. MCCLELLAN is now actively following the rebels up. We hope he will unflinchingly assail them wherever found. Our success is always in the attack.

abstract: Shelling was kept up at the enemy across the river at Shepherdstown until Friday night.  A report has come into Frederick that a force was crossing at Williamsport, and that a part of our army was sent to meet them. Heavy firing was heard at noon to-day in that direction and at Sharpsburgh, but up to to-night no intelligence has been received from either place.

abstract: The funeral exercises over the body of the late Gen. RENO took place Friday noon at Trinity Church, Boston, in the presence of a large concourse of spectators. It was the desire of friends that the funeral should be without military display. A large number of men eminent in civil and military life were present, including Gov. ANDREW and staff, Adjutant Gen. SCHOULER, Brigadier Gen. ANDREWS, Col. BURRILL, with many officers of regiments now in the vicinity of Boston.

abstract: It seems to be quite certain that the main bulk of the rebel army will make good its retreat, -- that it will fall back successfully upon its base of operations, whether that be at Winchester or at Richmond. On Saturday morning they were all safely out of Maryland, -- having crossed the Potomac, partly on Thursday, without attracting the attention of our army, and partly on Friday, in spite of our attempts, which do not seem to have been very formidable, to overtake and arrest them. On Saturday they had planted batteries on the Virginia side of the Potomac to resist pursuit. We have a report that Gen. MCCLELLAN had crossed and engaged them again; but, if this be true, the engagement was probably only with their rear guard, as they would scarcely detain their main army for the purpose of renewing the battle, unless the comparative weakness of the force which MCCLELLAN could throw across in a single day should offer them a tempting prospect of success.

abstract: -- Much uncertainty still exists in regard to the responsibility of the loss of Harper's Ferry. It does not seem clear that Gen. MCCLELLAN can be held responsible for it, although Col. MILES is reported to have sent to him six couriers on Saturday, begging for reinforcements, which, however, did not arrive as expected. Gen. FRANKLIN, who was in charge of them, encountered a heavy force of rebels on the way.
lead_paragraph: -- Much uncertainty still exists in regard to the responsibility of the loss of Harper's Ferry. It does not seem clear that Gen. abstract: There seems now to remain little doubt that a National force has at last really reoccupied (it would be absurd to say recaptured) Harper's Ferry. This was not done, however, until the rebels had made all the use they wished to of that important position. Having done so, they voluntarily abandoned it -- taking care, though, to destroy all the Government stores they were not disposed to take away with them. In this destruction they included the pontoon bridge over the Potomac, which, if destroyed by Col. MILES before the rebels came down upon him, would have completely checkmated them and prevented their making any use of the position. But what we should have done as an imperative necessity and failed to do, they did with no such prime object in view, but simply in pursuance of their general policy of weakening us at every possible point. If the rebels do not wish to recapture Harper's Ferry, we may perhaps be allowed to hold, occupy and possess it at our leisure.

abstract: To-night the Brooklyn Horticultural Society open the Brooklyn Academy of Music in grand and gorgeous style. The house has been superbly decorated with flags and banners, and beautifully entwined with floral garlands. Everybody will desire to be there, that they may see the exhibition, and not only that, but that they may aid the widows and children of the deceased soldiers of the army of the Union. On Friday night, in furtherance of the same blessed work, a grand promenade concert will be had at the same place, and under the same auspices. DODWORTH's unexcelled band will furnish the music, and a delightful evening may be confidently anticipated.
lead_paragraph: To-night the Brooklyn Horticultural Society open the Brooklyn Academy of Music in grand and gorgeous style.
