abstract: THE MAGDALENS AND THE ARMY WORK. One good, arising from the overplus of labor and scarcity of laborers, is the business it suppiles to our benevolent institutions.
lead_paragraph: THE MAGDALENS AND THE ARMY WORK. -- One good, arising from the overplus of labor and scarcity of laborers, is the business it suppiles to our benevolent institutions. The frail Sisters, who are for a time pent up within the "Magdalen Asylum" walls, know happier hours now than usually fall to their lot; for they have plenty to do, and, even more than this, they are inspired by the knowledge that they are working for their country. Their contract, procured through the efforts of the worthy Steward of the Institution. Mr. OFFER, covers the necessities of six thousand soldiers in the matter of underclothing and bed furniture, as ticks, pillow-slips, &c. Ten machines keep up a busy hum in the sewing-room, and the work was never more merrily done. The girls and women seem more than thankful for it, and vie with each other in progress. The papers are read to them once a day, and an eager attention is manifested by nearly all. Already two thousand garments of the present demand have been completed, and will be sent at once to the needy troops about Washington. Four sewing-machines have been purchased for the asylum, and the inmates take useful lessons thereon, thus practicing a trade which may afterward assist them to an honorable livelihood. They like the noisy machines best, for it sounds more as if they were accomplishing much. WHEELER & WILSON have lent them four, and GROVER & BAKER two, till the rush of work is over.

abstract: Were the question to be asked, "what disease is most prevalent among mankind," a countless multitude of haggard, pallid, and melancholy faces would answer "Dyspepsia." In all lands to which civilization has extended, this disease exists; but in this country the number of dyspeptics is larger, in proportion to the population, than in any other on the face of the earth. It is unquestionably one of the greatest of human afflictions, inasmuch as it not only breaks down the physical system, but depresses the mental and moral faculties to the verse, in many instances, of positive imbecility.

lead_paragraph: Our grave and gentlemanly cotemporary, the Journal of Commerce, was yesterday guilty of a slight indiscretion. In the excess of its joy over the recent victory of Antietam, which the Journal seems to regard rather as a political than as a military achievement, our neighbor unthinkingly admits the substantial identity of its own party at the North with a set of leaders at the South who have not commonly been regarded as the warmest friends of "the Union and the Constitution." Here are its words of jubilee:

abstract: The arrival of the steamship Nova Scotian off Cape Race, puts us in possession of European advices to the 12th instant -- two days later. The news, however, is meagre and unimportant. The sales of the week in the Liverpool Cotton Market had been only 18,500 bales, and the market closed dull, with a decline of 2d. on the week. The market closed somewhat firmer, and with a slight advance from the lowest figure. Breadstuffs were quiet, and Provisions flat. Consols were quoted at 93 5/8 for Money.

abstract: -- We fear we shall have to let go the anticipations of the assault on Charleston, raised by two or three reports. The Navy Department solemly denies the imputation. Nevertheless, the necessity of the possession of the place remains as pressing as ever. From the many and intricate channels leading into the harbor its effective blockade is impossible; and almost every day rebel craft slip in, laden with contraband aid and comfort, It is, in fact, the chief depot through which they receive their arms, ammunition, and military supplies. It would be worth the value of twenty iron-clads, that we should get possession of the place. The Potomac and Baltimore are now "safe," the iron-clads are relieved from duty at those points: why should not the Monitor and the Roanoke be sent down on this mission, while the Galena, Ironsides, &c. keep watch and ward in Hampton Roads over the Merrimac No. 2.

abstract: Not one man in a thousand can report correctly facts observed by him. Any one fa- miliar with the giving of testimony in courts or with reports of scientific phenomena by in- experienced persons, will readily agree to this statement.
lead_paragraph: Not one man in a thousand can report correctly facts observed by him. Any one familiar with the giving of testimony in courts or with reports of scientific phenomena by inexperienced persons, will readily agree to this statement. Very few men, indeed, when they observe facts, see the important ones, or remember them when they do see them. We presume the whole public, like ourselves, has felt this difficulty in the reports with regard to the condition and numbers of the rebel army. The accounts seemed so often purely "sensation descriptions," and to be made by people of so little habit of observation, or under such excitement of feeling, that we have come to put very little confidence in them.
headline: {'main': 'Condition of the Rebel Army.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Condition of the Rebel Army.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Now that the rebel invading army has been driven out of Maryland, we trust that there will be no further delay on the part of our Southwestern commanders in driving the invading rebels out of Kentucky. These Southwestern Generals, by combining their armies, will have a much larger force to operate with than Gen. MCCLELLAN had when he marched against the united rebel army of Virginia, while the foe they have to meet is not half the strength of that which was defeated last Wednesday at Antietam. Why do these Western Generals -- BUELL, WRIGHT and GRANT, -- permit such a great region of Kentucky to be for so long a time held by the Secessionists? The rebel army was expelled from Maryland within ten-days from the time it had crossed the Potomac; while in Kentucky, notwitstanding the overwhelming comparative advantages in our favor, a small rebel force has been allowed to hold and plunder more than half of the State for over a month. It is true the distances to be gone over are greater in Kentucky than they were in Maryland; but the other advantages we have mentioned on the Western side, far more than overbalance this difficulty. The BRAGG-SMITH army ought to have been, and could easily be, as quickly expelled from Kentucky as LEE's has been expelled from Maryland, if it were followed up and attacked with equal vigor. The Western soldiers will lose their deserved reputation for dash and daring if they permit the rebels much longer to revel in the capital, and fatten on the produce of the richest section, of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: -- Now that the rebel invading army has been driven out of Maryland, we trust that there will be no further delay on the part of our Southwestern commanders in driving the invading rebels out of Kentucky. MCCLELLAN had when he marched against the united rebel army of Virginia, while the foe they have to meet is not half the strength of that which was defeated last Wednesday at Antietam. Why do these Western Generals -- BUELL, WRIGHT and GRANT, -- permit such a great region of Kentucky to be for so long a time held by the Secessionists? The rebel army was expelled from Maryland within ten-days from the time it had crossed the Potomac; while in Kentucky, notwitstanding the overwhelming comparative advantages in our favor, a small rebel force has been allowed to hold and plunder more than half of the State for over a month. It is true the distances to be gone over are greater in Kentucky than they were in Maryland; but the other advantages we have mentioned on the Western side, far more than overbalance this difficulty. The BRAGG-SMITH army ought to have been, and could easily be, as quickly expelled from Kentucky as LEE's has been expelled from Maryland, if it were followed up and attacked with equal vigor. The Western soldiers will lose their deserved reputation for dash and daring if they permit the rebels much longer to revel in the capital, and fatten on the produce of the richest section, of Kentucky.

abstract: There has been no more important and farreaching document ever issued since the foundation of this Government than the proclamation of President LINCOLN concerning Slavery and slaves, published this morning.
lead_paragraph: There has been no more important and farreaching document ever issued since the foundation of this Government than the proclamation of President LINCOLN concerning Slavery and slaves, published this morning. The President opens up his proclamation by declaring that hereafter, as heretofore, the object of the war will be the restoration of the authority of the Constitution. He then observes that it is his purpose to again recommend to Congress, at its next meeting, the adoption of a scheme tendering aid to those Slave States which may adopt measures for the immediate or gradual abolishment of Slavery; to which he adds a remark that the efforts to colonize negroes outside of the United States will be continued. Then, after these introductory and secondary declarations, comes the gist of the proclamation, which we here repeat:

abstract: Our dispatches from the West are of a most Startling character. Gen. BRAGG is said to have escaped from Gen. BUELL, and to be marching rapidly on Louisville, Ky., which city is naturally thrown into a tremendous...
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from the West are of a most Startling character. Gen. BRAGG is said to have escaped from Gen. BUELL, and to be marching rapidly on Louisville, Ky., which city is naturally thrown into a tremendous excitement. And this excitement, instead of being confined to the populace, who are mostly non-combatants, and chiefly interested in saving their lives and property if the city is attacked, has seized upon the military commandant, Brig.-Gen. NELSON, and caused him to commit the most phrenzied and absurd actions. He has issued an order directing the women and children of Louisville to be prepared to leave the city without delay. And to add to the confusion and alarm Which such an order must bring upon a city of 70,000 inhabitants, aroused to a sudden danger, he instantly adds that Jefferson ferry (the only ferry by which the people could escape) is to be used "exclusively for military purposes."
headline: {'main': 'The Alarm at Louisville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Alarm at Louisville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Early yesterday morning, a young boy (?) ap- parently about 17 years of age, carpet-bag in hand, and attired in full Zouave costume, presented himself at a shipping office in the Third Precinct, and stated...
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning, a young boy (?) apparently about 17 years of age, carpet-bag in hand, and attired in full Zouave costume, presented himself at a shipping office in the Third Precinct, and stated his desire to embark on a whaling voyage. After conversing with the lad for some time, the person in charge of the office had his suspicions aroused, by the seeming effeminacy of the applicant, that all was not as it appeared. He accordingly sent for Capt. MOUNT, of the Third Precinct, who, immediately on seeing the youthful would-be seaman, pronounced her a female beyond all question, despite her very artful disguise. After a great deal of protestation, the young girl confessed that her name was BRIDGET SILK, she was seventeen years old, and was a native of Eastchester, N.Y., where she had been living with her sister. Her parents were dead some time. She had become imbued with a desire for romantic adventure, and for the purpose of carrying out her plans, had intended shipping for a whaling voyage. She had selected the Zouave costume as a better disguise than an orninary male attire, and she made quite a creditable Zu-Zu. Her first idea was to enter the army as a volunteer, but the difficulty of passing the doctor had restrained her from this course, as she knew no way of avoiding the -- to her -- awkward but necessary ceremony. She expressed her intention quite freely to run away again, if she was sent home, as she had determined to see the world outside the narrow limits of the village where she was reared. Capt. MOUNT presented her to Superintendent KENNEDY, who directed Officer RICE to take her to her friends. Mr. RICE, when we last saw him, was carrying a huge carpet-bag in one hand, and leading the girl-boy by the other, she followed by a crowd of curious masculinities.
headline: {'main': 'Romantic Adventure A Female Zouave.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Romantic Adventure A Female Zouave.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- About the only thing we know of the rebel army is, that it is all out of Maryland; and the telegraphic indications this morning are, that it is continuing its retreat in Virginia, and altogether leaving the line of the Potomac. There have been fears expressed that the rebels might suddenly cross once more into Maryland lower down the river than the point at which they got out of it, and suddenly march upon Washington while our array is absent. But, it must be remembered, that notwithstanding all cavils, we have an army left in Washington sufficient to defend it -- now that we know Baltimore is safe and loyal in the rear, -- while, in such an event, MCCLELLAN's victorious army would march back to Washington as quickly as it marched out from it a fortnight ago to pursue the rebels. On the south side of the Potomac we have another army under most gallant leaders, which it seems has not been sent to cut off the rebel retreat at any point. Possibly it has been kept at the forts to prevent the rebels from coming down from Harper's Ferry on the south side, capturing Arlington Heights, and attacking the Capital in front. It is difficult to tell where the rebel army is pushing to. Probably Gen. HALLECK is waiting to discover before he makes any moves. It would not be surprising if it did not halt till it got back to Richmond, or if it again took up the old quarters at Manassas -- which, at present, we could very easily prevent.

abstract: respondent, this morning, makes some grave statements in reference to the Franco-Mexican question. The French army in Mexico, it is reported, is to be carried up to 80,000 men, and is to remain in that country, and an immense amount of provisions have been bought up for the Expedition. The Engineer who has been sent out, is not going to locate a road from Vera Cruz to the Capital, "till after he has located a road across the Isthmus, from the Gulf of Mexico to the Pacific -- a road intended to counteract the Pacific Railroad of the Americans." Everything indicates a grand scheme of conquest and occupation in the New World by the French troops. NAPOLEON's schemes look to nothing less than a colonial empire in Mexico, whose revenues shall be derived from the rich silver and gold mines of that country, now and for a long time rendered almost entirely worthless by the political disorders that have prevailed. It is well for us to keep an eye on these things. They are intimately related to the purposes which the French and other European Governments entertain with reference to the breaking up of this Republic, and the establishment in its stead of a series of petty and rival Governments. Our unity and consolidation would be the destruction of all their selfish schemes on this continent.

abstract: This place may be considered the extreme right of the Union lines. Since the departure of the rebels across the river last Saturday, nothing of interest has occured. For the first time during the past four days I am enabled, by being upon the spot, to ascertain the facts in regard to the rebel proceedings upon the Upper Potomac, subsequently to their crossing the river, near Shepherdstown, into Virginia last Thursday.

abstract: The name and fame of GARIDALDI belong not to Italy alone, but to freedom and the world. His long life of devotion to ...
lead_paragraph: The name and fame of GARIDALDI belong not to Italy alone, but to freedom and the world. His long life of devotion to his country has passed into the treasury of historical inspiration; his marvelous victories have already become a legend of liberty; his very mistakes and extravagancies like the mistakes and extravagancies of every noble nature in its pursuit of noble ends, will transmit a golden warning and instruction of their own to future times. It should be matter for satisfaction, then, to all thinking men, that the Italian Government has decided to bring the hero of Sicily, now become the victim of Aspromonte, to a trial before the highest Court of Italian justice, the Italian people in Parliament assembled. The nature and extent of the fault which has been committed by the successful liberator of Naples and the Alps, in his unsuccessful at tempt at the liberation of Home, can only be fairly and adequately recorded in the result of such a trial before such a tribunal. Only in this way, too, can the Government of VICTOR EMANUEL do justice to itself and its own motives at the bar of history. For it is the most remarkable feature of this most remarkable case, that the accusing Government is itself upon trial at the same time with the accused rebel. The duty imposed upon VICTOR EMANUEL and his Ministry by the expedition against Rome, was a duty which needs to be gravely vindicated and established. It needs to be shown past all cavil, and with supreme solemnity, that the King, whose crown was set firmly upon his head by the right hand of the man who is to-day his prisoner, could only prove himself worthy to wear that crown by striking down that prisoner's arm when it was once more raised to fix the final cross of Capitoline splendor upon the diadem. A painful and terrible thing it was to do; and although the conscience of the civilized world has already justified the King of Italy in doing it, the future peace of Italy, not less than the royal record itself, demands that the justification should be made ull, formal and explicit.

abstract: The Emperor has received a letter from President JUAREX, in which he complains that it is imposible for him to establish a stable Government, precisely because of the French expedition against him. He therefore proposes an arrangement which would have, as he insists, the effect of separating the French troops from the faction which has hitherto supported them, and establish a good understanding between them and what he calls the national party.

abstract: CITY GOVERNMENT. To-day at 3 o'clock a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen will be held for the transaction of such business as may come before that august body. There are various rumors ...
lead_paragraph: CITY GOVERNMENT. -- To-day at 3 o'clock a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen will be held for the transaction of such business as may come before that august body. There are various rumors in the metropolitan atmosphere as to the sudden calling together of the civic fraternity, among which we hear of the possible removal of Mr. Engineer CRAVEN, and that Mr. Commissioner KNAPP intends serving an injunction on the Mayor preventing him from appointing a successor, &c. At all events, the business will be of more importance than any which could accidentally be brought up.

abstract: Editorial speculates on Confederate Army preparing for another battle on Virginia side of Potomac
snippet: Editorial speculates on Confederate Army preparing for another battle on Virginia side of Potomac
lead_paragraph: It is one consequence of the conditions under which our great civil war is waged, that the people of the loyal States are constantly tempted into forgetting that the questions at issue between the rebels and themselves must and can be settled only in the field. This is the case to-day, whatever may have been the aspects of the matter a year ago. The fortune of actual war is, or ought to be, the supremely engrossing subject of our national attention and anxiety. Had it been so, perhaps, from the first, we might have a briefer catalogue of mistakes and disasters to look back upon now.That it shall be so for the future should be the earnest determination of every thoughtful patriot. We must shake off the habit of contemplating the successive battles of the war as so many tremendous spasms, to be succeeded by lulls of reflection and hypothesis. The real position and progress of our arms is the really vital question of every day. When we are not gaining, we may be sure that we are, if not actually losing, in danger of losing ground; for our enemies are desperate, active, numerous, and unresting.

abstract: stated by a correspondent of one of the New-York papers that Mr. BILLINGS HOBART, Jr., of St. Denis, Md., is a Secessionist, and engaged in furnishing aid to the enemy. Through the maliciousness of some personal enemies he was recently arrested and brought to the Relay House. The charges against him were not substantiated. Mr. HOBART was born and educated at the North, and has relatives of high standing in this city. He is a strong Union man, and deserves to be relieved from the temporary odium which this false report has cost upon his character. -- Philadelphia Press.

abstract: GASPARIN, whose death in France is announced, is not the distinguished defender of our Republic and of free institutions before Europe -- with whom yesterday's evening papers confounded him. It is ADRIEN-ETIENNE-PIERRE, Comte DE GASPARIN, an old man, eighty years of age, who formerly figured somewhat in French politics, and wrote various works on agricultural, rural, veterinary and cognate matters. If the Count DE GASPARIN, whose name is so widely known and honored throughout this country, lives as long as his family namesake who has just died, he has more than a quarter of a century of activity and usefulness before him.
lead_paragraph: GASPARIN, whose death in France is announced, is not the distinguished defender of our Republic and of free institutions before Europe -- with whom yesterday's evening papers confounded him. abstract: The mammoth ship, still lies in Flushing Bay, where the damage sustained by running on a rock off Montauk Point on her last trip to this port is be- ing repaired. We learn that the reports of exper- ienced divers show that the ship's bottom was opened by the rock along a single line of her outer plate for a distance of several feet.
lead_paragraph: The mammoth ship, still lies in Flushing Bay, where the damage sustained by running on a rock off Montauk Point on her last trip to this port is be- ing repaired. We learn that the reports of exper- ienced divers show that the ship's bottom was opened by the rock along a single line of her outer plate for a distance of several feet. The inner "skin" or hull of the ship was not touched, and remains as dry as on the day of launching, and the vessel could proceed on her voyage across the ocean to-day with more safely than can any vessel having but a single hull. Nevertheless, her officers and agents are pushing forward her repair by a very simple method, tried once before in Milford Haven with entire success, and which has the entire approbation of distinguished American engineers.

abstract: A meeting was held on Friday evening last, in the Eight-sixth-street M.E. Church, for the purpose of encouraging enlistments in this regiment, now organizing under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association, H.M. DIKEMAN, Esq., in the ...
lead_paragraph: A meeting was held on Friday evening last, in the Eight-sixth-street M.E. Church, for the purpose of encouraging enlistments in this regiment, now organizing under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association, H.M. DIKEMAN, Esq., in the Chair. Hon. B.F. MANIERRE made a statement as to the origin and object of the Ironsides Regiment, which is already before the public, and was followed by brief though stirring remarks from Rev. H. Lounsberry, Col. Chas. Gould, Hon. A. Wakeman, Rev. A.P. Botsford, and Capt. Pullman, of Company A, whose headquarters are at No. 481 Third-avenue. The addresses were interspersed with several patriotic songs by the choir. A Committee, consisting of two from each of the churches located in Yorkville, was appointed to carry out the object of the meeting. One hundred dollars was contributed by Hon. A. WAKEMAN, and $10 by Mr. GEO. MARINOR. Another meeting will be held in the Eighty-sixth-street Presbyterian Church, on Monday evening, the 20th inst.

abstract: The intelligence of the fall of Harper's Ferry was fully confirmed yesterday. The event is extremely important, and every way auspicious for the Confederate cause. In some respects, it is one of ...
lead_paragraph: The intelligence of the fall of Harper's Ferry was fully confirmed yesterday. The event is extremely important, and every way auspicious for the Confederate cause. In some respects, it is one of the most momentous successes of the war. The number of prisoners captured is probably greater than has been taken in any other single engagement during the war, exceeding even the number taken by the Federal forces at Fort Donelson, or by the Confederates in the battles before Richmond. In material results, the victory is extraordinarily fruitful. Large quantities of small aims were taken; a great amount of ammunition, and several hundred wagons, ordnance stores, Quartermaster's and Commissary's stores. Such particulars as have come to hand will be found in another part of this morning's paper. In another point of view this success is highly important, it expels the last remnant of the federal army from the Valley, and secures the whole of that rich country to the Confederacy. It relieves Gen. LEE from all apprehension of danger in his rear, and opens a safe line of communication with Richmond. It might have been unsafe to leave the strong position of Harper's Ferry in possession of the enemy; but now that this point has, been provided for, Gen. LEE can prosecute his plans without apprehension.

abstract: WESTERN VIRGINIA. -- From an advertisement of the rebel Ordnance Department, in the Richmond Whig, we learn that "all preparations for Major-Gen. FLOYD's army are being concentrated at Lynchburgh." It would seem from this that FLOYD is making extensive preparations for work in Western Virginia, where the campaign has already opened on the Gauley and Kanawha Rivers, with considerable successes on the rebel side. We have hardly any troops in that great section of Virginia now to resist the advance of FLOYD's ten thousand "irregulars," and it would not be astonishing if he were shortly to make his way across the mountains, take advantage of its unprotected condition, and capture and hold it as KIRBY SMITH has captured and held Kentucky. There is only one way by which Western Virginia can be permanently held, other than by maintaining a large army there, and that is by the capture of East Tennessee. If we held Knoxville and Abingdon, on the line of the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad, there would be no further trouble with Western Virginia, and FLOYD's occupation would be gone. In its bearings upon the rebellion and the rebel armies in the East and in the West, the occupation of East Tennessee is the most important movement it is possible to make. But we are getting up expeditions to go into Texas, into the Indian Territory, and everywhere in rebeldom but there.
lead_paragraph: WESTERN VIRGINIA. -- From an advertisement of the rebel Ordnance Department, in the Richmond Whig, we learn that "all preparations for Major-Gen. abstract: Five years ago, during the progress of the "Great Revival" some young men of this City met in the North Dutch Church, corner of Fulton and William streets for prayer and Praise to the Most High. Their meetings soon became popular, and the good done at, and by them, was incalculable. Since that time the exercises have been continued without, intermission, though of late they have not been as fully attended as they were during the religious excitement.

abstract: Wellington Clapp et al. vs. Samuel B. Beckman et al. -- The plaintiffs brought a creditor's action against the defendants, to set aside an assignment made by the defendant Beekman and Henry Moore, by their firm name of Beekman & Co., on the ground that one or more of the preferences contained in the assignment -- e.g., to Loder & Co. and to B.F. Beekman & Co. -- were founded on fictitious and fraudulent indebtedness. On an affidavit setting forth these allegations, the plaintiffs petition the Court for a deposit of the account books of the firm Beekman & Co. with the County Clerk, to enable them to discover the real indebtness of Beekman & Co. to Loder & Co. and B.F. Beekman & Co.

abstract: mond Whig, of Sept. 20, just received, we find an interesting account of JACKSON's advance to attack POPE, at the end of August. The account is given in a letter from a young officer of Gen. A.P. HILL's division, which, with the division of EWELL and the old division of JACKSON himself, composed the corps d'armee of the latter officer, and made a total of probably 30,000 men. It appears from this account that after throwing POPE off his guard, by a feigned attack and retreat at Culpepper Springs, on the 22d August, JACKSON rejoined the main army of LEE and moved forward with that army, leading the advance, upon Bristow Station and Manassas Junction. On the march, EWELL's Division, we are told was engaged with a small force sent up by POPE from Warrenton, on the supposition that the advancing Confederate army was a "cavalry party!" At Manassas Junction the First New-Jersey Brigade was thrown upon the whole force of JACKSON's army, we are informed, under the same delusion, and actually "sent in a flag demanding the surrender" of the tremendous enemy into whose power they had thus unwittingly fallen! It was there and then that the gallant Brig.-Gen. TAYLOR met his death.
lead_paragraph: mond Whig, of Sept. 20, just received, we find an interesting account of JACKSON's advance to attack POPE, at the end of August. The account is given in a letter from a young officer of Gen. A.P. HILL's division, which, with the division of EWELL and the old division of JACKSON himself, composed the corps d'armee of the latter officer, and made a total of probably 30,000 men. It appears from this account that after throwing POPE off his guard, by a feigned attack and retreat at Culpepper Springs, on the 22d August, JACKSON rejoined the main army of LEE and moved forward with that army, leading the advance, upon Bristow Station and Manassas Junction. On the march, EWELL's Division, we are told was engaged with a small force sent up by POPE from Warrenton, on the supposition that the advancing Confederate army was a "cavalry party!" At Manassas Junction the First New-Jersey Brigade was thrown upon the whole force of JACKSON's army, we are informed, under the same delusion, and actually "sent in a flag demanding the surrender" of the tremendous enemy into whose power they had thus unwittingly fallen! It was there and then that the gallant Brig.-Gen. TAYLOR met his death.

abstract: Editorial on report Confederates are concentrating near Lynchburg
snippet: Editorial on report Confederates are concentrating near Lynchburg
lead_paragraph: Saturday states that among the captures made by the Confederates at Harper's Ferry on Monday of last week were two thousand negroes. Of course, these negroes were not paroled like our soldiers, but were driven South to be put to use, most likely, in the rebel army, or at some civil or military work in aid of the rebellion, or, perhaps, to be sold into Slavery. We have no doubt they will be subjected to the most atrocious treatment by their Southern captors. Many of them were undoubtedly freemen by birth; many had earned their freedom by services to our cause and our army; and all of them were under the guardianship and protection of the Government. Most of them were employed in various army work at Harper's Ferry, under the act of last session of Congress, authorizing the employment of negroes as military laborers. We suppose that Government will do nothing about these unfortunate persons, who had placed themselves under its care, though, by all the laws of war, of national honor, and of humanity, it is as much bound to see to their just treatment as to that of any other of its agents.

abstract: Two days' later advices from Europe have reached us by the steamship Scotia, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Liverpool on the 13th, and Queenstown on the 14th inst. The Index, the ...
lead_paragraph: Two days' later advices from Europe have reached us by the steamship Scotia, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Liverpool on the 13th, and Queenstown on the 14th inst. The Index, the London organ of the rebels, states that GEORGE N. SANDERS carried no communication whatever from the Confederate Government to its Commissioners in Europe. Serious disturbance had broken out at Pressnitz,. in Moravia, owing to the stoppage of the cotton factories. The riots continued for three days, and were only put an end by the arrival of a regiment of hussara. Thirty of the rioters were arrested. In England, attention was being generally attracted to jute as a substitute, in part, for cotton. A method is said to have been discovered by which it can be spun on cotton machinery. The price of jute, in consequence, had gone up 50 per cent. The Liverpool Cotton market was irregular, but an advance had taken place. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and provisions heavy! Consols were quoted at 93 1/2@93 5/8 for money. American Stocks, in consequence of the news of POPE'S reverses before Washington, were flat. Nothing at all seems as yet settled with respect to the fate of GARIBALDI and his followers. The Turin Government is evidently greatly embarrassed. The King, it is said, desires an amnesty, and the latest advices represent that it is almost settled that there will be one.

abstract: Affairs are very quiet. Good order prevails among the military.  Information has been received here that parties of rebel cavalry are scouring the country in the vicinity of Warrenton and the Rappahannock, impressing every able-bodied man they can find into the rebel army. Many refuse to serve, and some suceed in escaping and reaching our lines.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Tuesday. Sept. 23.

abstract: The Sanitary Commission is daily answering the requirements of eighty General Military Hospitals, not to speak of Regimental and other Hospitals. Of these forty-five hospitals, containing twenty thousand sick or wounded men, are in the District of Columbia. Whatever the surgeons want, which they cannot procure, according to regulations of the United States Purveyors, they can get from us, and they want enough to keep our vast storehouses, continually on the drain.
lead_paragraph: SANITARY COMMISSION, NEW-YORK AGENCY, No. 498 Broadway, Sept. 24, 1862.

abstract: The Republican State Convention assembled at Syracuse yesterday, and organized by the selection of Judge JOHNSON, of Albany, as temporary Chairman, with the requisite number of Secretaries. Some debate occurred as to the manner in which the Standing Committees should be chosen -- whether by the Chairman or by the Convention -- but it was finally decided that they should be appointed by the Chairman. The Committees on Contested Seats and Permanent Organization, having then been selected, the Convention took a recess until 4 o'clock. On reassembling the Convention was addressed by LYMAN TREMAINE, in review of Gov. SEYMOUR's address to the Democratic State Central Committee. The permanent organization was then effected, with Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, of New-York, as President. Other preliminaries having been settled, the Convention proceeded to the choice of candidates, and Hon. JAMES S. WADSWORTH was nominated for Governor on the first ballot. Subsequently, Hon. LYMAN TREMAINE, of Albany, was nominated for Lieutenant-Governor by acclamation, as was OLIVER LADUE, of Herkimer, for Canal Commissioner.

abstract: Human, floral and pomological beauty, fragrance and lusciousness permeated the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening, on the occasion of the annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society. The display of fruit, flowers and plants was enchanting, though creditable to Brooklyn mainly from the good taste shown in importations. Indeed, so far as Brooklyn proper was concerned, the most interesting item was a fine dish of sweet potatoes, "grown in the City."
lead_paragraph: Human, floral and pomological beauty, fragrance and lusciousness permeated the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday evening, on the occasion of the annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Horticultural Society. The display of fruit, flowers and plants was enchanting, though creditable to Brooklyn mainly from the good taste shown in importations. Indeed, so far as Brooklyn proper was concerned, the most interesting item was a fine dish of sweet potatoes, "grown in the City." The commodious stage of the Academy was thrown into a neat tent-scene, and the flooring was extended over the parquette, affording a spacious room for the arrangement of the exhibition tables, while the surrounding balconies enabled those who had viewed the choice exhibition, to enjoy the brilliant coup d'oeil, and at the same time be out of the way of those who came more to see than be seen.

abstract: The President has issued a Proclamation declaring that during the existing insurrection all rebels and insurgents, their aiders and abettors, within the United States, and all persons discouraging volunteer enlistments, resisting militia drafts, or guilty of any disloyal practice affording aid and comfort to the rebels, against the authority of the United States, shall be subject to martial law, and liable to trial and punishment by court-martial or military commission. The writ of habeas corpus is suspended in all such cases.
lead_paragraph: The President has issued a Proclamation declaring that during the existing insurrection all rebels and insurgents, their aiders and abettors, within the United States, and all persons discouraging volunteer enlistments, resisting militia drafts, or guilty of any disloyal practice affording aid and comfort to the rebels, against the authority of the United States, shall be subject to martial law, and liable to trial and punishment by court-martial or military commission. The writ of habeas corpus is suspended in all such cases.

abstract: Irving Hall has always been a favorite with the public. Its spaciousness especially commended it to the unvitiated, inartificial taste of those who think that a concert can be attended with comfort, that elbow room and a ball-room are not wholly incompatible with each other. But those who knew Irving Hall last Summer, even in its brightest days, when wit and beauty congregated within its walls, and soft eyes looking out from fanciful masks looked love to gliding dominos -- not of the cantate style -- that spoke again, will scarcely know Irving Hall in its present phase, so wondrous a change has it under, gone. Originally, it will be remembered, the ceiling was white; anon the hand of Time touched it and it became slightly yellow, now the skillful Signor GUIDICINI has touched it, and the result is a picture gallery, where the wandering eye can move at will for hours and alight when tired on the shoulders of a new and corpulent cherub, or sport -- if discursively inclined -- with smiling and unsuspicious seraphim. One can now enjoy himself al fresco. Signor GUIDICINI has made the ceiling a picture gallery, and if the flies do not strike contemplative attitudes, and give themselves all the other airs connoisseurship when they alight on it, they have no taste for art at all, and prove themselves eminently incapable of appreciating High Art in particular. The hand of an artist, Signor GARIBALDI, has also struck the walls, leaving them a beautiful blue without the faintest shade of black, in former times they were crimson, but we have enough of that sanguinary color elsewhere, and so hail its banishment from the walls of our favorite music hall with joy. As it now is, Irving Hall is decidedly the most attractive concert room in the City, -- we think we should not err in saying in the country -- throughout its adornments are in the best taste; and too much praise cannot be awarded to its enterprising proprietors, Messrs. HARRISON & Co., nor can too hearty and liberal a recognition be extended them. The hall was first thrown open to a few invited guests on Wednesday evening, the 10th, and the verdict then pronounced on it by the few will undoubtedly be endorsed by the many when its beauties are unveiled to them.

abstract: THE END OF THE SEDGWICK-STREET RIOT CASE. -- This case, which at first excited considerable attention, has been summarily dismissed and the defendants discharged. The examination was commenced some weeks since, but postponed from time to time. On Monday afternoon the hearing was to be resumed, but as neither complainants nor counsel appeared, the Justice, on motion of counsel for defendants, who were present, dismissed the case. The matter will, however, be brought to the attention of the next Grand Jury, which will be impanneled at the opening of the Court of Oyer and Terminar in October. It will be recollected that the rioters attacked WATSON's tobacco factory in Sedgwick-street, and after driving the employes -- all of whom were colored -- up stairs, attempted to set fire to the building. A number of the most active participants have since enlisted and are now at the seat of war.

abstract: Editorial on loyal slaves in South being assigned to camp drudgery
snippet: Editorial on loyal slaves in South being assigned to camp drudgery
lead_paragraph: It is constantly pressed on the public attention that the slave population of the South is a peculiarly effective element in war. The domineering politicians of the Gulf States, who, for so many years, ruled in the National Congress, and insulted the rest of the Union by their bullying speeches, prophesied freely of the coming rebellion, indicated their intended policy of invasion, and boasted that every man of their white population was a soldier and a hero, and could leave home to fight while his faithful slaves remained behind to labor, and by the fruits of cotton and sugar plantations, to feed and clothe his knight-errant master and family.

abstract: A special meeting of this Board was held last evening for the purpose of taking final action on the report of the Committee on By-Laws, Rules and Regulations. In relation to the teaching of special subjects, such as music, drawing, languages, &c., in the public schools, and the appropriations to be made for that purpose. The report was published at length in the TIMES of Friday last. The subject having been fully discussed at the previous meeting, Commissioner BRENNAN moved the adoption of the report, and on this he called the previous question. The Board refused to order the previous question, and the discussion of the merits of the report was resumed. An amendment offered by Commissioner MILLER, limiting the amount to be paid for teaching special subjects in the grammar departments to $500 each department and in the primary departments to $100 each, was adopted.

abstract: The people of Brooklyn are considerably excited in consequence of a fact which has been brought to light by a report of the Board of Water Commissioners, from which it appears that from two causes they are in danger at any time of being altogether cut off from a supply of water. There is according to the report, but a single main through which all the water for the supply of Brooklyn has to pass, and any accident to this main would leave the city entirely without water until it could be repaired. In addition to this it is found that at the present rate of increase in the consumption of Ridgewood water, the present main will not be sufficient to furnish a necessary supply. The principal main from the reservoir is 36 inches in diameter, and will supply 14,000,000 gallons in twelve hours.

abstract: Capt. JOHN KAVANAGH, of Company I, Sixty-third Regiment N.Y.V., (Gen. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER's Irish Brigade,) is now officially reported among the slain in the great battle of Antietam. Capt. KAVANAGH was one of the Irish exiles of 1848. Having taken a conspicuous part in the effort of O'BRIEN, MITCHEL, MEAGHER and O'GORMAN to secure the national independence of Ireland, he had to fly to America to escape the vengeance of the British Government. He spent most of his years in his adopted country in mercantile pursuits. On the outbreak of the present rebellion, he relinquished all business interests and devoted himself to the service of the Republic, to which he was most earnestly attached. He was one of the principal organizers of the Thirty-seventh Regiment New-York Volunteers. He was subsequently transferred to the Sixty-third Regiment, in conformity with his own desire to serve under his friend and fellow-exile, the gallant MEAGHER. He was a most energetic and fearless officer. He fell at the head of his company, in the heat of action. He had won for himself the enthusiastic devotion of a numerous circle of friends. Capt. KAVANAGH was comparatively a young man, hardly thirty-five years of age, of medium height; slender, but sinewy frame; fair complexion; and of prompt, decisive mental habits. He has left a wife and a very large family of young children to mourn the loss of a most affectionate husband and father. They are entitled to the protection of the country, in whose service the brave fellow cheerfully sacrificed his life.

abstract: -- We learn that Judge BARNARD, sitting at Chambers in the Supreme Court, yesterday, directed an order to be entered that all legal advertisements in proceedings before him should be published in the World. Considering how entirely above party considerations the Judge has always shown himself in the exercise of his judicial functions, we would not intimate that there was the least connection between this order and the recent transfer of the World into the Democratic communion, allegations of which have been so freely made. We prefer, for ourselves, to suppose that it is only from pure admiration of our cotemporary's devotion to principle and refusal to lend any countenance to those who would strike hands with the traitors, and embarrass the Government if they could, that His Honor has directed the insertion of the name of the World in his orders of publication, instead of those of the Atlas and the Leader, and the other papers upon which he has hitherto bestowed these crumbs of patronage.

abstract: Editorial speculates on next move on Potomac
snippet: Editorial speculates on next move on Potomac
lead_paragraph: The pause in the movements of the two armies on the Upper Potomac is significant. MCCLELLAN's army has not yet crossed in pursuit. The body of the rebel army is said to be massed on the opposite side of the river, only two or three miles distant. The two armies are near enough to each other to make it practicable to get reliable news between them; and Gen. MCCLELLAN is no doubt thoroughly satisfied that his foe is not unwilling for another battle in his chosen position.
headline: {'main': 'The situation on the Upper Potomac.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The situation on the Upper Potomac.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Military officers are too apt to forget that American soldiers are not mere "human machines," made to load and fire Enfields, or perform "double-quicks." Grant all that may be said of the "fit food for powder" of a portion of the rank and file of all armies, and it remains true that our ranks of volunteers are crowded by self-respecting, intelligent, moral and religious men conscious of their rights as well as their duties.
lead_paragraph: Military officers are too apt to forget that American soldiers are not mere "human machines," made to load and fire Enfields, or perform "double-quicks." Grant all that may be said of the "fit food for powder" of a portion of the rank and file of all armies, and it remains true that our ranks of volunteers are crowded by self-respecting, intelligent, moral and religious men -- conscious of their rights as well as their duties. They may endure the petty despotism which camp discipline enables some swaggering, swearing, drunken officer to establish over them, but they will detest the despot. They may perform the unwelcome and unnecessary fatigue or fighting Sunday-service exacted of them; but it will be under protest, and with the feeling at heart that they have been robbed or a precious right of rest for the weary, and worship for the devout. They expect to return to their homes when the war is over; and they want to carry with them the manly Christian virtues which made them objects of affection in the home-circle, undimmed by camp-stains; and in their hearts they honor the superior officer who seeks to guard their morals and promote their higher welfare. They know, too, that war is death-dealing work, and that proper preparation for its casualties does not lie in the pathway of Sabbath-breaking, drunkenness and profanity.
headline: {'main': 'Morals of the Army.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Morals of the Army.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Whereas I did, by proclamation, on the seventeenth day of July, 1862. offer, on behalf of the State, a bounty of fifty dollars to each private soldier who should thereafter volunteer into the service of the United States; and whereas I did also, by proclamation, on the thirteenth of August, 1862, declare that said bounty of fifty dollars would not be paid to any volunteer into new regiments whose enlistment should not have been made on or prior to the sixth day of September inst., but that the aforesaid bounty of fifty dollars would, until further notice, be continued and paid to private soldiers, who might enlist to serve for three years or the war, to fill up regiments, battalions and batteries of New-York State Volunteers which were in the field before the second day of July, 1862, and to those only;

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- MISS CARLOTTA PATTI. -- The second night is apt to be the test of debuts, as the month after the honeymoon is supposed to be of marriages; and, judged by this test, Miss CARLOTTA PATTI has good reason to be satisfied with her success in the light and graceful opera judiciously selected for her first appearance. A really handsome and appreciative audience last night confirmed the favorable verdict of Monday, and the debutante did herself credit in the increased confidence and ease of her carriage and her execution. Let us add a word of well-deserved praise for the fidelity and modesty with which Signor SHRIGLIA devotes himself, as tenors are not too often seen to do, to supporting the prima donna.

A really handsome and appreciative audience last night confirmed the favorable verdict of Monday, and the debutante did herself credit in the increased confidence and ease of her carriage and her execution. Let us add a word of well-deserved praise for the fidelity and modesty with which Signor SHRIGLIA devotes himself, as tenors are not too often seen to do, to supporting the prima donna.

abstract: Last night began the Jewish Festival of Rosh Hashoua, or the New Year. The festival is of the utmost sacredness to the followers of the Ancient Faith, demanding, during the two days of its continuance, absolute cessation of all business and rest from all work. Between the father and the members of his earthly family is held close communion. The confession of sin, the abasement of self, the metaphorical clothing of soul in sackcloth and ashes, and the earnest petition for forgiveness are alone matters which concern a faithful Israelite during this solemn season. No Hebrew who is an "Israelite indeed," would peril his soul by even an apparaent forgetfulness of this most sacred duty, and to-day that great body of our fellow-citizens, some forty thousand in number, men, women and children, are acknowledging humbly their shortcomings, and promising a future of well-doing.

abstract: The Seventy-ninth Session of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York, commenced yesterday morning, in St. John's Church, Varick-street. There was a large attendance of members from all parts of the State, about two hundred and fifty answering to their names. The morning was exclusively taken up with the imposing religious services with which the Convention is usually opened. Dr. DILLON, of St. Luke's Church, Brooklyn, read the opening services in the Liturgy, Rev. Mr. MAXSEY the first Lesson, and Rev. Mr. HOLLINGSWORTH the second. Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY, of the Church of the Incarnation, read the Litany, Rev. Mr. WESTON gave out the hymns, Rev. Dr. MCVICKAR read the Ante-communion service; Dr. BUELL, of Poughkeepsie, the Epistle; Dr. PRICE, of St. Stephen's, the Gospel; Dr. BUELL, of Poughkeepsie, delivered the sermon; Rev. Mr. MOORE, read the Offertory, Rev. Dr. MCVICKAR consecrated the Elements, and Rev. Drs. BROWN, and MCVICKAR, and Rev. Mr. MOORE administered the Sacrament.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, No. 525, is printed THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers ready for mailing. This is emphatically a BATTLE NUMBER. It contains graphic and full accounts of the late battles in Maryland, from the pens of our Special Correspondents, who were personally on the field. As a number for preservation, containing a complete record of the late desperate struggles in Maryland, the one published this morning is invaluable. In addition, it contains the latest news up to the moment of going to press, Special Correspondence from all the different Military Departments, a careful and complete summary of the rebellion news of the week, the President's Emancipation Proclamation, Letters from London and Paris, with extracts from our foreign exchanges, and the latest European news; a page of Editorial on the various topics of the day; the third of an interesting series of letters by Mr. WM. H. HURLBERT, descriptive of fifteen months' experience at the South; a carefully prepared Commercial page, items of domestic and agricultural interest compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and other matters of general interest. Altogether an invaluable number for preservation.

abstract: Editorial compares rebellion with French Revolution; Editorial compares US Civil War with revolutionary France in 1793-94
snippet: Editorial compares rebellion with French Revolution; Editorial compares US Civil War with revolutionary France in 1793-94
lead_paragraph: In casting around to test the impressive spectacle of the armed uprising presented by the loyal population of the United States during the past eighteen months, by like mani festations in the history of other nations, it is soon discovered that the circle of comparison really narrows itself down to one single historical point -- the uprising of revolutionary France to repel the invasion of the armed coalition of 1793-4. Nothing previously on record at all equals the savage energy with which the French people then rose to vindicate their newly won freedom and independence; and as there are between our situation and that of France during the Revolution many points of similitude, both in the imminence of the crisis and the universal enthusiasm with which it was met on the part of the people, we will best appreciate the magnitude of the efforts of the loyal States when set side by side with that other marvelous and hitherto unmatched exhibition of patriotic ardor. The result of the comparison will be, to show that we have already placed in the field as many soldiers as France was able to raise then; while if the results of a critical examination of the number of troops commonly claimed to have been raised by France shall be accepted, it will appear that the number really raised by her has been doubled by the levies that have spontaneously sprung forth in defence of the Union.

abstract: with reference to an unusual number of these disasters, we mentioned, at some length, the leading principles and facts about a modern and consistent theory of boiler explosions, and recommended to Government the importance of some appropriate tests and legislation. The upshot of the whole matter is, that the beginning of at least nearly every explosion is a rupture, and the beginning of a rupture is invariably CARELESSNESS, that is to say, grossly defective construction of material or management. Now these causes may be removed in two ways: a part of the boiler owners will be glad to avail themselves habitually of the remedy -- rigid, frequent and scientific inspection -- when once convinced that this is the real cure-all; and the public safety will be assured against the steam bomb-shells of reckless boiler owners by a stricter law. But an equally important result of official experiments would be to relieve any really modern and scientific conclusion from the popular incredulity due to misstatements and limited comprehension. Thus the weekly oracle of scientific information in this City attempts to disgrace the theory by putting ridiculous statements into the mouth of its advocates, and then making merry over the invention. The TIMES, in discussing the theory, stated that "Quite recently, while experimenting for a very different purpose, Mr. EDWIN STEVENS, of Hoboken, developed the great fact upon which its probability depends." All of which the oracle distorts into this: "Quite recently, while experimenting for a very different purpose, Mr. EDWIN STEVENS, of Hoboken, developed the great fact that water cannot exist as water under the atmospheric pressure at a higher temperature than 212 degrees." This wonted method of discussing patent rat-traps and self-acting hen-persuaders, quite unobjectionable in these higher walks of philosophy, we presume might be modified in matters all lied to the public safety, without detriment to he cause of science.

abstract: WHY IS IT? -- We hear frequent complaints of the non-payment of our three months' men. Very many of the volunteers who cheerfully went to the National Capital at the call of the Government, left place and employment, which on their return were beyond their reach; others laid out money in the purchase of extra clothing and comforts, which they can ill afford to lose. To them the amount, though comparatively small, would be most welcome, and it seems to us an ill requital on the part of the Government, which, having used the men in time of need, virtually refuse, now that they are mustered out, to pay them what was long ago their due. Why is it?

Why is it?

abstract: It has been finally decided that the draft shall be put in operation ix, this State on the 10th of next month. Before that time it is pretty certain that the enrollment will be entirely finished, and then nothing will interfers between able-bodied citizens and the neccesary for filing New-York's quota of the President's last requisition. The names of all persons supposed to be liable in this city and Brooklyn have been obtained, and 150 copyists are now employed (two-thirds of them in the daytime and the rest at night) registering these names in books. Meanwhile, the examiners have commenced work. Their duty is to check off names that have been entered more than once; as, for instance, where a resident has been enrolled both at his house and at his place of business. When the examiners are through, there will be an inquiry into claims of exemption, and as soon as the register is thus purged, drafting will begin.

abstract: Editorial lauds San Francisco's $100,000 gift to Army Sanitary Commission
snippet: Editorial lauds San Francisco's $100,000 gift to Army Sanitary Commission
lead_paragraph: --The munificent donation of $100,000 from the City of San Francisco to the Army Sanitary Commission has already relieved an infinite amount of human suffering, and saved the lives of very many of our gallant soldiers. The gift came just at the right moment -- immediately after the great battles in Maryland; and the Sanitary Commission, which was in danger of having to draw upon the future for means to relieve the tremendous strain upon it, was at once put in financial condition to procure whatever might be needed for the relief of the wounded. In a brief appeal from the Commission, published this morning, its President says that, at the recent battle-ground, they were able to be present two days in advance of regular supplies, with wagon-loads of stimulants, medicines and conveniences; and the same document, elsewhere justly says: "the first two days on a battle-field are more important than the next ten, to the saving of life and misery." The means to purchase these medicines and comforts, came from the generosity of California. When it is remembered that San Francisco is a city of only about seventy-five thousand inhabitants, and that this hundred thousand dollars is the fruit of public subscription, its value as a testimony of sympathy will be seen to be greatly enhanced. We understand that other cities in the Golden State will soon be heard from as having followed San Francisco's golden example. California has sent few troops to the war; for the simple reason that the Government has refused to accept them, as it would not pay to transport them such a vast distance. But there is no State in our broad domain in which the people are more thoroughly loyal to the Constitution and the Union; and, under present circumstances, they could not give a more gratefully-received proof of their loyalty.

abstract: Business at the Brooklyn Navy-yard is more brisk than ever. There are nearly 4,000 men in the different workshops and in the laborers' gang -- some of them are at work night and day. The ordnance department, in charge of Commodore TEMPLE, is continually working at guns of every calibre, for the craft almost daily leaving the station for blockading and other service. The engineers' shop is as busy as if no engines were built outside. The blacksmiths, carpenters, stone-cutters, and others are also incessantly engaged. The alterations necessary to make the United States corvette Savannah a school ship for volunteer officers, progress rapidly. The apartments in which practice is to be carried on are undergoing formation. The Savannah was formerly a 50-gun frigate, but was razeed some years ago. She will be ready for her new service in a few weeks. The Memphis, the newly purchased steamer, is now being made fit for transfer to the regular navy. She is a splendid iron ship, and is considered "a bargain." The Navy Department bought her a few days since at a prize auction. She was captured by the United States steamer Magnolia.

abstract: The Court-Martial appointed for the trial of Gen. McKINSTRY assembled this morning. In the absence of Gen. HARNEY, who has been ordered to Washington, and who left for the east this morning Gen. S.B. GRAHAM was elected acting President. The charges and specifications were called for, but the gentlemen having them in charge could not at once be found. After discussion of preliminary matters, the Court adjourned to meet on Friday.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, Thursday, Sept. 25.

abstract: -- The meeting of certain Governors on one of the mountain tops of Pennsylvania has excited much attention, and provoked in some quarters the most violent condemnation. Charges of secret conspiracy to overthrow the National Government have been freely offered by the sensational Press; while the most moderate view of the Press at large has been that measures unpalatable to the Administration were there to be rolled into pellets and forced down its reluctant throat. There was no ground, however, for any such apprehensions. That the meeting was probably ill-advised, and in all respects unfortunate, can hardly be doubted. There was too striking a resemblance between it and similar gatherings of State Right Governors in the South just before the rebellion broke out; and indeed, the substance as well as the form of the thing smacked unpleasantly of that violent Anti-National creed which has set this hapless people by the ears. It must also occur to the most casual thinker that one of the blessings of our Constitution is that it furnishes the President with authentic advisers in the shape of a Senate and House of Representatives, who could be called to the council board at once if the emergency required it, and whose regular annual meeting is at worst only a few weeks off. For these reasons, it might seem safe to omit, at this moment, any irregular and officious tenders of advice.

abstract: BOONSBORO, Md., Saturday Night, Sept. 20, 1862. I have been traveling in the track of the army  to-day, and came to-night, here at Boonsboro, within sound of our guns, a few of which I heard firing briskly just after sundown in the direction of the Potomac, which the advanced guard of our army is reported to have crossed to-day, in pursuit of the feeling rebel army.
lead_paragraph: BOONSBORO, Md., Saturday Night, Sept. 20, 1862.

abstract: Annual exhibition of fall and winter fashions, NYC
snippet: Annual exhibition of fall and winter fashions, NYC
lead_paragraph: New-York is emerging from its Summer chrysalis as bright and beautiful a butterfly as ever. The war, which it was supposed would paralyze all its energies and reduce infinitely the demand for and consumption of luxuries of all kinds, seems rather to have operated in a contrary direction, and by placing wealth in different hands from those which formerly held it, given an impulse to trade which is unexpected as it is gratifying. Broadway and other principal thoroughfares begin to wear their wonted brilliant aspect -- people are returning rapidly to town -- sidewalks are thronged, stores are crowded -- the important business of Fall shopping has commenced -- the signal for the display of all those varied textures and ingenious specimens of art and skill, which afford the best evidence of industrial resources, and act at the same time as traps for the unwary. The shopping community, however, never manifested a greater willingness to be caught. This season, above all others, shows no lack of the one thing needful. Whether it is that business is unusually prosperous, or money more than usually plentiful, or because investments are considered doubtful, and currency itself uncertain, most true it is that women never received so liberal a carte blanche, or encountered so little opposition to their suggestion that the family wardrobe needed replenishing. In fact, instances have been known, recently, where husbands have handed a fifty-dollar bill, unasked, to their astonished wives, with the recommendation to "pitch in" -- a reckless more of proceeding, unparallelled in domestic annals -- and which has led, in several cases, to misgivings that an extra bottle with a friend had something to do with it, or possibly some remnant of hereditary insanity.

abstract: The SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 838, is printed THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to containing the latest telegraphic news up to the moment of going to press, it contains full details of all that has transpired in Maryland to the latest possible dates, from the pens of our special correspondents. In it will also be found graphic and interesting letters from the other military departments the latest news from Richmond, the latest dates from Europe, and interesting letters from our special correspondents in London and Paris. Also, a page of Editorials on the various topics of the day; a carefully prepared Commercial page, items or domestic and agricultural interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and other matters of general interest.

abstract: SUICIDE. -- A locksmith named GEO. R. BELTTER, doing business at No. 85 Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, committed suicide Wednesday, by cutting his throat at his residence, No. 196 Crove-street. Deceased severed the jugular vein with a razor, and stood up, with the blood streaming into a pail, until he fell to floor from weakness, which was the first intimation the family had of the occurrence. Physicians were called in, but their aid was unavailing. Deceased has made several ineffectual attempts upon his life, by poison, drowning, and cutting his throat.

abstract: The situation in Kentucky derived many of its recent alarming features from the excitable temper and incapacity of Gen. NELSON, at Louisville, as we took occasion at the time to show. On a report, evidently quite vague in its character, that Gen. BRAGG was "marching rapidly upon Louisville," having eluded Gen. BUELL, Gen. NELSON indulged in a series of frantic orders and proclamations in regard to closing all business houses, sending off women and children, seizing ferries for military purposes, and so forth. Samson in Delilah's lap was not startled to more sudden activity by the cry that the Philistines were upon him, than was the valiant military commandant of Louisville, by the alleged advance of BRAGG. But, unfortunately, at this point, the parallel runs out. NELSON had no withes or cords to break -- he only broke the bubble of his own reputation.

abstract: The People vs. Jacob Faneback. -- The defendant was convicted of vending adulterated milk, and sentenced to pay a fine of $55, at the Court of Sessions. He appealed the case to this Court, contending that the act under which he was convicted was purely a sanitary measure, intended to prevent traffic in impure, diseased and unwholesome milk, and not to prevent fraud in the sale of diluted milk. That to put water into milk was not to corrupt it, according to dictionary definitions. Water was not a foreign admixture of milk, but its chief ingredient in its natural state, and it could not be adulterated by adding a little more.

abstract: This, the only public school in the Second Ward, held its opening exercises yesterday morning. The crowd of visitors was so great that access could  not be gained even to the reception-room, by those who were tardy in getting there. Two hundred and forty-two children comprise the regular attendance at this establishment, and yesterday, in their holiday attire, looked admirably, going through their various juvenile exercises with much credit.

abstract: Nothing of military importance is at present transpiring in Hagerstown. The chief point of interest is at Williamsport, where the right of the line is stationed. abstract: SUNDAY IN THE ARMY AND NAVY. The Sabbath Committee have issued a brief and well-considered appeal in behalf of the soldiers' and sailors' Sab- bath. Conceding all that can justly be claimed for the emergencies of military service, they simply ask "that the period of rest and worship to which our citizen-soldiers have been accustomed at home, shall not be thoroughly or needlessly interrupted by camp, fatigue or field duties."
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY IN THE ARMY AND NAVY. -- The Sabbath Committee have issued a brief and well-considered appeal in behalf of the soldiers' and sailors' Sab- bath. Conceding all that can justly be claimed for the emergencies of military service, they simply ask "that the period of rest and worship to which our citizen-soldiers have been accustomed at home, shall not be thoroughly or needlessly interrupted by camp, fatigue or field duties." The General Orders of MCCLELLAN and FOOTE, of last year, are cited as embodying the principles which the Committee seek to have recognized by the Government on this question. They have been almost universally approved by the army and the country, so that their incorporation in the Articles of War, or in an order of the General-in-Chief, would do no violence to public convictions, while it would render certain protection to a most valuable right of citizens in arms. The respectable source of this appeal, and its temperate tone, should secure for it the respectful attention of the public authorities and the gratitude of the army and navy, as well as of the parents and friends of our country's defenders.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- Mr. FORREST is in the full tide of one of the most successful engagements that even he has ever played in New-York. Each night that he performs Niblo's theatre is crowded to the full extent of its capacity in the way of seats, whilst the spacious lobbies are occupied by patient groups, who cannot be deterred from taking their chances of beholding the great tragedian by announcements of "standing room only" being in store for them. Mr. FORREST's popularity is not a matter for criticism or discussion. However opinions may differ as to his interpretation of this or that character, there is no question that he possesses that marked individuality -- that irresistible power of personal magnetism -- which compels public attention and respect. The physical may, in his case predominate over the mental, but that is not the point to be considered. Above and beyond all argument concerning his peculiar qualifications for such a part as Damon, or his disqualifications for such a part as Hamlet, stands the incontrovertible fact, that, whatever the part may be he is announced to play, an immense audience will assemble to see him, will be palpably delighted with everything he does, and will applaud him with an enthusiasm that can be elicited by no other actor of the day. Certain it is, if hostile criticism, in the face of this fact, declares that Mr. FORREST has no talent and is deficient in tact, then it cannot avoid the alternative that he must be endowed with some subtle kind of genius which is superior to tact and talent put together; for it is a genius that has raised him to a pinnacle of histrionic greatness, whence he can look down on those whose acknowledged tact and talent have been exerted for years in vain endeavors to supplant him.

abstract: The generous, bounties hitherto paid to recruits are being gradually discontinued. Each separate bounty as it is stopped is a warning to those who, having resolved to volunteer, still delay doing so until the last moment that their patriotism will allow. To those it is only necessary to ask the question, whether it be not better to join the army with a certainty of receiving a considerable sum of money, for immediate personal comforts or family necessities, than to join the army without that sum of money? Those who failed to volunteer on or before yesterday will not now be entitled to the City bounty of $50. The ordinance authorizing its payment only extended over twenty-one days, and yesterday that term expired. After next Thursday, the State bounty of $50 will also be withdrawn. That will deprive recruits of $100 altogether which each of them might just as well have put in his pockets or left to cheer the Winter fireside of his wife and children. The United States bounty of $29 is to be continued until further notice. It is more than likely that this bounty will be made a permanent institution -- a standing inducement for a sufficient number of volunteers to keep on joining the army to prevent any need for a supplementary draft.

abstract: From the recent statement of the Commissioners, we learn that the number of immigrants to this port, up to Sept. 24, 1861, was 57,089, and to a corresponding date in 1862 the number is 57,714, showing an increase of but 625 instead of 3,000, as was stated by the Journal of Commerce. We are far from feeling that this is a subject for regret -- on the contrary, the fact that there has not been a decided decrease is most significant and astonishing. During the past few months, the number of weekly arrivals has been slowly but steadily increasing. The war, so far from expelling emigrants, seems to invite them here. It is believed that when all the inducements come to be fully known in Europe, there will be a sudden and astonishing increase in the number of miners, mechanics, agriculturists, and persons willing to become soldiers, who will seek our shores. Letters, written by foreign residents of this country to their friends at home, stating these extraordinary inducements, will have a great effect on emigration. So also, it is thought, will the public appeal of Secretary SEWARD to the United States Consuls in Europe, recounting the many advantages which the emigrant will enjoy at this time.

abstract: editorial on military movements
snippet: editorial on military movements
lead_paragraph: The intelligence brought by the last arrival from Europe, which appeared in the letter of our well-informed Paris correspondent, regarding the proposed movements of France in Mexico, is of the highest importance. It appears, that at a recent Cabinet council, the French Government came to the decision to increase its army of occupation in Mexico from 30,000 to 80,000 men, and that arrangements, looking to the permanent stay of those forces in Mexico, were resolved upon. We are also informed that the Emperor has decided to immediately enter upon the construction, as a military necessity, of the railroad from Vera Cruz to the Capital, and that surveys of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec have been ordered, preparatory to the opening, under French control, of that must important American route of interoceanic communication.

abstract: Major PINCKNEY, one of the assistants of Gen. ANTHON, in effecting the enrolment in this City and Brooklyn, has made a curious discovery, in which the suffrage rights of a large number of citizens are involved. The Major invented a directory of election districts and streets for this City, and undertook to apply the principle to Brooklyn. He procured all the election district maps of that city, and while carefully describing in his books the boundaries of the districts, discovered this fact: that ten blocks in Williamsburgh, situated between Third and Fourth streets and North Fourth and North Fourteenth streets, are not included in any district. A search of the records revealed the fact that the inhabitants of this somewhat populous locality have never had any recognized legal existence; that no votes have ever been recorded there, and, therefore, if any of the citizens have at any time exercised the "right of suffrage," they did so in transgression of the law. One block in South Brooklyn was also found to have been left out by the election district makers. Major PINCKNEY has constituted the neglected localities sub-districts; and it by no means follows that because the citizens have never been allowed to vote, they will be debarred from fighting.
