abstract: Albert Uhl, plaintiff in error, vs. The People, defendants in error. -- The plaintiff in error was tried in the New-York General Sessions, upon an indictment for the murder of one Lee, on the 5th day of August, 1861. The prisoner was barkeeper for Louis Bleyart, at a liquor store, kept corner of Morris and West streets. The deceased, with several other persons, came to Bleyart's place, obtained liquor, and refused to pay. The deceased was in the act of striking the prisoner on the head with a large half-gallon pewter pitcher filled with water and ice, when prisoner shot him. It was proved on the trial that this pitcher was a deadly weapon. It was contended upon the trial that the prisoner acted in self-defence. Numerous exceptions were taken upon thetrial. The counsel for the prisoner contends that the Court below erred in permitting the prosecution (the defence having given no evidence on the subject) to prove the good character of the deceased for peace and quietness, to which prisoner's counsel duly excepted; and also that the Court below erred in charging. "If you (the jury) find that the prisoner was justified in defending himself, and carried that protection further than was necessary for his defenece, then he is guilty of manslaughter in some of the four degrees."

abstract: Editorial on condition of Confederate currency
snippet: Editorial on condition of Confederate currency
lead_paragraph: A further issue of Treasury notes having, on the 19th inst., been authorized by the rebel Congress, as a means of carrying on the war and replenishing their exhausted exchequer, it may be of some interest to review the present condition of the Southern currency, and to compare it with that existing in the peaceful and prosperous year preceding the rebellion.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington; Articles on his war photography; Articles on M B Brady war photography; Article on Brady work in photographing war
snippet: Dispatches from Washington; Articles on his war photography; Articles on M B Brady war photography; Article on Brady work in photographing war
lead_paragraph: The Horace Vernet of our great civil war is yet to appear, and as he is no doubt waiting upon the arrival of its Napoleon, we confess a serious anxiety for his advent. Nay, we may as well go further, and admit that we should be thankful, as things now stand, for smaller favors. We should gratefully accept a Pelissier, and commission an Yvon to record his achievements. But whenever the decisive man shall come, and with him the decisive hour, and the limner shall follow after to perpetuate for our children the "great deliverance" of the land in all its terrible beauty, the task of this latter will be greatly simplified to his cunning hand by the efforts which our leading photographic artist has made, and is making, to catch our armies "living as they rise," and, alas! to embalm our falling heroes ere they fall. From the outset of the war Mr. BRADY has been in the field. His cameras have followed the cannon from the Potomac to the York, from the Chesapeake to the Alleghanies. Scarce has the camp of the volunteer been pitched by the more or less muddy waters of the Chickahominy ere the patriotic Polyphemus plants himself within range, flings away his green curtain, and opens his one-eyed battery upon the scene. Like the sunlight which he presses into his service and ours, this silent Asmodeus penetrates into every secret, unveils every mystery. He captures the fugitive contraband as he urges his slow oxen through the splash of the Rappahannock fords, and sends him down through all coming time to reveal the insensibility of the negro race to the compromises of the Constitution, and to the beneficent influences of patriarchal order. Just glance at the group! Not a white face among them -- no Caucasian serpent seducing these wanderers from their Eden-home. They have equipped themselves -- spoiling their masters, perchance, as the Egyptians were spoiled by their fugitive slaves of old -- they have confiscated sundry rebel horses and wagons in advance of the acts of Congress, and they are making their way slowly northward -- Yankeeward -- freedomward. What instinct leads them do you think, and is there no "lesson for young statesmen" in this rude exodus without a Moses -- unless, indeed, we assume with the popular chorus that the spirit of JOHN BROWN is "marching on" before these simple Israelites in ebony!

abstract: We learn of no new movements in the army of the Potomac, though no official information is received. It is pretty certain that no portion of our forces under the immediate command of Gen. MCCLELLAN is on the Virginia side of the Potomac; and it is equally certain that the rebels have not left the line of the river. It is reported that they can be distinctly seen on the opposite side, both at Williamsport and at Falling Waters, at which latter point Gen. LEE's headquarters are located. It is believed that the rebels are operating injuriously on the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

abstract: -- The difficulty of solving American paradoxes must be more firmly impressed upon our foreign critics at each new arrival from this country. Of these anomalies, the most puzzling is the unabated credit of the Government. Why has it not yielded to the financial strain of a year and a half? How is it possible the Treasury has only to invite the contributions of the people to get them in excess of its demands; and this, in the face of every political discouragement? The thing outrages all probability. And yet the next steamer will carry out word that the Government has only had to ask for the gold of the country, offering for it certificates of deposit and a trifling interest, to give new value to the metal, and cause a million dollars to seek Government custody in a single day. What Government of Europe at peace, and in the enjoyment of the broadest prosperity, has an equal hold upon the confidence of its subjects?

abstract: MR. CHARLES BURDETT, for two years past connected with the New-York Times, died suddenly at his residence in this City on Wednesday morning last, in the 48th year of his age. Mr. BURDETT was an adopted son of the celebrated AARON BURR, and was educated at the military school of the late Capt. PARTRIDGE, at Middletown, Connecticut. In early life he obtained a Midshipman's commission in the Navy, and was for several years in the service. He was subsequently connected with the New-York Courier and Enquirer, and still later acted as private secretary to the Mayor under Mr. HAVEMEYER's and Mr. WOOD's administrations. He was also deputy-postmaster of the City under WM. V. BRADY. Of late years he has devoted himself principally to literature, and has published several novels, which obtained a wide circulation, among the most popular of which are Three per cent. a Month; Dora Barton, or The Banker's Ward; and Margaret Moncrief, or The First Love of Aaron Burr. The materials for the last work, which is of an historical character, were derived from private papers left in the hands of the author by his distinguished guardian. Mr. BURDETT was engaged in writing a sequel to this work at the time of his death. He leaves behind him a widow and two children, the eldest, a son, now serving as master's mate in the U.S. Navy, and the youngest a daughter of sixteen years. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon from the residence of his brother-in-law. Mr. H.D. HOWARD, No. 91 West Forty-Seventh-street, and was largely attended by the friends and acquaintances of the deceased. His remains were interred in Greenwood Cemetery.

abstract: Fifty thousand of our fellow-citizens of Hebrew blood were yesterday, and are to-day, engaged in one of the most ancient and solemn observances of the Jewish Faith. Rosh Hashona, or the Head of the Year, comprises the first two days of Tisri, the seventh month of the Israelitish sacred year, or the first of the civil year. In the First Book of Kings, this great month is called Ethanim or Continually Flowing, from the fact that the autumn rains then began to fill the dried up beds of brooks and rivers and to overflow the parched levels of Judea. This latter is the more ancient name, deriving its origin from the patriarchal period preceding the captivity. Nearly coinciding with our Christian October, it was, in some sense, also the late harvest month of the Hebrews, with whom the fullness and ripeness of the year immediately preceded the birth of its suscessor, and from the growth and culmination of sin in the human heart, the significance of the opening festival is also largely deduced. This month and New-Year began on Wednesday evening at sunset, and yesterday was celebrated the Feast of Trumpets, the first of a succession of Jewish festivals which will extend over the next four weeks, in the Book of Numbers we are told of the two trumpets of beaten silver which the Lord commanded Moses to make, and which were used in the wanderings of the Tribes to summon all the people together when on the eve of departure. These trumpets were subsequently employed at the opening of the solemn ceremonial to proclaim the New Year, and also at the beginning of the Sabbatical year and the Jubilee, as many passages in Numbers and the Book of Leviticus indicate. Hence arises the rite of the Shophar -- the Trumpet, or, in still more ancient usage, the Ram's Horn, which is blown by the High Priest in the Synagogue during the worship of the day. It was customary in the strictest Synagogues to offer up, on this day, in addition to the regular monthly sacrifices, a solemn holocaust in the name of the whole nation, and this consisted of a bullock, a ram, a kid, and seven lambs of the same year, with measures of flour and wine. Although, even in the Holy writings, the precise origin of the Feast of Trumpets is not distinctly stated, the entire period of the Rosh Hashonah proper, which covers two entire days, counting, according to Jewish custom, from sunset to sunset, is observed with the utmost reverence and solemnity, and the Israelite who does not, upon this occasion at least, worship like the rest in absolute penitence and self-abasement, to the exclusion of all worldly cares and occupations, is looked upon as abackslider from the ancient faith, and as one in extreme spiritual degradation and peril.

abstract: COMPLAINT OF THE VOLUNTEER SURGEONS. Great complaint is made in regard to the conduct  of many of the volunteer Surgeons, who recklessly amputate the limbs of the wounded, and leave them destitute of the care needed for their recovery. The object seems to be to secure practice for operating Surgeons. Many operations are performed without judgment, and in a totally unjustifiable manner, frequently hastening the death of the patient.

abstract: Editorial stresses need for ships as well as forts for adequate harbor defenses
snippet: Editorial stresses need for ships as well as forts for adequate harbor defenses
lead_paragraph: While agitating the subject of national defences, let us not be blinded by so strong an admiration for our iron navy as to believe it a panacea for every evil. We shall fall into a fatal error when we trust to ships, gunboats, or floating batteries alone, for the defence of our harbors or seacoast. All writers on military art agree on one point, that a land battery is in every way superior to one that floats. While the latter has to contend with an uncontrollable element, affecting the use of its guns, the precision of their aim, and the safety of its men from numberless causes, the first can fire from a firm foundation with a certainty of aim, and with a protection to its men that cannot be rated at less than ten to one. We will pass by the wooden ships in our calculation, and enter only upon those of iron, and yet not fail to see that vulnerable points are presented upon everything that floats, no matter how carefully constructed, that utterly outnumber the weak points of the weakest of our old stone fortifications.

abstract: The Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of New-York yesterday transacted a large amount of routine business. The Standing and Missionary Committees were elected, and a very important debate took place on the all-absorbing question among Episcopalians in this State of the division of the Diocese of New-York. No decision was arrived at. The question on the reports will be taken this morning.

abstract: The armies of BUELL and BRAGG left Lebanon, Penn., and Carthage, respectively, on the 21st, BUELL following the arc, and BRAGG the chord of a circle. abstract: The State canvas is fairly opened, and according to all appearances it bids fair to be one of the most hotly contested which we have ever known. abstract: The main interest among City politicians now centres upon the Street Commissioner. Mr. KNAPP yet acts in that capacity, and has not served, as rumored, any injunction upon the Mayor, restraining him from nominating a new man, while Comptroller HAWS refuses to sign any of Mr. KNAPP'S checks. This unpleasant state of affairs is not likely to last long, as there is a strong probability of a nomination at the next meeting of the Board.

abstract: The regular semi-monthly meeting, of this Board was held yesterday. The report of the Committee of the Whole was presented, from which it appears that  from the 12th to the 25th inst., 705 persons were sent to the Workhouse on Blackwell's Island, of whom 521  were females, and 184 males. Nine of the number had served a term at the Island for the one hundredth time.
lead_paragraph: The regular semi-monthly meeting, of this Board was held yesterday. The report of the Committee of the Whole was presented, from which it appears that from the 12th to the 25th inst., 705 persons were sent to the Workhouse on Blackwell's Island, of whom 521 were females, and 184 males. Nine of the number had served a term at the Island for the one hundredth time. The Board were notified of the arrival of 234 sick and wounded soldiers at the Island Hospital, and a requisition was made for 500 new shirts for their benefit. Four hundred and seventy soldiers have been returned to service from Bellevue Hospital, and 524 from the Island Hospital, since the last meeting of the Board. Five have died, as follows:

lead_paragraph: At noon, yesterday, a party of gentlemen called on his Grace Archbishop HUGHES, at his residence, and formally presented to him, in behalf of the Common Council, an elegantly engrossed copy of the resolutions of congratulation on his return from Europe, and extending to him the hospitalities of the City, as offered by Alderman BOOLE, and passed by the Common Council, in recognition of his semi-official diplomatic services in behalf of the Union cause, while he was abroad. The party consisted of Aldermen Farley, Boole, Walsh and Brady, Ex-Senator William McMurray, Lieut.-Col. J.V.D. Reeve, U.S.A.; Capt. John McMurray, U.S.A.; Albert Gordozo, Esq., and Terence P. Smith, Sergeant-at-Arms of the Board of Aldermen.

abstract: -- The President's proclamation, suspending the writ of habeas corpus in certain cases, excites quite as much disgust in the minds of the opponents of the Administration as did the Proclamation of Emancipation. The latter was pronounced objectionable because immediately impracticable, and as tending to provoke the augmented animosity of the South. The former is represented to be a return of the Administration to the policy of restricted speech and summary imprisonment, which excited so much popular discontent last Winter.

abstract: At the meeting of the Convention yesterday morning, among the lay delegates appeared Ex-Gov. JOHN A. KING, Dr. JAMES MCKUNE SMITH and JOHN JAY. The last-named gentleman, having been rejected as a delegate from his own parish, was chosen to represent St. Philips, (colored.) Bishop POTTER appeared in the Convention for a brief period, in order to attend to some indispensable business; having left the bedside of his dying son for that purpose. The Convention passed an appropriate resolution of condolence with him in his affliction. Dr. HAIGHT read the Bishop's Address. During the year six churches and chapels have been consecrated; thirty-two clergymen resigned their cures; the Bishop has held over 200 public services, preached 110 times, and confirmed 2.620 during the year. The Bishop's Address expressed in unmistakable terms his disapproval of the proposed division of the Diocese.

abstract: I desire to say to all Tennesseeans, and others, that Col. FELIX A. REEVE, late of East Tennessee, for the time being has his headquarters at the Gibson House, in Cincinnati, where he is engaged in making up a new regiment for the United States service in the region of Cumberland Cap, having his commission and authority from Washington. I know Col. REEVE well, and know him to be a man of excellent character and of sound morals, and of bravery equal to the occasion.

abstract: With great pleasure we call the attention of a generous public to the fact that to-night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, will be given a grand floral promenade concert in behalf of the widows and orphans of the dead soldiers of the army of the Union. The Brooklyn Horticultural Society, under the efficient management of the President, Mr. J.W. DEGRAW, and the Secretary, MR. C.B. MILLER, deserves the credit of the affair.
lead_paragraph: With great pleasure we call the attention of a generous public to the fact that to-night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, will be given a grand floral promenade concert in behalf of the widows and orphans of the dead soldiers of the army of the Union. The Brooklyn Horticultural Society, under the efficient management of the President, Mr. J.W. DEGRAW, and the Secretary, MR. C.B. MILLER, deserves the credit of the affair. They have, during the past few days, presented to the public the most magnificent display of flowers and fruit ever seen in that or any other American City, and, as a fitting close of a prosperous season, they propose this grand donation, through the hands of the Woman's Association, to the distressed widows and orphans.

abstract: The steamship Philadelphia, which touched at Havana on the way from New-Orleans, brings advices from Vera Cruz to the 11th inst. The vomito was making dreadful havoc among the French shipping. Many of the physicians had died, and only two were left in the whole fleet. It was believed that a conducta with a million of dollars, destined for the payment of the French troops at Orizaba, had been captured by the guerrillas. A report was current that the French were about to attack Jalapa.

abstract: Dispatches from Washington
snippet: Dispatches from Washington
lead_paragraph: interesting personal statement of GARIBALDI, touching the affair of Aspromonte, furnishes a curious revelation of the aims and hopes with which he began his enterprise. Nothing could more strikingly prove how firmly he believed himself to be engaged in a justifiable mission, and not in a civil war. He had, it seems, strictly enjoined on his followers not to fire on the royal troops, and even after he was wounded he repeated the order, GARIBALDI. does not explain how he expected to proceed after this peaceable, unresisting fashion, beyond saying that he "entertained the hope that the regular troops had received orders less sanguinary." The probability is, however, that he expected, when he refused to fire on the royal troops, they would join him with or without the consent of their commander. In this expectation he was sadly deceived, and it was perhaps not until he found himself a prisoner that he fully understood either his real position toward the Government or the real sentiment of the people. The letter of GARIBALDI, if it does not justify his enterprise, challenges a new and tender interest in that pure-souled and chivalrous character.

abstract: Quite a crowd assembled at a P.M. yesterday. in front of the establishment of H.M. BAILEY, Iron Founder, No. 199 Wooster-street, to witness a public trial of the new Fire Escape. Messrs. SHUTE, the inventor, J.M. MILLS, and Inspectors W.W. ADAMS, WEST, OWENS, ARMSTRONG, TAYLOR, SMITH and HYDE, and Messenger MOUNT, of the Department for the Survey and Inspection of Buildings, were present, with several members of the Press. The Escapeconsists of a ladder composed of a strong wrought-iron chain, on either side, with light but substantial rungs of the same material between, and property about twelve inches apart. This being flexible was wound around the axle of a windlass at the top of the building, and close to the coping of the roof. The windlass consists, on the one side, of a ratchet wheel, and on the other of an ordinary brake, similar to the kind used at our City ferries. When the chain ladder is wound up, a guiding rod, which extends to the basement of the buildings on either the outside or inside, as may be preferred, worked by the slightest pressure properly applied, detaches the teeth of the ratchet wheel, and in a moment the ladder runs out over a curving frame which throws it clear of the roof and building, to the pavement where, in another instant, it is secured to iron staples fixed in the curbstone. The brake regulates it, and it may be so tightened as to be nearly solid, thus relieving the apprehensions of timid persons. The building from which the experiment was yesterday made is a five-story house, sixty feet in sheer height, and men were carried up and down, in every attitude, by others, with ease and without danger. Messenger MOUNT bore a lad of sixteen, clinging to his neck, from the roof to the pavement in less than one minute. In fine, all the trials made were perfectly satisfactory.

abstract: At the meeting yesterday morning, the Church of the Resurrection of this City was admitted to union with the Convention. abstract: ROBERT DALE OWEN, inserted elsewhere, corrects a statement for which the TIMES on Thursday was indebted to the Indianapolis State Journal, touching a purchase of arms for Indiana. Mr. OWEN informs us that no Enfield rifles are bought by Government for so high a price as twenty-four dollars; the price for the ordinary weapon varying only fractionally from sixteen dollars. In the instances of Mr. OWEN's sale, the price was nearly two dollars beyond this standard, for the sufficient reason that the lot of weapons was of highly superior make and finish.

abstract: Morton's Gold Pens can be sent to any part of the country by mail, as safely as in any other way. Tens of thousands of dollars' worth have been sent out by mail during the past year, without the loss of a single one, and the number which has been sent back to be exchanged is very small. If the sender is particular to state what kind of a pen suits his hand, he will, in almost every instance, be fitted by return mail. Persons whose signature nobody can read, will be particular to write a duplicate plainly, together with the name of their Post-office, County and State.

abstract: Editorial calls for untiring devotion of time and resources by public to Army Sanitary Commission work
snippet: Editorial calls for untiring devotion of time and resources by public to Army Sanitary Commission work
lead_paragraph: The recent magnificent donation of one hundred thousand dollars, made by San Francisco to the Sanitary Commission, ought to and we hope will serve to fix the public attention more closely and profitably than ever upon this great practical agency of Christian civilization in the camp. With judgment and energy in the administration of its affairs, no easily assignable limit can be set to the good which this Commission may do, as no easily assignable limit can be set to the evils which its labors are designed to mitigate and to arrest. Could the citizens of the North, to whom the war is a rumor and a history; the dancers at Newport and Saratoga; the promenaders in Broadway and the Park; the busy and glittering throngs whose skimmer through our City streets makes the observer sometimes doubt whether all he sees about him is not a vast delusion and a dream, so little does it speak or show of the tremendous strife the nation is waging for existence; could these myriads for whom and for whose future the brave are dying by scores and hundreds every week, look in, for but one hour, upon the hospitals of the army -- pass but one night upon a moonlit field of battle fresh from the wrathful passage of the war-angels, it would need no voice of ours to [???] them to the cry which goes up unceasingly to these commissioners of mercy.

abstract: How many a splendid train of ideas has been interrupted and lost forever by the tripping of a bad pen! How many an editor, when the current of his invective was flowing freely, and he was flattering himself that that article would do the work for the "Last of Newspaper Generals," or the "Military Dictatorship," or the "Great Reconstructed of Cabinets," has suddenly found his page bespattered with ink, his speech with very hard words, and his "happiest vein" ruined for that day -- all because of a bad pen.

abstract: Charles H. Fleming, Plaintiff in Error, vs. The People, Defendants in Error. -- The plaintiff in error was tried in the New-York General Sessions on an indictment for bigamy. The indictment charged, that on the 11th of November, 1855, he married one Rowena Baldwin, and that on the 30th of December, 1861, lie did "marry and take as his wife one Jane A. Butt, and to the said Jane was then and there married, the said Rowena being then and there living, and in full life, against the form of the Statute," & c. The prosecution gave evidence tending to prove both marriages. The indictment did not negative any of the exceptions enumerated in the statute concerning bigamy.
lead_paragraph: Charles H. Fleming, Plaintiff in Error, vs. The People, Defendants in Error. -- The plaintiff in error was tried in the New-York General Sessions on an indictment for bigamy. The indictment charged, that on the 11th of November, 1855, he married one Rowena Baldwin, and that on the 30th of December, 1861, lie did "marry and take as his wife one Jane A. Butt, and to the said Jane was then and there married, the said Rowena being then and there living, and in full life, against the form of the Statute," & c. The prosecution gave evidence tending to prove both marriages. The indictment did not negative any of the exceptions enumerated in the statute concerning bigamy.

abstract: "To write with a steel pen is to be penny wise and pound foolish, for Mr. Morton's Gold Pen is cheaper in the end. We have used one of his for about six months, and if it only had wit as it has point, we would trust it to go alone, so beautifully does it work. Clergymen, clerks, literary and business men, who write constantly, should have a Pen adapted to their hand, that the easiest possible pressure may do the work; and for a person engaged in composition, the Pen should run so easily and uniformly as never to lead the thought from the subject to the instrument. After years of search, we found just this thing at Mr. Morton's, and the labor of writing and of composition has been lessened, and the pleasure of both increased. For their sakes and ours, we wish that all our correspondents would use his Pens."
lead_paragraph: "To write with a steel pen is to be penny wise and pound foolish, for Mr. Morton's Gold Pen is cheaper in the end. abstract: Jess H. Pomeroy vs. Mary J. Dustan. -- In this action plaintiff sues the dependant for services in repairing the ship Eloise, for which, it is alleged, she promised to pay $300 by the note of her husband, John F. Dustan. This the defendant [???] and alleges that payment was to be made by the person in whose name the vessel should be registered when the job was complete. The coverture of the defendant was urged on the trial in bar to the suit, but the Court held that such coverture should have been pleaded, to be made available, on the trial. The husband, however, was not permitted to testify in the case. Judgment for plaintiff for $921 33, with an extra allowance.

abstract: The particular part assigned to the Northern Democracy in the tragedy of rebellion was to distract the counsels of the North and, by dividing the loyalists of the country, insure the predominance of treason. Up to the moment when the patience of the people, tried beyond endurance by the outrage in Charleston harbor, gave impulse to the great political upheaval of April, 1861, the part was played with much courage and consistency, and not without promise of success. It was only when the acting became physically dangerous that the play was abandoned, to be resumed, however, when the tempest of popular passion should subside. It is now resumed. A great party has framed its platform for the sole purpose of weakening the Government by dividing the loyal sentiment of the North; and no device is too daring or revolutionary, and no trick or falsehood too vile, to be omitted from the task of promoting agitation and provoking insurrection.

abstract: Another difficulty has arisen in the Empire Brigade, at East New-York. It seems there was a deficiency of men in the different commands, and it was found necessary, in order to fill up the regiments to the maximum standard, to make a consolidation. The First Regiment, under the command of Col.
lead_paragraph: Another difficulty has arisen in the Empire Brigade, at East New-York. It seems there was a deficiency of men in the different commands, and it was found necessary, in order to fill up the regiments to the maximum standard, to make a consolidation. The First Regiment, under the command of Col. JOURDAN, got off to the seat of war about a week ago, and the others were to have left this week. The Fourth Regiment had the smallest number of men, there being but 485. and it was ordered that this command be consolidated with the Second and Third. On Monday last, Gen. SPINOLA, it appears, received orders to make the consolidation.
headline: {'main': 'Another Row in the Empire Brigade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Another Row in the Empire Brigade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Brig.-Gen. PHELPS has just published in the New-York Tribune a full statement of the difficulties which he experienced in executing the President's policy of emancipation before it was adopted. This is the substance of the case set forth by the General -- and so far as he is personally concerned in the matter, it is too plain to need discussion, that he sacrificed his peace of mind, his permanent usefulness in Louisiana, and his commission, to a thoroughly and curiously mistaken theory of his duty and his responsibilities. He went to Louisiana as a military agent of the Government at Washington, under the orders of a Major-General, regularly appointed and charged with the supreme direction of affairs in the Department to which Brig.-Gen. PHELPS had been assigned. Much meditating the grave issues of Slavery and emancipation, as it is creditable to him that he should have done, Gen. PHELPS became convinced that the continued existence of Slavery is incompatible, in the first instance, with the progress of civilization at the South, and, in the second instance, with the maintenance of the National authority over the seceded States. Thus convinced, he forthwith proceeded to act upon his convictions, and to establish at "Camp Parapet, near Garrollton, La.," a nucleus of free institutions for the South, reporting at the same time to his commanding officer that the Government at Washington really must come to some conclusion upon the question of emancipation, if it expected either to retain the services of Gen. PHELPS, or to put a satisfactory end to the rebellion. We mean no disrespect to Gen. PHELPS in this statement of his singular appeal -- for we are disposed to believe him as sincere and singleminded, as we cannot but think him mistaken in his estimate of his official obligations. Maj.-Gen. BUTLER evidently balancing for some time between the proprieties of his position, and his respect for Gen. PHELPS, was finally compelled to interpose his superior authority in execution of certain orders, which the apostolic Brigadier had hesitated to obey, and an unpleasant collision, which could have had but one result, and that not an agreeable one for Gen. PHELPS, was avoided only by the acceptance at Washington of that officer's resignation.
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. PHELPS has just published in the New-York Tribune a full statement of the difficulties which he experienced in executing the President's policy of emancipation before it was adopted. This is the substance of the case set forth by the General -- and so far as he is personally concerned in the matter, it is too plain to need discussion, that he sacrificed his peace of mind, his permanent usefulness in Louisiana, and his commission, to a thoroughly and curiously mistaken theory of his duty and his responsibilities. He went to Louisiana as a military agent of the Government at Washington, under the orders of a Major-General, regularly appointed and charged with the supreme direction of affairs in the Department to which Brig.-Gen. PHELPS had been assigned. Much meditating the grave issues of Slavery and emancipation, as it is creditable to him that he should have done, Gen. PHELPS became convinced that the continued existence of Slavery is incompatible, in the first instance, with the progress of civilization at the South, and, in the second instance, with the maintenance of the National authority over the seceded States. Thus convinced, he forthwith proceeded to act upon his convictions, and to establish at "Camp Parapet, near Garrollton, La.," a nucleus of free institutions for the South, reporting at the same time to his commanding officer that the Government at Washington really must come to some conclusion upon the question of emancipation, if it expected either to retain the services of Gen. PHELPS, or to put a satisfactory end to the rebellion. We mean no disrespect to Gen. PHELPS in this statement of his singular appeal -- for we are disposed to believe him as sincere and singleminded, as we cannot but think him mistaken in his estimate of his official obligations. Maj.-Gen. BUTLER evidently balancing for some time between the proprieties of his position, and his respect for Gen. PHELPS, was finally compelled to interpose his superior authority in execution of certain orders, which the apostolic Brigadier had hesitated to obey, and an unpleasant collision, which could have had but one result, and that not an agreeable one for Gen. PHELPS, was avoided only by the acceptance at Washington of that officer's resignation.

abstract: We have never believed there was the least reason to fear any danger from the comparatively few Indians now in the northern part of this State. They have no provocation to commence hostilities, or motives to join the tribes that have committed the terrible massacres on the western frontier of Minnesola,and both their interest and safety lie in the continuance of peace. We are confirmed in this opinion by the statements of Mr JOHN JACOBS, of Marionette, Oconto County, who made us a visit last week, and who, probably, has had a longer, more extensive and intimate acquaintance with the Indians of wiscousin than any other citizen in the State. He has traded with them during the past twenty years and understand fully their sentiments feelings, disposition and purposes. He informs us thatopportunities, if the Indians here fight at al, it will be for the whites, and not [???] them. abstract: Editorial speculates on McClellan next move on Potomac; Editorial on ex-US Sen. Wigfall activities in Confederate Congress; Editorial on ex-Sen. Wigfall activities in Confederate Congress
snippet: Editorial speculates on McClellan next move on Potomac; Editorial on ex-US Sen. Wigfall activities in Confederate Congress; Editorial on ex-Sen. Wigfall activities in Confederate Congress
lead_paragraph: Do our readers remember WIGFALL? It is some time since we have heard anything of this individual, and for ourselves we had almost forgotten his existence. But WIGFALL "still lives," and enlightens the Confederate Senate now and then as formerly he did our own. And, by the way, that we have got him out of the Senate Chamber of the United States, is no small good result of the rebellion.

abstract: It is now over four months since the Government decided to adopt a postal currency in other words, to issue notes of various denominations, from five cents upward which should be receivable at any Post-office for stamps, and should supply the deficiency in a circulating medium. In the meantime, the people, forbidden to use individual shinplasters, reluctantly adopted the use of ordinary postage-stamps as a temporary expedient.
lead_paragraph: It is now over four months since the Government decided to adopt a postal currency -- in other words, to issue notes of various denominations, from five cents upward -- which should be receivable at any Post-office for stamps, and should supply the deficiency in a circulating medium. abstract: Gen. WADSWORTH, who recently received thenomination of the Union Convention for Governorof this State, was serenaded last night at his residence in Washington, of which place he is at present the Military Governor. A great crowd was present, and in response to urgent calls the General appeared and made a speech, in which he clearly defined his position with reference to the war for putting down the rebellion. A special Report of his speech, received by telegraph, will be found in our columns this morning.

abstract: At an adjourned meeting of this Board, held yesterday forenoon, after the reading of the minutes, and the question being on the confirmation of the same, Aid. FROMENT said that the meeting of Friday, as well as the previous one of Wednesday, was held without due notice to the members, and he felt it a duty to his constituents to protest against these sudden meetings of the Board, sprung upon the members without proper notice, and he could not, under the circumstances, vote for a confirmation of the minute. On motion of Alderman BOOLE, the minutes were confirmed.
lead_paragraph: At an adjourned meeting of this Board, held yesterday forenoon, after the reading of the minutes, and the question being on the confirmation of the same, Aid. On motion of Alderman BOOLE, the minutes were confirmed.

abstract: stated in the TIMES of yesterday that the World newspaper "had become the property of Mr. FERNANDO WOOD." A note from Mr. MANTON MARBLE, who is the recognized editor of the journal referred to, assures us of the inaccuracy of the statement, and informs us that he is the sole proprietor. It is proper, perhaps, to say, that neither the present reference or the one complained of has been dictated by a disposition to place that gentleman in an offensive light before the public.

abstract: Ringel vs. Victor Heuback et al.; Bithofer et al., vs. Heuback et al. and Davenport, Receiver. The facts in this case, as stated by appellants, are these: Bilhofer et. al., brought a creditor's action against Heuback, et al., judgment debtors, and Henry Heuback, fraudulent vendor of a stock of goods, and filed their complaint Sept. 19, 1860.
lead_paragraph: Ringel vs. Victor Heuback et al.; Bithofer et al., vs. Heuback et al. and Davenport, Receiver. -- The facts in this case, as stated by appellants, are these: Bilhofer et. al., brought a creditor's action against Heuback, et al., judgment debtors, and Henry Heuback, fraudulent vendor of a stock of goods, and filed their complaint Sept. 19, 1860. In that action Jonh Davenport was appointed receiver, and [???] on the 14th day of November, 1860, he was directed to sell sufficient of the goods to pay plaintiff's demand of costs, and it was referred to Mr. Marbury to ascertain that amount, which he found to be $8,500. In the meantime, on the 26th day of October, Ringel commenced his creditor's action against the defendants, and on the 26th day of March, 1861, procured an order appointing Davenport receiver, in his action, of all the property which came into his possession when appointed receiver in the other action of Bilhofer and not then already sold by him as receiver in the Bilhofer action.

abstract: fect military lull has followed the great week of battles; but there are beginning to be signs that the dead-lock that has held the two armies on opposite banks of the Potomac ever since the close of the mighty duel in which each contestant claims to be victor, is destined speedily to be brought to an end. So long as the rebels either remained in the position they took up on the south side of the Potomac, or could make Gen. MCCLELLAN believe that they remained there, it was difficult for him to budge, for if he attempted to cross in pursuit there was the danger of his force being cut up in the process, while if he should retire to Washington, the enemy would be popping over into Maryland again. It would seem from present appearances that the rebel leadershave relied on their ability to deceive Gen. MCCLELLAN by an appearance of force, while they have used the opportunity to retire the main body of their army down the Shenandoah valley. The reconnoissances that have been made within the past two or three days on the Virginia side, and which have been pushed as far as Shepardstown and Martinsburgh, disclose nowhere anything more than a picket guard; and it is not unlikely that the chief force of the rebels is now at or near Winchester. Gen. MCCLELLAN will now, probably, transfer his army to the Virginia side of the Potomac; but what he will do after that it would not be easy to tell. If the rebels are left undisturbed in their position at Winchester, they will find in the rich harvest of this fertile valley abundant subsistence for the next three months.

abstract: SILVER PLATT. -- Since the Tax Law passed [???] a housewife has distressed herself with the [???] of a [???] Assistant Assessor ransacking her [???], truth and bureaus, and turning the contents of her [???] down, to ascertain the exact amount of [???]. The fears of such an intrusion upon the privacy of home are entirely groundless, Commissioner BOUTWELL has given particular instructions for the polite and dedorous entrencment of the Tax Laws; and the Assessors will forbid their Assistants to indulge in any unnecessary or impertinent inquisitiveness in the performance of their duties. In all inquiries protruding to the household they will rely upon the honesty of the citizen, rather than make the Tax Law tedious by a search of the premises. People who are fortunate enough to own silver spoons, tea-pots, sugar bowls, cream-pitchers, trays and other silver ware will be expected to ascertain the weight of them in Troy ounces. This can be most easily and accurately done at some silversmith's; and his certificate as to the weight will be accepted by the Assessor as correct. It is only upon the excess of 40 ounces, belonging to any one person, that the tax of three cents per ounce is chargeable. As an encouragement of the family institution, the framers of the law have exempted those silver mugs, which are the peculiar endowments of babyhood. In fact, everything which does not come under the head of silver tableware "kept for use," is exempt. While the law is thus tolerant of sliver ware, it puts a tax of 50 centsper troy ounce on all gold plate kept for use. People happening to have any of that kind of property in their houses, must have it weighed and certified to.

abstract: On the 30th of July, at Georgetown, British Guiana, a meeting was held on the subject of the immigration of free blacks from the United States. The United States Consul, Mr. EDWARDS, made a speech at the meeting, in the course of which be spoke of the policy of the President toward the slaves of the Border and Southern States, and the probability of the former manumitting their slaves on the plan proposed by the President, and the liberation of a large number of those in the Southern States as the Federal armies penetrated further into them.
lead_paragraph: On the 30th of July, at Georgetown, British Guiana, a meeting was held on the subject of the immigration of free blacks from the United States. The United States Consul, Mr. EDWARDS, made a speech at the meeting, in the course of which be spoke of the policy of the President toward the slaves of the Border and Southern States, and the probability of the former manumitting their slaves on the plan proposed by the President, and the liberation of a large number of those in the Southern States as the Federal armies penetrated further into them.

abstract: A PUBLIC MEETING IN AID OF THE FOURTEENTH REGIMENT N. Y. S. M.-Friday evening a public meeting was held at the Washington-street M. E. Church, for the purpose of aiding in recruiting the Fourteenth Regiment N. Y. S. M. to at least a minimum standard. The meeting was very well attended, and was very enthusiastic. A large number of ladies were...
lead_paragraph: A PUBLIC MEETING IN AID OF THE FOURTEENTH REGIMENT N.Y.S.M. -- Friday evening a public meeting was held at the Washington-street M. E. Church, for the purpose of aiding in recruiting the Fourteenth Regiment N. Y. S. M. to at least a minimum standard. The meeting was very well attended, and was very enthusiastic. A large number of ladies were present, as also were several members of the regiment on furlough from the seat of war, and officers on recruiting service. Mr. SAMUEL BOOTH presided, and Messrs. DANIEL F. WAY and ISAAC BADEAU acted as Secretaries. Stirring and patriotic addresses were made by Revs. G.C. FOSS and L. WARD, Hon. M.F. ODELL and WILLIAM H. BURLEIGH. The meeting was called under the direction of the Fourth Ward Bounty Committee, Hon. S.S. Powell, Joseph Reeves, Samuel Booth, C.W. Riley, Isaac Badeau and Seth R. Robins.

abstract: Recruiting for this new and already favorite regiment has proceeded so well that the corps has already reached the minimum number and will doubtless shortly reach the maximum. It is confidently expected by the officers that the regiment will be stationed at Fort Federal Hill, Baltimore, during the Winter, where they will be enabled to go through the same thorough and complete course of instruction that has made the First Regiment of Duryee's Zouaves so celebrated and procured for them the post of honor which was so long and successfully held during the late campaigns. There is something fascinating in the dress and peculiar style of the "Red Devils," causing the best classes of our young men to enter their ranks. In every battle in which they were engaged, the Fifth New-York invariably received their full share of praise, and as often as they have called for recruits, as often have they eclipsed all other organizations, both as to style of men and rapidity of enrollment. To-morrow (Sunday) the Second Duryee's Zouaves will have their first dress parade at Camp Washington, Staten Island. The event will be an interesting one to the many friends of the regiment, and visitors will have an opportunity of seeing how the men look in a body. Absentees are expected to report at the recruiting headquarters this afternoon to proceed to camp, or be treated as deserters.

abstract: COTTON The sales of the week amounted to 24,000 bales. The market was irregular, and had declined d, for American, d for Surats, and 2d, for other descriptions. On Friday the sales were 2,000 bales, the market closing at the above decline. Orleans Middling was quoted at 26 d.
lead_paragraph: COTTON -- The sales of the week amounted to 24,000 bales. The market was irregular, and had declined 1/2d, for American,1/4 d for Surats, and 2d, for other descriptions. On Friday the sales were 2,000 bales, the market closing at the above decline. Orleans Middling was quoted at 26 1/2d.

abstract: The amount paid out of the [???] City [???] up to and including the [???] of the period fixed by the ordinance -- was $227,500, leaving $272,500 still on hand. The number of enlistments then, from the 3d to the 24th inst., was 4,550 -- a far less proportion than such inducements would have led us to anticipate, On the closing days the rush was very great, the last furnishing a quota of no less than 300 applicants. Still, a few stragglers who enlisted within the time, but had not received their bounty, are dropping in, but recruiting under the provisions of the ordinance has come to almost a dead halt since a great mass of those who are willing to enlist for a consideration are awaiting the golden opportunity of the impending draft in the fond belief that "it is an ill wind that blows nobody good."

abstract: The firemen of New-York paid a splendid tribute of appreciation to Commander PORTER, of the gunboat Essex, last evening. Learning that the gallant sailor was stopping at the St. Nicholas, they planned a magnificent torchlight procession and serenade, which was carried out with the most gratifying success. Among the companies participating, were:...
lead_paragraph: The firemen of New-York paid a splendid tribute of appreciation to Commander PORTER, of the gunboat Essex, last evening. Learning that the gallant sailor was stopping at the St. Nicholas, they planned a magnificent torchlight procession and serenade, which was carried out with the most gratifying success. Among the companies participating, were: Hook and Ladder No. 6, Hose No. 23, Hose No. 24, Engine No. 34, Hose No. 11, Engine No. 31, Hose No. 7, Engine No. 57, and Engine No. 47. Delegations from these various organizations, in full fire costume; congregated at Fireman's Hall, and equipped with American flag-lanterns, torches and pyrotechnics of various descriptions, marched down Broadway, attended by an immense gathering of citizens, to the St. Nicholas Hotel. The route was enlivened by the music of DODWORTH's Band, and illuminated by the gay display of lanterns, and more particularly the rockets, Roman candles, blue lights, and other fireworks, which were profusely exhibited. The firemen did themselves infinite credit, not only in the completeness of their preparations, but in the enthusiasm which marked their entire demonstration.

abstract: tucky begins to breathe freely again, though the rescue of her commercial metropolis from the threatened seizure of the enemy has cost the country dearly. Still we do not blame Kentucky, nor think that the fact of a successful rebel invasion leaves any stain on her loyalty. The State has furnished every volunteer demanded by the National Government for the general defence. And this, after losing many thousands of her unworthy young men, who were allured but too easily into the ranks of treason. An agricultural people, in the quiet pursuit of their usual farm avocations, are never expected to repel an armed enemy coming upon them in force. Hence, the fairest and most loyal portion of Kentucky deserves sympathy in its misfortune. If the nation loses much by what has occurred there, the population who have been despoiled lose in proportion much more.

abstract: Editorial attacks European countries that chide US for its persistence in defending its national existence
snippet: Editorial attacks European countries that chide US for its persistence in defending its national existence
lead_paragraph: The Government of the United States is certainly the worst behaved in the world. It is drawing upon itself the frowns of the friends of political morality everywhere. England, with her feet upon Ireland, and her bayonets pressing against the breast of India, admonishes us that all peoples ought to be free to choose their own political associations, and that government without love is selfish empire. Her rulers are expending $350,000,000 a year to maintain a dominion that has been won by the sword. The little Island reverberates with the clink of hammers, building iron-clad fighting ships, and with the peals of ordnance denoting the trial of Armstrong guns. The newspapers applaud the new militia system, which is to convert every Englishman into a capable soldier. England thinks of nothing, apparently, so much as war;prepares for nothing so much as war; contracts enormous debts freely only for war; and all the time berates all other nations -- the United States particularly -- for any indulgence in war, no matter what the provocation. Better give up national life; better surrender natural boundaries; better yield up forts, mints and custom-houses; better perish utterly from the map of nations, than go to war against rebels. So says England to the United States, but so did England never in all her career of a thousand years and more. England spends nearly as much in peace as the United States does in war -- 350 millions a year. And all this is gathered, or supposed to be, from the labor of a hard-worked people, who have a pinched area and slender means of work.

abstract: During the past week, large numbers of new counterfeit bills, upon the banks in this and adjoining States have been put in circulation in New-York and Brooklyn. Owing to the rapidity with which the the general alarm was given by means of the Police Telegraph, and also to the activity of the patrolmen on duty, in the notifying the shopkeepers and others of the simultaneous movement of the counterfeiters, the latter have been, in a great measure foiled in their efforts to pass off the spurious notes. In too many instances, however, they have been successful, especially in respect to $5s upon the Union Bank of Sullivan County. These bills are exceedingly well executed, and so closely do they resemble the genuine that in some instances our best judges have been deceived by them. In the upper part of the city many of these counterfeits were successfully passed, even after notice by the police that the gang were operating with them. On Friday evening another combined attempt was made with well-executed counterfeit 3s on the Mechanics and Tradesmen's Bank of Portsmouth. N.H. A general alarm was given by telegraph, and the patrolmen put the public upon their guard before a large amount had been put inty circulation. Several arrests were made in the upper precincts.

abstract: DEATH FROM A FALL AN AWFUL CASE. A young seaman, named JOSEPH STRINGER, just returned from a cruise in one of the United States ves- sels, fell from the third-story window of the premises No. 56 Monroe-stroet, of a late hour on Saturday night. Deceased was out on a "lark" with some brother sailors, and had been drinking with them.
lead_paragraph: DEATH FROM A FALL -- AN AWFUL CASE. -- A young seaman, named JOSEPH STRINGER, just returned from a cruise in one of the United States ves- sels, fell from the third-story window of the premises No. 56 Monroe-stroet, of a late hour on Saturday night. Deceased was out on a "lark" with some brother sailors, and had been drinking with them. When he fell his body struck upon the iron railing beneath, cutting his right leg completely off below the knee, and mangling the body so as to render it unrecognizable. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, but he died two hours afterward, Coroner COLTON will hold an inquest on the body to-day. Deceased was respectably connected, and has parents residing in New-Hampshire. They have been telegraphed for.

abstract: It is evident that the good people who put their faith in HORATIO SEYMOUR, and shudder at the prospect of an American nationality purged of Slavery, have been not a litle cast down and disquieted by the recent apparent progress of the rebel arms.
lead_paragraph: It is evident that the good people who put their faith in HORATIO SEYMOUR, and shudder at the prospect of an American nationality purged of Slavery, have been not a litle cast down and disquieted by the recent apparent progress of the rebel arms. Having settled it to their own satisfaction that the armies of the Confederates are everywhere practically in the ascendant, and that the safety of Washington depends upon keeping Gen. MCCLELLAN chained, with all the men whom we can muster, in a condition of masterly inactivity and leisurely observation, the estimable "Conservatives" have been sedulously fretting about their fears of the terrible consequences likely to be visited upon the loyal States if we do not make haste to propitiate the victorious South. Conquest of the seceded States being impossible, in their judgment, the time, they think, has come for averting the alternative conquest of the loyal States, by a frank and immediate surrender. Should we now go back into the presence of President DAVIS, like the burgesses of Calais before EDWARD III., with ropes about our necks, and walking upon our knees, it is just possible, they opine, that we might be forgiven, the Union reconstructed on a basis of general acquiescence in all Southern demands, Mr. LINCOLN and Mr. HAMLIN be pensioned off with liberty to reside in Liberia or Chiriqui, and FERNANDO WOOD be sent out as Minister to England or France, vice ADAMS or DAYTON, banished to Hayti for life, and MASON or SLIDELL recalled for domestic promotion. Should we, however, prove obstinate at this crisis; should we elect State Governors who prefer liberty and the nation's life with war, to peace with National death and Slavery, and in a general way aid and abet President LINCOLN in his efforts at emancipation, then it is not easy to say what may happen to us -- to what extremities of vengeance the outraged Confederates may proceed, or what dire chastisement a banded Europe will desire for a people so infatuated and so insolent as to think their National existence a thing worth fighting for.

abstract: editorial on speech
snippet: editorial on speech
lead_paragraph: Our most reliable information from the Upper Potomac indicates that the bulk of the rebel force is at Winchester, which place is designed both as a base and a nucleus of operations; and the statements to the effect that the rebels are still in force on the south bank of the Potomac probably arise from the fact that they are keeping sufficient men in the vicinity to dispute the crossing of the forces -- they undoubtedly wishing to detain our army on the north back of the river, while fearing a movement to cut off their communications with Richmond. That this fear is well grounded will be gathered from our correspondence this morning.

abstract: T Carlyle's 3d vol. of Frederick the Great completed; reviewed; 3d vol. of Frederick the Great completed; reviewed
snippet: T Carlyle's 3d vol. of Frederick the Great completed; reviewed; 3d vol. of Frederick the Great completed; reviewed
lead_paragraph: -- CARLYLE has at last finished the third volume of his history of Frederick the Great, and the HARPERS publish it for the benefit of American readers. FREDERICK obtained the name of a mighty warrior, in his time and hence is designated the Great, as ALEXANDER was. The present day is excessively warlike. Every man in the United States is either a soldier, or becoming one, or criticising the actions of those who are in the field learning the game that FREDERICK played at. The publication of this third volume of FREDERICK the Great's history by CARLYLE is, therefore, very opportune, for it presents to us the first four years of warfare by the Prussian King when he was an apprentice at the business. The record of his early experience should be as useful to us as a primer to children. It ought to teach us the rudiments of military art and aptitude.

abstract: -- The rebels have thought better of the bloody instructions they put forth apropos of GEN. POPE's officers, and ninety-six of these, lately prisoners at Richmond, have within a few days been released upon parole. Whether it is the removal of the General that has placated the rebels, or whether they were moved by a gentle hint from our Government that any such discriminating treatment as they proposed would be retaliated two-fold on their prisoners, of whom we hold two to their one, we know not. Either cause would account for it, and, perhaps, both may have been instrumental in the result.

lead_paragraph: We hear, with some dismay, hints of Winter quarters -- of postponing an advance upon the rebels, and of training the 600,000 fresh troops who are rushing to the field of battle. We see intimations that Gen. McCLELLAN is throwing up substantial earthworks along the Upper Potomac; and, what is still more surprising, we find the policy of delay favored in quarters which have hitherto been the most zealous and emphatic for a prompt and vigorous prosecution of the war. abstract: The steamship Anglo-Saxon passed Cape Race early on Saturday morning, with advices from Europe five days later, and the City of Baltimore arrived here yesterday, with mails to the 18th. A summary of the news, which is of little importance, is given elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Anglo-Saxon passed Cape Race early on Saturday morning, with advices from Europe five days later, and the City of Baltimore arrived here yesterday, with mails to the 18th. A summary of the news, which is of little importance, is given elsewhere. A Paris correspondent believes Count MERCIER has been ordered by the French Government to make a conciliatory attempt to put a stop to the war in America for the sake of humanity. The Times' Paris correspondent says NAPOLEON will undoubtly favor the recognition of the Southern Confederacy, and is anxious the English Government should adopt a similar course. The excitement in the jute and hemp market had subsided. There is nothing new as regards the Roman question. GARIBALDI's health is said to be rather worse. The Polish nobles at Warsaw have adopted an address offensive to the Government. The sales of Cotton for the week amounted to 24,000 bales, the market being irregular, with a decline on all descriptions. Breadstuffs were irregular, and Provisions were quiet but firm. Consols were quoted at 93 5/8@93 1/2 for money. American securities were quiet.

abstract: London Shipping Gazette article says US proposes to issue letters of marque and reprisal to check hostilities by Southern privateers against US commerce
snippet: London Shipping Gazette article says US proposes to issue letters of marque and reprisal to check hostilities by Southern privateers against US commerce
lead_paragraph: A Nova Scotian cotemporary, received by the ast mail, contains an axtract from the Newfoundland Royal Gazette, from which it appears that the Governor of that Colony has received a dispatch from the Duke of Newcastle, dated the 1st ult., intimating that Earl RUSSELL "had been informed by the American Minister in London, that it is the intention of the United States Government to issue letters of marque, with a view of checking the hostilities carried on by Southern Privateers against United States Commerce." This information the Duke of Newcastle has thought it right to communicate without delay to the Governors of Newfoundland and New-Brunswick, "as serious inconveniences may result to British commerce from such a measure." The promptitude of the Colonia Secretary is commendable, but it is somewhat strange that information so intimately concerning the carrying trade of this country, should have been left to find its way here from our North American Colonies. The notice which has made its appearance in the Government journal of Newfoundland should, unquestionably, have appeared in the Government journal here, in the first instance. Yet we are not aware that the London Gazette has contained any intimation on the subject of this officially reported communication of Mr. ADAMS to Earl RUSSELL, respecting privateering. The document, however, which has appeared in the Newfoundland Royal Gazette is evidently genuine. It is put forth "by His Excellency's order," and bears the signature of the Acting Colonial Secretary. Assuming, then, that the Federal Government have resolved to carry out their intention with respect to the issue of letters of marque, the information is quite as necessary for our merchants and shipowners here as in the Colonies. If Federal privateers take the sea, they will probably not confine their operations to "checking the hostilities carried on by Southern privateers against United States Commerce" -- they will take the sea in aid of the Federal navy, either to assist in maintaining the blockade, or, what is more likely, to cooperate in effecting captures. Privateering has been formally abolished by the maritime States of Europe, Spain excepted, but it is still retained by America as a means of supplementing her naval force. There are two aspects in which the issue of letters-of-marque and reprisal may be regarded -- either as authority to ships to carry armaments for purposes of defence and capture, if attacked, or simply for the purpose of harrassing the commerce of the enemy, wherever it may be fallen in with -- or, as the old law of this country has it, "to seize the property of the aggressor nation without hazard of being condemned as robbers or pirates." Application was made early in the war to President LINCOLN to permit merchantmen to carry arms with a view to reprisals as well as defence, but it was refused. It would seem this refusal has been reconsidered, and that Northern merchantmen will be authorized to carry arms for purposes of aggression as well as defence. There can be no doubt that the law of nations justifies the Federal Government in resorting to this mode of increasing their maritime force. "When a State which has received, or supposes it has received (says WHEATON, E.I.L., p. 372) an inquiry from another nation, it delivers commissions to its officers and subjects to take the persons and property belonging to the other nation wherever the same may be found." This is the law of Reprisals as hitherto sanctioned by international usage, and the Cabinet of Washington are authorized to resort to it. But the evil of privateering consists in this -- that it superadds to patriotic motives those of private interest and cupidity, and has been found in the experience of nations to be most mischievous in its effects. Hence the Powers who met in Paris in 1856, agreed that its abolition was demanded by the progress of events as a remnant of barbarous warfare, inconsistent with the present advanced state of civilization. By the issue of letters-of-marque and reprisal, to meet the Southern privateers, the Federal Government at once concede the status of "another nation" to the Southern States. It is, however, incorrect to describe the Sumter, the Jeff. Davis, the Alabama, and other craft which have taken the sea under the Palmetto flag as privateers. They are, as the Confederate authorities assert, vessels commanded by officers regularly commissioned by the Confederate Government, and which have taken the sea in defence of the commerce of the South quite as much as to prey upon the commerce of the North. The point of view, however, in which we in this country must regard this issue of letters of marque by the Federal Government is, that it is intended thereby to reinforce the Federal fleet indefinitely, and, so far as neutral commerce has suffered inconvenience from the operations of that fleet, to increase that inconvenience. The armed vessels of the South are too few in number to necessitate a resort to privateering on the part of the North; but neutral vessels somehow do continue to enter and leave ports under blockade with valuable cargoes. These are the vessels for which the Northern privateers will be on the lookout, and not for the Sumter, that has long sizes changed hands at Gibraltar, the Alabama, or even the ubiquitous Ovieto. Hence it is, no doubt, that our Colonial Secretary has considered it his duty to warm our North American Colonists of the "serious inconvenience which may result to British commerce from such a measure," a warning which we feel is quite as necessary for our shipowners and merchants here as for those of Newfoundland or New-Brunswick. Our Government, cannot, of course, dispute the right of the Federal Government to grant licences to private adventurers to arm ships, whether for purposes of aggression or defence; but it will be their duty to see that no interference with neutral lawful commerce is attempted, under any pretence whatever.

abstract: The business of this port since the war commenced has exceeded the expectations of the most sanguine. When, at the commencement of our troubles, everything looked dark and gloomy, it was freely prophested that the result of the war, should it long continue, as far as our City was concerned, would be to greatly injure its material prosperity.
lead_paragraph: The business of this port since the war commenced has exceeded the expectations of the most sanguine. When, at the commencement of our troubles, everything looked dark and gloomy, it was freely prophested that the result of the war, should it long continue, as far as our City was concerned, would be to greatly injure its material prosperity. Many shrank appalled at the prospect, and all who could, prepared for the coming storm. The opinion most prevalent was that the withdrawal of the Southern trade, on which many of our merchants were dependent, would do the City great damage; that the anticipated general depression and stagnation of business throughout the country would keep at home the customers usually thronging to the City at stated periods, from our Northern cities and towns; that the people themselves would feel that they were about to be impoverished, and would in consequence curtail their expenses, and decrease their expenditures, to accord with the new order of things; that real estate in the City, influenced by the general feeling of uncertainty and doubt, would speedily deteriorate in value, and thus seriously affect a large portion of our community. Indeed, our Southern enemies, in the extremity of their hate, did not hesitate to assert that the North would be ruined, and that the City of New-York would no more be exultant in its wealth and prosperity. When, later, the immense army of the Republic had been placed in the field, and from every rural district, as well as from every city and town, our noble soldiers flocked to uphold their country's honor, and maintain their nation's integrity, fears were entertained that our farming interests would suffer from the want of labor -- that the transformation of our sturdy yeomen into hardy soldiers would cause whole sections, which, under other circumstances, would be cultivated and productive, to lie waste and useless. In all such speculations the people of this City were deeply interested. New-York has long been the City from which the people of our own land have drawn their supplies of merchandise and foreign commodities, and the port from whence had long been exported the stores of grain and provisions which other nations needed for their support. If, then, the war should cause this domestic demand to cease, and should also prevent the production of the articles of export, our City, more than any other, would be the sufferer.

abstract: CORONERS' INQUESTS. Coroner NORRIS held an inquest, on Saturday, upon the body of a boy named ALBERT SELLS, who came to his death from injuries sustained by falling from the front platform of one of the Jamaica Railroad cars, in Atlantic-street. The deceased and brother jumped off while the cars were in motion, and, falling under the wheel, one of his legs were crushed.
lead_paragraph: CORONERS' INQUESTS. -- Coroner NORRIS held an inquest, on Saturday, upon the body of a boy named ALBERT SELLS, who came to his death from injuries sustained by falling from the front platform of one of the Jamaica Railroad cars, in Atlantic-street. The deceased and brother jumped off while the cars were in motion, and, falling under the wheel, one of his legs were crushed. He was conveyed to the City Hospital, where the limb was amputated, but he did not long survive the operation. The mother of deceased is a music-teacher, residing in the Sixteenth Ward. She has, during the past few years, been peculiarly unfortunate. Her husband was drowned, and subsequently her two eldest sons met with accidents on railroads, which terminated in death. Now she is called to mourn the death of another son. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts.... An inquest was also held upon the body of BERNARD MCLAUGHLIN, who died suddenly at his residence No. 196 York-street, on Saturday. He was employed in the Navy-yard, and had just returned from work. A verdict of death from the bursting of a blood-vessel was rendered by the jury. A girl named MARY TEAL, employed as a servant in Sumter-street, (New-Brooklyn,) died at the City Hospital on Saturday, from the effects of burns sustained in consequence of the explosion of a fluid lamp, which she was engaged in lighting. A verdict of death from burns was rendered.

abstract: -- Our attention has been called to a somewhat remarkable provision in the seventy-seventh section of the Tax bill. The general impression in the country has been, that under that section every person using gold plate is liable to the tax, and also every person owning more than forty ounces of silver plate. It is claimed, however, that this is not the case. On examination of the bill it will be seen that its plain terms seem to impose the duty only on such owners of plate as also keep a "carriage, yacht, and billiard table."

lead_paragraph: We reproduce in another column an article from the London Shipping Gazette, commenting on an official document in the Newfoundland Royal Gazette, from which it appears that the Governor of Newfoundland has received a dispatch from the Duke of Newcastle. Her Majesty's Colonial Secretary, dated Aug. 1, intimating that Earl RUSSELL "had been informed by the American Minister in London that it is the intention of the United States Government to issue letters-of-marque, with a view of checking the hostilities carried on by Southern privateers against United States commerce."

abstract: On Saturday morning Miss CARLOTTA PATTI made the adieux of her brief but brilliant first season on the lyric stage to a crowded and enthusiastically good-natured house at the Academy of Music. The opera selected for this occasion was "Lucia di Lammermoor," in which Miss PATTI had appeared the evening before, and which was rendered all the more satisfactorily by herself and by the whole corps for what may be considered fairly enough as a preliminary grand rehearsal. We feel bound, however, in commending, as we most heartily do, the successful courage of Miss PATTI, her friends and her impresario, in thus bringing her forward upon a new arena of triumphs, to repeat our verdict, given after her debut in the role of Amina, that her lyrical future belongs essentially to the airy and peaceful, rather than to the intense and passionate school of art. In saying this we imply no censure, remember, for we simply indicate a vocation. To ask a prima-donna worthily to interpret for us the flutter of Zerline in the coils of the tempter, the enchanting coquetry of Rosina, the simple pathos of Linda, the rustic despair of the slandered Amina, is to offer her one of the most charming and brilliant careers possible upon the stage. That Miss PATTI, whether as singer or as actress, is scarcely equal to the lyrical and the dramatic force of Lucia, was sufficiently evident on Saturday, though her conception of the character was good, and her execution of the music, save in certain particulars which deserve kindly notice, was brilliant and accurate. The quality of Miss PATTI's voice betrays her, in passages which demand extreme frankness and fullness of declamatory emotion, into a shrillness which sometimes (as was the case very notably in the trio on Saturday) amounts to positive thinness and wiriness. She is apt, too, to exhaust her force too rapidly on the earlier phrases of an air, and though this mistake may possibly be due to the circumstance that, in passing from the concert room to the stage, Miss PATTI has not yet learned to measure accurately the, immense increase of the demand which the latter makes upon the strength and sustained volume of the voice over the former, it is a perilous mistake, which must lead to very bad effects, unless it be corrected in time, as it very easily can be.

In saying this we imply no censure, remember, for we simply indicate a vocation. To ask a prima-donna worthily to interpret for us the flutter of Zerline in the coils of the tempter, the enchanting coquetry of Rosina, the simple pathos of Linda, the rustic despair of the slandered Amina, is to offer her one of the most charming and brilliant careers possible upon the stage. abstract: editorial on resolution
snippet: editorial on resolution
lead_paragraph: Gen. WADSWORTH hits the nail exactly on the head when he assumes that he has been nominated for Governor because he is believed to be in earnest about crushing the rebellion. The men who made him a candidate do "believe that the rebellion can be crushed -- that it ought to be crushed, and that it shall be crushed." They do intend that this country shall be held together, -- that there shall be no dismemberment, no destruction of its integrity, -- and they are ready to spend their last dollar and to shed the last drop of their blood in their effort to save it from destruction.
