abstract: Miss BATEMAN mad eher last appearance for the present, at the Winter Garden, on Saturday evening. During her engagement, she has played in "The Hunchback," "The Lady of Lyons," Romeo and Juliet," "Geraldine," "Rosa Gregorlo" and "Macbeth," and has produced a new piece called "Beatrix, the Madonna of Art."
lead_paragraph: Miss BATEMAN mad eher last appearance for the present, at the Winter Garden, on Saturday evening. During her engagement, she has played in "The Hunchback," "The Lady of Lyons," Romeo and Juliet," "Geraldine," "Rosa Gregorlo" and "Macbeth," and has produced a new piece called "Beatrix, the Madonna of Art." "Beatrix" is an adaptation of a play by LEGOUVE, (a former co-laborer with SCRIBE in some of the best pieces attributed to the latter,) and written for the purpose of introducing Madame RISTORI to the Parisian public, in a character wherein should speak the language of her audience. The piece achieved a great success, and ran through nearly a whole season. It will never cause a sensation on the American stage; still it is a neatly-constructed, interesting sort of piece, very well worth seeing. The plot of it runs briefly thus: A Grand Duchess of one of those extraordinary German principalities that have Courts and Cabinets and armies and all the other pharaphernalia of nationality, yet are no bigger than so many Jersey farms, is possessed with a desire to render the little six-by-nine dominion, which she rules in the absence of the Prince, her son, as renowned for the presence of great minds in every department of art as it is contemptible in actual extent. To this end, she invites, among other notabilities, Beatrix a wonderful Italian actress and as virtuous as she is talented, to lend the lustre of her genius to certain festivities which are in contemplation at the palace. Beatrix accepts and arrives in company with her manager, Mr. KINGSTON. An American, who may be said to embody a French dramatist's idea of Mr. BARNUM. The great aim of the indefatigable KINGSTON is to prevent his Beatrix falling in love, as he has a contract with her, whereby he is bound to gain a fortune if no matrimonial engagement should induce her to break her business one. In aid of his purpose he secures the services of one Captain Kaerner a rejected suitor of Beatrix who binds himself for certain considerations to kill any rival who shall dare to make her an offer. It chances, however, that a dangerous lover appears upon the scene in the person of Prince Frederick, the Duchess's younger son, who had previously seen Beatrix in Vienna, and become madly infatuated with her. The idolatry of the lover, the struggle in the heart of Beatrix to stifle or disguise the reciprocal passion which she feels, the unconsciousness of the Grand Duchess, the anxieties of the manager, and the jealous perturbations of Captain Kaerner give rise to numerous effective situations. The closing scene, in which Beatrix (learning the dignity to which, by the death of an uncle and resignation of a brother, Prince Frederick is advanced) rejects the crown he wishes to share with her, (because she seems to think it might injure him in the estimation of the world to marry an actress,) might be made very impressive if it were judiciously elaborated a trifle.

abstract: Editorial notes Maine and New Jersey are banner states for fulfilling quotas for military
snippet: Editorial notes Maine and New Jersey are banner states for fulfilling quotas for military
lead_paragraph: -- Maine follows New-Jersey in having filled her entire quotas under both calls of the President for 300,000 men; but as all the troops from Maine are enlisted for three years or the war, whereas the last ten thousand raised by New-Jersey are only for nine months, Maine fairly claims the honorable title of the Banner State.

abstract: The NEW YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 839, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains the latest news up to the moment of going to press. Special correspondence from all the different military departments. A complete and careful summary of the news of the week, both general and rebellion. European intelligence, Gen. WADSWORTH's speech in Washington, and special dispatches from the Capital. A page of editorial on the current topics of the day, commercial news, and items of agricultural interest compiled from various sources.

abstract: We regret to announce the death of Hon. J. PRESCOTT HALL, at Newport, R.I., in the 67th year of his age. Few men have enjoyed a healthier political or physical existence than he, and few could, at the expiration of a long and honorably active life, pass away leaving so few enemies behind him, and so many friends to mourn his death.

abstract: Editorial speculates on Confederate position and plans in Virginia
snippet: Editorial speculates on Confederate position and plans in Virginia
lead_paragraph: The Richmond newspapers are busily engaged in covering the retreat of Gen. LEE from Maryland. They announce Antietam as a glorious Confederate victory, which enabled the Confederate General to withdraw his troops in safety after accomplishing the "real object of his campaign," the capture, to wit, of Harper's Ferry, with all its stores of arms and munitions of war. The programme of invasion, the world is gravely requested to believe, was only a clever device for casting dust in the eyes of MCCLELLAN and the North, and once more the Northern eagle" towering in his pride of place," has by the mousing swamp-owl been hawked at and killed.

abstract: Gen. NELSON, whose name has become famous during the war, in connection with the operations of our armies in the Southwest, was shot and almost instantly killed yesterday morning at the Galt House in Louisville by Gen. JEFF. C. DAVIS, also famous in the same connection.
lead_paragraph: Gen. NELSON, whose name has become famous during the war, in connection with the operations of our armies in the Southwest, was shot and almost instantly killed yesterday morning at the Galt House in Louisville by Gen. JEFF. C. DAVIS, also famous in the same connection. There has been a personal difficulty between the two Generals for some time, and the immediate provocation to the homicide is understood to have been some very insulting language used by Gen. NELSON.

snippet: Editorial says election of Seymour and his ticket would give aid and comfort to rebellion; Editorial says election of H Seymour as Gov. of NYS would give aid and comfort to rebellion
lead_paragraph: The Seymourites object strenuously to being classed with traitors. They are shocked at the bad manners of those who venture upon such rude aspersions. Mr. SEYMOUR himself says he does not see why he can't be permitted to denounce and oppose the Government, without being classed among its enemies. The Republicans, he says, complain of Mr. LINCOLN although they elected him. Why should he be denied the same privilege, when he did everything in his power to keep him out?

abstract: October
snippet: October
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic, for October, opens with a charming paper -- "Autumnal Tints" -- by the late HENRY D. THOREAU; "King of the Gypsies" he was called while he lived, the forest was his home, and birds and herbs his most familiar companions. He was on talking terms with oaks. The aspen forgot to tremble in his presence, the mimosa to shrink at his approach. And he reproduces the tints of our autumnal woods with a freshness and faithfulness that passes the skill of other men. "David Gaunt" is brought to an end in the current number -- "Mr. Axtell" unfortunately is not. NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE contributes a pleasant paper -- "Leamington Spa." From the "Spa" comes bubbling up a question that is certainly worth serious consideration. Let Sir CRESSWELL CRESSWELL listen: "I wonder whether a middle-aged husband ought to be considered as legally married to all the accretions that have overgrown the slenderness of his bride, since he led her to the altar, and which make her so much more than he ever bargained for?" Here is, indeed, a vast field for speculation opened, which only the Divorce courts can adequately solve. "House Building" is an architectural article by J. ELIOT CABOT. Dr. EDWARD JARVIS discourses of the sanitary condition of the army. E.H. DEBBY treats of the resources of the South. An interesting memoir is given of ELISABETH SARA SHEPPARD, with a brief paper -- a niche in the heart -- by this lamented authoress. There is a charming little Arab poem by ALDRICH, an elegaic one by BAYARD TAYLOR, and some verses anent the war and Autumn by WHITTIER.

abstract: Albany Argus, "has no terrors to us. The people would prefer to try another remedy first.

abstract: Gen. STAHL still makes his headquarters at Centreville, and has abundance of work for the force at his disposal. The whole country about here, as far as our scouts have been, is filled with small parties of guerrillas and scouts of the enemy, who are not unfrequently quite bold in their operations. Only yesterday a squad of rebel cavalry came within our lines, and fired upon a superior picket force composed of infantry.
lead_paragraph: NEAR CENTERVILLE, Friday, Sept. 26, 1862.

abstract: The seventh annual show of the New-Jersey Agricultural Society commences to-day at Newton in [???] County and will continue until Friday.The entries, we understand, are numerous, embracing some of the finest stock in the country. The competition will close on Thursday. On Friday, the Governor, with distinguished invited guests, will be present, the annual address will be delivered, and the premiums awarded, after which a special premium, open to any horse, will be contended for, and theprize animals exhibited. The occasion promises to be one of peculiar interest.

abstract: THE STREET DEPARTMENT. Business proceeded quite as usual at the Street Department yesterday, notwithstanding the removal of the Street Commissioner and his Deputy.
lead_paragraph: THE STREET DEPARTMENT. -- Business proceeded quite as usual at the Street Department yesterday, notwithstanding the removal of the Street Commissioner and his Deputy. Except an unusual crowd about the office, discussing the peculiar position of affairs, and speculating about what would happen further to bring matters to a crisis, there was no appearance of anything unusual going on. It could not be definitely ascertained whether the Mayor favored Mr. KNAPP disputing the validity of his removal, or acquiesced in that act. It was said that the Comptroller was still [???] on the same point, but would declare his mind today. In the afternoon it was rumored that the Mayer would nominate a candidate for confirmation as Street Commissioner, and send it to the Aldermen at 5 o'clock. Some surprise was expressed at this, as the impression was quite strong that the Mayor would stand by Mr. KNAPP, and it was reasoned that a nomition by the former would be an acquiescence in the removal of the latter. That the nomination would be rejected, was conceded by all. It is believed that all the [???] will [???] rejected, till he overcome [???] with Aldermen. abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yes- terday afternoon, President HENRY in the Chair. The lobby was densely crowded with spectators, in anticipation of some action in reference to the Street Department.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yes- terday afternoon, President HENRY in the Chair. The lobby was densely crowded with spectators, in anticipation of some action in reference to the Street Department. They were soon gratified, a communication from the Mayor, nominating FRED. LAW OLMSTED for Street Commissioner, being presented and read immediately after the approval of the minutes.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, the neighborhood of Sullivan-street, in the Eighth Ward particularly the colored residents were thrown into a state of intense excitement, by the report that a colored man named JOSEPH P. THOMPSON, residing at No. 41 Sullivan-street, was murdered, by having his throat cut by his wife.
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday morning, the neighborhood of Sullivan-street, in the Eighth Ward -- particularly the colored residents -- were thrown into a state of intense excitement, by the report that a colored man named JOSEPH P. THOMPSON, residing at No. 41 Sullivan-street, was murdered, by having his throat cut by his wife. On investigation, it appears that the deceased, THOMPSON, who was a married man, had been residing with a colored woman other than his wife, for some time past at the above-mentioned place. At 6 o'clock, his wife, who goes by the name of AMANDA THOMPSON, came into his room, and while he was in bed some conversation ensued between them, the nature of which has not transpired. After a few moments AMANDA drew a razor from her pocket and cut her husband's throat, inflicting a most ghastly wound. The deceased sprang up from the bed and followed the murderess a few feet, but he almost immediately fell to the ground and expired in about ten minutes. AMANDA deliberately walked from the room to the street, and thence to the Fifth Precinct Station-house, where she delivered herself up to the officer in charge, stating what she had done. In the meantime the Eighth Precinct Police discovered the murder, and Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at the Eighth Ward Station-house yesterday afternoon, when evidence, of which the following is the substance, was given:

abstract: is, we conceive, pretty fairly foreshadowed in an article in the leading London journal, an extract from which comes to us by telegraph from Cape Race. Commenting on the probability of such a measure, the Times "trusts that Mr. LINCOLN will refrain from an act which will be at once a crime and a blunder, which will in no way advance the National cause, but only deepen and render eternal the hatred between the two sections." This is, doubtless, very much the view which the tribe of European carpers and critics will take of the proclamation. It will not make them a whit more friendly or more fair. To suppose it would do so would be to ignore the very obvious fact that they are hostile on principle. It has suited their purpose, for a twelvemonth back, to represent that we were quite as much in love with Slavery, and quite as anxious to preserve it, as the rebels themselves. The Proclamation will drive them from this position, but they will then turn round and, like the Times, vituperate the act as "a crime and a blunder." We trust Mr. LINCOLN will not deceive himself by discounting any very large amount of European sympathy on account of his Emancipation decree, for if he does we fear he will lean on a broken reed.

abstract: Our secession scribes deal very gingerly with the President's proclamation. They say much less terrible things about it than they threatened in advance. It is not to be supposed that they have experienced any change of heart in regard to Slavery; but they evidently consider it somewhat more dangerous than it used to be to praise and glorify the peculiar institution. They croak a little, it is true, about making this a war for abolition, but they do it faintly and with evident misgivings. Like Macbeth's amen, it "sticks in their throats."

abstract: Gen. JEFF. C. DAVIS, whose name gains an unfortunate prominence in connection with this lamentable affair, was appointed a Lieutenant in the regular army from the State of Indiana, in 1848. He entered the artillery service on June 17; on Feb. 29, 1852, was promoted to a First Lieutenantcy; and on May 14, 1861, was made a Captain, with leave of absence to take command of the Twenty-second Regiment of Indiana Volunteers. He was assigned to the command of a brigade by Gen. FREMONT, with the rank of Brigadier-General, and when that officer was removed from command of the Western Department, he came near losing both his brigade and regimental command. Gallant service which he performed under Gen. POPE, assisting in the capture of one thousand prisoners in Central Missouri, brought him into notice again, and he retained command of his brigade under Gen. CURTIS, taking a prominent part in achieving the glorious victory of Pea Ridge, Arkansas. It was not until after this action that Congress confirmed his appointment as Brigadier-General. It remains to be seen whether the commission of this homicide will terminate his military career.

abstract: The otherwise unhappy condition of things in Kentucky is just now rendered still more so by the unfortunate collision between two Generals of the Union army, Gens. NELSON and DAVIS, resulting in the death of the former.
lead_paragraph: The otherwise unhappy condition of things in Kentucky is just now rendered still more so by the unfortunate collision between two Generals of the Union army, Gens. NELSON and DAVIS, resulting in the death of the former. The quarrel, to be sure, was private and personal; but Gen. NELSON has just been acting a very prominent part in Kentucky; he has numerous friends there, and has won great favor by his early and long devotion to the Union cause. In the present hot blood of the State, there is reason to fear the occurrence may widen into something more than a mere personal feud fatally concluded.

abstract: how utterly shameless and fraudulent are those exposures of private property to public outcry, known as Sheriff's sales. The knowledge has, however, been thrust upon them by Judge BARNARD, who took occasion a few days since to say in open court, and for the benefit of John Doe, Richard Roe and others, that those sales are illusory; "that they are attended by a lot of Jews and swindlers, bidding collusively, and, finally, the property is disposed of to one of the gang." It was the opinion of the magistrate that the profession should apply for orders to sell property taken in execution through other channels. Had the inquiry been pressed, doubtless the Bench would have specified what channels, unpolluted by "Jews and swindlers," the public should resort to.It was not to be expected that all the parties implicated in this wholesale denunciation would submit tranquilly. The "Jews" might do so, for is not sufferance the badge of all their tribe? But Sheriff LYNCH, by whom theoretically the sales are directly made, and into whose pockets drop the fees at the rate of a very handsome percentage, would be more than mortal did he not rise up against this destructive assault upon his customers, his honor, and his perquisites. He does so in another column of the TIMES. Those customers, -- and LYNCH is a judge, -- are not the rogues and cheats the bench, in its wrath or with deep design, pronounces them. They are fair men, true men, men of means, eager for bargains, solicitous of investing advantageously monies honestly earned, and incapable of those knavish combinations ascribed to them.

abstract: GEN. NELSON was a native of Mason County, Ky.. and entered the navy at an early age. For several years he held the rank of Lieutenant, and was, we believe, the Executive Officer of the vessel which brought KOSSUTH to this country. At that time he gained quite a notoriety by the efforts which he made to expose the conduct of Commodore LONG toward the distinguished exile who had been placed under his protection. A little more than a year ago Lieut. NELSON, on account of his intimate acquaintance with the people of the West, and, probably, through the influence of Senator CRITTENDEN, of Kenturky, whose special protege he was, was appointed to the command of the Ohio River fleet of gunboats. Soon afterward, however, he was transferred to service on land, and at once was commissioned to attempt to give a practical shape to the hitherto latent loyalty on the [???]. As early as April, 1861, he [???]. of the formation of the first Union camp in [???] at a point between Gerrardsville and Danville, and was known as Camp Dick Robinson. Col. GEORGE H. THOMAS havin been made a Brigadier-General, was ordered to the command of this post, and NELSON, who was then Colonel, commenced the formation of a second camp at Washington, Mason County. After a short stay at this point, Col. NELSON took the field at the head of a brigade, and at once leaped into fame and a Brigadier-Generalship by routing a rebel force at Piketon, Ky., which was under the command of one Brig.Gen. WILLIAMS. Gen. NELSON was subsequently attached to Gen. BUELL's command, and displayed great gallantry in the battle of Shiloh. Promoted to a Major-Generalship, he has since held various responsible positions, and at the time Gen. BRAGG commenced his invasion of Kentucky, was ordered into that State to organize the forces to opposo his advance, and hold him in check until Gen. BUELL could move his army north.

abstract: MR. GOTTSCHALK AT IRVING HALL. Mr. GOTTSCHALK gives a concert on Thursday evening, at Irving Hall. He will be assisted by Mr. THEODORE THOMAS and Mrs. KEMPTON, a contralto of great estimation in private circles, who, on this occasion, makes her debut in public.
lead_paragraph: MR. GOTTSCHALK AT IRVING HALL. -- Mr. GOTTSCHALK gives a concert on Thursday evening, at Irving Hall. He will be assisted by Mr. THEODORE THOMAS and Mrs. KEMPTON, a contralto of great estimation in private circles, who, on this occasion, makes her debut in public. Mr. GOTTSCHALK has been absent from New-York for some time, delighting the residents of the fashionable watering places, and paying occasional visits to the larger rural cities of Northern New-York, Connecticut and Massachusetts. He will be warmly welcomed by the public on his return. The sale of tickets commences to-day, at BEER & SCHIRMER'S, No. 701 Broadway; SIBELL, & SAULSBURT'S No. 7 Nassau-street, and at Irving Hall.
